    not affected by electric and magnetic fields
    (allow any three, 1 each)
  2. 495 nm = 495 × 10-9 m
    number = 1/(495 × 10-9) = 2.02 × 106
    (allow 2 or more significant figures)
    1. allow 10-7   →   10-11 m
    2. allow 10-3   →   10-6 m
  1. The majority of candidates could state at least one of the many features common to the regions. A frequent error was to specify a common speed for waves throughout the spectrum with no mention of the medium in which the waves are travelling. 
  2. The unit conversion from nanometres to metres presented very few difficulties. A surprisingly large number of candidates then failed to complete the calculation. Eight significant figures for the answer was common. 
  3. Most answers were within acceptable limits. However, it was clear that a minority had no appreciation of the wavelengths. Values more appropriate to long-wave radio were not uncommon.  

Answer: (b) 2.02 × 106.

NO. 41题号：34355
  1. Fig. 4.1 shows the variation with time t of the displacement x of one point in a progressive wave.

    Fig. 4.2 shows the variation with distance d along the same wave of the displacement x.

    1. Use Figs. 4.1 and 4.2 to determine, for this wave,
      1. the amplitude,

         amplitude = ....................................... mm
      2. the wavelength,

         wavelength = ................................... m
      3. the frequency,

         frequency = .......................................Hz
      4. the speed.

         speed = .........................................ms-1
      [6]
    2. On Fig.4.2, draw a second wave having the same amplitude but half the frequency as that shown. [1]

  2. Light of wavelength 590 nm is incident at right anfles to a diffraction grating having 5.80 × 105 lines per metre, as illustrated in Fig. 4.3.

    A screen is placed parallel to and 1.50 m from the grating. Calculate
    1. the spacing, in µm, of the lines of the grating,

      spacing = ................................ µm
    2. the angle θ to the original direction of the light at which the first order diffracted image is seen,

      angle = ......................................º
    3. the minimum length L of the screen so that both first order diffracted images may be viewed at the same time on the screen. 

      length = .............................................. m
      [5]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2003/Winter/Paper2/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a.i 1. amplitude = 0.4(0) mm A1 [6]
2. wavelength = 7.5 × 10-2 m
   (1 sig. fig. -1 unless already penalised)		 A1
3. period = 0.225 ms
   frequency = 1/T = 4400 Hz		 C1
A1
4. v = fλ
      = 4400 × 7.5 × 10-2
      = 330 m s-1		 C1
A1
a.ii reasonable shape, same amplitude and wavelength doubled B1 [1]
b.i 1.7(2) µm A1 [5]
b.ii d sinθ = nλ (double slit formula scores 0/2)
1.72 × 10-6 × sin θ = 590 × 10-9
θ = 20.1° (allow 20°)
C1
A1
b.iii ½L = 1.5 tan20.1
L = 1.1 m		 C1
A1
    1. 1. amplitude = 0.4(0) mm
      2. wavelength = 7.5 × 10-2 m
          (1 sig. fig. -1 unless already penalised)
      3. period = 0.225 ms
          frequency = 1/T = 4400 Hz
      4. v = fλ
          = 4400 × 7.5 × 10-2
          = 330 m s-1
    2. reasonable shape, same amplitude and wavelength doubled
    1. 1.7(2) µm
    2. d sinθ = nλ (double slit formula scores 0/2)
      1.72 × 10-6 × sin θ = 590 × 10-9
      θ = 20.1° (allow 20°)
    3. ½L = 1.5 tan20.1
      L = 1.1 m
    1. Most candidates correctly determined the amplitude and the wavelength, although a significant minority attempted to find the wavelength from the displacement - time graph. In 3 approximately one half of all candidates failed to convert milliseconds to seconds when finding the frequency. Calculation of the speed presented very few problems although answers were sometimes quite bizarre.
    2. Some candidates drew a second wave on Fig. 4.1 rather than on Fig. 4.2. Others drew a separate diagram. It was very common to find that the wave drawn had double the frequency, rather than half the frequency of the original wave. 
    1. A surprisingly large number of candidates did not realise that the grating spacing is simply the reciprocal of the number of lines per unit length of the grating. Others were confused by the need to express the answer in micrometres. 
    2. It was pleasing to note that most candidates did use the grating formula dsinθ = nλ although a significant number thought that d represented either the distance between the double slit and the screen or the number of lines per metre. 
    3. There was a significant number of attempts to solve this problem using a double slit formula. However, there were many clear correct solutions although there was some confusion as regards the use of sine or tangent. 
NO. 42题号：34354

The variation with time t of the displacement x of a point in a transverse wave T1 is shown in Fig.5.1.

  1. By reference to displacement and direction of travel of wave energy, explain what is meant by a transverse wave.
    ..........................................................................[1]
  2. A second transverse wave T2, of amplitude A has the same waveform as wave T1 but lags behind T1 by a phase angle of 60°. The two waves T1 and T2 pass through the same point.
    1. On Fig. 5.1, draw the variation with time t of the displacement x of the point in wave T2. [2]

    2. Explain what is meant by the principle of superposition of two waves.
      .......................................................................[2]
    3. For the time t = 1.0 s, use Fig. 5.1 to determine, in terms of A,
      1. the displacement due to wave T1 alone,

         displacement = ……………………………………
      2. the displacement due to wave T2 alone,

         displacement = ……………………………………
      3. the resultant displacement due to both waves.

         displacement = …………………………
      [3]

Q5/9702/2/O/N/02

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2002/Winter/Paper2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a displacement & direction of energy travel normal to one another B1 [1]
b.i phase angle of 60º correct ...(need to see 1½ wavelengths)
lags behind T1		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.ii waves must be in same place (at same time)
resultant displacement = sum of individual diaplacements		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.iii 1. –½A
2. ½A ...... (allow e.c.f.)
3. zero ...... (allow e.c.f.)		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
  1. displacement & direction of energy travel normal to one another
    1. phase angle of 60º correct ...(need to see 1½ wavelengths)
      lags behind T1
    2. waves must be in same place (at same time)
      resultant displacement = sum of individual diaplacements
    3. 1. –½A
      2. ½A ...... (allow e.c.f.)
      3. zero ...... (allow e.c.f.)
  1. Most candidates did appreciate the basic concept of what is meant by a transverse wave. However, despite the fact that explicit instructions were given in the question, many imprecise explanations were given. Statements such as 'the wave moves at right angles to the motion' were not uncommon. A reference to the direction of the displacement and of energy travel was required.
    1. Fewer than one half of the candidates deduced that a phase angle of 60° corresponded to 1 cm along the x-axis of the graph and even fewer showed a wave that lagged behind the given wave.
    2. Most candidates did appear to have some understanding of coherence. However, an appreciable proportion either did not establish that the waves must coincide at some point or made reference to amplitude rather than displacement.
    3. Although a minority did not appear to understand what was expected, the majority did read off values from the graph and then gave a resultant displacement consistent with their values. Weaker candidates frequently ignored whether the displacement was positive or negative.
NO. 43题号：34353
  1. Explain the principle of superposition.
    ...............................................................................[2]
  2. Sound waves travel from a source S to a point X along two paths SX and SPX, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

    1. State the phase difference between these waves at X for this to be the position of
      1. a minimum,
         phase difference = ....................... unit ............... [1]
      2. a maximum.
         phase difference = ........................ unit ............... [1]
    2. The frequency of the sound from S is 400 Hz and the speed of sound is 320 m s–1.
      Calculate the wavelength of the sound waves.

      wavelength = ............................................. m [2]
    3. The distance SP is 3.0 m and the distance PX is 4.0 m. The angle SPX is 90°.
      Suggest whether a maximum or a minimum is detected at point X. Explain your answer.
      .........................................................................[2]

Q5/9702/23/M/J/13

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_3/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a when waves overlap / meet
the resultant displacement is the sum of the individual displacements of the waves		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.i 1. phase difference = 180º / (n + ½) 360º (allow in rad) B1 [1]
2. phase difference = 0 / 360º / (n360º) (allow in rad) B1 [1]
b.ii v = fλ
λ = 320 / 400 = 0.80m		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.iii path difference = 7 – 5 = 2 (m)
   = 2.5λ
hence minimum
or maximum if phase change at P is suggested
M1

A1		 [2]
  1. when waves overlap / meet
    the resultant displacement is the sum of the individual displacements of the waves
    1. 1. phase difference = 180º / (n + ½) 360 º (allow in rad)
      2. phase difference = 0 / 360º / (n360º) (allow in rad)
    2. v = f λ
      λ = 320 / 400 = 0.80 m
    3. path difference = 7 – 5 = 2 (m) = 2.5 λ
      hence minimum
      or maximum if phase change at P is suggested

There appeared to be a general lack of understanding of the difference between phase difference and path difference.

  1. The required statement was given by a significant number of candidates. There were some statements that described the addition of amplitude that were not accepted and some did not describe what was added to obtain a resultant at all. 
    1. There was confusion between path difference and phase difference. A large number of candidates appeared not to know the phase difference required for a maximum and a minimum. 
    2. The correct value for the wavelength was determined by the vast majority of candidates.
    3. This was a difficult final part to the question that was correctly answered by a small number of candidates. The working for the path difference and its relationship to the wavelength was required from first principles.
NO. 44题号：34352

Fig. 5.1 shows a string stretched between two fixed points P and Q.

A vibrator is attached near end P of the string. End Q is fixed to a wall. The vibrator has a frequency of 50 Hz and causes a transverse wave to travel along the string at a speed of 40 m s-1.

    1. Calculate the wavelength of the transverse wave on the string.

      wavelength = ............................................. m [2]
    2. Explain how this arrangement may produce a stationary wave on the string.
      ....................................................................................... [2]
  2. The stationary wave produced on PQ at one instant of time t is shown on Fig.5.2.
    Each point on the string is at its maximum displacement.

    1. On Fig. 5.2, label all the nodes with the letter N and all the antinodes with the letter A. [2]

    2. Use your answer in (a)(i) to calculate the length of string PQ.

      length = ............................................. m [1]
    3. On Fig. 5.2, draw the stationary wave at time (t + 5.0ms). Explain your answer.
      .......................................................................................... [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i v = fλ
λ = 40 / 50 = 0.8(0) m		 C1
A1		 [2]
a.ii waves (travel along string and) reflect at Q / wall / fixed end
incident and reflected waves interfere / superpose		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.i nodes labelled at P, Q and the two points at zero displacement
antinodes labelled at the three points of maximum displacement		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.ii (1.5λ for PQ hence PQ = 0.8 × 1.5) = 1.2m A1 [1]
b.iii T = 1 / f = 1/50 = 20ms
5 ms is ¼ of cycle
horizontal line through PQ drawn on Fig. 5.2		 C1
A1
B1		 [3]
    1. v = fλ
      λ = 40 / 50 = 0.8(0) m
    2. waves (travel along string and) reflect at Q / wall / fixed end
      incident and reflected waves interfere / superpose
    1. nodes labelled at P, Q and the two points at zero displacement
      antinodes labelled at the three points of maximum displacement
    2. (1.5λ for PQ hence PQ = 0.8 × 1.5) = 1.2 m
    3. T = 1 / f = 1/50 = 20 ms
      5 ms is ¼ of cycle
      horizontal line through PQ drawn on Fig. 5.2
    1. This was generally well answered by the vast majority of candidates.
    2. The stronger candidates were able to describe the meeting or overlapping of an incident wave from the vibrator and a reflected wave from the wall. Greater detail was required for the second mark, such as stating that there is interference between these waves to produce standing waves. Candidates should be advised that merely stating the general description of how stationary waves are formed is not sufficient when a specific example is referred to in the question.
    1. The majority of candidates knew the positions of the nodes and antinodes. Credit was sometimes lost when omissions were made e.g. at the ends P and Q of the wave or the middle antinode.
    2. This was generally well answered. The weaker candidates were not able to link their answer to (a)(i) for the wavelength with the number of waves shown on Fig. 5.2.
    3. The majority of candidates considered the wave shown on Fig. 5.2 to be a progressive wave when calculating the position of the waveform after a further 5ms. The drawing of the stationary wave every ¼ of a period would help candidates understand the variations in the waveform.
NO. 45题号：34351
  1. State three conditions required for maxima to be formed in an interference pattern produced by two sources of microwaves.
    1. ........................................................................
    2. ........................................................................
    3. ........................................................................ [3]
  2. A microwave source M emits microwaves of frequency 12 GHz. Show that the wavelength of the microwaves is 0.025 m. [3]

  3. Two slits S1 and S2 are placed in front of the microwave source M described in (b), as shown in Fig 5.1.

    The distances S1O and S2O are equal. A microwave detector is moved from O to P. The distance S1P is 0.75 m and the distance S2P is 0.90 m.
    The microwave detector gives a maximum reading at O.
    State the variation in the readings on the microwave detector as it is moved slowly along the line from O to P.
    ........................................................................... [3]
  4. The microwave source M is replaced by a source of coherent light.
    State two changes that must be made to the slits in Fig. 5.1 in order to observe an interference pattern.
    1. ....................................................................
    2. .................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a waves overlap / meet / superpose
coherence / constant phase difference (not constant λ or frequency)
path difference = 0, λ, 2λ or phase difference = 0, 2π, 4π
same direction of polarisation/unpolarised		 (B1)
(B1)
(B1)
(B1)		 max. 3 [3]
b λ = v / f
f = 12 × 109 Hz
λ = 3 × 108 / 12 × 109 (any subject)
  = 0.025m		 C1
C1
M1
A0		 [3]
c maximum at P
several minima or maxima between O and P
5 maxima / 6 minima between O and P
or 7 maxima / 6 minima including O and P		 B1
B1

B1		 [3]
d slits made narrower
slits put closer together
  (not just 'make slits smaller')
Allow tilting the slits M1 and explanation of axes of rotation A1		 B1
B1


 [2]
  1. waves overlap / meet / superpose
    coherence / constant phase difference (not constant λ or frequency)
    path difference = 0, λ, 2λ or phase difference = 0, 2π, 4π
    same direction of polarisation/unpolarised
  2. λ = v / f
    f = 12 × 109 Hz
    λ = 3 × 108 / 12 × 109   (any subject)
       = 0.025 m
  3. maximum at P
    several minima or maxima between O and P
    5 maxima / 6 minima between O and P
    or 7 maxima / 6 minima including O and P
  4. slits made narrower
    slits put closer together
    (not just 'make slits smaller')
    Allow tilting the slits M1 and explanation of axes of rotation A1
  1. The necessary conditions (i.e. coherence, superposition and phase/path difference) for maxima were stated in many answers, but frequently there was a lack of clarity. When referring to phase, it was not made clear whether the sources or the waves were being considered. Some candidates did, quite correctly, consider polarisation.
  2. This was a simple derivation. A small minority of answers involved the speed of sound. Others gave an incorrect power of ten for GHz.
  3. There were very few comprehensive answers where the number of maxima or minima between O and P were considered. The most common answer was to assume a minimum half-way between O and P and then to have the first maximum at P.
  4. Many answers did include narrower slits placed closer together. It was common to find that the question had not been read carefully and, consequently, changes other than those to the slits were suggested. Candidates do need to be encouraged to be precise. Vague answers such as "make the slits smaller" do not make it clear as to what aspect of the slits is being considered.
NO. 46题号：34349
  1. Use the principle of superposition to explain the formation of a stationary wave.
    ...............................................................................[3]
  2. Describe an experiment to determine the wavelength of sound in air using stationary waves. Include a diagram of the apparatus in your answer.
    ...............................................................................[3]
  3. The variation with distance x of the intensity I of a stationary sound wave is shown in Fig. 6.1.

    1. On the x-axis of Fig. 6.1, indicate the positions of all the nodes and anti nodes of the stationary wave. Label the nodes N and the antinodes A. [1]

    2. The speed of sound in air is 340 ms–1.
      Use Fig. 6.1 to determine the frequency of the sound wave.

      frequency = ............................................ Hz [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_2/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a two waves travelling (along the same line) in opposite directions overlap/meet
same frequency / wavelength
resultant displacement is the sum of displacements of each wave / produces nodes and antinodes		 M1
A1

B1		 [3]
b apparatus: source of sound + detector + reflection system
adjustment to apparatus to set up standing waves – how recognised
measurements made to obtain wavelength		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
c.i at least two nodes and two antinodes A1 [1]
c.ii node to node = λ / 2 = 34 cm (allow 33 to 35cm)
c = fλ
f = 340 / 0.68 = 500 (490 to 520)Hz		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
  1. two waves travelling (along the same line) in opposite directions overlap/meet
    same frequency / wavelength
    resultant displacement is the sum of displacements of each wave / produces nodes and antinodes
  2. apparatus: source of sound + detector + reflection system
    adjustment to apparatus to set up standing waves – how recognised
    measurements made to obtain wavelength
    1. at least two nodes and two antinodes
    2. node to node = λ / 2 = 34 cm (allow 33 to 35cm)
      c = fλ
      f = 340 / 0.68 = 500  (490 to 520) Hz

The majority of candidates found this question demanding. The experimental description in (b) was omitted or poorly attempted by a significant number of candidates. 

  1. The explanation of the formation of a stationary wave was not given in sufficient detail by the majority of candidates. Many suggested that the waves needed to superpose or interfere instead of meet or overlap. The principle of superposition was generally given correctly, but some candidates gave an incomplete statement, or added amplitudes rather than displacements for which no credit could be awarded. 
  2. This part was generally poorly answered. The apparatus was often incomplete and not clearly labelled. A loudspeaker should have included a signal generator to produce a sound of variable frequency. Many omitted the adjustments to obtain resonance, and the distance between adjacent nodes or antinodes was often not linked with the wavelength.
    1. Only a small number of candidates were able to correctly interpret the graph. A significant number of candidates appeared not to have read the text or Fig. 6.1 carefully and assumed that the graph was of displacement against distance rather than intensity against distance.
    2. The distance between two adjacent nodes or two adjacent antinodes was linked to half the wavelength by only a small number of candidates. 
NO. 47题号：34348
  1. A laser is used to produce an interference pattern on a screen, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

    The laser emits light of wavelength 630 nm. The slit separation is 0.450 mm. The distance between the slits and the screen is 1.50 m. A maximum is formed at P1 and a minimum is formed at P2.
    Interference fringes are observed only when the light from the slits is coherent.
    1. Explain what is meant by coherence.
      .....................................................................[2]
    2. Explain how an interference maximum is formed at P1.
      .....................................................................[1]
    3. Explain how an interference minimum is formed at P2.
      .....................................................................[1]
    4. Calculate the fringe separation.

      fringe separation = ............................................. m [3]
  2. State the effects, if any, on the fringes when the amplitude of the waves incident on the double slits is increased.
    ...................................................................................[3]

Q6/9702/21/M/J/12

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_1/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i coherence: constant phase difference
                  between (two) waves		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii path difference is either λ or nλ
or phase difference is 360° or n × 360° or n2π rad		 B1 [1]
a.iii path difference is either λ/2 or (n + ½) λ
or  phase difference is odd multiple of either 180° or π rad		 B1 [1]
a.iv w = λD / a
   = [630 × 10–9 × 1.5] / 0.45 × 10–3
   = 2.1 × 10–3m		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
b no change to dark fringes
no change to separation/fringe width
bright fringes are brighter/lighter/more intense		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
    1. coherence: constant phase difference
                  between (two) waves
    2. path difference is either λ or nλ
      or phase difference is 360° or n × 360° or n2π rad
    3. path difference is either λ/2 or (n + ½) λ
      or   phase difference is odd multiple of either 180° or π rad
    4. w = λD / a
         = [630 × 10–9 × 1.5] / 0.45 × 10–3
         = 2.1 × 10–3 m
  2. no change to dark fringes
    no change to separation/fringe width
    bright fringes are brighter/lighter/more intense
    1. There were many references to 'constant frequency' and 'constant wavelength'. Of the minority who did specify 'constant phase difference', few made any comment as to what would have this constant relationship.
    2. A small minority of candidates referred to the condition based on path difference or on phase difference. However, the majority described this in very elementary terms based on 'crests' and 'troughs'.
    3. Again, this was very poorly answered using elementary terms. 
    4. The majority of candidates answered this correctly. A minority made either power-of-ten errors or errors when manipulating the formula that gave rise to unrealistic answers. 
  2. A significant minority linked changes in amplitude with changes in either frequency or wavelength. A number of candidates made reference to 'the fringes', without specifying whether the light fringes or the dark fringes were under consideration. 
NO. 48题号：34347
  1. A transverse progressive wave travels along a stretched string from left to right. The shape of part of the string at a particular instant is shown in Fig. 6.1.

    The frequency of the wave is 15 Hz.
    For this wave, use Fig. 6.1 to determine
    1. the amplitude,

      amplitude = .......................................... mm [1]
    2. the phase difference between the points P and Q on the string,

      phase difference = ................................................ [1]
    3. the speed of the wave.

      speed = ........................................ m s–1 [2]
  2. The period of vibration of the wave is T. The wave moves forward from the position shown in Fig 6.1 for a time 0.25 T. On Fig. 6.1, sketch the new position of the wave. [2]

  3. Another stretched string is used to form a stationary wave. Part of this wave, at a particular instant, is shown in Fig. 6.2.

    The points on the string are at their maximum displacement.
    1. State the phase difference between the particles labelled X and Y.

      phase difference = ................................................ [1]
    2. Explain the following terms used to describe stationary waves on a string:
      antinode: ...........................................................................
      node: ................................................................................... [1]
    3. State the number of antinodes shown on Fig. 6.2 for this wave.

      number of antinodes = ................................................ [1]
    4. The period of vibration of this wave is τ. On Fig. 6.2, sketch the stationary wave 0.25 τ after the instant shown in Fig. 6.2. [1]

Q6/9702/23/M/J/11

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper2_3/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i amplitude = 7.6 mm    allow 7.5 mm A1 [1]
a.ii 180° / π rad A1 [1]
a.iii v = f × λ
   = 15 × 0.8
   = 12 ms–1		 C1
A1		 [2]
b correct sketch with peak moved to the right
curve moved by the correct phase angle / time period of 0.25 T		 B1
B1		 [2]
c.i zero (rad) A1 [1]
c.ii antinode maximum amplitude,
node zero amplitude / displacement 		 A1 [1]
c.iii 3 A1 [1]
c.iv horizontal line through central section of wave B1 [1]
    1. amplitude = 7.6 mm    allow 7.5 mm
    2. 180° / π rad
    3. v = f × λ = 15 × 0.8 = 12 ms–1 
  2. correct sketch with peak moved to the right
    curve moved by the correct phase angle / time period of 0.25 T
    1. zero (rad)
    2. antinode maximum amplitude,
      node zero amplitude / displacement
    3. 3
    4. horizontal line through central section of wave

A large majority of candidates produced good answers to (a) and (b) but then did not answer (c) to the same standard.

    1. This was generally well answered. Only a small minority misread the scale on the graph. The vast majority understood the term 'amplitude'.
    2. The term 'phase difference' was not known or understood by the majority of candidates. There were many incorrect answers that referred to wavelength. Credit was not given when the unit was omitted. 
    3. The vast majority of candidates obtained the correct answer. There were a few candidates who seemed to be unaware of the need to convert the wavelength determined from the graph in centimetres into metres when the speed of the wave is required in m s–1. 
  2. There were many good sketches drawn of the new position of the wave. A few candidates were unable to relate the distance moved by wave in the given time to the wavelength of the wave. Candidates also need to read the question carefully as some missed the reference to the frequency and were unable to complete (a)(iii), and some drew a new wave with a frequency four times the one given in the question.
    1. The term 'phase difference' was not known or understood by the majority of candidates.
    2. The terms 'antinode' and 'node' needed to be described with reference to amplitude. Candidates seldom gave this explanation.
    3. The answers given by candidates suggested a general confusion between antinodes and nodes.
    4. There were very few correct sketches drawn of the new position of the wave. The majority of candidates drew a travelling wave rather than a stationary wave. Candidates need to know the variations in the positions of a stationary wave as it vibrates. 
NO. 49题号：34346
  1. Apparatus used to produce interference fringes is shown in Fig.6.1. The apparatus is not drawn to scale.

    Laser light is incident on two slits. The laser provides light of a single wavelength.
    The light from the two slits produces a fringe pattern on the screen. A bright fringe is produced at C and the next bright fringe is at B. A dark fringe is produced at P.
    1. Explain why one laser and two slits are used, instead of two lasers, to produce a visible fringe pattern on the screen.
      ......................................................................... [1]
    2. State the phase difference between the waves that meet at
      1. B ............................................. [1]
      2. P ............................................. [1]
    3. 1. State the principle of superposition.
         ........................................................................... [2]
      2. Use the principle of superposition to explain the dark fringe at P.
         ........................................................................... [1]
  2. In Fig. 6.1 the distance from the two slits to the screen is 1.8 m. The distance CP is 2.3 mm and the distance between the slits is 0.25 mm.
    Calculate the wavelength of the light provided by the laser.

    wavelength = ........................................... nm [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper2_2/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i to produce coherent sources or constant phase difference B1 [1]
a.ii 1. 360° / 2π rad allow n × 360° or n × 2π (unit missing –1) B1 [1]
2. 180° / π rad allow (n × 360°) – 180° or (n × 2π) – π B1 [1]
a.iii 1. waves overlap / meet
   (resultant) displacement is sum of displacements of each wave		 B1
B1		 [2]
2. at P crest on trough (OWTTE) B1 [1]
b λ = ax / D
   = 2 × 2.3 × 10–3 × 0.25 ×10–3 / 1.8
   = 639 nm		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
    1. to produce coherent sources or constant phase difference
    2. 1. 360° / 2π rad allow n × 360° or n × 2π (unit missing –1)
      2. 180° / π rad allow (n × 360°) – 180° or (n × 2π) – π
    3. 1. waves overlap / meet
          (resultant) displacement is sum of displacements of each wave
      2. at P crest on trough (OWTTE)
  2. λ = ax / D
       = 2 × 2.3 × 10–3 × 0.25 ×10–3 / 1.8
       = 639 nm
    1. A majority of candidates realised the need for coherent sources for this experiment. A significant minority suggested that two sources would not give the same wavelength or frequency.
    2. The phase difference was not given correctly by the majority of candidates. Incorrect values were often given or values were given for the path difference in terms of wavelength. Many candidates did not gain credit as they gave answers without units. 
    3. 1. The principle of superposition was given correctly by a significant number of candidates. However, answers were spoilt by the omission of key words. The waves need to 'overlap' and the resultant 'displacement' is required rather than the resultant amplitude. Stating that the waves need to superpose merely repeats the question and does not help in the explanation of superposition. 
      2. The explanation in terms of the principle of superposition of the dark fringe at P was only given by a minority of candidates. The answers were generally too vague with many stating that there was destructive interference with no reference to the relevant principle.
  2. The correct equation was generally known and given with acceptable symbols. The fringe width was often not substituted into the equation correctly as a factor of two was omitted. A number of candidates were unable to convert the answer calculated in metres into nanometres. The use of non-conventional symbols with the subsequent wrong substitution of values meant that some candidates did not score the credit available for the correct equation. 
NO. 50题号：34345
  1. Explain the term interference.
    ............................................................................ [1]
  2. A ripple tank is used to demonstrate interference between water waves.
    Describe
    1. the apparatus used to produce two sources of coherent waves that have circular wavefronts,
      ............................................................................ [2]
    2. how the pattern of interfering waves may be observed.
      ............................................................................ [2]
  3. A wave pattern produced in (b) is shown in Fig. 7.1.

    Solid lines on Fig. 7.1 represent crests.
    On Fig. 7.1,
    1. draw two lines to show where maxima would be seen (label each of these lines with the letter X), [1]
    2. draw one line to show where minima would be seen (label this line with the letter N). [1]

Q7/9702/21/M/J/11

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper2_1/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a when waves overlap / meet, (resultant) displacement is the sum of the individual displacements B1 [1]
b.i two (ball-type) dippers
connected to the same vibrating source /motor
or
one wave source described
with two slits		 (M1)
(A1)

(M1)
(A1)		 [2]
b.ii lamp with viewing screen on opposite side of tank
means of freezing picture e.g. strobe		 B1
B1		 [2]
c.i two correct lines labelled X B1 [1]
c.ii correct line labelled N B1 [1]
  1. when waves overlap / meet, (resultant) displacement is the sum of the individual displacements
    1. two (ball-type) dippers
      connected to the same vibrating source /motor
      or
      one wave source described
      with two slits
    2. lamp with viewing screen on opposite side of tank
      means of freezing picture e.g. strobe
    1. two correct lines labelled X
    2. correct line labelled N
  1. Explanations were, almost invariably, incomplete. It was realised that interference occurs when waves meet at a point. The result was usually expressed in very simple terms such as 'the production of crests and troughs'. Candidates should provide a clear statement that the resultant displacement is given by the sum of the individual displacements.
    1. Most answers were limited to a description of some form of dipper or dippers, without there being any clear means by which coherent waves would be produced. Either the two dippers must be driven by the same source of vibrations or a single dipper should be placed behind a double slit.
    2. A significant number of candidates did not attempt this part of the question and many others misread the question. Instead of describing how the waves would be observed, they attempted to describe what would be seen. Of those who did describe the use of an appropriately placed light source and screen, very few included some form of strobe. 
  3. There were many scripts where this part of the question was not attempted. Where lines were drawn, many showed the line for minima as being in the position of the zero order maximum.
NO. 51题号：34344
  1. A source of sound has frequency f. Sound of wavelength λ is produced by the source.
    1. State
      1. what is meant by the frequency of the source,
      ........................................................................[1]
      2. the distance moved, in terms of λ, by a wavefront during n oscillations of the source.

        distance = ................................................ [1]
    2. Use your answers in (i) to deduce an expression for the speed v of the wave in terms of f and λ. [2]

  2. The waveform of a sound wave produced on the screen of a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.) is shown in Fig. 5.1.

    The time-base setting of the c.r.o. is 2.0 ms cm–1.
    1. Determine the frequency of the sound wave.

      frequency = ............................................Hz
    2. A second sound wave has the same frequency as that calculated in (i). The amplitude of the two waves is the same but the phase difference between them is 90°.
      On Fig. 5.1, draw the waveform of this second wave. [1]

Q5/9702/23/M/J/10

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper2_3/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i 1. number of oscillations per unit time (not per second)
2. nλ		 B1
A1		 [1]
[1]
a.ii v = distance / time = nλ/t
n/t = f  hence v = fλ
or f oscillations per unit time so fλ is distance per unit time
distance per unit time is v so v = fλ		 M1
A1
M1
A1		 [2]
b.i 1.0 period is 3 × 2 = 6.0 ms
frequency = 1/(6 × 10–3) = 170Hz		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii wave (with approx. same amplitude and) with correct phase difference B1 [1]
    1. 1. number of oscillations per unit time (not per second)
      2. nλ
    2. v = distance / time = nλ/t
      n/t = f  hence  v= fλ
      or f oscillations per unit time so fλ is distance per unit time
      distance per unit time is v so v = fλ
    1. 1.0 period is 3 × 2 = 6.0 ms
      frequency = 1/(6 × 10–3) = 170 Hz
    2. wave (with approx. same amplitude and) with correct phase difference

This question differentiated well between the candidates. 

    1. 1. A number of answers did not refer to the frequency of the source. The number of waves passing a point was not relevant to the question and did not score. Candidates who mixed quantities with units were not given credit.
      2. The majority of candidates gave the correct answer to this part.
    2. Only the good candidates were able to demonstrate a valid method of deducing the correct expression v = fλ from the information given in the question.
    1. The weaker candidates had difficulty using the time-base setting and converting the ms into seconds. The average candidate and above completed this part of the question without difficulty.
    2. There were some very poor diagrams. The candidates would be able to correct their work if they had used a pencil rather than having to cross out work that needed correction but had been done in ink. The good candidates drew correctly constructed waveforms across the diagram. However, these were seldom seen. 
NO. 52题号：34343
  1. State two features of a stationary wave that distinguish it from a progressive wave.
    1. ..............................................................................
    2. .............................................................................. [2]
  2. A long tube is open at one end. It is closed at the other end by means of a piston that can be moved along the tube, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

    A loudspeaker producing sound of frequency 550 Hz is held near the open end of the tube.
    The piston is moved along the tube and a loud sound is heard when the distance L between the piston and the open end of the tube is 45 cm.
    The speed of sound in the tube is 330 ms-1.
    1. Show that the wavelength of the sound in the tube is 60 cm. [1]

    2. On figure, mark all the positions along the tube of
      1. the displacement nodes (label these with the letter N),
      2. the displacement antinodes (label these with the letter A).
        [3]
  3. The frequency of the sound produced by the loudspeaker in (b) is gradually reduced.
    Determine the lowest frequency at which a loud sound will be produced in the tube of length L = 45 cm.

    frequency = .......................................... Hz [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper2_2/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a e.g. no energy transfer
amplitude varies along its length/nodes and antinodes
neighbouring points (in inter-nodal loop) vibrate in phase, etc.
(any two, 1 mark each to max 2		 B2 [2]
b.i λ = (330 × 102)/550
λ = 60cm		 M1
A0		 [1]
b.ii node labelled at piston
antinode labelled at open end of tube
additional node and antinode in correct positions along tube		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
c at lowest frequency, length = λ/4
λ = 1.8 m
frequency = 330/1.8
= 180Hz		 C1

C1
A1		 [3]
  1. e.g. no energy transfer
    amplitude varies along its length/nodes and antinodes
    neighbouring points (in inter-nodal loop) vibrate in phase, etc.
    (any two, 1 mark each to max 2
    1. λ = (330 × 102)/550
      λ = 60cm
    2. node labelled at piston
      antinode labelled at open end of tube
      additional node and antinode in correct positions along tube
  3. at lowest frequency, length = λ/4
    λ = 1.8 m
    frequency = 330/1.8 = 180 Hz

Part (c) was often poorly answered or left blank.

  1. The majority of candidates only scored one mark for this part. Generally this was for reference to the non-transfer of energy. There was confusion between amplitude and displacement; nodes and antinodes were given the wrong way round. A considerable number explained how stationary waves could be produced rather than giving two features.
    1. A significant majority obtained this mark. However, the change from metres to centimetres was often inserted as what appeared to be an afterthought.
    2. The good candidates gained full marks for this part. The average candidates lost marks due to a lack of labelling or poor quality diagrams. The vast majority of marks were lost due to a lack of labelling at the piston and open end of the tube. The weaker candidates scored zero for this part.
  3. The correct answer was only obtained by the very good candidates. Many of the candidates obtained a frequency that was greater than that used in (b) without any comment. The number of candidates realising that the length of the tube for the lowest frequency was equal to one quarter of the wavelength was surprisingly low. 
NO. 53题号：34342
  1. State what is meant by the diffraction of a wave.
    .......................................................................................................  [2]
  2. A laser produces a narrow beam of coherent light of wavelength 632 nm. The beam is incident normally on a diffraction grating, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

    Spots of light are observed on a screen placed parallel to the grating. The distance between the grating and the screen is 165 cm.
    The brightest spot is P. The spots formed closest to P and on each side of P are X and Y.
    X and Y are separated by a distance of 76 cm.
    Calculate the number of lines per metre on the grating.

    number per metre = ................................................. [4]
  3. The grating in (b) is now rotated about an axis parallel to the incident laser beam, as shown in Fig. 4.2.

    State what effect, if any, this rotation will have on the positions of the spots P, X and Y.
    ............................................................................................... [2]
  4. In another experiment using the apparatus in (b), a student notices that the distances XP and PY, as shown in Fig. 4.1, are not equal.
    Suggest a reason for this difference.
    ................................................................................................ [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper2_1/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a when a wave (front) passes by/incident on an edge/slit
wave bends/spreads (into the geometrical shadow)		 M1
M1		 [2]
b tan θ = 38/165   [4]
θ = 13° C1
d sin θ = nλ C1
d = 2.82 × 10–6 C1
number = (1/d =) 3.6 × 105 A1
c P remains in same position
X and Y rotate through 90°		 B1
B1		 [2]
d either  screen not parallel to grating
or  grating not normal to (incident) light		 B1 [1]
  1. when a wave (front) passes by/incident on an edge/slit
    wave bends/spreads (into the geometrical shadow)
  2. tan θ = 38/165
    θ = 13°
    d sin θ = nλ
    d = 2.82 × 10–6
    number = (1/d =) 3.6 × 105
  3. P remains in same position
    X and Y rotate through 90°
  4. either  screen not parallel to grating
    or   grating not normal to (incident) light
  1. Most definitions were adequate, although some candidates did not make it sufficiently clear as to whether they were considering refraction or diffraction. 
  2. Many answers were wrongly based on a formula for double-slit diffraction. Candidates who did recall the correct formula often went on to use the wrong value of θ or wrongly identified n as the number of lines per metre. 
  3. There were some comprehensive answers but many were lacking in key details. The more-able candidates realised that P remains in the same position and that both X and Y rotate through 90º. 
  4. Very few candidates realised that the reason for the difference was either that the screen was no longer parallel to the diffraction grating or that the diffraction grating was no longer normal to the incident light.
NO. 54题号：34341

A double-slit interference experiment is set up using coherent red light as illustrated in Fig. 5.1.

The separation of the slits is 0.86 mm.
The distance of the screen from the double slit is 2.4 m.
A series of light and dark fringes is observed on the screen.

  1. State what is meant by coherent light.
    .........................................................................[1]
  2. Estimate the separation of the dark fringes on the screen.

    separation = .......................................... mm [3]
  3. Initially, the light passing through each slit has the same intensity.
    The intensity of light passing through one slit is now reduced.
    Suggest and explain the effect, if any, on the dark fringes observed on the screen.
    .........................................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Summer/Paper2_2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a constant phase difference B1 [1]
b allow wavelength estimate 750nm → 550nm
separation = λD / x
        = (650 × 10–9 × 2.4) / (0.86 × 10–3)
        = 1.8 mm
(allow 2 marks from inappropriate estimate if answer is in range 10cm → 0.1mm)		 C1
C1

A1

 [3]
c no longer complete destructive interference /
amplitudes no longer completely cancel
so dark fringes are lighter
M1
M1		 [2]
  1. constant phase difference
  2. allow wavelength estimate 750 nm  →  550 nm
    separation = λD / x
    = (650 × 10–9 × 2.4) / (0.86 × 10–3)
    = 1.8mm
    (allow 2 marks from inappropriate estimate if answer is in range 10cm → 0.1mm)
  3. no longer complete destructive interference / amplitudes no longer completely cancel
    so dark fringes are lighter
  1. Answers frequently included a reference to 'constant phase difference'. However, rarely was 'constant phase difference' put into context.
  2. Most answers did include a statement of the correct expression but, frequently, unconventional symbols were left unexplained. The most common correct estimate for the wavelength was 700nm but often, estimates gave rise to ridiculous values for the separation.
  3. There were very few correct answers. The most common responses were that 'the dark fringes will get darker' or that 'the light fringes will become darker but the dark fringes will be unaffected'. 
NO. 55题号：34340

Two sources S1 and S2 of sound are situated 80 cm apart in air, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

The frequency of vibration can be varied. The two sources always vibrate in phase but have different amplitudes of vibration.

A microphone M is situated a distance 100 cm from S1 along a line that is normal to S1S2.

As the frequency of S1 and S2 is gradually increased, the microphone M detects maxima and minima of intensity of sound.

  1. State the two conditions that must be satisfied for the intensity of sound at M to be zero.
    1. ...............................................................................
    2. ............................................................................... [2]
  2. The speed of sound in air is 330 m s–1.
    The frequency of the sound from S1 and S2 is increased. Determine the number of minima that will be detected at M as the frequency is increased from 1.0 kHz to 4.0 kHz.

    number = ................................................ [4]

Q5/9702/21/M/J/09

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Summer/Paper2_1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a either  phase difference is π rad / 180°
or  path difference (between waves from S1 and S2) is ½λ / (n + ½)λ
either  same amplitude / intensity at M
or  ratio of amplitudes is 1.28 / ratio of intensities is 1.282
B1

B1		 [2]
b path difference between waves from S1 and S2 = 28 cm
wavelength changes from 33 cm to 8.25 cm
minimum when λ = (56 cm,) 18.7 cm, 11.2 cm, (8.0 cm)
so two minima		 B1
B1
B1
B1		 [4]
  1. either phase difference is π rad / 180°
    or path difference (between waves from S1 and S2) is ½λ / (n + ½)λ
    either same amplitude / intensity at M
    or ratio of amplitudes is 1.28 / ratio of intensities is 1.282
  2. path difference between waves from S1 and S2 = 28 cm
    wavelength changes from 33 cm to 8.25 cm
    minimum when λ = (56 cm,) 18.7 cm, 11.2 cm, (8.0 cm)
    so two minima
  1. Answers were disappointing in that references to path difference and to amplitude were rarely seen.
  2. The majority of candidates did not appear to understand how to approach this problem, perhaps as a result of a failure to answer part (a). Very few even calculated the path difference.
NO. 56题号：34337

A long tube, fitted with a tap, is filled with water. A tuning fork is sounded above the top of the tube as the water is allowed to run out of the tube, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

A loud sound is first heard when the water level is as shown in Fig. 6.1, and then again when the water level is as shown in Fig. 6.2.

Fig. 6.1 illustrates the stationary wave produced in the tube.

  1. On Fig. 6.2,
    1. sketch the form of the stationary wave set up in the tube, [1]
    2. mark, with the letter N, the positions of any nodes of the stationary wave. [1]
  2. The frequency of the fork is 512 Hz and the difference in the height of the water level for the two positions where a loud sound is heard is 32.4 cm.
    Calculate the speed of sound in the tube.

    speed = …………………… m s–1 [3]
  3. The length of the column of air in the tube in Fig. 6.1 is 15.7 cm.
    Suggest where the antinode of the stationary wave produced in the tube in Fig. 6.1 is likely to be found. [2]

Q6/9702/02/M/J/06

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Summer/Paper2/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i correct shape drawn B1 [1]
a.ii two nodes marked correctly B1 [1]
b ½λ = 0.324 m
v = fλ
   = 512 × 2 × 0.324
   = 332 m s–1		 C1
C1

A1		 [3]
c ¼λ = 16.2 cm
either antinode is 0.5 cm above top of tube
or antinode is 16.2 cm above water surface		 C1

A1		 [2]
    1. correct shape drawn
    2. two nodes marked correctly
  2. ½λ = 0.324 m
    v = fλ = 512 × 2 × 0.324 = 332 m s–1
  3. ¼λ = 16.2 cm
    either antinode is 0.5 cm above top of tube
    or antinode is 16.2 cm above water surface
    1. Most sketches did indicate a node at the water surface. However, many failed to recognise that, since the two diagrams represent water levels for two successive loud sounds, then the separation of the two levels must correspond to one half wavelength. All too frequently, the sketches drawn indicated that the candidate had no real understanding of the concept.
    2. Most candidates did identify the nodes on their diagrams.
  2. Almost all candidates could give a correct expression relating speed, wavelength and frequency. Despite inappropriate diagrams, many did realise that the distance specified would be one half wavelength.
  3. Most candidates merely stated that the antinode would be at, or slightly above, the top of the tube. There were some correct solutions but many who did attempt a quantitative answer assumed the wavelength to be a multiple of the quoted length of the air column, rather than the wavelength they had calculated in (b).
NO. 57题号：34336
  1. Explain what is meant by the diffraction of a wave.
    ................................................................................[2]
  2. Light of wavelength 590 nm is incident normally on a diffraction grating having 750 lines per millimetre.
    The diffraction grating formula may be expressed in the form 
                     d sinθ = nλ.
    1. Calculate the value of d, in metres, for this grating. 

      d = ............................................. m [2]
    2. Determine the maximum value of n for the light incident normally on the grating.

      maximum value of n = .......................................... [2]
    3. Fig. 5.1 shows incident light that is not normal to the grating.

      Suggest why the diffraction grating formula, d sinθ = nλ, should not be used in this situation.
      ................................................................................[1]
  3. Light of wavelengths 590 nm and 595 nm is now incident normally on the grating.
    Two lines are observed in the first order spectrum and two lines are observed in the second order spectrum, corresponding to the two wavelengths.
    State two differences between the first order spectrum and the second order spectrum.
    1. ..............................................................................
    2. .............................................................................. [2]

Q5/9702/02/M/J/05

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2005/Summer/Paper2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a When a wave (front) is incident on an edge
or an obstacle/slit/gap
Wave 'bends' into the geometrical
shadow/changes direction/spreads 
M1

A1		 [2]
b.i d = 1/(750 × 103) 
   = 1.33 × 10-6 m		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii 1.33 × 10-6 × sin90° = n × 590 × 10-9
n = 2 (must be an integer)		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.iii formula assumes no path difference of light before
entering grating or
there is a path difference before the grating		 B1 [1]
c e.g. lines further apart in second order
lines fainter in second order
(allow any sensible difference: 1 each, max 2)
(if differences stated but without reference to the orders, max 1 mark)
B2		 [2]
  1. When a wave (front) is incident on an edge
    or an obstacle/slit/gap
    Wave ‘bends’ into the geometrical
    shadow/changes direction/spread
    1. d = 1/(750 × 103) 
         = 1.33 × 10-6 m 
    2. 1.33 × 10-6 × sin90° = n × 590 × 10-9
      n = 2 (must be an integer)
    3. formula assumes no path difference of light before
      entering grating or
      there is a path difference before the grating
  3. e.g. lines further apart in second order
    lines fainter in second order
    (allow any sensible difference: 1 each, max 2)
    (if differences stated but without reference to the orders, max 1 mark)
  1. Candidates should be encouraged to be as precise as possible with definitions and explanations. Most answers included a statement, with varying degrees of clarity, that diffraction is the bending or spreading of waves through a narrow gap or at an edge. However, wording was frequently ambiguous so that the explanation could apply to refraction. Statements such as 'change of direction when meeting an obstacle' are not acceptable.
    1. This simple calculation caused many problems. Not only were there many errors involving powers-of-ten in otherwise correct calculations but also, many candidates thought that they must use the grating formula given in the question.
    2. In most scripts where d had been calculated correctly, then the maximum value of n was also correct. However, candidates who had made errors in d by as much as factors of up to 1012 usually also calculated equally ridiculous answers for n, without comment.
    3. Very few candidates recognised that the correct use of the formula relies on the fact that light incident on the grating has no path difference. Most candidates repeated the question by stating that the light is not normal to the grating.
  3. Many candidates gave at least one relevant difference, based on either angles of diffraction or intensity. A surprisingly large number of answers ignored the fact that the question specified the two wavelengths involved. Consequently, answers referred to different wavelengths, frequencies or colour. In others, there were vague mentions of angles, without a clear indication as to which angle reference was being made.

Answers: (b)(i) 1.33 × 10–6 m, (ii) 2. 

NO. 58题号：34335

Fig. 6.1 shows wavefronts incident on, and emerging from, a double slit arrangement.

The wavefronts represent successive crests of the wave. The line OX shows one direction along which constructive interference may be observed.

  1. State the principle of superposition.
    .............................................................................................. [3]
  2. On Fig. 6.1, draw lines to show
    1. a second direction along which constructive interference may be observed (label this line CC),
    2. a direction along which destructive interference may be observed (label this line DD).
      [2]
  3. Light of wavelength 650 nm is incident normally on a double slit arrangement. The interference fringes formed are viewed on a screen placed parallel to and 1.2 m from the plane of the double slit, as shown in Fig. 6.2.

    The fringe separation is 0.70 mm.
    1. Calculate the separation a of the slits.

      separation = .................................. m [3]
    2. The width of both slits is increased without changing their separation a. State the effect, if any, that this change has on
      1. the separation of the fringes,
      .......................................................................................
      2. the brightness of the light fringes,
      ........................................................................................
      3. the brightness of the dark fringes.
      ........................................................................................
      [3]

Q6/9702/02/M/J/04

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2004/Summer/Paper2/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a When two (or more) waves meet (not 'superpose' or 'interfere')
resultant displacement
is the sum of individual (displacements)		 B1
M1
A1		 [3]
b.i any correct line through points of intersection of crests B1 [2]
b.ii any correct line through intersections of a crest and a trough B1
c.i λ = ax/D   OR   λ = asin θ and θ = x/D
650 × 10-9 = (a × 0.70 × 10-3)/1.2
a = 1.1 × 10-3 m		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
c.ii 1. no change
2. brighter
3. no change (accept stay/remain dark)		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
  1. When two (or more) waves meet (not 'superpose' or 'interfere')
    resultant displacement
    is the sum of individual (displacements)
    1. any correct line through points of intersection of crests
    2. any correct line through intersections of a crest and a trough
    1. λ = ax/D   OR   λ = asin θ and θ = x/D
      650 × 10-9 = (a × 0.70 × 10-3)/1.2
      a = 1.1 × 10-3 m
    2. 1. no change
      2. brighter
      3. no change (accept stay/remain dark)
  1. There were some very clear concise statements of the principle. However, there were many muddled versions which failed to make clear that the principle applies to the effect at a point in a medium of two or more waves meeting at that point. The waves do not ‘interact’, but produce a resultant displacement that is the vector sum of the individual displacements at that point. Many candidates referred, quite wrongly, to amplitude rather than displacement. 
  2. Most candidates were able to identify a line along which there would be constructive interference but far fewer gave a correct direction for destructive interference. Many did, in fact, draw a second line where constructive interference would be observed. Others drew lines where the waves from the two openings did not overlap. 
    1. There were some scripts where an incorrect formula was quoted and, sometimes, units were muddled. However, the majority of calculations were correct. 
    2. This was not answered well and indicated that many candidates did not understand the basic concepts.

Answer: (c)(i) 1.1 x 10-3 m.

NO. 59题号：34334

Fig. 2.1 shows the variation with distance x along a wave of its displacement d at a particular time.


The wave is a progressive wave having a speed of 330 m s–1.

    1. Use Fig. 2.1 to determine the wavelength of the wave.

      wavelength = ................................... m
    2. Hence calculate the frequency of the wave.

      frequency = .................................... Hz 
      [3]
  2. A second wave has the same frequency and speed as the wave shown in Fig. 2.1 but has double the intensity. The phase difference between the two waves is 180°.
    On the axes of Fig. 2.1, sketch a graph to show the variation with distance x of the displacement d of this second wave. [2]

Q2/9702/02/M/J/04

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2004/Summer/Paper2/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a.i λ = 0.6 m B1 [3]
a.ii frequency (= v/ λ ) = 330/0.60
                  = 550 Hz
(use of c = 3 × 108 ms-1 scores no marks) 		 C1
A1
b amplitude shown as greater than a but less than 2a and constant
correct phase
(wave to be at least three half-periods, otherwise -1 overall) 		 B1
B1

 [2]
    1. λ = 0.6 m
    2. frequency (= v/ λ ) = 330/0.60 = 550 Hz 
      (use of c = 3 × 108 ms-1 scores no marks)
  2. amplitude shown as greater than a but less than 2a and constant
    correct phase
    (wave to be at least three half-periods, otherwise -1 overall)
  1. With few exceptions, candidates read correctly the wavelength from the graph and completed the calculation to obtain the frequency. 
  2. Relatively few sketches indicated a wave with an appropriate amplitude. Many candidates did indicate, either by formula or by words, that the square of the amplitude is proportional to intensity. However, this fact was rarely translated to the sketch. The majority of sketches did show the correct phase for the new wave. 

Answers: (a)(i) 0.60 m, (ii) 550 Hz. 

NO. 60题号：34333
  1. State three conditions that must be satisfied in order that two waves may interfere.
    1. ................................................................................................
    2. ................................................................................................
    3. ................................................................................................ [3]
  2. The apparatus illustrated in Fig. 4.1 is used to demonstrate two-source interference using light.

    The separation of the two slits in the double slit arrangement is a and the interference fringes are viewed on a screen at a distance D from the double slit. When light of wavelength λ is incident on the double slit, the separation of the bright fringes on the screen is x.
    1. 1. Suggest a suitable value for the separation a of the slits in the double slit.
      .......................................................................................
      2. Write down an expression relating λ, a, D and x.
      .......................................................................................
      [2]
    2. Describe the effect, if any, on the separation and on the maximum brightness of the fringes when the following changes are made.
      1. The distance D is increased to 2D, keeping a and λ constant.
      separation: ...............................................................................................
      maximum brightness: ..........................................................................
      2. The wavelength A is increased to 1.5A, keeping a and D constant.
      separation: ...............................................................................................
      maximum brightness: ..........................................................................
      3. The intensity of the light incident on the double slit is increased, keeping A, a and D constant.
      separation: ...............................................................................................
      maximum brightness: .......................................................................... 
      [7]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2003/Summer/Paper2/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a e.g. both transverse/longitudinal/same type
meet at a point,
same direction of polarisation, etc.......1 each, max 3 .................
(allow 1 mark for any condition for observable interference)		 B3 [3]
b.i.1 allow 0.3 mm → 3 mm B1 [2]
b.i.2 λ= ax/D (allow any subject). B1
b.ii.1 separation increased
less bright		 B1
B1		 [7]
b.ii.2 separation increased
less bright		 B1
B1
b.ii.3 separation unchanged
fringes brighter
further detail, i.e quantitive aspect in (ii)1 or (ii)2
(in (b), do not allow e.c.f. from (b)(i)2)		 B1
B1
B1
  1. e.g. both transverse/longitudinal/same type
    meet at a point,
    same direction of polarisation, etc.......1 each, max 3
    (allow 1 mark for any condition for observable interference)
    1. 1. allow 0.3 mm   →   3 mm.
      2. λ = ax/D (allow any subject)
    2. 1. separation increased.
         less bright
      2. separation increased.
         less bright
      3. separation unchanged.
         fringes brighter.
         further detail, i.e quantitive aspect in (ii)1 or (ii)2.
         (in (b), do not allow e.c.f. from (b)(i)2)
  1. It was expected that the general conditions for interference would be given. That is, the waves should both be of the same type, they should be unpolarised or polarised in the same direction and they should meet at a point. However, most chose to give the conditions for an interference pattern to be visible. Some credit was given for this.
    1. Very few candidates could give an appropriate separation. Many were of the order of the wavelength of light or the screen-slit separation. However, most answers were correct for the expression relating λ, a, D and x.
    2. Most candidates scored more than half of the available marks for this part of the question. Despite being given some numerical changes, some candidates answered in a purely qualitative manner. The most common error was in the maximum brightness when the wavelength is increased. Although most realised that the fringes would broaden, they did not relate this broadening to the re-distribution of energy and the consequent decrease in intensity.
NO. 61题号：34321
  1. An electric field is set up between two parallel metal plates in a vacuum. The deflection of α-particles as they pass between the plates is shown in Fig. 7.1.

    The electric field strength between the plates is reduced. The α-particles are replaced by β-particles. The deflection of β-particles is shown in Fig. 7.2.

    1. State one similarity of the electric fields shown in Fig. 7.1 and Fig. 7.2.
      ..................................................................[1]
    2. The electric field strength in Fig. 7.2 is less than that in Fig. 7.1. State two methods of reducing this electric field strength.
      1. ...................................................................
      2. ................................................................... [2]
    3. By reference to the properties of α-particles and β-particles, suggest three reasons for the differences in the deflections shown in Fig. 7.1 and Fig. 7.2.
      1. .....................................................................
      2. .....................................................................
      3. ..................................................................... [3]
  2. A source of α-particles is uranium-238. The nuclear reaction for the emission of α-particles is represented by
         
    State the values of
    W ...............
    X ...............
    Y ...............
    Z ............... [2]
  3. A source of β-particles is phosphorus-32. The nuclear reaction for the emission of β-particles is represented by
           
    State the values of
    A ...............
    B ...............
    C ...............
    D ............... [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Winter/Paper2_1/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i the direction of the fields is the same OR fields are uniform OR constant electric field strength OR E = V / d with symbols explained B1 [1]
a.ii reduce p.d. across plates
increase separation of plates		 B1
B1		 [2]
a.iii α opposite charge to β (as deflection in opposite direction)
β has a range of velocities OR energies (as different deflections) and α all have same velocity OR energy (as constant deflection)
α are more massive (as deflection is less for greater field strength)		 B1

B1
B1		 [3]
b W = 234 and X = 90
Y = 4 and Z = 2		 B1
B1		 [2]
c A = 32 and B = 16 and C = 0 and D = –1 B1 [1]
    1. the direction of the fields is the same OR fields are uniform OR constant electric field strength OR E = V / d with symbols explained
    2. reduce p.d. across plates
      increase separation of plates
    3. α opposite charge to β (as deflection in opposite direction)
      β has a range of velocities OR energies (as different deflections) and
      α all have same velocity OR energy (as constant deflection)
      α are more massive (as deflection is less for greater field strength)
  2. W = 234 and X = 90
    Y = 4 and Z = 2
  3. A = 32 and B = 16 and C = 0 and D = –1

This question was generally well answered by many candidates. 

    1. The majority of candidates gave acceptable answers. A common error was to give a statement that referred to the field lines rather than to give a similarity of the electric fields. There was also reference to the charge on the plates or that both fields/field lines go/travel from positive to negative. 
    2. This part was generally well answered with full credit awarded to many candidates. A significant number of candidates were imprecise and indicated a decreased voltage or potential difference without indicating that this is between the plates. 
    3. This part of the question was effective at differentiating the candidates. The most common correct answer was that the α-particles and β-particles have opposite charge. Many answers referred to α-particles being 'heavier', rather than more massive, than β-particles. The least understood reason was that β-particles have a range of energies while α-particles have the same energy. There were a significant number of incomplete answers, such as those describing a property of the α-particle but not comparing it with the same property of the β-particle. 
  2. This was generally well answered.
  3. This was generally well answered. 
NO. 62题号：34319

A nuclear reaction between two helium nuclei produces a second isotope of helium, two protons and 13.8 MeV of energy. The reaction is represented by the following equation.

  1. Complete the nuclear equation. [2]

  2. By reference to this reaction, explain the meaning of the term isotope.
    ................................................................ [2]
  3. State the quantities that are conserved in this nuclear reaction.
    ................................................................ [2]
  4. Radiation is produced in this nuclear reaction.
    State
    1. a possible type of radiation that may be produced,
      ....................................................... [1]
    2. why the energy of this radiation is less than the 13.8 MeV given in the equation.
      ....................................................... [1]
  5. Calculate the minimum number of these reactions needed per second to produce power of 60 W.

    number = ........................................... s–1 [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper2_2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a
A numbers correct  (4 and 1)
Z numbers correct  (2 and 1)
B1
B1		 [2]
b both nuclei have 2 protons
the two isotopes have 1 neutron and two neutrons
[allow 1 for 'same number of protons but different number of neutrons']		 B1
B1

 [2]
c proton number and neutron number
energy – mass
momentum		 B1
B1
B1		 [2]
d.i γ radiation B1 [1]
d.ii product(s) must have kinetic energy B1 [1]
e 13.8MeV = 13.8 × 1.6 × 10–19 × 106 (= 2.208 × 10–12)
60 = n × 13.8 × 1.6 × 10–13
n = 2.7(2) × 1013 s–1		 C1

A1		 [2]
  1. 32He + 32He   →   42He  + 2 11p + Q
    A numbers correct (4 and 1)
    Z numbers correct (2 and 1)
  2. both nuclei have 2 protons
    the two isotopes have 1 neutron and two neutrons
    [allow 1 for ‘same number of protons but different number of neutrons’]
  3. proton number and neutron number
    energy – mass
    momentum
    1. γ radiation
    2. product(s) must have kinetic energy
  5. 13.8 MeV = 13.8 × 1.6 × 10–19 × 106 (= 2.208 × 10–12)
    60 = n × 13.8 × 1.6 × 10–13
    n = 2.7(2) × 1013 s–1
  1. This part was generally answered correctly. A significant minority made errors by ignoring the factor of 2 for the proton or left the question blank.
  2. There were only a few candidates who described the meaning of isotopes with reference to nuclei. Even fewer referred to the nuclear equation given in the question. The majority who scored any marks gained just one mark for the reference to atoms having the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons.
  3. A significant number of candidates scored one mark. The conservation of energy-mass was given by more candidates than on previous papers. Many candidates did not score this mark as there was a suggestion that energy and mass were both conserved. 
    1. This was generally poorly answered with many guesses or no answer given. 
    2. A statement that referred to the products having kinetic energy was mentioned by very few candidates.
  5. The calculation was completed by only the able candidates. Some strong candidates made a power of ten error or used an incorrect conversion factor for the charge on an electron. Many were unable to convert the 13.8 MeV into joule.
NO. 63题号：34318
  1. Describe the structure of an atom of the nuclide 23592U.
    ................................................................ [2]
  2. The deflection of α-particles by a thin metal foil is investigated with the arrangement shown in Fig. 6.1. All the apparatus is enclosed in a vacuum.

    The detector of α-particles, D, is moved around the path labelled WXY.
    1. Explain why the apparatus is enclosed in a vacuum.
      ....................................................................... [1]
    2. State and explain the readings detected by D when it is moved along WXY.
      ....................................................................... [3]
  3. A beam of α-particles produces a current of 1.5 pA. Calculate the number of α-particles per second passing a point in the beam.
    number = ........................................... s–1 [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper2_1/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a 92 protons in the nucleus and 92 electrons around nucleus
143 neutrons (in the nucleus)		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.i α-particle travels short distance in air B1 [1]
b.ii very small proportion in backwards direction / large angles
majority pass through with no /small deflections
either most of mass is in very small volume (nucleus) and is charged or most of atom is empty space		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
c I = Q / t
n / t = (1.5 × 10–12) /( 2 × 1.6 × 10–19)
n / t = 4.7 × 106 s–1		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
  1. 92 protons in the nucleus and 92 electrons around nucleus
    143 neutrons (in the nucleus)
    1. α-particle travels short distance in air
    2. very small proportion in backwards direction / large angles
      majority pass through with no /small deflections
      either most of mass is in very small volume (nucleus) and is charged or most of atom is empty space
  3. I = Q / t
    n / t = (1.5 × 10–12) /( 2 × 1.6 × 10–19)
    n / t = 4.7 × 106 s–1
  1. There were very few completely correct answers as a result of not reading the question carefully. Candidates were asked to describe the atom. The majority that gave suitable answers generally only stated the number of protons and neutrons in the nucleus with little or no description of the atom. 
    1. The limited range of α-particles in air was not considered by the vast majority of candidates as a reason for evacuating the apparatus used for the deflection of such particles.  
    2. The majority of candidates were not adequately prepared for describing and explaining the readings obtained in this experiment, and would have benefited from further study of this part of the syllabus. 
  3. The link between the current and the charge on the α-particles was not given by the vast majority of candidates. The majority of candidates did not produce an answer. 
NO. 64题号：34317

Two horizontal metal plates are separated by distance d in a vacuum. A potential difference V is applied across the plates, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

A horizontal beam of α-particles from a radioactive source is made to pass between the plates.

  1. State and explain the effect on the deflection of the α-particles for each of the following changes:
    1. The magnitude of V is increased.
      .............................................................. [1]
    2. The separation d of the plates is decreased.
      .............................................................. [1]
  2. The source of α-particles is replaced with a source of β-particles.
    Compare, with a reason in each case, the effect of each of the following properties on the deflections of α- and β-particles in a uniform electric field:
    1. charge
      .................................................................... [2]
    2. mass
      .................................................................... [2]
    3. speed
      .................................................................... [1]
  3. The electric field gives rise to an acceleration of the α-particles and the β-particles.
    Determine the ratio 
       

    ratio = .................................................. [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper2_3/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i greater deflection
greater electric field / force on α-particle		 M0
A1		 [1]
a.ii greater deflection
greater electric field / force on α-particle		 M0
A1		 [1]
b.i either  deflections in opposite directions
           because oppositely charged
or  β less deflection
     β has smaller charge		 M1
A1
(M1)
(A1)		 [2]
b.ii α smaller deflection
because larger mass		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.iii β less deflection because higher speed B1 [1]
c either  F = ma and F = Eq  or a = Eq / m C1 [3]
C1
ratio = 1 /4000 or  2.5 × 10–4 or  2.7 × 10–4 A1
    1. greater deflection
      greater electric field / force on α-particle
    2. greater deflection
      greater electric field / force on α-particle
    1. either deflections in opposite directions
            because oppositely charged
      or   β less deflection
            β has smaller charge
    2. α smaller deflection
      because larger mass
    3. β less deflection because higher speed

    ratio = either 
    or    [2e × 1 / 2000 u] / [e × 4u]

  1. A significant number of answers did not include any explanation. Consequently, full credit could not be given. 
    1. This was generally well answered by reference to opposite charges and deflection to named plates.
    2. There were many correct responses. However, a minority made reference to mass in u and then became confused when dealing with the mass of the β-particle.
    3. In most answers, it was realised that, in general, a β-particle has a higher speed. The effect of this higher speed, when isolated from other factors, was understood by only a minority of candidates.
  3. Very few candidates arrived at the correct answer. In the majority of cases, only mass or only charge was considered, even where the expression a = Eq/m was quoted.

    and a different number of neutrons

      x = 56
