  1. The required explanation of an isotope was not well known by a large number of candidates. Candidates must refer to nuclei in their explanation of isotopes.
    1. Very few candidates were able to give the required quantity conserved in a nuclear reaction.
    2. Well prepared candidates completed the analysis and gained full credit. It was clear that many candidates had not had sufficient practice with these types of reactions.

NO. 66题号：34314
  1. Explain what is meant by radioactive decay.
    ....................................................................... [2]
    1. State how the random nature of radioactive decay may be inferred from observations of the count rate. 
      ....................................................................... [1]
    2. A radioactive source has a long half-life so that, over a period of several days, its rate of decay remains constant.
      State the effect, if any, of a rise in temperature on this decay rate.
      ....................................................................... [1]
    3. Suggest why some radioactive sources are found to contain traces of helium gas.
      ....................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper2_3/Q9
Question Answer Marks  
a nucleus emits α-particles or β-particles and/or γ-radiation
to form a different / more stable nucleus		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.i fluctuations in count rate (not 'count rate is not constant') B1 [1]
b.ii no effect B1 [1]
b.iii if the source is an α-emitter
either  α-particles stopped within source (and gain electrons)
or  α-particles are helium nuclei
allow 1/2 for 'parent nucleus gives off radiation to form daughter nucleus' 		 B1

B1

 [2]
  1. nucleus emits α-particles or β-particles and/or γ-radiation
    to form a different / more stable nucleus
    1. fluctuations in count rate (not ‘count rate is not constant’)
    2. no effect
    3. if the source is an α-emitter
      either    α-particles stopped within source (and gain electrons)
      or    α-particles are helium nuclei
      allow 1/2 for ‘parent nucleus gives off radiation to form daughter nucleus’
  1. The attention of candidates should be drawn to the distinction between atom, nucleus, nucleon and nuclide. In this question, it is the nucleus that emits either α- or β- and/or γ-radiation to form either a different or a more stable nucleus. Furthermore, there is a common misconception that the α- or β- and/or γ-radiations are radioactive.
  2. Parts (i) and (ii) were answered well. In (iii), most candidates did realise that the source must be an α-emitter. Common misconceptions were either that the α-particles must combine with βparticles to form helium atoms or that the α-particles are helium atoms.

  1. Uranium (U) has at least fourteen isotopes.
    Explain what is meant by isotopes.
    ........................................................................ [2]
  2. One possible nuclear reaction involving uranium is

    1. State three quantities that are conserved in a nuclear reaction.
      1. ...............................................................
      2. ...............................................................
      3. ............................................................... [3]
    2. For this reaction, determine the value of
      1. Z,

         Z = ............................................... [1]
      2. x.

         x = ............................................... [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper2_1/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a either  different forms of same element
or  nuclei have same number of protons
different numbers of neutrons (in the nucleus)
M1
A1		 [2]
b.i proton number conserved
nucleon number conserved
mass-energy conserved		 B1
B1
B1		 [2]
b.ii 1. Z = 36 A1 [1]
2. x = 3 A1 [1]
  1. either different forms of same element
    or nuclei have same number of protons
    different numbers of neutrons (in the nucleus)
    1. proton number conserved
      nucleon number conserved
      mass-energy conserved
    2. 1. Z = 36
      2. x = 3
  1. The attention of candidates should be drawn to the distinction between atom, nucleus, nucleon and nuclide. In this question, it is nuclei that have the same number of protons that should be used to explain isotopes.
    1. Very few candidates were able to give more than one correct quantity that is conserved in a nuclear reaction. 
    2. Very few candidates were able to apply the conservation laws to the nuclear equation and obtain the correct values. 
NO. 68题号：34311

Tungsten-184 (18474W) and tungsten-185 (18574W) are two isotopes of tungsten.

Tungsten-184 is stable but tungsten-185 undergoes β-decay to form rhenium (Re).

  1. Explain what is meant by isotopes.
    ......................................................................... [2]
  2. The β-decay of nuclei of tungsten-185 is spontaneous and random.
    State what is meant by
    1. spontaneous decay,
      ............................................................... [1]
    2. random decay.
      ................................................................ [1]
  3. Complete the nuclear equation for the β-decay of a tungsten-185 nucleus.
          18574W → .................. + ................  [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper2_2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a either forms of same element
or atoms / nuclei with same number of protons
atoms / nuclei contain different numbers of neutrons
(use of 'element' rather than atoms / nuclei scores max 1 mark)		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i decay is not affected by environmental factors
(allow two named factors) 		 B1 [1]
b.ii either  time of decay (of a nucleus) cannot be predicted
or  nucleus has constant probability in a given time		 B1 [1]
c 18575Re B1 [2]
either  0−1e  or  0−1β B1
    [Total: 6]
  1. either forms of same element
    or   atoms / nuclei with same number of protons
    atoms / nuclei contain different numbers of neutrons
    (use of ‘element’ rather than atoms / nuclei scores max 1 mark)
    1. decay is not affected by environmental factors
      (allow two named factors)
    2. either time of decay (of a nucleus) cannot be predicted
      or  nucleus has constant probability in a given time
  3. 18575 Re
    either  0−1e   or   0−1β
  1. As is usual with questions on this topic, there was widespread confusion between terms such as nucleus, nuclide, neutron, element and isotope. For example, a common answer was a statement that isotopes are 'elements with the same proton number......'. Candidates should be encouraged to use the terms proton number and nucleon number rather than atomic number and mass number. 
  2. Most candidates could explain the meaning of spontaneity. However, explanations of randomness frequently lacked precision. Rather than 'it cannot be determined which atom will decay next', candidates should be encouraged to consider constant probability per unit time of the decay of a nucleus. 
  3. A common error was to give the symbol for the daughter nucleus as W. Surprisingly, the representation of the β-particle was frequently incorrect. 
NO. 69题号：34310

An α-particle A approaches and passes by a stationary gold nucleus N. The path is illustrated in Fig. 7.1.

  1. On Fig. 7.1, mark the angle of deviation D of this α-particle as a result of passing the nucleus N. [1]

  2. A second α-particle B has the same initial direction and energy as α-particle A.
    On Fig. 7.1, complete the path of α-particle B as it approaches and passes by the nucleus N. [2]

  3. State what can be inferred about atoms from the observation that very few α-particles experience large deviations.
    ..................................................................... [2]
  4. The nucleus N could be one of several different isotopes of gold.
    Suggest, with an explanation, whether different isotopes of gold would give rise to different deviations of a particular α-particle. 
    ..................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper2_1/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a deviation shown correctly B1 [1]
b smaller deviation (not zero deviation)
acceptable path wrt position of N		 M1
A1		 [2]
c the nucleus is (very) small
in comparison to the atom
(special case: 'atom is mostly empty space' scores 1 mark)		 M1
A1		 [2]
d deviation depends on charge on the nucleus / N / electrostatic repulsion
same charge so no change in deviation		 B1
B1		 [2]
    [Total: 7]
  1. deviation shown correctly
  2. smaller deviation (not zero deviation)
    acceptable path wrt position of N
  3. the nucleus is (very) small
    in comparison to the atom
    (special case: ‘atom is mostly empty space’ scores 1 mark)
  4. deviation depends on charge on the nucleus / N / electrostatic repulsion
    same charge so no change in deviation

The average mark for this question was very low. 

  1. Very few candidates showed the angle of deviation by drawing two construction lines. The majority marked an angle between a continuation of the horizontal section and the curved section. The weaker candidates put a D on the diagram without any angle being marked. 
  2. The good candidates generally scored some credit in this part for showing less deflection. However, a large number of candidates started the deflection far too late and the curve drawn was not symmetrical about the nucleus N. The weaker candidates often showed the same deflection for both particles A and B. 
  3. The commonest answer was to state that the atom was mostly empty space. Only a minority of candidates compared the size of the nucleus with that of the atom. A significant number of candidates referred to the atom of the α-particle or its proximity of approach to the nucleus and hence failed to answer the question. 
  4. The majority of candidates obtained some credit for realising that the deviation would not change as the number of protons would not change. Very few candidates explained that the deflection depended on the charge present on the nucleus N, and hence few scored full marks. A significant minority suggested that the deflection would differ due to the change in mass of the nucleus. 
NO. 70题号：34309

Thoron is a radioactive gas. The variation with time t of the detected count rate C from a sample of the gas is shown in Fig. 8.1.

Radioactive decay is said to be a random and spontaneous process.

  1. Explain, by reference to radioactive decay, what is meant by a random process.
    .............................................................................. [2]
  2. State the feature of Fig. 8.1 which indicates that the process is
    1. a decay process,
      .................................................................... [1]
    2. random.
      .................................................................... [1]
  3. A second similar sample of thoron is prepared but it is at a much higher temperature.
    The variation with time of the count rate for this second sample is determined.
    State the feature of the decay curves for the two samples that suggests that radioactive decay is a spontaneous process.
    .............................................................................. [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2008/Winter/Paper2/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a nucleus has constant probability of decay
per unit time / in a given time
(allow 1 mark for 'cannot predict which nucleus will decay next') 		 M1
A1

 [2]
b.i count rate / activity decreases B1 [1]
b.ii count rate fluctuates / is not smooth B1 [1]
c either  the (decay) curves are similar / same
or  curves indicate same half-life		 B1 [1]
  1. nucleus has constant probability of decay
    per unit time / in a given time
    (allow 1 mark for ‘cannot predict which nucleus will decay next’)
    1. count rate / activity decreases
    2. count rate fluctuates / is not smooth
  3. either   the (decay) curves are similar / same
    or   curves indicate same half-life
  1. Many answers involved a statement that it is not possible to predict when a nucleus will decay. Such a statement is inadequate at AS Level. Others made reference to constant probability of decay without stating that this constant probability is per unit time. 
  2. With few exceptions, both parts were answered satisfactorily. 
  3. Most answers included a statement that the curves would be 'the same'. Usually, some explanation was given although this was not necessary. A minority of candidates thought that the curve would be steeper. 
NO. 71题号：34308
  1. Evidence for the nuclear atom was provided by the α-particle scattering experiment. State the results of this experiment.
    ..................................................................................... [2]
  2. Give estimates for the diameter of
    1. an atom,
      ........................................................................... [1]
    2. a nucleus.
      ........................................................................... [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2007/Winter/Paper2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a most α-particles deviated through small angles 
(accept 'undeviated')
few α-particles deviated through angles greater than 90°		 B1

B1		 [2]
b.i allow 10–9 m → 10–11 m B1 [1]
b.ii allow 10–13 m → 10–15 m
(if (i) and (ii) out of range but (ii) = 10–4(i), then allow 1 mark)
(if no units or wrong units but (ii) = 10–4(i), then allow 1 mark)		 B1


 [1]
  1. most α-particles deviated through small angles
    (accept ‘undeviated’)
    few α-particles deviated through angles greater than 90°
    1. allow 10–9 m   →   10–11 m
    2. allow 10–13 m  →  10–15 m
      (if (i) and (ii) out of range but (ii) = 10–4(i), then allow 1 mark)
      (if no units or wrong units but (ii) = 10–4(i), then allow 1 mark)
  1. A significant number of candidates discussed the conclusions that could be drawn from the experiment rather than state the results. Many did summarise the results very clearly. However, there were more who failed to appreciate the importance of the relative numbers of particles that are deflected either only slightly or through an angle greater than 90°. 
  2. There were many acceptable estimates for the diameters of the atom and of the nucleus. It was apparent, however, that a significant minority of candidates had no appreciation of the numbers involved. Estimates for the nuclear diameter varied from 10-54 m to many metres.
NO. 72题号：34307

The α-particle scattering experiment provided evidence for the existence of a nuclear atom.

  1. State what could be deduced from the fact that
    1. most α-particles were deviated through angles of less than 10°,
      .......................................................................... [2]
    2. a very small proportion of the α-particles was deviated through angles greater than 90°.
      .......................................................................... [2]
  2. Fig. 7.1 shows the path AB of an α-particle as it approaches and passes by a stationary gold nucleus.

    On Fig. 7.1, draw lines (one in each case) to complete the paths of the α-particles passing by the gold nucleus when the initial direction of approach is
    1. along line CD,
    2. along line EF.
      [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2004/Winter/Paper2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i nucleus is small 
in comparison to size of atom		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii nucleus is massive/heavy/dense
and charged  (allow to be scored in (i) or (ii))		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.i symmetrical path and deviation correct w.r.t. position of nucleus
deviation less than in path AB		 B1
B1		 [3]
b.ii deviation > 90° and in correct direction B1
    1. nucleus is small
      in comparison to size of atom
    2. nucleus is massive/heavy/dense
      and charged    (allow to be scored in (i) or (ii))
    1. symmetrical path and deviation correct w.r.t. position of nucleus
      deviation less than in path AB
    2. deviation > 90º and in correct direction
  1. Few candidates appeared to have significant knowledge of the conclusions drawn from the scattering experiment. Many answers ignored evidence related to the nuclear atom but instead, discussed properties of α-particles. Others quoted characteristics of the nuclear atom but attributed evidence for the characteristics to the wrong observation. Candidates should be discouraged from stating that 'the atom is mostly empty space'. Instead, the relative diameters of the nucleus and the atom should be discussed.
    1. There were very few good diagrams showing the paths of the particles. The paths should show symmetry with respect to the position of the nucleus. This was rarely the case. The path starting along CD should have a smaller deviation than that starting along AB but in many scripts, CD was drawn parallel to AB.
    2. This path should indicate a deviation much greater than 90° in a 'downwards' direction. Instead, many showed a deflection in an upwards direction and, not infrequently, the α-particle 'bouncing' off the nucleus. 
NO. 73题号：34306

One isotope of iron may be represented by the symbol 5626Fe.

  1. State, for one nucleus of this isotope,
    1. the number of protons,

      number = ……………………………………
    2. the number of neutrons.

      number = …………………………………
      [2]
  2. The nucleus of this isotope of iron may be assumed to be a sphere of radius 5.7×10–15 m.
    Calculate, for one such nucleus,
    1. the mass,

      mass = …………………………………. kg
    2. the density.

      density = …………………………………. kg m–3
      [4]
  3. An iron ball is found to have a density of 7900 kg m–3. By reference to your answer in (b)(ii), suggest what can be inferred about the structure of an atom of iron.
    ........................................................................ [2]

Q6/9702/2/O/N03

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2003/Winter/Paper2/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i 26 protons B1 [2]
a.ii 30 neutrons B1
b.i mass = 56 × 1.66 × 10-27
(allow × 1.67 × 10-27 but 0/2 for use of 26 or 30)
        = 9.3 × 10-26 kg		 C1

A1		 [4]
b.ii density = mass/volume where volume = 4/3 × π × r3
  = (9.3 × 10-26)/(4/3 × π × {5.7 × 10-15}3)
  = 1.2 × 1017 kg m-3 		 C1

A1
c nucleus occupies only very small fraction of volume of atom
or 'lot of empty space inside atom'
(do not allow spacing between atoms)
any further good physics e.g. nuclear material is very dense
B1

B1		 [2]
    1. 26 protons
    2. 30 neutrons
    1. mass = 56 × 1.66 × 10-27
      (allow × 1.67 × 10-27 but 0/2 for use of 26 or 30)
      = 9.3 × 10-26 kg
    2. density = mass/volume where volume = 4/3 × π × r3
      = (9.3 × 10-26)/(4/3 × π × {5.7 × 10-15}3)
      = 1.2 × 1017 kg m-3
  3. nucleus occupies only very small fraction of volume of atom
    or 'lot of empty space inside atom'
    (do not allow spacing between atoms)
    any further good physics e.g. nuclear material is very dense
  1. With few exceptions, the correct numbers were given.
    1. When finding the mass of the nucleus, some candidates did not include the mass of the neutrons. Many of those who elected to use the Avogadro constant confused the gram-mole and the kilogram-mole. 
    2. As is often the case, a large number of candidates could not recall the formula for the volume of a sphere. Most of those who could find the volume of a sphere correctly calculated the density. 
  3. Very few answers involved the relatively very high density of the nucleus and the smallness of the fraction of the volume of the atom occupied by the nucleus. Most answers were, quite wrongly, based on atomic structure and the spaces between atoms. 
NO. 74题号：34305

A nucleus of an atom of francium (Fr) contains 87 protons and 133 neutrons.

  1. Write down the notation for this nuclide. [2]
       
  2. The nucleus decays by the emission of an α-particle to become a nucleus of astatine (At).
    Write down a nuclear equation to represent this decay. [2]

A level PHYSICS 2002/Winter/Paper2/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a shows nucleon number as 220
shows proton number as 87		 B1
B1		 [2]
b shows products as 42He  OR 42α
and 21685At ... (allow e.c.f. from (a))		 B1
B1		 [2]
  1. shows nucleon number as 220
    shows proton number as 87
  2. shows products as 42He  OR 42α
    and 21685At ... (allow e.c.f. from (a))
  1. The majority of answers were correct but a significant minority did give the neutron number for the nucleon number.
  2. Although the majority of answers were correct, it was not uncommon to find an equation implying bombardment of the francium nucleus by the alpha particle rather than alpha particle decay.

    2. With reference to the two forms of uranium, explain the term isotopes.

      Y = ............................

    2. Explain why the sum of the masses of the uranium nucleus and of the neutron does not equal the total mass of the products of the reaction.

A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_3/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i nucleus contains 92 protons
nucleus contains 143 neutrons   (missing 'nucleus' 1/2)
outside / around nucleus 92 electrons
most of atom is empty space / mass concentrated in nucleus
total charge is zero
diameter of atom ~ 10–10 m or size of nucleus ~ 10–15 m
any two of (B1) marks		 B1
B1
(B1)
(B1)
(B1)
(B1)

 [4]
a.ii nucleus has same number / 92 protons
nuclei have 143 and 146 neutrons   (missing 'nucleus' 1/2)		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.i Y = 35
Z = 85		 A1
A1		 [2]
b.ii mass-energy is conserved in the reaction B1 [2]
mass on rhs of reaction is less so energy is released
explained in terms of E = mc2		 B1
    1. nucleus contains 92 protons
      nucleus contains 143 neutrons     (missing ‘nucleus’ 1/2)
      outside / around nucleus 92 electrons
      most of atom is empty space / mass concentrated in nucleus
      total charge is zero
      diameter of atom ~ 10–10 m or size of nucleus ~ 10–15 m
      any two of marks
    2. nucleus has same number / 92 protons
      nuclei have 143 and 146 neutrons    (missing ‘nucleus’ 1/2)
    1. Y = 35
      Z = 85
    2. mass-energy is conserved in the reaction
      mass on rhs of reaction is less so energy is released explained in terms of E = mc2
    1. Many very brief descriptions of the atom of uranium were given. Candidates should be encouraged to pay attention to the number of marks available: here the four marks available should have been an indication that the description needed detail. 
    2. The explanations given by the vast majority of candidates did not answer the question with reference to the nuclei of the isotopes of uranium. The general comparison of nuclei was seldom described. The comparison of atoms or elements did not gain credit.
    1. The correct values were determined by only a small number of candidates. The values needed for the neutron seemed to cause problems for many of the candidates. 
    2. Candidates found it difficult to give acceptable answers to this question. Mass-energy conservation was rarely described. The idea that the mass of the reactants was greater than the mass of the products was seldom described. The link with the mass difference being converted to energy and being released in the reaction was described by a very small number of candidates. 
NO. 76题号：34302
  1. Describe the two main results of the α-particle scattering experiment.
    result 1: .....................................................................
    result 2: ..................................................................... [3]
  2. Relate each of the results in (a) with the conclusions that were made about the nature of atoms.
    result 1: .....................................................................
    result 2: ..................................................................... [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_1/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a the majority/most went straight through
 or were deviated by small angles		 B1 [3]
a very small proportion/a few were deviated by large angles
small angles described as < 10° and large angles described as >90°		 B1
B1
b most of the atom is empty space/nucleus very small compared with atom
mass and charge concentrated in (very small) nucleus
correct links made with statements in (a)		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
  1. the majority/most went straight through
    or were deviated by small angles

    a very small proportion/a few were deviated by large angles
    small angles described as < 10° and large angles described as >90°

  2. most of the atom is empty space/nucleus very small compared with atom
    mass and charge concentrated in (very small) nucleus
    correct links made with statements in (a)
  1. Many answers involved α-particles having no deviation, rather than small deviations. It is important that candidates realise that the great majority were subject to small deviations of less than 10° and that very few had deviations greater than 90°. A reference to the relative numbers and to the sizes of the angles was expected. 
  2. A common statement was that the nucleus has a large mass. This is insufficient. It should be stated that the mass of the atom is concentrated in the charged nucleus. Likewise, stating that the nucleus is small has little meaning until a comparison is made with the size of the atom. Few candidates linked the observations in (a) with the conclusions in (b).

  1. W = 1 and X = 0
    Y = 2
    Z = 55
  2. explanation in terms of mass – energy conservation
    energy released as gamma or photons or kinetic energy of products or em radiation

A significant number of candidates scored full credit in (a) but very few were able to give good answers in part (b).

  1. The majority of candidates were able to obtain some credit. A significant number were unable to give the correct values for the neutron and so lost credit here.
  2. The link with the conservation of mass-energy was described by only a very small number of candidates.
NO. 78题号：34299
  1. The spontaneous decay of polonium is shown by the nuclear equation

      1. .....................................................................................

Q7/9702/21/M/J/12

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_1/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i 2 protons and 2 neutrons B1 [1]
a.ii e.g. positively charged 2e
 mass 4u
 constant energy
 absorbed by thin paper or few cm of air (3cm → 8cm)
 (not low penetration)
 highly ionizing
 deflected in electric/magnetic fields
 (One mark for each property, max 2)		 B2 [2]
b mass-energy is conserved
difference in mass 'changed' into a form of energy
energy in the form of kinetic energy of the products / γ-radiation
photons / e.m. radiation		 B1
B1

B1		 [3]
    1. 2 protons and 2 neutrons
    2. e.g. positively charged 2e
      mass 4u
      constant energy
      absorbed by thin paper or few cm of air (3cm → 8cm)
      (not low penetration)
      highly ionizing
      deflected in electric/magnetic fields
      (One mark for each property, max 2)
  2. mass-energy is conserved
    difference in mass ‘changed’ into a form of energy
    energy in the form of kinetic energy of the products / γ-radiation photons / e.m. radiation
    1. X was frequently identified as being an α-particle, without any reference given to either the number of protons or the number of neutrons.
    2. Where full credit was not awarded in this section, it was, in general, as a result of insufficient detail, for example 'positively charged', 'large mass', or 'low penetrating power'.
  2. This part was not understood by many candidates. Very few mentioned mass-energy conservation. Common answers were based on the idea of 'energy being conserved and thus energy being released as heat'. It was expected that candidates would appreciate that the mass difference would be seen as kinetic energy of products and/or energy of emitted photons.
NO. 79题号：34298

One property of α-particles is that they produce a high density of ionisation of air at atmospheric pressure. In this ionisation process, a neutral atom becomes an ion pair. The ion pair is a positively-charged particle and an electron.

  1. State
    1. what is meant by an α-particle, 
      ........................................................................... [1]
    2. an approximate value for the range of α-particles in air at atmospheric pressure.

      range = ........................................... cm [1]
  2. The energy required to produce an ion pair in air at atmospheric pressure is 31 eV.
    An α-particle has an initial kinetic energy of 8.5 × 10–13 J.
    1. Show that 8.5 × 10–13 J is equivalent to 5.3 MeV. [1]

    2. Calculate, to two significant figures, the number of ion pairs produced as the α-particle is stopped in air at atmospheric pressure.

      number = ................................................. [2]
    3. Using your answer in (a)(ii), estimate the average number of ion pairs produced per unit length of the track of the α-particle as it is brought to rest in air.

      number per unit length = ........................................ [2]

Q7/9702/23/M/J/10

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper2_3/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i either  helium nucleus
or  particle containing two protons and two neutrons		 B1 [1]
a.ii allow any value between 1cm and 10cm  B1 [1]
b.i energy = (8.5 × 10–13)/(1.6 × 10–13)
= 5.3MeV		 M1
A0		 [1]
b.ii number = (5.3 × 106)/31
= 1.7 × 105 (allow 2 s.f. only)		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.iii number per unit length = (1.7 × 105) /(a)(ii)
correct numerical value
correct unit
A1
B1		 [2]
    1. either helium nucleus
      or particle containing two protons and two neutrons
    2. allow any value between 1cm and 10cm
    1. energy = (8.5 × 10–13)/(1.6 × 10–13) = 5.3 MeV
    2. number = (5.3 × 106)/31
      = 1.7 × 105 (allow 2 s.f. only)
    3. number per unit length = (1.7 × 105) /any value between 0.01 to 0.10
      correct numerical value
      correct unit

A significant minority left some or all parts of (b) blank.

    1. The majority of candidates answered this part correctly. A minority referred to a helium atom and did not score this mark.
    2. A minority of candidates gave distances smaller than the size of an atom. However, the majority gave answers within the accepted range.  
    1. The MeV unit for energy appeared to confuse a number of candidates. This unit is specifically mentioned in section 3.4 of the syllabus 'Additional Information' and should be familiar to candidates at this level. However, the value in SI units was also given and better candidates were able to see the link.
    2. Candidates did not have to complete (b)(i) to be able to complete the next two parts. The good candidates continued to complete the calculation and very few failed to read the need to give the answer to two significant figures. 
    3. Those candidates who completed this part often failed to give an appropriate unit in their answer and lost a mark. Only very good candidates were able to score highly on this part.
NO. 80题号：34297
  1. The radioactive decay of some nuclei gives rise to the emission of α-particles. State
    1. what is meant by an α-particle,
      .......................................................................[1]
    2. two properties of α-particles.
      1. ..........................................................................
      2. .......................................................................... [2]
  2. One possible nuclear reaction involves the bombardment of a stationary nitrogen-14 nucleus by an a-particle to form oxygen-17 and another particle.
    1. Complete the nuclear equation for this reaction. [2]
         
    2. The total mass-energy of the nitrogen-14 nucleus and the α-particle is less than that of the particles resulting from the reaction. This mass-energy difference is 1.1 MeV.
      1. Suggest how it is possible for mass-energy to be conserved in this reaction.
        .................................................................[1]
      2. Calculate the speed of an α-particle having kinetic energy of 1.1 MeV.

        speed = ....................................... m s–1 [4]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper2_2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i either  helium nucleus
or  contains 2 protons and 2 neutrons		 B1 [1]
a.ii e.g. range is a few cm in air/sheet of thin paper
speed up to 0.1 c
causes dense ionisation in air
positively charged or deflected in magnetic or electric fields
(any two, 1 each to max 2)		 B2 [2]
b.i 42α B1 [2]
either  11p or 11H B1
b.ii 1. initially, α-particle must have some kinetic energy B1 [1]
2. 1.1 MeV = 1.1 × 1.6 × 10–13 = 1.76 × 10–13 J
EK = ½mv2
1.76 × 10–13 = ½ × 4 × 1.66 × 10–27 × v2
v = 7.3 × 106 m s–1
use of 1.67 × 10–27 kg for mass is a maximum of 3/4		 C1
C1
C1
A1

 [4]
    1. either  helium nucleus
      or   contains 2 protons and 2 neutrons
    2. e.g. range is a few cm in air/sheet of thin paper
      speed up to 0.1 c
      causes dense ionisation in air
      positively charged or deflected in magnetic or electric fields
      (any two, 1 each to max 2)
    1. 42α
      either 11p or 11H
    2. 1. initially, α-particle must have some kinetic energy
      2. 1.1 MeV = 1.1 × 1.6 × 10–13 = 1.76 × 10–13 J
          EK = ½mv2
          1.76 × 10–13 = ½ × 4 × 1.66 × 10–27 × v2
          v = 7.3 × 106 m s–1
          use of 1.67 × 10–27 kg for mass is a maximum of 3/4

The majority of candidates were able to score almost full marks for (a) and (b)(i). Very few candidates scored full marks for the remaining parts of the question.

    1. The majority of candidates gave the correct response. Only a small minority referred to a helium atom or particle and lost the mark.
    2. The majority of candidates gave two properties. Vague answers that did not score the marks were the 'least penetrating' or the 'most ionising'.
    1. The equation was generally completed correctly. The lack of knowledge of a symbol for the proton caused the weaker candidates to lose the second mark. 
    2. 1. The majority of candidates were unable to give a satisfactory answer. 
      2. The conversion of MeV into J was ignored by all but the very good candidates. The use of eV in examination papers is referred to in the 'Additional Information' section 3.4 of the syllabus. The mass of the α-particle was also incorrectly given by most candidates. Very few candidates obtained a correct value for the speed of the α-particle.
NO. 81题号：34295

The spontaneous and random decay of a radioactive substance involves the emission of either α-radiation or β-radiation and/or γ-radiation.

  1. Explain what is meant by spontaneous decay.
    .......................................................................... [2]
  2. State the type of emission, one in each case, that
    1. is not affected by electric and magnetic fields,
      ................................................................. [1]
    2. produces the greatest density of ionisation in a medium,
      ................................................................. [1]
    3. does not directly result in a change in the proton number of the nucleus,
      ................................................................. [1]
    4. has a range of energies, rather than discrete values.
      ................................................................. [1]

Q8/9702/21/M/J/09

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Summer/Paper2_1/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a rate of decay / activity / decay (of nucleus) is not affected by external factors / environment / surroundings
 (If states specific factor(s), rather than giving general statement above, then give 2 marks for two stated factors, but 1 mark only if one factor stated) 		 B2 [2]
b.i gamma / γ B1 [1]
b.ii alpha / α B1 [1]
b.iii gamma / γ B1 [1]
b.iv beta / β B1 [1]
  1. rate of decay / activity / decay (of nucleus) is not affected by external factors / environment / surroundings
    (If states specific factor(s), rather than giving general statement above, then give 2 marks for two stated factors, but 1 mark only if one factor stated)
    1. gamma / γ
    2. alpha / α
    3. gamma / γ
    4. beta / β
  1. The majority of answers included a reference to external factors. Some candidates either confused spontaneity and randomness or described both without making clear which answer was relevant to spontaneity.
  2. In general, parts (i), (ii) and (iii) were answered correctly. Very few identified the range of
    energies with β-particles. The most common incorrect answer was γ-rays. 
NO. 82题号：34294

Uranium-236 (23692U) and Uranium-237 (23792U) are both radioactive.
Uranium-236 is an α-emitter and Uranium-237 is a β-emitter.

  1. Distinguish between an α-particle and a β-particle.
    ....................................................................................[4]
  2. The grid of Fig. 7.1 shows some proton numbers Z on the x-axis and the number N of neutrons in the nucleus on the y-axis.

    The α-decay of Uranium-236 (23692U) is represented on the grid. This decay produces a nucleus of thorium (Th).
    1. Write down the nuclear equation for this α-decay.
      ..................................................................................[2]
    2. On Fig. 7.1, mark the position for a nucleus of
      1. Uranium-237 (mark this position with the letter U),
      2. Neptunium, the nucleus produced by the β-decay of Uranium-237 (mark this position with the letters Np).
      [2]

Q7/9702/02/M/J/08

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2008/Summer/Paper2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a α-particle: either  helium nucleus or  contains 2 protons + 2 neutrons or  42He B1 [4]
β-particle: either  electron or  0−1e B1
α speed < β speed (1)
α discrete values of speed/energy, β continuous spectrum (1)
either  α ionising power >> β ionising power
or  α range << β range (1)
α positive, β negative (only if first two B marks not scored) (1)
α mass > β mass (only if first two B marks not scored) (1)
(any two sensible pairs of statements relevant to differences, – do not allow statements relevant to only α or β, 1 each, max 2)		 B2
b.i M1
A1		 [2]
b.ii 1. correct position for U at Z = 92, N = 145
2. correct position for Np relative to U i.e. Z + 1 and N – 1		 B1
B1		 [2]
  1. α-particle: either  helium nucleus   or   contains 2 protons + 2 neutrons   or 42He
    β-particle: either   electron   or 0−1e
    α speed < β speed
    α discrete values of speed/energy, β continuous spectrum
    either   α ionising power >> β ionising power
    or   α range << β range
    α positive, β negative (only if first two B marks not scored)
    α mass > β mass (only if first two B marks not scored)
    (any two sensible pairs of statements relevant to differences, – do not allow statements relevant to only α or β, 1 each, max 2)
    1. 23692U  →  23290Th  + 42He
    2. 1. correct position for U at Z = 92, N = 145
      2. correct position for Np relative to U i.e. Z + 1 and N – 1
  1. Most candidates attempted to relate α- and β-particles to helium nuclei and electrons respectively. However, many stated that an α-particle is a helium atom. Others thought that α- / β-particles are emitted by helium nuclei / electrons. Many candidates compared properties such as speed, range and ionising power. However, such comparisons frequently either lacked sufficient detail or were inaccurate so that credit could not be given.
    1. Most candidates correctly gave the required equation. The most common error was the representation of the α-particle with some symbol other than that of a helium nucleus.
    2. Most candidates did show the correct position on the grid for uranium-237. Comparatively few positioned the neptunium nucleus to show that β-decay resulted in an increase by one in the proton number and a corresponding decrease in the neutron number. 
NO. 83题号：34291

Fig. 8.1 shows the position of Neptunium-231 (23193Np) on a diagram in which nucleon number (mass number) A is plotted against proton number (atomic number) Z.

  1. Neptunium-231 decays by the emission of an α-particle to form protactinium.
    On Fig. 8.1, mark with the symbol Pa the position of the isotope of protactinium produced in this decay. [1]
  2. Plutonium-243 (24394Pu) decays by the emission of a β-particle (an electron).
    On Fig. 8.1, show this decay by labelling the position of Plutonium-243 as Pu and the position of the daughter product as D. [2]

Q8/9702/02/M/J/05

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2005/Summer/Paper2/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a position shown as A = 227, Z = 91 B1 [1]
b Pu shown as A = 243, Z = 94
D shown with A = APu and with Z = (ZPu + 1) 		 B1
B1		 [2]
  1. position shown as A = 227, Z = 91
  2. Pu shown as A = 243, Z = 94
    D shown with A = APu and with Z = (ZPu + 1)
  1. Few candidates failed to plot correctly the position for the isotope of protactinium.
  2. The values of A and Z were given and consequently, almost all candidates who attempted this task did plot the position correctly. It was realised that the daughter product of plutonium would have the same value for A. However, opinion was divided as to whether Z should be 93 or 95.  
NO. 84题号：34282
  1. Two horizontal metal plates are connected to a power supply, as shown in Fig. 7.1.

    The separation of the plates is 40 mm.
    The switch S is then closed so that a potential difference of 1.2kV is applied across the plates.
    1. On Fig. 7.1, draw six field lines to represent the electric field between the metal plates.  [2]

    2. Calculate the electric field strength E between the plates.

      E = ...................................... V m–1 [2]
  2. The switch S is opened and the plates lose their charge. Two very small metal spheres A and B joined by an insulating rod are placed between the metal plates as shown in Fig. 7.2.

    Sphere A has charge –e and sphere B has charge +e, where e is the charge of a proton.
    The length AB is 15mm. The rod is supported at its centre C so that the rod is horizontal and in equilibrium.
    The switch S is then closed so that the potential difference of 1.2kV is applied across the plates.
    1. There is a force acting on A due to the electric field between the plates.
      Show that this force is 4.8 × 10–15N. [2]

    2. The insulating rod joining A and B is fixed in the position shown in Fig. 7.2.
      Calculate the torque of the couple acting on the rod.

      torque = ........................ unit .................. [3]
    3. The insulating rod is now released so that it is free to rotate about C.
      State and explain the position of the rod when it comes to rest.
      .................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Winter/Paper1_2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i six vertical lines from plate to plate equally spaced across plates B1 [2]
[only allow if greatest to least spacing is < 1.3, condone slight curving on the two edges. There must be no area between the plates where an additional line(s) could be added.]
arrow downwards on at least one line		 B1
a.ii E = V / d
 = 1200 / 40 × 10–3 = 3.0 × 104 V m–1 (allow 1 s.f.)		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.i F = Ee
 = 3 × 104 × 1.6 × 10–19 = 4.8 × 10–15 N		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii couple = F × separation of charges
  = 4.8 × 10–15 × 15 × 10–3 = 7.2 × 10–17
unit: N m or unit consistent with unit used for the separation		 C1
A1
B1		 [3]
b.iii A at top/next to +ve plate B at bottom/next to −ve plate vertically aligned
[could be shown on the diagram]
forces are equal and opposite in same line / no resultant force and no resultant torque		 M1

A1		 [2]
    1. six vertical lines from plate to plate equally spaced across plates
      [only allow if greatest to least spacing is < 1.3, condone slight curving on the two edges. There must be no area between the plates where an additional line(s) could be added.]
      arrow downwards on at least one line
    2. E = V / d = 1200 / 40 × 10–3 = 3.0 × 104 V m–1 (allow 1 s.f.)
    1. F = Ee = 3 × 104 × 1.6 × 10–19 = 4.8 × 10–15 N
    2. couple = F × separation of charges
                = 4.8 × 10–15 × 15 × 10–3 = 7.2 × 10–17
      unit: N m or unit consistent with unit used for the separation
    3. A at top/next to +ve plate B at bottom/next to −ve plate vertically aligned
      [could be shown on the diagram]
      forces are equal and opposite in same line / no resultant force and no resultant torque
    1. When completing such drawings, it is expected that reasonable care will be taken to ensure a true representation. In this situation, many lost credit because the lines were not equally spaced (judged 'by eye') or did not extend over the full region between the plates. 
    2. This was completed successfully by most candidates. 
    1. The answer was given and, consequently, very few candidates failed to arrive at the correct answer. 
    2. Most answers, and the unit, were correct. A minority confused the moment of one force with the torque of the couple. 
    3. This part of the question expected a statement and explanation. There were very few attempts at an explanation in terms of there being no resultant force and no resultant couple. Although the great majority of answers made reference to the end A moving upwards and the end B moving downwards, there were comparatively few clear statements that the rod would come to rest either 'vertical' or, more correctly, parallel to the electric field. 
NO. 85题号：34281

A battery connected in series with a resistor R of resistance 5.0 Ω is shown in Fig. 6.1.

The electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the battery is 9.0V and the internal resistance is r.
The potential difference (p.d.) across the battery terminals is 6.9V.

  1. Use energy considerations to explain why the p.d. across the battery is not equal to the e.m.f. of the battery.
    .................................................................... [2]
  2. Calculate
    1. the current in the circuit,

      current = ......................................... A [2]
    2. the internal resistance r.

      r = ............................................. Ω  [2]
  3. Calculate, for the battery in the circuit,
    1. the total power produced,

      power = ............................................ W [2]
    2. the efficiency.

      efficiency = ........................................ [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Winter/Paper2_3/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a e.m.f. = total energy available (per unit charge)
some (of the available energy) is used/lost/wasted/given out in the internal
resistance of the battery (hence p.d. available less than e.m.f.)		 B1

B1		 [2]
b.i V = IR
I = 6.9 / 5.0 = 1.4 (1.38) A		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii r = lost volts / current
  = (9– 6.9) / 1.38 = 1.5(2) Ω		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.i P = EI (not P = VI if only this line given or 9 V not used in second line)
   = 9 × 1.38 = 12 (12.4) W		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.ii efficiency = output power / total power
 = VI / EI = 6.9 / 9 or (9.52) / (12.4) = 0.767 / 76.7%		 C1
A1		 [2]
  1. e.m.f. = total energy available (per unit charge)
    some (of the available energy) is used/lost/wasted/given out in the internal resistance of the battery (hence p.d. available less than e.m.f.)
    1. V = IR
      I = 6.9 / 5.0 = 1.4 (1.38) A
    2. r = lost volts / current
      = (9– 6.9) / 1.38 = 1.5(2) Ω
    1. P = EI (not P = VI if only this line given or 9 V not used in second line)
         = 9 × 1.38 = 12 (12.4) W
    2. efficiency = output power / total power
      = VI / EI = 6.9 / 9 or (9.52) / (12.4) = 0.767 / 76.7%
  1. In most answers, there was a satisfactory statement as regards energy losses in the internal resistance. Candidates should be encouraged not to refer to the energy 'overcoming' the internal resistance. 
    Very few answers included a satisfactory reference to the e.m.f. of the battery. It was expected that e.m.f. would be considered in terms of the total energy available (per unit charge). 
    1. This was completed successfully by the majority of candidates.
    2. In a significant number of answers, there was no appreciation of lost volts. Successful candidates either calculated the lost volts or they applied Ohm's law to the complete circuit. 
    1. In general, a relevant expression for power was quoted. However, where this expression was given as P = VI, many substituted the terminal p.d. rather than the e.m.f. of the battery.
    2. Most candidates did not use answers from previous calculations but, rather, they started afresh. The majority arrived at the correct conclusion.  
NO. 86题号：34279

A circuit used to measure the power transfer from a battery is shown in Fig. 4.1. The power is transferred to a variable resistor of resistance R.

The battery has an electromotive force (e.m.f.) E and an internal resistance r. There is a potential difference (p.d.) V across R. The current in the circuit is І.

  1. By reference to the circuit shown in Fig. 4.1, distinguish between the definitions of e.m.f. and p.d.
    ........................................................................ [3]
  2. Using Kirchhoff's second law, determine an expression for the current І in the circuit. [1]

  3. The variation with current І of the p.d. V across R is shown in Fig. 4.2.

    Use Fig. 4.2 to determine
    1. the e.m.f. E,

      E = ............................................ V [1]
    2. the internal resistance r.

      r = ............................................ Ω [2]
    1. Using data from Fig. 4.2, calculate the power transferred to R for a current of 1.6 A.

      power = ........................................... W [2]
    2. Use your answers from (c)(i) and (d)(i) to calculate the efficiency of the battery for a current of 1.6 A.

      efficiency = ........................................... % [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper2_3/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a e.m.f. = chemical energy to electrical energy
p.d. = electrical energy to thermal energy
idea of per unit charge		 M1
M1
A1		 [3]
b E = I (R +r) or I = E / (R +r)  (any subject) B1 [1]
c.i E = 5.8V  B1 [1]
c.ii evidence of gradient calculation or calculation with values from graph
e.g. 5.8 = 4 + 1.0 × r 
r = 1.8Ω
C1
A1		 [2]
d.i P = VI
P = 2.9 × 1.6 = 4.6 (4.64)W		 C1
A1		 [2]
d.ii power from battery = 1.6 × 5.8 = 9.28 or efficiency = VI / EI
efficiency = (4.64 / 9.28) × 100 = 50 % or (2.9 / 5.8) × 100 = 50%		 C1
A1		 [2]
  1. e.m.f. = chemical energy to electrical energy
    p.d. = electrical energy to thermal energy
    idea of per unit charge
  2. E = I (R +r) or I = E / (R +r)   (any subject)
    1. E = 5.8 V
    2. evidence of gradient calculation or calculation with values from graph
      e.g. 5.8 = 4 + 1.0 × r
      r = 1.8 Ω
    1. P = VI
      P = 2.9 × 1.6 = 4.6 (4.64) W
    2. power from battery = 1.6 × 5.8 = 9.28 or efficiency = VI / EI
      efficiency = (4.64 / 9.28) × 100 = 50 % or (2.9 / 5.8) × 100 = 50%
  1. Many statements were based on general statements as regards e.m.f. and potential difference. Consequently, there were many references to 'other forms of energy', rather than energy changes relevant to the given circuit.  
  2. Answers to this part were generally satisfactory. It was not necessary for current to be the subject of the equation. 
    1. There were numerous instances where the e.m.f. was given as 6.0V, rather than 5.8V. 
    2. A minority of candidates confused the external resistance with the internal resistance. The majority did, however, use the graph correctly to determine the internal resistance. 
    1. This calculation was completed successfully by most candidates.
    2. The number of correct responses was in a minority. The usual mistake was to divide the answer in (d)(i) by that in (b)(i). This is clearly incorrect and should have been recognised as such. A pure number cannot be provided by dividing a power by an e.m.f. 
NO. 87题号：34277
  1. Define electrical resistance.
    ..................................................................... [1]
  2. A circuit is set up to measure the resistance R of a metal wire. The potential difference (p.d.) V across the wire and the current І in the wire are to be measured.
    1. Draw a circuit diagram of the apparatus that could be used to make these measurements. [3]

    2. Readings for p.d. V and the corresponding current І are obtained. These are shown in Fig. 2.1.

      Explain how Fig. 2.1 indicates that the readings are subject to
      1. a systematic uncertainty,
         ............................................................. [1]
      2. random uncertainties.
         ............................................................. [1]
    3. Use data from Fig. 2.1 to determine R. Explain your working.

      R = ............................................. Ω [3]
  3. In another experiment, a value of R is determined from the following data:
    Current І = 0.64 ± 0.01 A and p.d. V = 6.8 ± 0.1 V.
    Calculate the value of R, together with its uncertainty. Give your answer to an appropriate number of significant figures.

    R = ..................... ± .................... Ω [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper2_1/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a resistance = potential difference / current B1 [1]
b.i metal wire in series with power supply and ammeter
voltmeter in parallel with metal wire
rheostat in series with power supply or potential divider arrangement 
or variable power supply		 B1
B1

B1		 [3]
b.ii 1. intercept on graph B1 [1]
2. scatter of readings about the best fit line B1 [1]
b.iii correction for zero error explained
use of V and corrected І values from graph
resistance = V / І = 22.(2)Ω [e.g. 4.0 / 0.18]		 B1
C1
A1		 [3]
c R = 6.8 / 0.64 = 10.625
%R = %V + %І
 = (0.1 / 6.8) × 100 + (0.01 / 0.64) × 100
 = 1.47% + 1.56%
∆R = 0.0303 × 10.625 = 0.32Ω
R = 10.6 ± 0.3 Ω		 C1


C1

A1		 [3]
  1. resistance = potential difference / current
    1. metal wire in series with power supply and ammeter
      voltmeter in parallel with metal wire
      rheostat in series with power supply or potential divider arrangement or variable power supply
    2. 1. intercept on graph
      2. scatter of readings about the best fit line
    3. correction for zero error explained
      use of V and corrected І values from graph
      resistance = V/ І = 22.(2)Ω [e.g. 4.0 / 0.18]
  3. R = 6.8 / 0.64 = 10.625
    %R = %V + %І
        = (0.1 / 6.8) × 100 + (0.01 / 0.64) × 100
        = 1.47% + 1.56%
    ∆R = 0.0303 × 10.625 = 0.32Ω
    R = 10.6 ± 0.3 Ω
  1. The definition of resistance was given by a small minority of candidates. 
    1. The circuit diagrams were generally of poor quality. Many had no meters or the voltmeter was placed in series with an ammeter. There were very few circuits that included any means of varying the current in the circuit such as a rheostat.
    2. A very small minority were able to distinguish between systematic and random uncertainties.
    3. Very few candidates realised that the graph showed a systematic uncertainty in the ammeter readings and hence they did not make a correct calculation of the resistance. 
  3. The correct value for the resistance was calculated by a significant number of candidates. The calculation of the uncertainty in R was not calculated correctly by the vast majority. A very small number were able to state the value for R with a correct number of significant figures determined by the uncertainty value.
NO. 88题号：34276
  1. Distinguish between potential difference (p.d.) and electromotive force (e.m.f.) in terms of energy transformations.
    ........................................................................[2]
  2. Two cells A and B are connected in series with a resistor R of resistance 5.5 Ω, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

    Cell A has e.m.f. 4.4 V and internal resistance 2.3 Ω. Cell B has e.m.f. 2.1 V and internal resistance 1.8 Ω.
    1. State Kirchhoff's second law.
      ................................................................ [1]
    2. Calculate the current in the circuit. 

      current = ............................................. A [2]
    3. On Fig. 4.1, draw an arrow to show the direction of the current in the circuit. Label this arrow I. [1]

    4. Calculate
      1. the p.d. across resistor R,

         p.d. = ............................................. V [1]
      2. the terminal p.d. across cell A,

         p.d. = ............................................. V [1]
      3. the terminal p.d. across cell B.

         p.d. = ............................................. V [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper2_3/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a B1 [2]
B1
b.i sum of e.m.f.s (in a closed circuit) = sum of potential differences B1 [1]
b.ii 4.4 – 2.1 = I × (1.8 + 5.5 + 2.3)
I = 0.24 A		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.iii arrow (labelled) I shown anticlockwise A1 [1]
b.iv 1. V = I × R = 0.24 × 5.5 = 1.3(2)V A1 [1]
2. VA = 4.4 – (I × 2.3) = 3.8(5)V A1 [1]
3. either VB = 2.1 + (I × 1.8) or  VB = 3.8 – 1.3
    = 2.5(3)V		 C1
A1		 [2]
  1. p.d. = energy transformed from electrical to other forms / unit charge
    e.m.f. = energy transformed from other forms to electrica / unit charge
    1. sum of e.m.f.s (in a closed circuit) = sum of potential differences
    2. 4.4 – 2.1 = I × (1.8 + 5.5 + 2.3)
      I = 0.24 A
    3. arrow (labelled) I shown anticlockwise
    4. 1. V = I × R = 0.24 × 5.5 = 1.3(2)V
      2. VA = 4.4 – (I × 2.3) = 3.8(5)V
      3. either VB = 2.1 + (I × 1.8) or VB = 3.8 – 1.3
          = 2.5(3) V
  1. Most statements were satisfactory with reference being made to 'other forms of energy'. Candidates should be advised not to make specific reference to 'chemical energy' when referring to e.m.f. or to 'thermal energy' for potential difference.
    1. Answers here were generally satisfactory although there was some confusion with Kirchhoff's first law. 
    2. In many answers, the sum of the e.m.f.s was calculated, rather than the difference.
    3. Some candidates did not answer this part of the question, perhaps because they missed it unintentionally. Candidates should be advised to read the question paper carefully.
    4. In general, part 1 was answered correctly when allowance was made for the candidate's value of current. Many answers in parts 2 and 3 were incorrect. In most of these cases, the e.m.f. was not included and each response involved solely the product of current and an internal resistance. 
NO. 89题号：34273
  1. Define the ohm.
    ................................................................ [1]
  2. Determine the SI base units of resistivity. 

    base units of resistivity = ........................................... [3]
  3. A cell of e.m.f. 2.0 V and negligible internal resistance is connected to a variable resistor R and a metal wire, as shown in Fig. 5.1.
               
    The wire is 900 mm long and has an area of cross-section of 1.3×10–7 m2. The resistance of the wire is 3.4 Ω.
    1. Calculate the resistivity of the metal wire. 

      resistivity = ................................................. [2]
    2. The resistance of R may be varied between 0 and 1500 Ω.
      Calculate the maximum potential difference (p.d.) and minimum p.d. possible across the wire.

      maximum p.d. = ............................................ V
      minimum p.d. = .............................................. V [2]
    3. Calculate the power transformed in the wire when the potential difference across the wire is 2.0 V.

      power = ............................................. W [2]
  4. Resistance R in (c) is now replaced with a different variable resistor Q. State the power transformed in Q, for Q having
    1. zero resistance,

      power = ............................................. W [1]
    2. infinite resistance.

      power = ............................................. W [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper2_1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a ohm = volt / ampere B1 [1]
b ρ = RA / l or unit is Ωm
units: VA–1m2m–1 = NmC–1A–1m2m–1
          = kgm2 s–2A–1 s–1A–1m2m–1
          = kgm3 s–3A–2		 C1
C1

A1		 [3]
c.i ρ = [3.4 × 1.3 × 10–7] / 0.9
   = 4.9 × 10–7 (Ωm)		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.ii max = 2.(0) V
min = 2 × (3.4 /1503.4) = 4.5 × 10–3 V		 A1
A1		 [2]
c.iii P = V2 / R or P = VI and V = IR 
  = (2)2 / 3.4
  = 1.18 (allow 1.2) W		 C1

A1		 [2]
d.i power in Q is zero when R = 0 B1 [1]
d.ii power in Q = 0 / tends to zero as R = infinity B1 [1]
  1. ohm = volt / ampere
  2. ρ = RA / l or unit is Ωm
    units: VA–1m2m–1 = NmC–1A–1m2m–1
    = kgm2 s–2A–1 s–1A–1m2m–1
    = kgm3 s–3A–2
    1. ρ = [3.4 × 1.3 × 10–7] / 0.9 = 4.9 × 10–7 (Ωm) 
    2. max = 2.(0) V
      min = 2 × (3.4 /1503.4) = 4.5 × 10–3 V
    3. P = V2 / R  or  P = VI  and  V = IR
      = (2)2 / 3.4
      = 1.18 (allow 1.2) W
    1. power in Q is zero when R = 0
    2. power in Q = 0 / tends to zero as R = infinity
  1. Many candidates were not able to give an acceptable definition.
  2. Candidates generally gained at least partial credit for giving the defining equation for resistivity or its units.
    1. A significant number of candidates obtained the correct answer. 
    2. The majority of candidates were unable to interpret the series circuit and obtain the correct distribution of the potential difference across the two resistances. 
    3. Well prepared candidates calculated the correct answer.
    1. There were a number of correct answers. Application of a formula caused problems for some candidates. 
    2. Very few candidates were able to give the correct answer. Candidates did not appear to realise the effect on the circuit of adding a resistance with a very large value.
NO. 90题号：34272

An electric heater has a constant resistance and is rated as 1.20kW, 230V.

The heater is connected to a 230V supply by means of a cable that is 9.20m long, as illustrated in Fig. 8.1.

The two copper wires that make up the cable each have a circular cross-section of diameter 0.900 mm. The resistivity of copper is 1.70×10–8 Ω m.

  1. Show that
    1. the resistance of the heater is 44.1 Ω, [2]

    2. the total resistance of the cable is 0.492 Ω. [2]

  2. The current in the cable and heater is switched on. Determine, to three significant figures, the power dissipated in the heater.

    power = .......................................... W [3]
  3. Suggest two disadvantages of connecting the heater to the 230 V supply using a cable consisting of two thinner copper wires.
    1. ........................................................................
    2. ........................................................................ [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper2_3/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a.i either P = V2 / R  or  I = 1200 / 230 or 5.22
                                R = (230 × 230) / 1200
R = 2302 / 1200 or R = 230 / 5.22
   = 44.1Ω                  = 44.1Ω		 C1

M1
A0		 [2]
a.ii R = ρL / A
   = (1.7 × 10–8 × 9.2 × 2) / (π × {0.45 × 10–3}2)
   = 0.492Ω		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
b current = 230 /44.6
power = (230 /44.6)2 × 44.1
           = 1170W
(allow full credit for solution based on potential divider)		 C1
C1
A1

 [3]
c e.g. less power dissipated in the heater / smaller p.d. across heater / more power loss in cable / current lower
cable becomes heated / melts
(any two sensible suggestions, 1 each, max 2) 		 B1
B1		 [2]
    1. either P = V2/ R
           R = 2302/ 1200 = 44.1Ω
      or I = 1200 / 230 or 5.22
          R = (230 × 230) / 1200
          R = 230 / 5.22 = 44.1 Ω
    2. R = ρL / A
         = (1.7 × 10–8 × 9.2 × 2) / (π × {0.45 × 10–3}2)
         = 0.492 Ω
  2. current = 230 /44.6
    power = (230 /44.6)2 × 44.1 = 1170 W
    (allow full credit for solution based on potential divider)
  3. e.g. less power dissipated in the heater / smaller p.d. across heater / more power loss in cable / current lower
    cable becomes heated / melts
    (any two sensible suggestions, 1 each, max 2)
    1. This task was completed successfully by most candidates and adequate explanation was given. 
    2. The formula for resistivity was given correctly in most scripts. Where candidates are asked to derive a given numerical answer then they should give a clear explanation. In this instance, a factor of 2 appeared all too frequently without any explanation in order to arrive at the given answer. 
  2. This calculation proved to be difficult for most candidates. A correct approach was to calculate the current using the combined resistance of the heater and the cable. Then the power of the heater could be found using the resistance of the heater. Very frequently, the total power dissipated in the heater and the cable was determined.
  3. There were many incomplete answers. Candidates should be advised to state carefully where any additional power is dissipated when two or more components are involved.
NO. 91题号：34270

The variation with temperature of the resistance RT of a thermistor is shown in Fig. 6.1.

The thermistor is connected into the circuit of Fig. 6.2.

The battery has e.m.f. 9.0V and negligible internal resistance. The voltmeter has infinite resistance.

  1. For the thermistor at 22.5 ℃, calculate
    1. the total resistance between points A and B on Fig. 6.2,

      resistance = ......................................... Ω [2]
    2. the reading on the voltmeter.

      voltmeter reading = ...........................V [2]
  2. The temperature of the thermistor is changed. The voltmeter now reads 4.0V.
    Determine
    1. the total resistance between points A and B on Fig. 6.2,

      resistance = ......................................... Ω [2]
    2. the temperature of the thermistor.

      temperature = ......................................°C [2]
  3. A student suggests that the voltmeter, reading up to 10 V, could be calibrated to measure temperature.
    Suggest two disadvantages of using the circuit of Fig. 6.2 with this voltmeter for the measurement of temperature in the range 0 ℃ to 25℃.
    1. ..........................................................................
    2. .......................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper2_2/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i at 22.5 °C, RT = 1600Ω or 1.6kΩ
total resistance = 800Ω		 C1
A1		 [2]
a.ii either use of potential divider formula  or current = 9 / 2000 (4.5mA)
V = (0.8/2.0) × 9  or  V = (9/2000) × 800
   = 3.6V                       = 3.6V		 C1

A1		 [2]
b.i total resistance = 4/5 × 1200
= 960 Ω		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii for parallel combination, 1/960 = 1/1600 + 1/RT
RT = 2400Ω / 2.4kΩ
temperature = 11°C
C1
A1		 [2]
c e.g. only small part of scale used / small sensitivity
       non-linear
(any two sensible suggestions, 1 each, max 2)		 B1
B1

 [2]
    1. at 22.5 °C, RT = 1600 Ω or 1.6 kΩ
      total resistance = 800 Ω
    2. either use of potential divider formula
      V = (0.8/2.0) × 9
         = 3.6 V
      or current = 9 / 2000 (4.5 mA)
          V = (9/2000) × 800
             = 3.6 V
    1. total resistance = 4/5 × 1200 = 960 Ω
    2. for parallel combination, 1/960 = 1/1600 + 1/RT
      RT = 2400 Ω / 2.4 kΩ
      temperature = 11 °C
  3. e.g. only small part of scale used / small sensitivity
    non-linear
    (any two sensible suggestions, 1 each, max 2)

Candidates should be advised to read the questions carefully. In this question this applies to the circuit diagram as well as the text. 

    1. Many of the more able candidates calculated the resistance between the points A and B correctly. There were some candidates who then went on to calculate the total resistance of the circuit. This was not asked for. 
    2. Many candidates seemed to be unaware that the calculation of the total resistance between A and B had simplified the circuit. The calculation of the potential difference across AB should have been straightforward using the potential divider formula or by calculating the circuit current first. Candidates used incorrect combinations of resistance, potential difference and current as well as mixing resistance values in Ω and kΩ. A common error was to consider the 9 V from the supply to be across the 1200 Ω resistor. 
    1. The more able candidates calculated the correct answer. A few candidates went on to calculate the resistance of the thermistor and gave this as their answer. Such candidates need to be advised to read the question carefully. A common error was to use the current calculated in (a)(ii). The candidates who followed this method had not read the question that stated the temperature of the thermistor had changed and hence so had the resistance in the circuit and therefore the current. The more able candidates were able to recover from this error and obtained full credit in (b)(ii) with error carried forward being applied. 
    2. A minority of candidates obtained a correct answer. A significant number of candidates assumed that the total resistance between points A and B has a linear relationship with temperature.
  3. There were very few correct answers. Answers tended to be vague without any application of the answers obtained in the question or any reference to the problems of this arrangement. 
NO. 92题号：34269
  1. A lamp is rated as 12 V, 36 W.
    1. Calculate the resistance of the lamp at its working temperature.

      resistance = ............................................ Ω [2]
    2. On the axes of Fig. 6.1, sketch a graph to show the current-voltage (I–V) characteristic of the lamp. Mark an appropriate scale for current on the y-axis. [3]
  2. Some heaters are each labelled 230 V, 1.0 kW. The heaters have constant resistance.
    Determine the total power dissipation for the heaters connected as shown in each of the diagrams shown below.


    1. power = .......................................... kW [1]


    2. power = .......................................... kW [1]


    3. power = .......................................... kW [2]
