A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper2_1/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i either P = V2 / R   or  P = VI and V = IR
   R = 4.0 Ω		 C1
A1		 [2]
a.ii sketch vertical axis labelled appropriately
(straight) line from origin then curved in correct direction
line passes through 12 V, 3.0 A		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
b.i 2.0 kW A1 [1]
b.ii 0.5 kW A1 [1]
b.iii total resistance = 3R / 2
power = 0.67 kW		 C1
A1		 [2]
    1. either P = V2 / R   or   P = VI and V = IR
      R = 4.0 Ω
    2. sketch vertical axis labelled appropriately
      (straight) line from origin then curved in correct direction
      line passes through 12 V, 3.0 A
    1. 2.0 kW
    2. 0.5 kW
    3. total resistance = 3R / 2
      power = 0.67 kW
    1. For the majority of candidates, this calculation presented few difficulties. 
    2. The more able candidates completed the graph with few problems. Candidates should be encouraged to include on the axes of a sketch graph the values that are relevant to any data that is provided or calculated in the question.
  2. There were very few correct answers. All three calculations proved to be difficult for most candidates. The calculation of the power dissipation in resistors when the resistors are connected across a power supply in straightforward parallel or series combinations was found to be particularly difficult. 
NO. 93题号：34263
  1. Distinguish between the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of a cell and the potential difference (p.d.) across a resistor.
    ........................................................................ [3]
  2. Fig. 7.1. is an electrical circuit containing two cells of e.m.f. E1 and E2.

    The cells are connected to resistors of resistance R1, R2 and R3 and the currents in the branches of the circuit are I1, I2 and I3, as shown.
    1. Use Kirchhoff's first law to write down an expression relating I1, I2 and I3.
      .................................................................... [1]
    2. Use Kirchhoff's second law to write down an expression relating
      1. E2, R2, R3, I2 and I3 in the loop XBCYX, 
      .................................................................... [1]
      2. E1, E2, R1, R2, I1 and I2 in the loop AXYDA.
      .................................................................... [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Winter/Paper2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a both measure (energy / work) / charge
for e.m.f., transfer of chemical energy to electrical energy
for p.d., transfer of electrical energy to thermal energy / other forms		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
b.i I1 + I2 = I3 B1 [1]
b.ii 1. E2 = I2R2 + I3R3 B1 [1]
2. E1 - E2 = I1R1 - I2R2 B1 [1]
  1. both measure (energy / work) / charge
    for e.m.f., transfer of chemical energy to electrical energy
    for p.d., transfer of electrical energy to thermal energy / other forms
    1. I1 + I2 = I3
    2. 1. E2 = I2R2 + I3R3
      2. E1 - E2 = I1R1 - I2R2
  1. Some answers were limited to stating that e.m.f. is the p.d. across the terminals of the cell when the cell is on open circuit. The most common approach was to associate e.m.f. and p.d. with the work done in transferring an unspecified amount of charge around either a complete or an external circuit respectively. More acceptable answers discussed the energy conversions in the two cases. Significantly, regardless of approach, candidates very frequently failed to emphasise that both e.m.f. and p.d. are measures of energy conversion or work done per unit charge. 
    1. Most candidates successfully applied Kirchhoff's first law. 
    2. The second law was not nearly as well understood and, indeed, many answers either did not even involve a complete equation or e.m.f. was equated to current. Where equations were established, signs were frequently incorrect. For example, E1 and E2 were given the same sign, despite clearly having the two cells in opposite directions in the stated loop. 
NO. 94题号：34260

Fig. 6.1 shows the variation with applied potential difference V of the current I in an electrical component C.

    1. State, with a reason, whether the resistance of component C increases or decreases with increasing potential difference.
      .................................................................... [2]
    2. Determine the resistance of component C at a potential difference of 4.0 V.

      resistance = …………………….. Ω [2]
  2. Component C is connected in parallel with a resistor R of resistance 1500 Ω and a battery of e.m.f. E and negligible internal resistance, as shown in Fig. 6.2.

    1. On Fig. 6.1, draw a line to show the variation with potential difference V of the current I in resistor R. [2]

    2. Hence, or otherwise, use Fig. 6.1 to determine the current in the battery for an e.m.f. of 2.0 V.

      current = ……………………… A [2]
  3. The resistor R of resistance 1500 Ω and the component C are now connected in series across a supply of e.m.f. 7.0 V and negligible internal resistance.
    Using information from Fig. 6.1, state and explain which component, R or C, will dissipate thermal energy at a greater rate.
    .............................................................................. [3] 
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2004/Winter/Paper2/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i resistance is ratio V/I (at a point) 
either gradient increases or I increases more rapidly than V
(If states R = reciprocal of gradient, then 0/2 marks here)		 B1
B1

 [2]
a.ii current = 2.00 mA
resistance = 2 000 Ω		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.i straight line from origin
passing through (6.0 V, 4.0 mA)  (allow ½ square tolerance)		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.ii individual currents are 0.75 mA and 1/33 mA
current in battery = 2.1 mA
(allow argument in terms of P = I2R or IV) 		 C1
A1

 [2]
c same current in R and in C
p.d. across C is larger than that across R
so since power = VI, greater in C
(allow argument in terms of P = I2R or IV)		 M1
M1
A1

 [3]
    1. resistance is ratio V/I (at a point)
      either gradient increases or I increases more rapidly than V
      (If states R = reciprocal of gradient, then 0/2 marks here)
    2. current = 2.00 mA
      resistance = 2 000 Ω
    1. straight line from origin
      passing through (6.0 V, 4.0 mA)    (allow ½ square tolerance)
    2. individual currents are 0.75 mA and 1/33 mA
      current in battery = 2.1 mA
      (allow argument in terms of P = I2R or IV)
  3. same current in R and in C
    p.d. across C is larger than that across R
    so since power = VI, greater in C
    (allow argument in terms of P = I2R or IV)
    1. There were very few correct answers. Most candidates stated, or implied, that resistance is related to the gradient of the line, rather than to the co-ordinates of the point on the line. Many suggested that resistance would decrease because gradient is increasing.
    2. Most candidates did calculate the resistance correctly, although a significant number read the current from the graph as being 2 A, rather than 2 mA. 
    1. A surprisingly large number of candidates made no attempt to draw the required line. Most other candidates did draw a straight line through the origin, but in many cases, the choice of gradient appeared to be rather arbitrary. 
    2. Only a minority of answers indicated that the total current in the battery would be the sum of the currents in the two components. Most candidates gave the current in the resistor as the total current. Where an attempt was made to calculate the total circuit resistance, many either considered the two components to be in series or assumed the resistance of C to be that calculated in (a)(ii) and then went on to use the expression for resistors in parallel. 
  3. This section was very poorly answered. Most candidates failed to realise that, with components R and C now in series, there would be the same current in each. Furthermore, many assumed that there would be the same p.d. across each. Although most answers included a correct expression for rate of dissipation of energy, most drew unwarranted conclusions. General qualitative and incorrect statements were common, despite the fact that candidates were directed towards use of information from Fig. 6.1. 

Answers: (a)(ii) 2000 ± 50 Ω; (b)(ii) 2.1 mA.

NO. 95题号：34259

An electric heater is rated as 240 V, 1.2 kW and has constant resistance.

  1. For the heater operating at 240 V,
    1. show that the current in the heater is 5.0 A,

    2. calculate its resistance.

      resistance=……………..Ω
      [4]
  2. The heater in (a) is connected to a mains supply by means of two long cables, as illustrated in Fig. 7.1.

    The cables have a total resistance of 4.0 Ω. The voltage of the mains supply is adjusted so that the heater operates normally at 240V. Using your answers in (a), where appropriate, calculate
    1. the potential difference across the cables,

      potential difference = .......................................... V
    2. the voltage of the mains supply,

      voltage = ..................................................V
    3. the power dissipated in the cables.

      power dissipated = ......................................... W
      [3]
  3. Using information from (b), determine the efficiency e at which power is transferred from the supply to the heater. That is, calculate
    ε = power dissipated in heater / power input from supply.

    efficiency = .................................................. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2003/Winter/Paper2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i P = Vi
1200 = 240 × i
i = 5.0		 C1
M1
A0		 [4]
a.ii V = iR
240 = 5.0 × R
R = 48Ω
C1
A1
b.i p.d. = (5.0 × 4.0 =) 20 V A1 [3]
b.ii mains voltage = (240 + 20 =) 260 V A1
b.iii P = (20 × 5.0 =) 100 W A1
c power input = 1200 + 100 = 1300 W
efficiency = 1200/1300 = 0.92		 C1
A1		 [2]
    1. P = Vi
      1200 = 240 × i
      i = 5.0 A
    2. V = iR
      240 = 5.0 × R
      R = 48 Ω
    1. p.d. = (5.0 × 4.0 =) 20 V
    2. mains voltage = (240 + 20 =) 260 V
    3. P = (20 × 5.0 =) 100 W
  3. power input = 1200 + 100 = 1300 W
    efficiency = 1200/1300 = 0.92
  1. Most candidates correctly used the power and voltage ratings to show that the current is 5A and then calculated the resistance. A small number of answers involved assuming the current is 5A in order to calculate the resistance, then using this resistance value to show that the current is 5A.  
  2. Most candidates answered correctly all three parts. However, some did misunderstand what is meant by 'potential difference across the cables'. Others failed to appreciate that the mains voltage must be the sum of the potential differences across the heater and the cables.
  3. Although there were many correct solutions, it was apparent that some candidates did not appreciate the situation. Some did not associate 1.2 kW with the power dissipated in the heater, often using the power dissipated in the cables. A significant number of answers gave efficiencies in excess of 100%. 
NO. 96题号：34258

Two large flat metal plates A and B are placed 9.0 cm apart in vacuum as illustrated in Fig. 5.1.

A potential difference of 450 V is maintained between the plates by means of a battery.

    1. On Fig. 5.1, draw an arrow to indicate the direction of the electric field between plates A and B.

    2. Calculate the electric field strength between A and B.

      field strength = ...........................N C–1
      [3]
  2. An electron is released from rest at the surface of plate A.
    1. Show that the change in electric potential energy in moving from plate A to plate B is 7.2 × 1017 J.

    2. Determine the speed of the electron on reaching plate B.

      speed = ............................................. m s–1
      [4]
  3. On the axes of Fig. 5.2, sketch a graphic show the variation with distance d from plate A of the speed v of the electron. [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2003/Winter/Paper2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i arrow from B towards A B1 [3]
a.ii E = V/d
   = 450/(9.0 × 10-2)
   = 5.0 × 103 N C-1 (accept 1 sig. fig)
C1
A1
b.i energy = qV or Eqd
   = 1.6 × 10-19 × 450
   = 7.2 × 10-17 J		 C1
A1
A0		 [4]
b.ii Ek = ½mv2
7.2 × 10-17 = ½ × 9.1 × 10-31 × v2
v = 1.26 × 107 m s-1
C1
A1
c line from origin, curved in correct direction but not 'level out' B1 [1]
    1. arrow from B towards A
    2. E = V/d
         = 450/(9.0 × 10-2)
         = 5.0 × 103 N C-1 (accept 1 sig. fig)
    1. energy = qV or Eqd
      = 1.6 × 10-19 × 450
      = 7.2 × 10-17 J
    2. Ek = ½mv2
      7.2 × 10-17 = ½ × 9.1 × 10-31 × v2
      v = 1.26 × 107 m s-1
  3. line from origin, curved in correct direction but not 'level out'
    1. In most scripts, the direction was correct although some candidates would have been well advised to use a ruler. 
    2. The unit of electric field strength was given as N C-1, rather than V m-1. Consequently, the most common error was a failure to convert the unit of distance to the metre. 
    1. Many either correctly calculated the force on the electron and the work done by that force or used the product of charge and change in potential between the plates. Some made no attempt at this calculation or attempted to use the expression mgh with g being the acceleration of free fall. 
    2. There was a higher frequency of success in this calculation than in (i). The most common error was a failure to take the square root in the final stage of the work. Consequently, candidates settled for an answer of the order of 1014 m s-1, without any comment.
  3. There were very few correct sketches. The most frequent answer was a straight line. Candidates should realise that if the velocity increases at a constant rate, then the displacement will increase at an increasing rate, giving rise to a curve with a progressively decreasing gradient.
NO. 97题号：34257

A student set up the circuit shown in Fig. 7.1.

The resistors are of resistance 15 Ω and 45 Ω. The battery is found to provide 1.6×105 J of electrical energy when a charge of 1.8×104 C passes through the ammeter in a time of 1.3 × 105 s.

  1. Determine
    1. the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the battery,

      e.m.f. = …………………………………….. V
    2. the average current in the circuit.

      current = …………………………………….. A
      [4]
  2. During the time for which the charge is moving, 1.1×105 J of energy is dissipated in the 45 Ω resistor.
    1. Determine the energy dissipated in the 15 Ω resistor during the same time.

      energy = …………………………………. J
    2. Suggest why the total energy provided is greater than that dissipated in the two resistors.
      .........................................................................
      [4]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2002/Winter/Paper2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i e.m.f = energy / change
= (1.6 × 105) / (1.8 × 104)
= 8.9 V		 C1

A1		 [4]
a.ii current = ΔQ / Δt
= (1.80 × 104) / (1.3 × 105)
= 0.14 A		 C1

A1
b.i energy ∝ R (or formula)
energy = (15/45) × 1.14 × 105 
            = 3.7 × 104 J		 C1
C1
A1		 [4]
b.ii energy dissipated in internal resistance (of battery)
 OR in extra resistance in circuit		 B1
    1. e.m.f = energy / change
      = (1.6 × 105) / (1.8 × 104)
      = 8.9 V
    2. current = ΔQ / t
      = (1.80 × 104) / (1.3 × 105)
      = 0.14 A
    1. energy ∝ R (or formula)
      energy = (15/45) × 1.14 × 105 = 3.7 × 104 J
    2. energy dissipated in internal resistance (of battery)
      OR in extra resistance in circuit
  1. A common error was to assume that the total resistance of the circuit was 60 , thereby ignoring internal resistance of the battery and any other resistance in the circuit. Those candidates who recalled that e.m.f is energy converted per unit charge and that current is charge passing per unit time had little difficulty with the calculations.
    1. Those candidates who realised that, for constant current, energy dissipated is proportional to resistance had no difficulty with this calculation. Others made cumbersome, but correct, calculations, even re-calculating given data such as the time.
    2. Attempts to justify the 'loss' of energy were frequently fundamentally unsound and confirmed earlier suspicions that the internal resistance of the battery had not been considered.
NO. 98题号：34255
  1. Define potential difference (p.d.).
    ..............................................................................[1] 
  2. A battery of electromotive force 20 V and zero internal resistance is connected in series with two resistors R1 and R2, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

    The resistance of R2 is 600 Ω. The resistance of R1 is varied from 0 to 400 Ω.
    Calculate
    1. the maximum p.d. across R2,

      maximum p.d. = .............................................. V [1]
    2. the minimum p.d. across R2.

      minimum p.d. = .............................................. V [2]
  3. A light-dependent resistor (LDR) is connected in parallel with R2, as shown in Fig. 6.2.

    When the light intensity is varied, the resistance of the LDR changes from 5.0 kΩ to 1.2 kΩ.
    1. For the maximum light intensity, calculate the total resistance of R2 and the LDR.

      total resistance = ............................................. Ω [2]
    2. The resistance of R1 is varied from 0 to 400 Ω in the circuits of Fig. 6.1 and Fig. 6.2. State and explain the difference, if any, between the minimum p.d. across R2 in each circuit. Numerical values are not required.
      ..........................................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_3/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a (from electrical to other forms) B1 [1]
b.i maximum 20V A1 [1]
b.ii minimum = (600 / 1000) × 20
   = 12 V		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.i use of 1.2kΩ
1/1200 + 1/600 = 1/R, R = 400Ω		 M1
A1		 [2]
c.ii total parallel resistance (R2 + LDR) is less than R2
(minimum) p.d. is reduced		 M1
A1		 [2]
  1. p.d. = (work done / energy transformed)/charge  (from electrical to other forms)
    1. maximum 20 V
    2. minimum = (600 / 1000) × 20 = 12 V 
    1. use of 1.2 k Ω
      1/1200 + 1/600 = 1/R, R = 400 Ω
    2. total parallel resistance (R2 + LDR) is less than R2
      (minimum) p.d. is reduced

The basic understanding of a potential divider circuit was understood by a significant number of candidates.

  1. A correct definition was given by minority of candidates. 
    1. The correct answer was given by most candidates. 
    2. A significant number of candidates obtained the correct answer. 
    1. The majority of candidates selected the correct value for the resistance of the LDR for maximum light intensity. The majority of these candidates made a correct calculation for the two resistors in parallel. 
    2. The reduction in the value of the total resistance of R2 and the LDR in parallel compared with R2 on its own was only realised by a minority of candidates. The link with a reduced proportion of the overall resistance in the circuit and hence a reduced minimum potential difference across R2 was rarely described.
NO. 99题号：34254
  1. Define charge.
    ..............................................................................[1]
  2. A heater is made from a wire of resistance 18.0 Ω and is connected to a power supply of 240 V. The heater is switched on for 2.60 Ms.
    Calculate
    1. the power transformed in the heater,

      power = ............................................. W [2]
    2. the current in the heater,

      current = .............................................. A [1]
    3. the charge passing through the heater in this time,

      charge = ............................................. C [2]
    4. the number of electrons per second passing a given point in the heater.

      number = ........................................... s–1 [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_2/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a charge = current × time B1 [1]
b.i P = V2 / R
   = (240)2 / 18 = 3200W		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii I = V / R = 240 / 18 = 13.3A A1 [1]
b.iii charge = It = 13.3 × 2.6 × 106
     = 3.47 × 107 C		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.iv number of electrons = 3.47 × 107 / 1.6 × 10–19 (= 2.17 × 1026)
number of electrons per second = 2.17 × 1026 / 2.6 × 106 = 8.35 × 1019		 C1
A1		 [2]
  1. charge = current × time
    1. P = V2/ R = (240)2/ 18 = 3200 W
    2. I = V / R = 240 / 18 = 13.3A
    3. charge = It = 13.3 × 2.6 × 106 = 3.47 × 107 C 
    4. number of electrons = 3.47 × 107 / 1.6 × 10–19 (= 2.17 × 1026)
      number of electrons per second = 2.17 × 1026 / 2.6 × 106 = 8.35 × 1019

The majority of candidates scored at least half of the available marks on this question. Poor answers were generally seen for the definition in (a) and in the use of an incorrect power of ten in (b)(iii).

    1. Only a minority of candidates were able to give a satisfactory answer. Candidates should be informed that a symbol equation such as It will only gain marks for a definition if the symbols are defined. Many candidates confused the definition with that of current or gave a mixture of units and quantities. 
    1. This was generally well answered.
    2. This was generally well answered.
    3. The correct formula was used by the majority of candidates but arithmetic errors often resulted in an incorrect final answer.
    4. The stronger candidates were generally able to determine the total number of electrons. Only a minority went on to determine the number of electrons per second. The weaker candidates often gave no response.
NO. 100题号：34253

Two resistors A and B have resistances R1 and R2 respectively. The resistors are connected in series with a battery, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

The battery has electromotive force (e.m.f.) E and zero internal resistance.

  1. State the energy transformation that occurs in
    1. the battery,
      ....................................................................... [1]
    2. the resistors.
      ....................................................................... [1]
  2. The current in the circuit is Ι.
    State the rate of energy transformation in
    1. the battery,  
      ................................................................ [1]
    2. the resistor A. 
      ................................................................ [1]
  3. The resistors are made from metal wires. Data for the resistors are given in Fig. 6.2.

    Use information from Fig. 6.2 to determine the ratio
           

    ratio = .................................................. [3]
  4. The resistors A and B are connected in parallel across the same battery of e.m.f. E.
    Determine the ratio 
           

    ratio = .................................................. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_1/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i chemical to electrical B1 [1]
a.ii electrical to thermal / heat or heat and light B1 [1]
b.i (PB =) EI  or  I2(R1 + R2) A1 [1]
b.ii (PR =) I2R1 A1 [1]
c R = ρl / A or clear from the following equation
ratio = I2R1 / I2R2 = or R1 has 8 × resistance of R2
   = 8 or 8:1		 B1
C1
A1		 [3]
d P = V2 / R or E2 / R
(V or E the same) hence ratio is 1/8 or 1:8 = 0.125 (allow ecf from (c))		 C1
A1		 [2]
    1. chemical to electrical
    2. electrical to thermal / heat or heat and light
    1. (PB =) EI or I2(R1 + R2)
    2. (PR =) I2R1
  3. R = ρl / A or clear from the following equation
    ratio = I2R1 / I2R2 = or R1 has 8× resistance of R2
    = 8 or 8:1
  4. P = V2/ R  or  E2/ R
    (V or E the same) hence ratio is 1/8 or 1:8 = 0.125 (allow ecf from (c))
  1. Generally, correct answers were given. Some candidates did not read the question carefully and, as a result, did not consider these specific examples but instead referred to "other forms of energy".
  2. Weaker candidates found difficulty with this question. There was confusion between power and energy. Frequently, general expressions were quoted that did not include the terms E, R1 and R2.
  3. Candidates should be encouraged to quote relevant formulae at the start of any determination. Many answers involved a jumble of numbers and letters without any explanation. A significant number of candidates gave their answer as the ratio of the resistances without any consideration of the same current in the resistors.
  4. There were some answers that were explained adequately but it was common to find that it was not appreciated that the p.d. across the resistors would be the same, with different currents.
NO. 101题号：34252

      .......................................................................[1]

      .......................................................................[1]
  2. A variable resistor of resistance R is used to control the current in a circuit, as shown in Fig. 5.1.
       
    The generator G has e.m.f. 20 V and internal resistance 0.50 Ω. The battery has e.m.f. 12 V and internal resistance 0.10 Ω. The current in the circuit is 2.0 A.
    1. Apply Kirchhoff's second law to the circuit to determine the resistance R.

      R = ............................................. Ω [2]
    2. Calculate the total power generated by G.

      power = ............................................. W [2]
    3. Calculate the power loss in the total resistance of the circuit.

      power = ............................................. W [2]

Q5/9702/23/M/J/12

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_3/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i sum of currents into a junction = sum of currents out of junction B1 [1]
a.ii charge B1 [1]
b.i ΣE = ΣIR
20 – 12 = 2.0(0.6 + R)  (not used 3 resistors 0/2)
R = 3.4Ω
C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii P = EI
= 20 × 2
= 40W		 C1

A1		 [2]
b.iii P = I2R
P = (2)2 × (0.1 + 0.5 + 3.4)
= 16W		 C1

A1		 [2]
b.iv efficiency = useful power / output power
24 / 40 = 0.6 or 12 × 2 / 20 × 2 or 60%		 C1
A1		 [2]
    1. sum of currents into a junction = sum of currents out of junction
    2. charge
    1. ΣE = ΣIR
      20 – 12 = 2.0(0.6 + R)   (not used 3 resistors 0/2)
      R = 3.4 Ω
    2. P = EI
      = 20 × 2
      = 40 W
    3. P = I2R
      P = (2)2 × (0.1 + 0.5 + 3.4)
      = 16 W
    4. efficiency = useful power / output power
      24 / 40 = 0.6 or 12 × 2 / 20 × 2 or 60%
    1. This was generally well answered.
    2. A significant number of candidates gave current rather than charge as the answer here.
    1. The majority of candidates were unable to correctly apply Kirchhoff's second law. The two values of the e.m.f. were often added, and not all the resistances in the circuit were included in the stated equation.
    2. This was generally well answered. An error made by a number of candidates was to use V2 /R for the power produced, with the internal resistance of the generator used for R.
    3. The majority of candidates quoted the correct expression, and well prepared candidates used the total resistance in the circuit. A significant number of candidates used only the sum of the internal resistances, or the value of R determined in (b)(i).
    4. Well prepared candidates used the values obtained in (b)(ii) and (iii) to correctly calculate the efficiency. A significant number of candidates were unable to substitute the relevant values for the power into an acceptable expression for efficiency.
NO. 102题号：34250

A battery of electromotive force 12 V and negligible internal resistance is connected to two resistors and a light-dependent resistor (LDR), as shown in Fig. 4.1.

An ammeter is connected in series with the battery. The LDR and switch S are connected across the points XY.

  1. The switch S is open. Calculate the potential difference (p.d.) across XY.

    p. d. = .............................................. V  [3]
  2. The switch S is closed. The resistance of the LDR is 4.0 kΩ. Calculate the current in the ammeter.

    current = .............................................. A [3]
  3. The switch S remains closed. The intensity of the light on the LDR is increased.
    State and explain the change to
    1. the ammeter reading,
      ............................................................................ [2]
    2. the p.d. across XY.
      ............................................................................ [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_2/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a total resistance = 20 (kΩ)
current = 12 / 20 (mA)  or potential divider formula
p.d. = [12 / 20] × 12 = 7.2V		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
b parallel resistance = 3 (kΩ)
total resistance 8 + 3 = 11 (kΩ)
current = 12 / 11 × 103 = 1.09 × 10–3 or 1.1 × 10–3A		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
c.i LDR resistance decreases
total resistance (of circuit) is less hence current increases		 M1
A1		 [2]
c.ii resistance across XY is less
less proportion of 12V across XY hence p.d. is less		 M1
A1		 [2]
  1. total resistance = 20 (kΩ)
    current = 12 / 20 (mA)   or potential divider formula
    p.d. = [12 / 20] × 12 = 7.2 V
  2. parallel resistance = 3 (kΩ)
    total resistance 8 + 3 = 11 (kΩ)
    current = 12 / 11 × 103 = 1.09 × 10–3   or 1.1 × 10–3 A
    1. LDR resistance decreases
      total resistance (of circuit) is less hence current increases
    2. resistance across XY is less
      less proportion of 12 V across XY hence p.d. is less

Candidates generally scored good marks for parts (a) and (b). 

  1. This was generally well answered by the majority of candidates.
  2. This part was generally well answered. A minority of candidates were unable to calculate the total resistance in the parallel section of the circuit, or made an error in the power-of-ten for the resistance value.
    1. A large number of candidates did not make their explanations clear. There were many vague statements about resistance decreasing, without making a clear reference to the resistance of the LDR or the resistance of the complete circuit. A significant number of candidates incorrectly stated that the resistance of the LDR would increase with increased light intensity.
    2. Well prepared candidates were able to explain that the resistance in the parallel section would decrease. Very few candidates were able to explain why this would cause the proportion of the p.d. available from the power supply to be less than in (a). 
NO. 103题号：34249
    1. State Kirchhoff's second law.
      .....................................................................[1]
    2. Kirchhoff's second law is linked to the conservation of a certain quantity. State this quantity.
      .....................................................................[1]
  2. The circuit shown in Fig. 5.1 is used to compare potential differences.

    The uniform resistance wire XY has length 1.00 m and resistance 4.0 Ω. Cell A has e.m.f. 2.0 V and internal resistance 0.50 Ω. The current through cell A is I. Cell B has e.m.f. E and internal resistance r.
    The current through cell B is made zero when the movable connection J is adjusted so that the length of XJ is 0.90 m. The variable resistor R has resistance 2.5 Ω.
    1. Apply Kirchhoff's second law to the circuit CXYDC to determine the current I.

      I = .............................................. A [2]
    2. Calculate the potential difference across the length of wire XJ.

      potential difference = .................................. V [2]

A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i sum of e.m.f.'s = sum of p.d.'s around a loop/circuit B1 [1]
a.ii energy B1 [1]
b.i 2.0 = I × (4.0 + 2.5 + 0.5)
I = 0.286A (allow 2 s.f.)
(If total resistance is not 7Ω, 0/2 marks)		 C1
A1

 [2]
b.ii R = [0.90 / 1.0] × 4 (= 3.6)
V = IR = 0.286 × 3.6 = 1.03V
(If factor of 0.9 not used, then 0/2 marks)		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.iii E = 1.03V A1 [1] 
b.iv either  no current through cell B
or  p.d. across r is zero		 B1 [1] 
    1. sum of e.m.f.’s = sum of p.d.’s around a loop/circuit
    2. energy
    1. 2.0 = I × (4.0 + 2.5 + 0.5)
      I = 0.286 A   (allow 2 s.f.)
      (If total resistance is not 7 Ω, 0/2 marks)
    2. R = [0.90 / 1.0] × 4 (= 3.6)
      V = I R = 0.286 × 3.6 = 1.03V
      (If factor of 0.9 not used, then 0/2 marks)
    3. E = 1.03 V
    4. either    no current through cell B
      or   p.d. across r is zero

Many candidates found this question to be very demanding, and appeared not to have studied potential differences along a uniform wire.

    1. Frequently, the definition was given without reference to the sums of the e.m.f. or the potential differences.
    2. Many gave incorrect responses to this. Common answers were current, charge, p.d. and e.m.f. 
    1. There were relatively few correct answers. In the majority of cases, the total resistance of the circuit CXYDC was not considered.
    2. An 'error-carried-forward' from (i) was accepted here, but this did not result in many candidates being given credit. Most answers involved the total resistance of the wire XY, rather than the resistance of the length XJ.
    3. Very few candidates appreciated that the e.m.f. would be equal to the answer given in (ii). In many scripts, this part of the question was not attempted.
    4. The most common answer was based on negligible internal resistance. Very few understood that the current in the internal resistor would be zero and consequently there would be no 'lost volts'.

A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_1/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a.i R = V2 / P  or  P = IV and V = IR 
   = (220)2 / 2500
   = 19.4Ω (allow 2 s.f.)		 C1

A1		 [2]
c.ii R = ρl / A
l = [19.4 × 2.0 × 10–7] / 1.1 × 10–6
  = 3.53 m (allow 2 s.f.)		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
b.i P = 625, 620 or 630W A1 [1]
b.ii R needs to be reduced
Either length ¼ of original length
or area 4× greater 
or diameter 2× greater		 C1


A1		 [2]
    1. R = V2/ P   or   P = IV and V = IR
      = (220)2 / 2500
      = 19.4 Ω (allow 2 s.f.)
    2. R = ρl / A
      l = [19.4 × 2.0 × 10–7] / 1.1 × 10–6
         = 3.53 m (allow 2 s.f.)
    1. P = 625, 620 or 630W
    2. R needs to be reduced
      Either    length ¼ of original length
      or area 4× greater
      or diameter 2× greater

This was generally answered well. 

    1. Most answers were correct. A significant number of candidates, calculated the current and then used the expression V = IR, rather than calculating the resistance directly using the expression P = V2 /R.
    2. Again, the majority of answers were correct with very few errors being made when re-arranging the expression for resistivity.
    1. Almost all candidates calculated this correctly. Candidates should always consider the number of significant figures when giving their answers. 
    2. Most answers did include a statement to the effect that the resistance must be reduced, but only the more able candidates gave a quantitative explanation.
NO. 105题号：34247

    2. Explain how the resistance of the lamp may be calculated for any voltage from its I – V characteristic.
      ......................................................................[1]

    1. State and explain why the resistance of each lamp when they are connected in series is different from the resistance of each lamp when they are connected in parallel.
      .....................................................................[3]
    2. Each lamp is marked with a rating '12 V, 50 W'. Calculate the total resistance of the circuit for the two lamps connected such that each lamp uses this power.

      total resistance = ............................................. Ω [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper2_3/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i Start from (0,0) and smooth curve in correct direction
Curve correct for end section never horizontal 		 B1
B1		 [2]
a.ii R = V / I hence take co-ords of V and I from graph and calculate V / I B1 [1]
b.i each lamp in parallel has a greater p.d. / greater current
lamp hotter
resistance of lamps in parallel greater 		 M1
M1
A1		 [3]
b.ii P = V2 / R  or P = VI and V = IR
R = 144 / 50 = 2.88 for each lamp
total R = 1.44 Ω 		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
    1. Start from (0,0) and smooth curve in correct direction
      Curve correct for end section never horizontal
    2. R = V / I hence take co-ords of V and I from graph and calculate V / I
    1. each lamp in parallel has a greater p.d. / greater current
      lamp hotter
      resistance of lamps in parallel greater
    2. P = V2/ R   or   P = VI  and  V = IR
      R = 144 / 50 = 2.88 for each lamp
      total R = 1.44 Ω

This question was poorly answered by the majority of candidates. 

    1. The characteristic for a filament lamp was generally poorly drawn. The lines were seldom drawn with enough care to produce a smooth curve that did not become horizontal.
    2. The majority of answers did not refer to the co-ordinates of a point on the characteristic. The two most common explanations that did not gain credit were to give the equation that defines resistance without further comment or a description to determine the resistance from the inverse of the gradient of the line. 
    1. There were some good answers where candidates realised that the potential difference across the lamps in the two circuits was different. The effect of a higher potential difference producing a higher temperature and hence a higher resistance for the lamp was seldom explained by candidates. A large proportion of candidates did not read the question carefully. The answers given by these candidates were related to the total resistance for resistors connected in parallel compared with the resistors connected in series.
    2. The resistance of a lamp under the conditions stated was calculated correctly by a large proportion of the candidates. More able candidates went on to calculate the total resistance for the lamps connected in parallel. A significant number of candidates calculated the total resistance for the lamps connected in series or did not calculate a total resistance. The connection between the rating given for the lamp and the circuit that provided the lamp with 12 V was not made by these candidates. 
NO. 106题号：34245
  1. A variable resistor is used to control the current in a circuit, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

    The variable resistor is connected in series with a 12 V power supply of negligible internal resistance, an ammeter and a 6.0 Ω resistor. The resistance R of the variable resistor can be varied between 0 and 12 Ω.
    1. The maximum possible current in the circuit is 2.0 A. Calculate the minimum possible current.

      minimum current = ...................................... A [2]
    2. On Fig. 5.2, sketch the variation with R of current I1 in the circuit. [2]
  2. The variable resistor in (a) is now connected as a potential divider, as shown in Fig. 5.3.

    Calculate the maximum possible and minimum possible current I2 in the ammeter.

    maximum I2 = ........................................ A
    minimum I2 = ......................................... A [2]
    1. Sketch on Fig. 5.4 the I – V characteristic of a filament lamp. [2]
    2. The resistor of resistance 6.0 Ω is replaced with a filament lamp in the circuits of
      Fig. 5.1 and Fig. 5.3. State an advantage of using the circuit of Fig. 5.3, compared to the circuit of Fig 5.1, when using the circuits to vary the brightness of the filament lamp.
      .................................................................. [1]

Q5/9702/21/M/J/11

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper2_1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i I = 12 / (6 + 12)
minimum current = 0.67 A		 C1
A1		 [2]
a.ii correct start and finish points
correct shape for curve with decreasing gradient		 M1
A1		 [2]
b maximum current = 2.0 A
minimum current = 0		 A1
A1		 [2]
c.i smooth curve starting at (0,0) with decreasing gradient
end section not horizontal 		 M1
A1		 [2]
c.ii full range of current / p.d. possible
or  currents / p.d. down to zero
or  brightness ranging from off to full brightness		 B1 [1]
    1. I = 12 / (6 + 12)
      minimum current = 0.67 A
    2. correct start and finish points
      correct shape for curve with decreasing gradient
  2. maximum current = 2.0 A
    minimum current = 0
    1. smooth curve starting at (0,0) with decreasing gradient
      end section not horizontal
    2. full range of current / p.d. possible
      or currents / p.d. down to zero
      or brightness ranging from off to full brightness
    1. With few exceptions, the correct answer was given. A significant number of candidates did assume that the total resistance of the circuit would be 12 Ω and thus gave the current as being 1.0 A.
    2. There were few acceptable sketches. Many candidates did not have the line commencing at (0.0, 2.0) but instead, started at (6.0, 2.0). Others continued the line beyond R = 12 Ω. There were very few graphs where the line was drawn as an appropriate curve between the two end points. 
  2. There were very few correct answers, with many giving an incorrect value of 3.0 A for the maximum current and then not giving an answer for the minimum. Candidates should be encouraged to study this application of the potential divider. 
    1. It was expected that the sketching of this graph would present few problems. This was not the case, with only a minority scoring full credit. Where an acceptable line was drawn for low values of V, the curve frequently showed constant current at higher values of V.
    2. Most answers were concerned with the maximum current that could be achieved rather than the fact that, with the potential divider, the full range of currents is possible.
NO. 107题号：34244
    1. State what is meant by an electric current.
      ........................................................................[1]
    2. Define electric potential difference.
      ........................................................................[1]
  2. The variation with potential difference V of the current I in a component Y and in a resistor R are shown in Fig. 6.1.

    Use Fig. 6.1 to explain how it can be deduced that resistor R has a constant resistance of 20 Ω.
    ...............................................................................[2]
  3. The component Y and the resistor R in (b) are connected in parallel as shown in Fig. 6.2.

    A battery of e.m.f. E and negligible internal resistance is connected across the parallel combination.
    Use data from Fig. 6.1 to determine
    1. the current in the battery for an e.m.f. E of 6.0 V,

      current = ..............................................A [1]
    2. the total resistance of the circuit for an e.m.f. of 8.0 V.

      resistance = ............................................. Ω [2]
  4. The circuit of Fig. 6.2 is now re-arranged as shown in Fig. 6.3.

    The current in the circuit is 0.20 A.
    1. Use Fig. 6.1 to determine the e.m.f. E of the battery.

      E = ..............................................V [1]
    2. Calculate the total power dissipated in component Y and resistor R. 

      power = .............................................W [2]

Q6/9702/23/M/J/10

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper2_3/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i movement/flow of charged particles B1 [1]
a.ii work done per unit charge (transferred) B1 [1]
b straight line through origin
resistance = V/ I , with values for V and I shown
= 20 Ω
(using the gradient loses the last mark) 		 B1
M1
A0

 [2]
c.i 0.5A A1 [1]
c.ii either  resistance of each resistor is 20Ω or total current = 0.8A
either  combined resistance = 10 Ω or  R = E/ I = 10Ω		 C1
A1		 [2]
d.i 10 V A1 [1]
d.ii power = EI
= 10 × 0.2 = 2.0W		 C1
A1		 [2]
    1. movement/flow of charged particles
    2. work done per unit charge (transferred)
  2. straight line through origin
    resistance = V/ I , with values for V and I shown
    = 20 Ω
    (using the gradient loses the last mark)
    1. 0.5A
    2. either resistance of each resistor is 20 Ω or total current = 0.8 A
      either combined resistance = 10 Ω or R = E/ I = 10 Ω
    1. 10 V
    2. power = EI  = 10 × 0.2 = 2.0 W

This question was poorly completed by the majority of candidates.

    1. The majority of candidates were able to describe an electric current as a movement of charge.
    2. Only the very good candidates were able to give an acceptable definition of electric potential difference.
  2. The majority of candidates stated incorrectly that the resistance was related to the gradient of the current against potential difference graph. The resistance was constant because the straight line went through the origin. Many answers suggested that the resistance was calculated using ΔV / ΔI. 
    1. The candidates did not appear to interpret the circuit diagram and use data from Fig. 6.1 correctly. There were many misconceptions of this circuit showing resistors in parallel.
    2. Many of the candidates continued with their answer to (c)(i) apparently unaware of the different battery producing a different current and hence resistance for the thermistor. 
    1. The majority of candidates were not able to interpret this circuit showing resistors in series. The answers were often the potential difference for just one of the resistors.
    2. The majority of candidates gained marks in this section by error carried forward. 
      The good candidates scored highly on (c) and (d). 
NO. 108题号：34242

An electric heater is to be made from nichrome wire. Nichrome has a resistivity of 1.0 × 10–6Ω m at the operating temperature of the heater.
The heater is to have a power dissipation of 60 W when the potential difference across its terminals is 12 V.

  1. For the heater operating at its designed power,
    1. calculate the current,






      current = .............................................. A [2]

    2. show that the resistance of the nichrome wire is 2.4 Ω.





      [2]

  2. Calculate the length of nichrome wire of diameter 0.80 mm required for the heater.






    length = ............................................. m [3]

  3. A second heater, also designed to operate from a 12 V supply, is constructed using the same nichrome wire but using half the length of that calculated in (b).
    Explain quantitatively the effect of this change in length of wire on the power of the heater.

    ..........................................................................................................................................
    ..........................................................................................................................................
    ..........................................................................................................................................
    ......................................................................................................................................[3]

[Total: 10]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper2_1/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i P = VI
60 = 12 × I
I = 5.(0) A		 C1

A1		 [2]
a.ii either  V = IR  or  P = I2R or  P = V2 / R
either  12 = 5 × R  or  60 = 52 × R  or  60 = 122/R
R = 2.4 Ω		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
b R = ρL/A
A = π × (0.4 × 10–3)2 (= 5.03 × 10–7)
L = (2.4 × 5.03 × 10–7)/(1.0 × 10–6)
  = 1.2 m		 C1
C1

A1		 [3]
c resistance is halved
either  current is doubled  or  power ∝ 1/R
power is doubled 		 M1
M1
A1		 [3]
    1. P = VI
      60 = 12 × I
      I = 5.(0) A
    2. either   V = IR    or   P = I2R   or   P = V2 / R
      either 12 = 5 × R   or   60 = 52 × R   or   60 = 122 /R
      R = 2.4 Ω
  2. R = ρL/A
    A = π × (0.4 × 10–3)2 (= 5.03 × 10–7)
    L = (2.4 × 5.03 × 10–7)/(1.0 × 10–6)
       = 1.2 m
  3. resistance is halved
    either current is doubled or power ∝ 1/R
    power is doubled
  1. With few exceptions, the correct answers and explanations were given for both (i) and (ii).
  2. Although there were many correct answers, a significant number of candidates were unable to recall the expression for the area of cross-section of the wire.
  3. Candidates need to be advised on how to answer questions where a quantitative explanation is required. All too often, candidates gave qualitative explanations by merely referring to the 'decrease' or 'increase' of a quantity, without any numerical information being given. A common error, made by those candidates that did attempt a quantitative explanation, was to think that the potential difference across the wire would halve in order to give a constant current. 
NO. 109题号：34241
  1. State what is meant by an electric field.
    ........................................................................................... [1]
  2. The electric field between an earthed metal plate and two charged metal spheres is illustrated in Fig.5.1.

    1. On Fig.5.1, label each sphere with (+) or (–) to show its charge.  [1]

    2. On Fig.5.1, mark a region where the magnitude of the electric field is
      1. constant (label this region C),  [1]
      2. decreasing (label this region D).  [1]
  3. A molecule has its centre P of positive charge situated a distance of 2.8 × 10–10 m from its centre N of negative charge, as illustrated in Fig.5.2.

    The molecule is situated in a uniform electric field of field strength 5.0 × 104 V m–1. The axis NP of the molecule is at an angle of 30° to this uniform applied electric field.
    The magnitude of the charge at P and at N is 1.6 × 10–19 C.
    1. On Fig. 5.2, draw an arrow at P and an arrow at N to show the directions of the forces due to the applied electric field at each of these points.  [1]
    2. Calculate the torque on the molecule produced by the forces in (i).

      torque = ......................................... N m   [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper2_1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a region/area where a charge experiences a force B1 [1]
b.i left-hand sphere (+), right-hand sphere (–) B1 [1]
b.ii 1. correct region labelled C within 10 mm of central part of plate
  otherwise within 5 mm of plate		 B1 [1]
2. correct region labelled D area of field not included for (b)(ii)1 B1 [1]
c.i arrows through P and N in correct directions B1 [1]
c.ii torque = force × perpendicular distance (between forces)
  = 1.6 × 10–19 × 5.0 × 104 × 2.8 × 10–10 × sin30
  = 1.1 × 10–24 N m		 C1

A1		 [2]
  1. region/area where a charge experiences a force
    1. left-hand sphere (+), right-hand sphere (–)
    2. 1. correct region labelled C within 10 mm of central part of plate otherwise within 5 mm of plate
      2. correct region labelled D area of field not included for (b)(ii)1
    1. arrows through P and N in correct directions
    2. torque = force × perpendicular distance (between forces)
      = 1.6 × 10–19 × 5.0 × 104 × 2.8 × 10–10 × sin30
      = 1.1 × 10–24 N m
  1. Although many of the answers were satisfactory, there was some confusion between 'electric field' and 'electric field strength'. Many inadequate answers included a reference to 'electric force', without explaining that the force was on an electric charge.
    1. With very few exceptions, the spheres were correctly labelled to show their charge.
    2. The majority of candidates could identify the two regions. However, a significant number of answers failed to be given credit as a result of careless drawing.
    1. Most answers were correct, although a small minority showed both of the forces in the same direction or showed them at right-angles to the electric field. 
    2. Frequently, the answer lacked any detailed explanation. Calculations often made no allowance for the angle of 30˚. 
NO. 110题号：34240
  1. A network of resistors, each of resistance R, is shown in Fig. 7.1.

    Switches S1 and S2 may be 'open' or 'closed'.
    Complete Fig. 7.2 by calculating the resistance, in terms of R, between points X and Y for the switches in the positions shown. [3]
  2. Two cells of e.m.f. E1 and E2 and negligible internal resistance are connected into a network of resistors, as shown in Fig. 7.3.

    The currents in the network are as indicated in Fig. 7.3.
    Use Kirchhoff's laws to state the relation
    1. between currents I1, I2, I3 and I4,
      ..............................................................................[1]
    2. between E1, E2, R, and I3 in loop NKLMN,
      ..............................................................................[1]
    3. between E2, R, I3 and I4 in loop NKQN.
      ..............................................................................[1]

a ∞ A1 [3]
