R A1
b.i I1 + I3 = I2 + I4 A1 [1]
b.ii E2 – E1 = I3R A1 [1]
b.iii E2 = I3R + 2I4R A1 [1]
  1. ∞
    2R
    R
    1. I1 + I3 = I2 + I4
    2. E2 – E1 = I3R
    3. E2 = I3R + 2I4R
  1. With few exceptions, the answer for both switches 'open' was, surprisingly, given as zero.
  2. Answers to all three parts in the scripts of more-able candidates were correct. The usual errors were associated with the directions of current and e.m.f.
NO. 111题号：34234

A circuit contains three similar lamps A, B and C. The circuit also contains three switches, S1, S2 and S3, as shown in Fig. 7.1.

One of the lamps is faulty. In order to detect the fault, an ohm-meter (a meter that measures resistance) is connected between terminals X and Y. When measuring resistance, the ohmmeter causes negligible current in the circuit.

Fig. 7.2 shows the readings of the ohm-meter for different switch positions.

  1. Identify the faulty lamp, and the nature of the fault.
    faulty lamp: ...........................................................................
    nature of fault: ..................................................................... [2]
  2. Suggest why it is advisable to test the circuit using an ohm-meter that causes negligible current rather than with a power supply. [1]
  3. Determine the resistance of one of the non-faulty lamps, as measured using the ohmmeter. 

    resistance = …………………… Ω [1]
  4. Each lamp is marked 6.0 V, 0.20 A.
    Calculate, for one of the lamps operating at normal brightness,
    1. its resistance,

      resistance = …………………… Ω [2]
    2. its power dissipation.

      power = …………………… W [2]
  5. Comment on your answers to (c) and (d)(i). [2]

Q7/9702/02/M/J/06

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Summer/Paper2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a lamp C
lamp is shorted		 M1
A1		 [2]
b shorted lamp A would cause damage to the supply/lamps
/blow fuse in supply		 B1 [1]
c 15 Ω B1 [1]
d.i V = I R
R = 30 Ω		 C1
A1		 [2]
d.ii P = VI  or  I2R  or  V2/R
P = 1.2 W		 C1
A1		 [2]
e filament is cold when measuring with ohm-meter in (b)
resistance of filament rises as temperature rises		 B1
B1		 [2]
  1. lamp C
    lamp is shorted
  2. shorted lamp A would cause damage to the supply/lamps/blow fuse in supply
  3. 15 Ω
    1. V = I R
      R = 30 Ω
    2. P = VI    or    I2R   or   V2/ R
      P = 1.2 W
  5. filament is cold when measuring with ohm-meter in (b)
    resistance of filament rises as temperature rises
  1. The majority of candidates did identify correctly the faulty lamp. However, all three lamps and, indeed, all three switches were variously nominated. Of those candidates who correctly identified the faulty lamp, the majority were unable to state the nature of the fault. The most common explanations were 'the filament has broken' or 'the lamp has fused'. 
  2. Candidates were very aware of the danger of being electrocuted and many warned of the damage which might be caused. Very few, however, recognised that the predicted damage might arise only if lamp A is shorted.
  3. With few exceptions, candidates arrived at the correct answer for the resistance.
  4. Not surprisingly, almost all candidates correctly applied Ohm's law in (i). Only a small number failed to calculate the power in (ii).
  5. Very few candidates seemed to realise that, in normal operation, a lamp is bright because the filament is at high temperature. Consequently, very few accounted for the difference in resistance as being due to the rise in temperature of the filament. Statements such as 'resistance increases as current increases' were, regrettably, all too common.
NO. 112题号：34233
  1. Define the resistance of a resistor. 
    .............................................................................[1]
  2. In the circuit of Fig. 7.1, the battery has an e.m.f. of 3.00 V and an internal resistance r. R is a variable resistor. The resistance of the ammeter is negligible and the voltmeter has an infinite resistance.

    The resistance of R is varied. Fig. 7.2 shows the variation of the power P dissipated in R with the potential difference V across R.

    1. Use Fig. 7.2 to determine
      1. the maximum power dissipation in R,

          maximum power = ....................................... W
      2. the potential difference across R when the maximum power is dissipated.

          potential difference = .................................. V
          [1]
    2. Hence calculate the resistance of R when the maximum power is dissipated.

      resistance = ............................................. Ω [2]
    3. Use your answers in (i) and (ii) to determine the internal resistance r of the battery.

      r = ............................................. Ω [3]
  3. By reference to Fig. 7.2, it can be seen that there are two values of potential difference V for which the power dissipation is 1.05 W.
    State, with a reason, which value of V will result in less power being dissipated in the internal resistance. [3]

Q7/9702/02/M/J/05

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2005/Summer/Paper2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a potential difference/current B1 [1]
b.i 1) 1.13 W
2) 1.50 V		 B1 [1]
b.ii power = V2 / R or power = VI and V = IR
R = 1.502/1.13
   = 1.99 Ω		 C1

A1		 [2]
b.iii either E = IR + Ir   or voltage divided between R and r
I = 1.5 / 2.0 (=0.75 A)   p.d. across R = p.d. Across r = 1.5
3.0 = 1.5 + 0.75r
r = 2.0 Ω    so R = r = 1.99 Ω		 C1
C1

A1		 [3]
c larger p.d. across R means smaller p.d. across r
smaller power dissipation at larger value of V
since power is VI and I is same for R and r		 M1
A1
A1		 [3]
  1. potential difference/current
    1. 1. 1.13 W
      2. 1.50 V
    2. power = V2 / R or power = VI and V = IR
      R = 1.502 /1.13 = 1.99 Ω
    3. either E = IR + Ir      or voltage divided between R and r
      I = 1.5 / 2.0 (=0.75 A)       p.d. across R = p.d. Across r = 1.5
      3.0 = 1.5 + 0.75r
      r = 2.0 Ω          so R = r = 1.99 Ω
  3. larger p.d. across R means smaller p.d. across r
    smaller power dissipation at larger value of V
    since power is VI and I is same for R and r
  1. Many candidates gave unsatisfactory answers in terms of 'the hindrance' or 'the opposition to the current'. Of those who did attempt a definition in terms of a ratio, many were imprecise, either defining the unit rather than the property or, frequently, using the unqualified term 'voltage' when what was intended is the potential difference across the resistor.
    1. The vast majority of answers were correct for the data point.
    2. With few exceptions, the calculation was completed successfully.
    3. This part of the calculation was more challenging and there were many well-expressed correct solutions. However, there were significant numbers of answers where work was laid out poorly. In such cases, many candidates failed to appreciate whether they were dealing with the e.m.f. of the battery, the p.d. across the resistor or the p.d. across the internal resistor. A small but significant number of candidates treated the external and internal resistors as if they were in parallel. 
  3. This part was poorly answered with very few showing clarity of thought. Many candidates made no mention of internal resistance, simply quoting a formula for power dissipation, and concluding that the lower value of the p.d. across R would give a smaller power, ignoring the fact that both the value of the current and the resistance would change. Others stated that the larger p.d. across R would give greater power dissipation in R thus the power dissipation in the inernal resistor must be smaller. A minority of candidates argued, quite correctly, that a larger p.d. across R would give a smaller p.d. across the internal resistance and since internal resistance is constant and P = V2/r, then the power dissipation in the internal resistor would be lower.

Answers: (b)(i) 1.13 W, 1.50 V, (ii) 1.99 Ω, (iii) 1.99 Ω.

NO. 113题号：34231

A thermistor has resistance 3900 Ω at 0 °C and resistance 1250 Ω at 30 °C. The thermistor is connected into the circuit of Fig. 8.1 in order to monitor temperature changes.

The battery of e.m.f. 1.50 V has negligible internal resistance and the voltmeter has infinite resistance.

  1. The voltmeter is to read 1.00 V at 0 °C. Show that the resistance of resistor R is 7800 Ω. [2]
  2. The temperature of the thermistor is increased to 30 °C. Determine the reading on the voltmeter.

    reading = ................................... V [2]
  3. The voltmeter in Fig. 8.1 is replaced with one having a resistance of 7800 Ω.
    Calculate the reading on this voltmeter for the thermistor at a temperature of 0 °C.

    reading = ................................... V [2]

Q8/9702/02/M/J/04

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2004/Summer/Paper2/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a V/E = R/Rtot   or   0.5 = l × 3900 
1.0/1.5 = R/(R + 3900)    or 1.0 = 0.5R/3900
R = 7800Ω.     or R = 7800Ω		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
b V = 1.5 × (7800/{7800 + 1250})   or I = 1.5/(7800 + 1250)
= 1.29 V.   or V = IR = 1.29 V		 C1
A1		 [2]
c Combined resistance of R and voltmeter is 3900 Ω
reading at 0 °C is 0.75 V		 C1
A1		 [2]
  1. V/E = R/Rtot     or   0.5 = l × 3900 
    1.0/1.5 = R/(R + 3900)      or 1.0 = 0.5R/3900
    R = 7800Ω.     or R = 7800Ω
  2. V = 1.5 × (7800/{7800 + 1250})     or I = 1.5/(7800 + 1250)
    = 1.29 V.      or V = IR = 1.29 V 
  3. Combined resistance of R and voltmeter is 3900 Ω
    reading at 0 °C is 0.75 V

Candidates who fully understood the principle of the potentiometer found all three parts of this question quite straightforward and many answers were very clearly presented. On the other hand, there were, quite evidently, some candidates who had little or no experience of analysis of circuits.

  1. The answer was provided in the question and, consequently, credit was given for a clear explanation as to how the answer was derived. Weaker candidates frequently made incomplete attempts to apply Ohm's Law to various parts of the circuit, with little or no explanation. Generally, the correct conclusion was reached, but by incorrect or dubious means.
  2. A common error was to assume that the current, as calculated in (a), would remain the same, despite a change in resistance. There were some well-explained answers, based on a calculation of the current in the circuit and application of Ohm's law to the resistor R.
  3. Most candidates who attempted this part of the calculation were successful in calculating the combined resistance of the voltmeter and the resistor R. A surprisingly large number then calculated the potential difference across a resistance of 7800 Ω as being the voltmeter reading.

Answers: (b) 1.29 V; (c) 0.75 V. 

NO. 114题号：34230

A household electric lamp is rated as 240 V, 60 W. The filament of the lamp is made from tungsten and is a wire of constant radius 6.0 × 10–6 m. The resistivity of tungsten at the normal operating temperature of the lamp is 7.9 × 10–7 Ω m.

  1. For the lamp at its normal operating temperature, [3]
    1. calculate the current in the lamp,

      current = ........................................ A
    2. show that the resistance of the filament is 960 Ω.

  2. Calculate the length of the filament.

    length = ........................................ m [3]
  3. Comment on your answer to (b). [1]

Q7/9702/02/M/J/04

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2004/Summer/Paper2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i P = VI
current = 60/240 = 0.25 A		 C1
A1		 [3]
a.ii R ( = V/I) = 240/0.25
     = 960 Ω		 M1
A0
b R = ρ L/A (wrong formula, 0/3)
960 = (7.9 x 10-7 x L)/(π x {6.0 x 10-6}2)
L = 0.137 m
(use of A = 2πr, then allow 1/3 marks only for resistivity formula)		 C1
C1
A1

 [3]
c e.g. the filament must be coiled/it is long for a lamp
(allow any sensible comment based on candidate's answer for L)		 B1 [1]
    1. P = VI
      current = 60/240 = 0.25 A
    2. R ( = V/I) = 240/0.25 = 960 Ω
  2. R = ρ L/A (wrong formula, 0/3)
    960 = (7.9 × 10-7 × L)/(π × {6.0 × 10-6}2)
    L = 0.137 m
    (use of A = 2πr, then allow 1/3 marks only for resistivity formula)
  3. e.g. the filament must be coiled/it is long for a lamp
    (allow any sensible comment based on candidate's answer for L)
  1. These simple calculations were completed successfully in most cases. It is surprising that, at this level, there is a small minority that believe that current and voltage are related by the expression V = I/R.
  2. The majority of the calculations of the length were correct. Most failures were accounted for by wrong formulae, inconsistent units or an incorrect expression for the cross-sectional area of the wire. 
  3. Most comments on the answer for the length of the filament did not attempt to relate its suitability for the household electric lamp and were simply 'it is short' or 'it is long'. A small number did state that the filament, longer than the diameter of the lamp, would be coiled. 

Answers: (a)(i) 0.25 A; (b) 0.137 m.

NO. 115题号：34229

A filament lamp operates normally at a potential difference (p.d.) of 6.0 V. The variation with p.d. V of the current I in the lamp is shown in Fig.5.1.

  1. Use Fig to determine, for lamp, [4]
    1. resistance when it is operating at a p.d. of 6.0 V.
    2. change in resistance when p.d. increases from 6.0 V to 8.0 V.

  2. Lamp is connected into circuit of Fig.5.2.

    R is a fixed resistor of resistance 200 Ω. Battery has e.m.f. E and negligible internal resistance. [4]
     
    1. On Fig, draw a line to show variation with p.d. V of the current I in the resistor R.
       
    2. Determine e.m.f. of the battery for the lamp to operate normally.
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2003/Summer/Paper1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i resistance = V/I
                 = 6.0/(40 × 10-3)
                 = 150 Ω
(no marks for use of gradient)		 C1 

A1

 [4]
a.ii at 8.0 V, resistance = 8.0/(50 × 10-3) = 160 Ω
change = 10 Ω		 C1
A1
b.i straight line through origin
passes through I = 40 mA, V = 8.0V		 M1
A1		 [4]
b.ii current in both must be 40 mA
e.m.f. = 8.0 + 6.0 = 14.0 V		 C1
A1
    1. resistance = V/I
      = 6.0/(40 × 10-3)
      = 150 Ω
      (no marks for use of gradient)
    2. at 8.0 V, resistance = 8.0/(50 × 10-3) = 160 Ω.
      change = 10 Ω
    1. straight line through origin.
      passes through I = 40 mA, V = 8.0V
    2. current in both must be 40 mA
      e.m.f. = 8.0 + 6.0 = 14.0 V
  1. It was pleasing to note that very few candidates used a gradient when attempting to calculate either the resistance or the change in resistance. A minority did find the ratio I/V but the usual error was a failure to recognise that the current is in milliamps, not amps.
    1. Although most candidates did draw a straight line through the origin, a surprisingly large proportion did not have the correct gradient.
    2. Answers to this part of the question were very disappointing and only the most able candidates were able to arrive at the correct answer. In many attempts, different currents were used when calculating the potential difference across the lamp and across R. Many others equated the potential difference across R to the e.m.f. of the battery.
NO. 116题号：34224
  1. Explain what is meant by plastic deformation.
    ..................................................................... [1]
  2. A copper wire of uniform cross-sectional area 1.54 × 10-6 m2 and length 1.75 m has a breaking stress of 2.20 × 108 Pa. The Young modulus of copper is 1.20 × 1011 Pa.
    1. Calculate the breaking force of the wire.

      breaking force = ........................................ N [2]
    2. A stress of 9.0 ×107 Pa is applied to the wire. Calculate the extension. 

      extension = ............................................ m [2]
  3. Explain why it is not appropriate to use the Young modulus to determine the extension when the breaking force is applied.
    ............................................................................ [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper2_1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a when the load is removed then the wire / body object does not return to its original shape / length B1 [1]
b.i stress = force / area
F = 220 × 106 × 1.54 × 10–6 = 340 (338.8)N		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii E = (F × l) / (A × e)
e = (90 × 106) × 1.75 / (1.2 × 1011) = 1.31 × 10–3m		 C1
A1		 [2]
c the stress is no longer proportional to the extension B1 [1]
  1. when the load is removed then the wire / body object does not return to its original shape / length
    1. stress = force / area
      F = 220 × 106 × 1.54 × 10–6 = 340 (338.8) N
    2. E = (F × l) / (A × e)
      e = (90 × 106) × 1.75 / (1.2 × 1011) = 1.31 × 10–3 m
  3. the stress is no longer proportional to the extension
  1. The explanation of plastic deformation was given by a very small number of candidates.
    1. A significant number of candidates gave the correct answer. 
    2. A significant number of adequately prepared candidates determined the correct answer.
  3. Very few candidates realised that the use of the Young modulus was only appropriate where the force was proportional to the extension.
NO. 117题号：34222
  1. State Hooke's law.
    ................................................................... [1]
  2. The variation with extension x of the force F for a spring A is shown in Fig. 6.1.

    The point L on the graph is the elastic limit of the spring.
    1. Describe the meaning of elastic limit.
      ............................................................... [1]
    2. Calculate the spring constant kA for spring A. 

      kA = ....................................... N m–1 
    3. Calculate the work done in extending the spring with a force of 6.4 N. 

      work done = .............................................. J [2]
  3. A second spring B of spring constant 2kA is now joined to spring A, as shown in Fig. 6.2.

    A force of 6.4 N extends the combination of springs.
    For the combination of springs, calculate
    1. the total extension,

      extension = ............................................. m [1]
    2. the spring constant.

      spring constant = ....................................... N m–1 [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper2_1/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a extension is proportional to force (for small extensions) B1 [1]
b.i point beyond which (the spring) does not return to its original length when the load is removed B1 [1]
b.ii gradient of graph = 80Nm–1 A1 [1]
b.iii work done is area under graph / ½ Fx / ½ kx2
= 0.5 × 6.4 × 0.08 = 0.256 (allow 0.26) J		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.i extension = 0.08 + 0.04 = 0.12 m A1 [1]
c.ii spring constant = 6.4 / 0.12 = 53.3Nm–1 A1 [1]
  1. extension is proportional to force (for small extensions)
    1. point beyond which (the spring) does not return to its original length when the load is removed
    2. gradient of graph = 80 Nm–1
    3. work done is area under graph / ½ Fx / ½ kx2
      = 0.5 × 6.4 × 0.08 = 0.256 (allow 0.26) J
    1. extension = 0.08 + 0.04 = 0.12 m
    2. spring constant = 6.4 / 0.12 = 53.3 Nm–1
  1. Well prepared candidates gave the correct definition. A significant number of candidates were unable to give the required definition.
    1. There were very few answers given with the required precision. A common error was to include a vague reference to a limit rather than the point beyond which the object does not return to its original length. Many candidates also omitted the condition of 'when the force is removed'. A significant minority also confused the elastic limit with the limit of proportionality. 
    2. A significant number of candidates were able to determine the correct value. There were powers of ten errors and misreading of the scales by the weaker candidates. 
    3. A number of candidates were able to obtain the correct value. A significant number of candidates used an inappropriate equation for the work done extending a spring. 
  3. This part tested the understanding of the term 'spring constant'. Very few candidates were able to demonstrate a good understanding and hence correct answers were seldom seen. Candidates would benefit from further experience of solving problems involving spring constants.
NO. 118题号：34221

A spring hangs vertically from a fixed point and a mass of 94 g is suspended from the spring, stretching the spring as shown in Fig. 5.1.

The mass is raised vertically so that the length of the spring is its unextended length. This is illustrated in Fig. 5.2.

The mass is then released. The mass moves through a vertical distance of 2.6 cm before temporarily coming to rest. This position is illustrated in Fig. 5.3.

  1. State which diagram, Fig. 5.1, Fig. 5.2 or Fig. 5.3, illustrates the position of the mass such that
    1. the mass has maximum gravitational potential energy,
      .................................................................... [1]
    2. the spring has maximum strain energy.
      .................................................................... [1]
  2. Briefly describe the variation of the kinetic energy of the mass as the mass falls from its highest position (Fig. 5.2) to its lowest position (Fig. 5.3).
    ................................................................ [1]
  3. The strain energy E stored in the spring is given by the expression 
              E = ½kx2
    where k is the spring constant and x is the extension of the spring.
    For the mass moving between the positions shown in Fig. 5.2 and Fig. 5.3,
    1. calculate the change in the gravitational potential energy of the mass, 

      change = ........................................... J
    2. determine the extension of the spring at which the strain energy is half its maximum value.

      extension = ........................................ cm
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper2_3/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i Fig. 5.2 B1 [1]
a.ii Fig. 5.3 B1 [1]
b kinetic energy increases from zero then decreases to zero B1 [1]
c.i ∆EP = mg∆h / mgh
  = 94 × 10–3 × 9.8 × 2.6 × 10–2 using g = 10 then –1 
  = 0.024 J		 C1

A1		 [2]
c.ii either 0.024 = ½k × (2.6 × 10–2)2
          0.012 = ½k × d2
                 d = 0.018m
                    = 1.8cm		 C1
C1

A1		 [3]
or ½ kd2 = ½k × (2.6 × 10–2)2 – ½kd2
         kd2 = ½k × (2.6 × 10–2)2
            d = 0.018m
               = 1.8cm		 (C1)
(C1)

(A1)		  
    1. Fig. 5.2
    2. Fig. 5.3
  2. kinetic energy increases from zero then decreases to zero
    1. ∆EP = mg∆h / mgh
      = 94 × 10–3 × 9.8 × 2.6 × 10–2 using g = 10 then –1
      = 0.024J
    2. either 0.024 = ½ k × (2.6 × 10–2)2
      0.012 = ½k × d2
      d = 0.018m
         = 1.8cm
      or ½ kd2 = ½k × (2.6 × 10–2)2 – ½kd2
      kd2 = ½k × (2.6 × 10–2)2
      d = 0.018m
         = 1.8cm
  1. Most answers were correct.
  2. The majority of answers referred to zero kinetic energy initially with maximum kinetic energy at the lowest point. Candidates should be encouraged to read the question carefully. They were told that, at the lowest point, the mass temporarily comes to rest and thus the kinetic energy must be zero at this point.
    1. For the majority of candidates, this calculation presented few difficulties. Care should always be taken to ensure that, in numerical questions, the values substituted for quantities have consistent units (usually SI units). If the units used are inconsistent then this often leads to a power-of-ten error in the final answer. 
    2. In some scripts, the answer was obtained, quite correctly, using proportionality. The most common approach was to determine a value for the spring constant and then to substitute into the expression E = ½kx2. As in (c)(i), attention should be drawn to the correct use of units to prevent a power-of-ten error.
NO. 119题号：34219
  1. A uniform wire has length L and constant area of cross-section A.
    The material of the wire has Young modulus E and resistivity ρ.
    A tension F in the wire causes its length to increase by ΔL.

    For this wire, state expressions, in terms of L, A, F, ΔL and ρ for
    1. the stress σ,
      .............................................................. [1]
    2. the strain ε,
      .............................................................. [1]
    3. the Young modulus E, 
      ............................................................... [1]
    4. the resistance R.
      ............................................................... [1]
  2. One end of a metal wire of length 2.6 m and constant area of cross-section 3.8 × 10–7 m2 is attached to a fixed point, as shown in Fig. 4.1.
                 
    The Young modulus of the material of the wire is 7.0×1010 Pa and its resistivity is 2.6×10–8 Ω m.
    A load of 30 N is attached to the lower end of the wire. Assume that the area of cross-section of the wire does not change.
    For this load of 30 N,
    1. show that the extension of the wire is 2.9 mm, [1]
    2. calculate the change in resistance of the wire.

      change = ....................................... Ω [2]
  3. The resistance of the wire changes with the applied load.
    Comment on the suggestion that this change of resistance could be used to measure the magnitude of the load on the wire.
    ..................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper2_1/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a.i F / A B1 [1]
a.ii ∆L / L B1 [1]
a.iii allow FL / A∆L B1 [1]
a.iv allow ρL / A  or  ρ (L + ∆L) / A B1 [1]
b.i ∆L = FL / EA
   = (30 × 2.6) / (7.0 × 1010 × 3.8 × 10–7)
   = 2.93 × 10–3 m = 2.93 mm
M1
A0		 [1]
b.ii ∆R = ρ∆L / A
   = (2.6 × 10–8 × 2.93 × 10–3) / (3.8 × 10–7)
   = 2.0 × 10–4 Ω		 C1

A1		 [2]
c change in resistance is (very) small
so method is not appropriate		 M1
A1		 [2]
    1. F / A
    2. ∆L / L
    3. allow FL / A∆L
    4. allow ρL / A    or    ρ (L + ∆L) / A
    1. ∆L = FL / EA
      = (30 × 2.6) / (7.0 × 1010 × 3.8 × 10–7)
      = 2.93 × 10–3 m = 2.93 mm
    2. ∆R = ρ∆L / A
      = (2.6 × 10–8 × 2.93 × 10–3) / (3.8 × 10–7)
      = 2.0 × 10–4 Ω
  3. change in resistance is (very) small
    so method is not appropriate
  1. This part was straightforward and a significant number of candidates were able to give correct expressions for the majority of quantities.
    1. For the majority of candidates who gave the correct expression in (a), this calculation presented few difficulties. The answer being given in the question helped some candidates from making a power-of-ten error.
    2. For the majority of candidates, this calculation caused considerable difficulty. Care should always be taken to ensure that, in numerical questions, the values substituted for quantities have consistent units (usually SI units). If the units used are inconsistent then this often leads to a power-of-ten error in the final answer. 
  3. Many candidates did not realise that the very small change in resistance was a reason why the method was inappropriate. 
NO. 120题号：34215

A straight wire of unstretched length L has an electrical resistance R. When it is stretched by a force F, the wire extends by an amount ∆L and the resistance increases by ∆R. The area of cross-section A of the wire may be assumed to remain constant.

    1. State the relation between R, L, A and the resistivity ρ of the material of the wire.
      ................................................................... [1]
    2. Show that the fractional change in resistance is equal to the strain in the wire. [2]

  2. A steel wire has area of cross-section 1.20×10–7 m2 and a resistance of 4.17 Ω.
    The Young modulus of steel is 2.10×1011 Pa.
    The tension in the wire is increased from zero to 72.0 N. The wire obeys Hooke's law at these values of tension.
    Determine the strain in the wire and hence its change in resistance. Express your answer to an appropriate number of significant figures.

    change = ………………………… Ω [5]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Winter/Paper2/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i R = ρL / A B1 [3]
a.ii strain = ∆L / L
either ∆R = ρ∆L /A  or R ∝ L with ρ and A constant
dividing, ∆R / R = ∆L / L		 B1
B1
A0
b Young modulus = stress / strain
strain = 72.0 / (1.20 × 10-7 × 2.10 × 1011)
     = 2.86 × 10-3  (allow 1/350
∆R = 2.86 × 10-3 × 4.17 = 1.19 × 10-2 Ω
answer given to 3 sig. fig		 C1
C1
A1
A1
B1		 [5]
    1. R = ρL / A
    2. strain = ∆L / L
      either ∆R = ρ∆L /A     or  R ∝ L with ρ and A constant
      dividing, ∆R / R = ∆L / L
  2. Young modulus = stress / strain
    strain = 72.0 / (1.20 × 10-7 × 2.10 × 1011)
              = 2.86 × 10-3 (allow 1/350
    ∆R = 2.86 × 10-3 × 4.17 = 1.19 × 10-2 Ω
    answer given to 3 sig. fig
    1. Most formulae were correct. 
    2. In most answers, a satisfactory definition of strain was given. Candidates did then arrive at the correct conclusion but frequently, explanation was either totally lacking or inadequate. It was common to assume that resistance is proportional to length (or worse still, equal to length!), without giving any indication as to what has to be held constant. 
  2. This was answered well by most candidates although a small number confused stress and strain. Most answers were given appropriately to three significant figures. Interestingly, a significant number did not recognise the connection with the relation they had just derived in (a). Instead, they made laborious calculations to find the new resistance and hence the change in resistance. 
NO. 121题号：34214
  1. A metal wire has an unstretched length L and area of cross-section A. When the wire supports a load F, the wire extends by an amount ∆L. The wire obeys Hooke's law.
    Write down expressions, in terms of L, A, F and ∆L, for
    1. the applied stress, 
      .................................................................................
    2. the tensile strain in the wire, 
      .................................................................................
    3. the Young modulus of the material of the wire. 
      .................................................................................
      [3]
  2. A steel wire of uniform cross-sectional area 7.9×10–7 m2 is heated to a temperature of 650 K. It is then clamped between two rigid supports, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

    The wire is straight but not under tension and the length between the supports is 0.62 m. The wire is then allowed to cool to 300 K.
    When the wire is allowed to contract freely, a 1.00 m length of the wire decreases in length by 0.012 mm for every 1 K decrease in temperature.
    1. Show that the change in length of the wire, if it were allowed to contract as it cools from 650 K to 300 K, would be 2.6 mm. [2]

    2. The Young modulus of steel is 2.0×1011 Pa. Calculate the tension in the wire at 300 K, assuming that the wire obeys Hooke's law.

      tension = …………………………… N [2]
    3. The ultimate tensile stress of steel is 250 MPa. Use this information and your answer in (ii) to suggest whether the wire will, in practice, break as it cools.
      ................................................................... [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2004/Winter/Paper2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i F/A B1 [3]
a.ii ∆L/L B1
a.iii FL/A.∆L B1
b.i ∆L = 0.012 × 0.62 × 350
     = 2.6 mm		 M2
A0		 [2]
b.ii 2.0 × 1011 = (F × 0.62)/(7.9 × 10-7 × 2.6 × 10-3)
F = 660 N		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.iii either stress when cold = 660/(7.9 × 10-7) = 840 MPa
or  tension at uts = 198 N		 M1 [3]
either this is greater than the ultimate tensile stress
or tension at uts is less then tension in (ii)		 A1
the wire will snap A1
(Allow possibility for the two 'A' marks to be scored as long as some quantitative answer – even if incorrect – has been given for the ‘M’ mark)     
    1. F/A
    2. ∆L/L
    3. FL/A.∆L
    1. ∆L = 0.012 × 0.62 × 350 = 2.6 mm
    2. 2.0 × 1011 = (F × 0.62)/(7.9 × 10-7 × 2.6 × 10-3)
      F = 660 N
    3. either stress when cold = 660/(7.9 × 10-7) = 840 MPa
      or tension at uts = 198 N
      either this is greater than the ultimate tensile stress
      or tension at uts is less then tension in (ii)
      the wire will snap
      (Allow possibility for the two 'A' marks to be scored as long as some quantitative answer – even if incorrect – has been given for the 'M' mark)
  1. The expressions were known by most candidates. It was pleasing to note that very few confused stress with strain. 
    1. Most candidates did multiply together the three quantities to obtain the correct result. However, rarely was there a clear argument. Candidates should be encouraged to explain clearly their working, especially where they are asked to 'show' the derivation of a given result. 
    2. There was the usual problem associated with changing the subject of an equation. Apart from this, candidates successfully calculated the tension. 
    3. The problem could be approached by calculating either the stress in the wire (assuming it does not snap) or the tension equivalent to the ultimate tensile stress. There were many correct answers with good valid arguments based on an initial calculation. Some candidates attempted to equate tension with stress and others were confused by the fact that the unit of the Young modulus is the same as that of stress. 

Answers: (b)(ii) 660 N, (iii) wire will snap. 

NO. 122题号：34213

An aluminium wire of length 1.8 m and area of cross-section 1.7 × 10−6 m2 has one end fixed to a rigid support. A small weight hangs from the free end, as illustrated in Fig. 9.1.

The resistance of the wire is 0.030 Ω and the Young modulus of aluminium is 7.1×1010 Pa.

The load on the wire is increased by 25 N.

  1. Calculate
    1. the increase in stress, 

      increase = …………………………………… Pa
    2. the change in length of the wire. 

      change = ……………………………………. m
      [4]
  2. Assuming that the area of cross-section of the wire does not change when the load is increased, determine the change in resistance of the wire.

    change = ……………………………… Ω [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2002/Winter/Paper2/Q9
Question Answer Marks  
a.i stress = F/A
= 25 / (1.7 × 10–6)
= 1.47 × 107 Pa ......(do not allow 1 sig fig)		 C1

A1		 [4]
a.ii stress = E × strain
1.47 × 107 = 7.1 × 1010 × (Δl / 1.8)
Δl = 0.37 mm		 C1

A1
b R = ρl / A     OR   R ∝ L
so, ΔR /R = Δl / l
ΔR = (3.7 × 10–4 / 1.8) × 0.03 = 6.2 × 10–6 Ω		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
May calculate ρ = 2.833 ... × 10–8 Ω m
giving new R as  3.000617 × 10–2 Ω
hence  ΔR - full credit possible

However, if rounds off ρ as 2.83 × 10–8 Ω m
then Rnew  <  Rold!
Allow 1 mark only for R ∝ L		    
    1. stress = F/A
      = 25/ (1.7 × 10-6)
      = 1.47 × 107 Pa ......(do not allow 1 sig fig)
    2. stress = E × strain
      1.47 × 107 = 7.1 × 1010 × (Δl / 1.8)
      Δl = 0.37 mm
  2. R = ρl / A     OR   R ∝ L
    so, ΔR /R = Δl / l
    ΔR = (3.7 × 10-4 / 1.8) × 0.03 = 6.2 × 10-6 Ω

    May calculate ρ = 2.833 ... × 10-8 Ω m
    giving new R as  3.000617 × 10-2 Ω
    hence  ΔR - full credit possible

    However, if rounds off ρ as 2.83 × 10-8 Ω m
    then Rnew  <  Rold!
    Allow 1 mark only for R ∝ L
  1. Candidates who knew expressions for stress, strain and the Young modulus had little difficulty with these calculations, most errors being algebraic or arithmetical. However, a significant number of answers indicated a lack of knowledge of this topic.
  2. Most candidates who attempted this calculation did give an expression for resistivity but very few went on to give a correct solution using simple proportion. The majority calculated a value for the resistivity. However, when they then found the final resistance, they used insufficient significant figures in the value for the resistivity, resulting in an apparent decrease in resistance for the stretched wire. Candidates who 'carried' the value in their calculators frequently arrived at the correct result.
NO. 123题号：34212
  1. Define
    1. stress,
      .................................................................................. [1]
    2. strain.
      .................................................................................. [1]
  2. The Young modulus of the metal of a wire is 0.17 TPa. The cross-sectional area of the wire is 0.18 mm2.
    The wire is extended by a force F. This causes the length of the wire to be increased by 0.095 %.
    Calculate
    1. the stress, 

      stress = ............................................ Pa [4]
    2. the force F. 

      F = ............................................. N [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_3/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a.i stress = force / cross-sectional area B1 [1] 
a.ii strain = extension / original length B1 [1] 
b.i E = stress / strain
E = 0.17 × 1012
stress = 0.17 × 1012 × 0.095 / 100
   = 1.6(2) × 108 Pa		 C1
C1
C1
A1		 [4] 
b.ii force = (stress × area) = 1.615 × 108 × 0.18 × 10–6
   = 29(.1)N		 C1
A1		 [2]
    1. stress = force / cross-sectional area
    2. strain = extension / original length
    1. E = stress / strain
      E = 0.17 × 1012
      stress = 0.17 × 1012 × 0.095 / 100 = 1.6(2) × 108 Pa
    2. force = (stress × area) = 1.615 × 108 × 0.18 × 10–6 = 29(.1) N
    1. The definition was generally given correctly. The detail of the cross-sectional area is a requirement for the definition.
    2. The definition was generally given correctly. The detail of the original length is a requirement for the definition.
    1. There were many correct solutions. A significant number of candidates were unable to determine the strain from the information given. The Young modulus was also used with an incorrect power of ten.
    2. A significant number of candidates gained full marks owing to the application of error carried forward from (i). The conversion from mm2 to m2 for the area caused problems for some candidates.
NO. 124题号：34211

Energy is stored in a metal wire that is extended elastically.

  1. Explain what is meant by extended elastically.
    ................................................................................ [2]
  2. Show that the SІ units of energy per unit volume are kg m–1 s–2. [2]

  3. For a wire extended elastically, the elastic energy per unit volume X is given by
                X = Cε2E
    where C is a constant,
             ε is the strain of the wire,
    and E is the Young modulus of the wire.

    Show that C has no units. [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_1/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a the wire returns to its original length (not 'shape')
when the load is removed		 M1
A1		 [2]
b energy: N m / kg m2 s–2 and volume m3
energy / volume: kgm2s–2 / m3
energy / volume: kgm–1 s–2		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
c ε has no units
E: kg m s–2 m–2
units of RHS: kgm–1 s–2 = LHS units / satisfactory conclusion to show C has no units		 B1
M1
A1		 [3]
  1. the wire returns to its original length (not 'shape')
    when the load is removed
  2. energy: N m / kg m2 s–2 and volume m3
    energy / volume: kgm2s–2 / m3
    energy / volume: kgm–1 s–2
  3. ε has no units
    E: kg m s–2 m–2
    units of RHS: kgm–1 s–2 = LHS units / satisfactory conclusion to show C has no units
  1. A common answer was based on extension being proportional to force. Reference should have been made to the wire returning to its original length on removal of the load. Candidates often used imprecise or unsuitable terms such as "size", "shape", "position" and "state".
  2. The final expression for the SI units of energy per unit volume was given. Many candidates did derive the units of energy. Others lost credit by just giving an expression for the units of energy, without any explanation. In "show that" questions candidates should be advised that full details of the procedure are vital. 
  3. This proof required that candidates should derive the units for the Young modulus and also state that strain has no unit. A common error was to quite correctly state that strain is the ratio of extension and original length but then to go on to give the unit of strain as '0' or '1'. 
NO. 125题号：34210
  1. Define the Young modulus.
    ..........................................................................[1]
  2. A load F is suspended from a fixed point by a steel wire. The variation with extension x of F for the wire is shown in Fig. 5.1.

    1. State two quantities, other than the gradient of the graph in Fig, that are required in order to determine the Young modulus of steel.
      1. ....................................................................
      2. .................................................................... [1]
    2. Describe how the quantities you listed in (i) may be measured.
      ..........................................................................[2]
    3. A load of 3.0 N is applied to the wire. Use Fig. 5.1 to calculate the energy stored in the wire.

      energy = .............................................. J [2]
  3. A copper wire has the same original dimensions as the steel wire. The Young modulus for steel is 2.2×1011 Nm–2 and for copper is 1.1×1011 Nm–2.
    On Fig. 5.1, sketch the variation with x of F for the copper wire for extensions up to 0.25 mm. The copper wire is not extended beyond its limit of proportionality. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a E = stress / strain B1 [1]
b.i 1. diameter / cross sectional area / radius
2. original length		 B1 [1]
b.ii measure original length with a metre ruler / tape
measure the diameter with micrometer (screw gauge)
allow digital vernier calipers		 B1
B1

 [2]
b.iii energy = ½ Fe or area under graph or ½ kx2
            = ½ × 0.25 × 10–3 × 3 = 3.8 × 10–4 J		 C1
A1		 [2]
c straight line through origin below original line
line through (0.25, 1.5)		 M1
A1		 [2]
  1. E = stress / strain
    1. 1. diameter / cross sectional area / radius
      2. original length
    2. measure original length with a metre ruler / tape
      measure the diameter with micrometer (screw gauge)
      allow digital vernier calipers
    3. energy = ½ Fe or area under graph or ½ kx2
      = ½ × 0.25 × 10–3 × 3 = 3.8 × 10–4 J
  3. straight line through origin below original line
    line through (0.25, 1.5)

A large number of candidates answered this question well.

  1. The majority of candidates gave correct definitions here.
    1. A significant number of candidates gave both required quantities. Candidates should be encouraged to give full descriptions of quantities to be measured. In this case the quantities required the 'original' length and the 'cross-sectional' area.
    2. This was generally well answered. Some credit was lost by candidates who suggested that a micrometer screw gauge could be used to measure the radius or cross-sectional area of the wire. Some answers described the use of a ruler for the original length but this was considered to be too vague.
    3. Many candidates answered this well. Errors were made by not converting the extension, from the reading on the graph, from millimetres to metres. A minority of candidates used the expression for work done as the product of force and extension rather than the product of the average force and extension. 
  3. A large number of candidates did not recognise that a wire of the same dimensions but with a lower Young modulus value would extend more easily than the steel wire, and hence less force would be needed to produce the same extension. A small number of candidates disadvantaged themselves by drawing their own diagram, rather than drawing their answer on Fig. 5.1 as instructed in the question. 
NO. 126题号：34209

One end of a spring is fixed to a support. A mass is attached to the other end of the spring.
The arrangement is shown in Fig. 3.1.

  1. The mass is in equilibrium. Explain, by reference to the forces acting on the mass, what is meant by equilibrium.
    ..............................................................................[2]
  2. The mass is pulled down and then released at time t = 0. The mass oscillates up and down. The variation with t of the displacement of the mass d is shown in Fig. 3.2.

    Use Fig. 3.2 to state a time, one in each case, when
    1. the mass is at maximum speed,

      time = .............................................. s [1]
    2. the elastic potential energy stored in the spring is a maximum, 

      time = .............................................. s [1]
    3. the mass is in equilibrium. 

      time = .............................................. s [1]
  3. The arrangement shown in Fig. 3.3 is used to determine the length l of a spring when different masses M are attached to the spring.
             
    The variation with mass M of l is shown in Fig. 3.4.
    1. State and explain whether the spring obeys Hooke's law.
      ..........................................................................[2]
    2. Show that the force constant of the spring is 26 N m–1. [2]

    3. A mass of 0.40 kg is attached to the spring. Calculate the energy stored in the spring. 

      energy = .............................................. J [3]

Q3/9702/21/M/J/12

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_1/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a Resultant force (and resultant torque) is zero
Weight (down) = force from/due to spring (up)		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.i 0.2, 0.6, 1.0s (one of these) A1 [1]
b.ii 0, 0.8s (one of these) A1 [1]
b.iii 0.2, 0.6, 1.0s (one of these) A1 [1]
c.i Hooke's law: extension is proportional to the force (not mass)
Linear/straight line graph hence obeys Hooke's law		 B1
B1		 [2]
c.ii Use of the gradient (not just F = kx)
K = (0.4 × 9.8) / 15 × 10–2
   = 26(.1) Nm–1		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
c.iii either  energy = area to left of line or energy = ½ ke2
= ½ × [(0.4 × 9.8) / 15 × 10–2] × (15 × 10–2)2 
= 0.294 J (allow 2 s.f.)		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
  1. Resultant force (and resultant torque) is zero
    Weight (down) = force from/due to spring (up)
    1. 0.2, 0.6, 1.0s (one of these)
    2. 0, 0.8s (one of these)
    3. 0.2, 0.6, 1.0s (one of these)
    1. Hooke’s law: extension is proportional to the force (not mass)
      Linear/straight line graph hence obeys Hooke’s law
    2. Use of the gradient (not just F = kx)
      K = (0.4 × 9.8) / 15 × 10–2
          = 26(.1) Nm–1
    3. either energy = area to left of line or energy = ½ ke2
      = ½ × [(0.4 × 9.8) / 15 × 10–2] × (15 × 10–2)2
      = 0.294 J (allow 2 s.f.)
  1. Most candidates gave a general statement regarding forces in equilibrium. Very few then went on to refer to the forces acting on the mass. Candidates should be able to distinguish between tension in the spring and the force on the mass due to the spring.
  2. There were a few candidates who gave correct answers for all three parts. However, many answers indicated a lack of understanding when trying to interpret the graph. A common error was to give the time for maximum speed as 0.40 s. 
    1. There were many appropriate statements of Hooke’s law, although few correctly related the law to the graph in Fig. 3.4. A common misunderstanding was to state that mass is proportional to length, thus satisfying the law. 
    2. In most cases, the gradient of the graph was used with few attempting a 'one point' solution. A significant number of candidates took the value of g to be 10ms–2 and then made no comment as to why they had not obtained the value given for the force constant. Candidates should be advised always to use the data provided in the question paper. 
    3. The majority of candidates gave a correct expression for stored energy (½kx2 or ½Fx), but many then assumed that x was the length of the spring rather than its extension. 
NO. 127题号：34208
  1. State Hooke's Law.
    ...............................................................................[1]
  2. A spring is compressed by applying a force. The variation with compression x of the force F is shown in Fig. 4.1.

    1. Calculate the spring constant. 

      spring constant = ....................................... N m–1 [1]
    2. Show that the work done in compressing the spring by 36 mm is 0.81 J. [2]

  3. A child's toy uses the spring in (b) to shoot a small ball vertically upwards. The ball has a mass of 25 g. The toy is shown in Fig. 4.2.

    1. The spring in the toy is compressed by 36 mm. The spring is released.
      Assume all the strain energy in the spring is converted to kinetic energy of the ball.
      Using the result in (b)(ii), calculate the speed with which the ball leaves the spring.

      speed = ........................................ m s–1 [2]
    2. Determine the compression of the spring required for the ball to leave the spring with twice the speed determined in (i).

      compression = .......................................... mm [2]
    3. Determine the ratio 

      ratio = ................................................ [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper2_3/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a force is proportional to extension B1 [1]
b.i gradient of graph determined (e.g. 50 / 40 ×10–3) = 1250 Nm–1 A1 [1]
b.ii W = ½ k x2  or W = ½ final force × extension
   = 0.5 × 1250 × (36 × 10–3)2  or 0.5 × 45 × 36 × 10–3
   = 0.81 J		 M1
M1
A0		 [2]
c.i 0.81 = ½ mv2
v = 8.0 (8.0498) ms–1		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.ii 4 × KE / 4 × WD or 3.24 J
hence twice the compression = 72 mm		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.iii Max height is when all KE or WD
or elastic PE is converted to GPE
ratio = 1/4 or 0.25
C1
A1		 [2]
  1. force is proportional to extension
    1. gradient of graph determined (e.g. 50 / 40 ×10–3 ) = 1250 Nm–1
    2. W = ½ k x2   or W = ½ final force × extension
      = 0.5 × 1250 × (36 × 10–3)2   or 0.5 × 45 × 36 × 10–3
      = 0.81 J
    1. 0.81 = ½ mv2
      v = 8.0 (8.0498) ms–1
    2. 4 × KE / 4 × WD or 3.24 J
      hence twice the compression = 72 mm
    3. Max height is when all KE or WD
      or elastic PE is converted to GPE
      ratio = 1/4 or 0.25
  1. A significant number of candidates were unable to state Hooke's law correctly. Candidates should be advised that a relationship involving symbols is not given any credit unless the symbols are defined.
    1. There were a significant number of candidates who obtained an appropriate value for the spring constant. There are two main methods that could improve the answers obtained by candidates. The compression on the graph was given in millimetres. Candidates should be advised to convert to metres in the calculation for the spring constant. The coordinates used from the graph need to be read accurately. Candidates should select points from the line that are easy to read from the axes. 
    2. The value given for the work done enabled a significant number of candidates to show the correct working. There were a significant number of candidates who clearly changed the presentation of their working to fit the required answer. In general the method for obtaining the work done compressing a spring was not known by many of the candidates. 
    1. The majority of candidates knew the expression for the kinetic energy and correctly calculated the speed of the ball. Very few candidates did not convert the mass from grams into kilograms.  
    2. The more able candidates correctly determined the compression needed to give the increased speed. The majority of candidates were not able to relate the increased speed with the correct increase in kinetic energy and hence work done on the spring. 
    3. The ratio was correctly calculated by the candidates with high ability. There were a significant number of well-presented answers from these candidates. 
NO. 128题号：34205
  1. Tensile forces are applied to opposite ends of a copper rod so that the rod is stretched.
    The variation with stress of the strain of the rod is shown in Fig.5.1.

    1. Use Fig.5.1 to determine the Young modulus of copper.

      Young modulus = .......................................... Pa  [3]

  2. The walls of the tyres on a car are made of a rubber compound.
    The variation with stress of the strain of a specimen of this rubber compound is shown in Fig.5.2.
                
    As the car moves, the walls of the tyres bend and straighten continuously.
    Use Fig.5.2 to explain why the walls of the tyres become warm.
    ............................................................................[3]

A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper2_2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i Young modulus = stress/strain
data chosen using point in linear region of graph
Young modulus = (2.1 × 108)/(1.9 × 10–3) 
= 1.1 × 1011 Pa		 C1
M1

A1		 [3]
a.ii This mark was removed from the assessment, owing to a power-of-ten inconsistency in the printed question paper. 1 [1]
b area between lines represents energy/area under curve represents energy M1 [3]
when rubber is stretched and then released/two areas are different  A1
this energy seen as thermal energy/heating/difference represents energy released as heat A1
    1. Young modulus = stress/strain
      data chosen using point in linear region of graph
      Young modulus = (2.1 × 108)/(1.9 × 10–3)
      = 1.1 × 1011 Pa
    2. This mark was removed from the assessment, owing to a power-of-ten inconsistency in the printed question paper.
  2. area between lines represents energy/area under curve represents energy
    when rubber is stretched and then released/two areas are different
    this energy seen as thermal energy/heating/difference represents energy released as heat
    1. The majority of candidates obtained full marks for this part. The majority read the scales on the graph correctly. The weaker candidates either went beyond the linear part of the graph or made errors with the powers of ten.
    2. This mark was removed from the assessment, owing to a power-of-ten inconsistency in the printed question paper.
  2. Very few candidates answered the question fully as no reference was made to the graph in their explanations. The failure to read the question meant that a large number of good candidates were unable to gain any credit.
NO. 129题号：34201

A spring is placed on a flat surface and different weights are placed on it, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

The variation with weight of the compression of the spring is shown in Fig. 2.2.

The elastic limit of the spring has not been exceeded.

    1. Determine the spring constant k of the spring.

      k = ........................................... N m–1
    2. Deduce that the strain energy stored in the spring is 0.49 J for a compression of 3.5 cm. [2]

  2. Two trolleys, of masses 800 g and 2400 g, are free to move on a horizontal table. The spring in (a) is placed between the trolleys and the trolleys are tied together using thread so that the compression of the spring is 3.5 cm, as shown in Fig. 2.3.

    Initially, the trolleys are not moving.
    The thread is then cut and the trolleys move apart.
    1. Deduce that the ratio is equal to 3.0. [2]

    2. Use the answers in (a)(ii) and (b)(i) to calculate the speed of the trolley of mass 800 g.

      speed = ........................................... m s–1 [3]

Q2/9702/02/M/J/08

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2008/Summer/Paper2/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a.i k is the reciprocal of the gradient of the graph
k = {32 / (4 × 10–2) = } 800 N m–1		 C1
A1		 [2]
a.ii either  energy = average force × extension  or  ½kx2
or  area under graph line
energy = ½ × 800 × (3.5 × 10–2)2  or  ½ × 28 × 3.5 × 10–2
energy = 0.49 J
C1
M1
A0		 [2]
b.i momentum before cutting thread = momentum after
0 = 2400 × V – 800 × v
v / V = 3.0		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
b.ii energy stored in spring = kinetic energy of trolleys
0.49 = ½ × 2.4 × (v)2 + ½ × 0.8 × v2
v = 0.96 m s–1
(if only one trolley considered, or masses combined, allow max 1 mark)		 C1
C1
A1

 [3]
    1. k is the reciprocal of the gradient of the graph
      k = {32 / (4 × 10–2) = } 800 N m–1
    2. either energy = average force × extension or ½kx2
      or area under graph line
      energy = ½ × 800 × (3.5 × 10–2)2  or ½ × 28 × 3.5 × 10–2
      energy = 0.49 J
    1. momentum before cutting thread = momentum after
      0 = 2400 × V – 800 × v
      v / V = 3.0 
    2. energy stored in spring = kinetic energy of trolleys
      0.49 = ½ × 2.4 × ( 1/3 v)2 + ½ × 0.8 × v2
      v = 0.96 m s–1
      (if only one trolley considered, or masses combined, allow max 1 mark)
NO. 130题号：34200

Fig. 5.1 shows the variation with force F of the extension x of a spring as the force is increased to F3 and then decreased to zero.

  1. State, with a reason, whether the spring is undergoing an elastic change.
    ..................................................................................... [1]
  2. The extension of the spring is increased from x1 to x2.
    Show that the work W done in extending the spring is given by
            W = ½k(x22 – x12),
    where k is the spring constant. [3]

  3. A trolley of mass 850 g is held between two fixed points by means of identical springs, as shown in Fig. 5.2.

    When the trolley is in equilibrium, the springs are each extended by 4.5 cm. Each spring has a spring constant 16 N cm–1.
    The trolley is moved a distance of 1.5 cm along the direction of the springs. This causes the extension of one spring to be increased and the extension of the other spring to be decreased. The trolley is then released. The trolley accelerates and reaches its maximum speed at the equilibrium position.
    Assuming that the springs obey Hooke’s law, use the expression in (b) to determine the maximum speed of the trolley.

    speed = …………………………. m s–1 [4]

Q5/9702/02/M/J/06

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Summer/Paper2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a no hysteresis loop/no permanent deformation
(do not allow 'force proportional to extension')
so elastic change		 M1

A0		 [1]
b work done = area under graph line OR average force × distance
                  = ½Fx      ½(F2 + F1)(x2 – x1)
F = kx, so work done = = ½kx2    ½k(x2 + x1)(x2 – x1)
work done = ½k(x22 – x12)		 B1
A1
A1
A0		 [3]
c gain in energy of trolley = ½k(0.0602 – 0.0452) + ½k(0.0302 – 0.0452)
                                       = 0.36 J
kinetic energy = ½ × 0.85 × v2 = 0.36
v = 0.92 m s–1		 C1
C1
C1
A1		 [4]
  1. no hysteresis loop/no permanent deformation
    (do not allow ‘force proportional to extension’)
    so elastic change
  2. work done = area under graph line OR average force × distance
    = ½Fx            ½(F2 + F1)(x2 – x1)
    F = kx, so work done = = ½kx2       ½k(x2 + x1)(x2 – x1)
    work done = ½k(x22 – x12)
  3. gain in energy of trolley = ½k(0.0602 – 0.0452) + ½k(0.0302 – 0.0452) = 0.36 J
    kinetic energy = ½ × 0.85 × v2 = 0.36
    v = 0.92 m s–1
  1. Many candidates failed to make it clear that the evidence for an elastic change is that there is zero extension when the load is removed. The most common answer was 'the graph is a straight line'.
  2. There were some well-explained answers that showed every step clearly. However, it was not uncommon to find attempts that lacked logical argument. Symbols changed without explanation. For example, x became Δx or (x2 – x1) and, even more frequently, (x2 – x1)2 became (x22 – x12). There were many answers that included appropriate algebra but lacked a clear indication of an understanding of the underlying physics.
  3. Very few candidates were able to calculate the total energy stored in the springs. Having been instructed to use the expression in (b), many did not realise that the trolley is controlled by two springs but the formula in (b) is for one spring only. Consequently, most solutions began by substitution into the expression in (b), with a variety of numbers used for x2 and x1. However, most candidates did calculate an energy and then equated this energy to the maximum kinetic energy of the trolley.
NO. 131题号：34198
  1. Fig. 3.1 shows the variation with tensile force of the extension of a copper wire. [3]

    1. State whether copper is a ductile, brittle or polymeric material.
    2. 1. On Fig. 3.1, mark with the letter L the point on the line beyond which Hooke's law does not apply.
      2. State how the spring constant for the wire may be obtained from Fig. 3.1.
  2. A copper wire is fixed at one end and passes over a pulley. A mass hangs from the free end of the wire, as shown in Fig. 3.2. 

    The length of wire between the fixed end and the pulley is 2.5 m. When the mass on the wire is increased by 6.0 kg, a pointer attached to the pulley rotates through an angle of 6.5°. The pulley, of diameter 3.0 cm, is rough so that the wire does not slide over it.
    1. For this increase in mass,
      1. show that the wire extends by 0.17 cm,

      2. calculate the increase in strain of the wire.

         increase in strain =…………..  [4]
    2. The area of cross-section of the wire is 7.9 × 10-7 m2.
      Calculate the increase in stress produced by the increase in load.

      increase in stress = .............................. Pa  [3]
    3. Use your answers to (i) 2 and (ii) to determine the Young modulus of copper.

      Young modulus = ..................... Pa  [3]
    4. Suggest how you could check that the elastic limit of the wire is not exceeded when the extra load is added. [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2003/Summer/Paper2/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a.i ductile B1 [3]
a.ii.1 L shown at end of straight line B1
a.ii.2 reciprocal of gradient of straight line region B1
b.i.1 circumference = 3π cm  or arc = rθ.
extension = (6.5/360) × 3π   = 1.5 sin (or tan) 6.5
                = 0.17 cm		 C1
M1
A0		 [4]
b.i.2 strain = extension/length
         = 0.17/250
         = 6.8 × 10–4		 C1

A1
b.ii stress = force/area
          = (6.0 × 9.8)/(7.9 × 10-7)
          = 7.44 × 107 Pa		 C1 
C1 
A1		 [3]
b.iii Young modulus = stress/strain
                          = (7.44 × 107)/(6.8 × 10-4)
                          = 1.1 × 1011 Pa		 C1

A1		 [2]
b.iv remove extra load and see if pointer returns to original position or wire returns to original length B1 [1]
    1. 1. L shown at end of straight line
      2. reciprocal of gradient of straight line region
    1. 1. circumference = 3π cm    or arc = rθ.
          extension = (6.5/360) × 3π
          = 1.5 sin (or tan) 6.5
          = 0.17 cm
      2. strain = extension/length
          = 0.17/250
          = 6.8 × 10-4
    2. stress = force/area
      = (6.0 × 9.8)/(7.9 × 10-7) 
      = 7.44 × 107 Pa
    3. Young modulus = stress/strain
      = (7.44 × 107)/(6.8 × 10-4)
      = 1.1 × 1011 Pa
    4. remove extra load and see if pointer returns to original position or wire returns to original length
    1. With very few exceptions, candidates recognised that the graph is for a ductile material.
    2. Most did mark the point L at the end of the straight-line portion of the graph. Although most did associate the spring constant with the gradient of the graph, they frequently failed to state explicitly that it is the inverse of the gradient of the straight-line region.
  2. Those candidates who realised that they needed to find the length of that part of the circumference of the pulley that subtends an angle of 6.5° at the centre had little difficulty with the derivation. A significant number of candidates did not attempt an answer.
    The three calculations presented very few problems for those candidates who knew the relevant formulae. The most common error was confusion over units, though some did confuse mass and weight when calculating the stress. Most candidates correctly checked that the elastic limit had not been exceeded by removing the additional load and checking that the wire had returned to its original length.
NO. 132题号：34177
  1. Define pressure.
    ......................................................................... [1]
  2. Use the kinetic model to explain the pressure exerted by a gas.
    ......................................................................... [4]
  3. Explain whether the collisions between the molecules of an ideal gas are elastic or inelastic.
    ......................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_1/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a pressure = force / area (normal to force) A1 [1]
b molecules/atoms/particles in (constant) random/haphazard motion
molecules have a change in momentum when they collide with the walls
(force exerted on molecules) therefore force on the walls
reference to average force from many molecules/many collisions		 B1
M1
A1
A1		 [4]
c elastic collision when kinetic energy conserved
temperature constant for gas		 B1
B1		 [2]
  1. pressure = force / area (normal to force)
  2. molecules/atoms/particles in (constant) random/haphazard motion
    molecules have a change in momentum when they collide with the walls
    (force exerted on molecules) therefore force on the walls
    reference to average force from many molecules/many collisions
  3. elastic collision when kinetic energy conserved
    temperature constant for gas
  1. When defining pressure, a statement of the ratio is essential. The use of the unclear term "force over area" should be discouraged.  
  2. Many answers lost credit by being too simplistic, being based on a statement that the molecules collide with the walls, producing a force/pressure. It was expected that reference would be made to the random nature of the motion of the gas molecules – not a random motion of the gas. Any discussion of force/impulse should have been preceded by a reference to momentum change. Finally, the averaging of the force/impulse from many collisions to give pressure should have been included.
  3. Most answers were confined to a statement as to what is meant by elastic collisions. Some described elastic collisions as where there is energy conservation instead of kinetic energy conservation. Very few realised that the consequence of elastic collisions is that the temperature of the gas does not change. 
NO. 133题号：34176
  1. Show that the pressure P due to a liquid of density ρ is proportional to the depth h below the surface of the liquid. [4]

  2. The pressure of the air at the top of a mountain is less than that at the foot of the mountain. Explain why the difference in air pressure is not proportional to the difference in height as suggested by the relationship in (a).
    ...............................................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_3/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a V = h × A
m = V × ρ
W = h × A × ρ × g
P = F / A
P = hρg
P is proportional to h if ρ is constant (and g)
B1
B1
B1

B1		 [4]
b density changes with height
hence density is not constant with link to formula		 B1
B1		 [2]
  1. V = h × A
    m = V × ρ
    W = h × A × ρ × g
    P = F / A
    P = hρg
    P is proportional to h if ρ is constant (and g)
  2. density changes with height
    hence density is not constant with link to formula
  1. Most candidates correctly stated the definitions of pressure and density. Well prepared candidates were able to link these two definitions and obtain an expression for the pressure in terms of the depth h in a liquid. Only a small minority went on to explain that the density had to be constant for the relationship between pressure and depth to be proportional.
  2. A small number of candidates recognised that the density of air is less at the top of a mountain. Very few candidates recognised the connection between the density not being constant and the effect on the relationship given in (a).
NO. 134题号：34174
  1. State two assumptions of the simple kinetic model of a gas.
    1. .............................................................................
    2. ............................................................................. [2]
  2. Use the kinetic model of gases and Newton's laws of motion to explain how a gas exerts a pressure on the sides of its container.
    ................................................................................. [3]

Q6/9702/21/M/J/11

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper2_1/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a any two of:
 large number of molecules / atoms / particles
 molecules in random motion
 no intermolecular forces
 elastic collisions
 time of collisions much less than time between collisions
 volume of molecules much less than volume of containing vessel		 B1 + B1 [2]
b molecules collide with the walls
change in momentum of molecules implies force (on molecules)
molecules exert equal and opposite force on wall
pressure is averaging effect of many collisions
(any three statements, 1 each)		 B3 [3]
  1. any two of:
    large number of molecules / atoms / particles
    molecules in random motion
    no intermolecular forces
    elastic collisions
    time of collisions much less than time between collisions
    volume of molecules much less than volume of containing vessel
  2. molecules collide with the walls
    change in momentum of molecules implies force (on molecules)
    molecules exert equal and opposite force on wall
    pressure is averaging effect of many collisions
    (any three statements, 1 each)
  1. Candidates should make reference to the atoms/molecules/particles of the gas. In many answers, it was the gas itself that was said to be in random motion. A common misconception was that the mass of the atoms is negligible. 
  2. Very few candidates were able to progress beyond a statement that the gas atoms would collide with the walls of the containing vessel. It was expected that this statement would be followed by an argument based on the change in momentum of the atom being caused by a force exerted by the wall on the atom and that there would be an equal but opposite force exerted by the atom on the wall. Many such collisions per unit time would average out to give a steady force/pressure. 
NO. 135题号：34170
  1. Explain what is meant by the internal energy of a substance.
    ....................................................................................... [2]
  2. State and explain, in molecular terms, whether the internal energy of the following increases, decreases or does not change.
    1. a lump of iron as it cooled
      ....................................................................................... [3]
    2. some water as it evaporates at constant temperature
      ....................................................................................... [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Summer/Paper2/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a sum of (random) kinetic and potential energies
of the atoms/molecules of the substance		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i potential energy unchanged as atoms remain in same positions
allow 'reduced because atoms slightly closer together' 
vibrational kinetic energy reduced because temperature lower
so internal energy less		 M1

M1
A1		 [3]
b.ii potential energy increases because separation increases
kinetic energy unchanged because temperature unchanged
so internal energy increases		 M1
M1
A1		 [3]
  1. sum of (rendom) kinetic end potential energies
    of the atoms/molecules of the substance
    1. potential energy unchanged as atoms remain in same positions
      allow 'reduced beceuse atoms sliqhtly closer together'
      vibrational kinetic energy reduced because temperature lower 
      so intemal energy less
    2. potential energy increases because separation increases 
      kinetic energy unchanged because temperature unchanged
      so internal energy increases
  1. Potential and kinetic energy were mentioned in most answers. However, frequently it was not made clear that it is the sum total of the random kinetic and potential energies of the atoms or molecules of the substance that constitute its internal energy.
    1. Most candidates referred to a reduction in kinetic energy of the molecules but 'reduced speed' was frequently given as the explanation, rather than a decrease in temperature. Potential energy was usually ignored.
    2. In general, this was poorly answered partly because candidates were unable to accept that the evaporation takes place at constant temperature. They insisted that the mean kinetic energy of the water would decrease because 'faster molecules would escape'. The large majority of candidates either ignored potential energy or stated that it would remain constant, clearly ignoring the fact that the evaporated water is still part of the system. Those who did include potential energy frequently implied that the energy increases because the vapour rises. 
NO. 136题号：34150
  1. Define the terms
    1. power,
      ..................................................................... [1]
    2. the Young modulus. 
      ...................................................................... [1]
  2. A crane is used to lift heavy objects, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

    The motor in the crane lifts a total mass of 1800 kg from rest on the ground. The cable supporting the mass is made of steel of Young modulus 2.4×1011 Pa. The cross-sectional area of the cable is 1.3×10– 4 m2. As the mass leaves the ground, the strain in the cable is 0.0010. Assume the weight of the cable to be negligible.
    1. 1. Use the Young Modulus of the steel to show that the tension in the cable is 3.1×104 N. [2]

      2. Calculate the acceleration of the mass as it is lifted from the ground.

      acceleration = .................................. m s–2 [3]
    2. The motor now lifts the mass through a height of 15 m at a constant speed.
      Calculate
      1. the tension in the lifting cable,

         tension = ....................................... N [1]
      2. the gain in potential energy of the mass.

         gain in potential energy = ............................... J [2]
    3. The motor of the crane is 30% efficient. Calculate the input power to the motor required to lift the mass at a constant speed of 0.55 m s–1.

      input power = ...................................... W [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper2_3/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a.i power = work done per unit time / energy transferred per unit time / rate of work done B1 [1]
a.ii Young modulus = stress / strain B1 [1]
b.i 1. E = T / (A × strain) (allow strain = ε)
 T = E × A × strain = 2.4 × 1011 × 1.3 × 10–4 × 0.001
   = 3.12 × 104N		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
2. T – W = ma
  [3.12 × 104 – 1800 × 9.81] = 1800a
  a = 7.52 ms–2		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
b.ii 1. T = 1800 × 9.81 = 1.8 × 104N A1 [1]
2. potential energy gain = mgh
  = 1800 × 9.81 × 15
  = 2.7 × 105 J		 C1

A1		 [2]
b.iii P = Fv
  = 1800 × 9.81 × 0.55
input power = 9712 × (100/30) = 32.4 × 103W		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
    1. power = work done per unit time / energy transferred per unit time / rate of work done
    2. Young modulus = stress / strain
    1. 1. E = T / (A × strain) (allow strain = ε)
          T = E × A × strain = 2.4 × 1011 × 1.3 × 10–4 × 0.001
            = 3.12 × 104 N
      2. T – W = ma
          [3.12 × 104 – 1800 × 9.81] = 1800a
          a = 7.52 ms–2
    2. 1. T = 1800 × 9.81 = 1.8 × 104 N
      2. potential energy gain = mgh
          = 1800 × 9.81 × 15
          = 2.7 × 105 J
    3. P = Fv
         = 1800 × 9.81 × 0.55
      input power = 9712 × (100/30) = 32.4 × 103 W
    1. Generally, definitions were satisfactory. Candidates should be advised that power involves a transfer of energy and, therefore, defining power as being 'energy/time' is not sufficient. 
    2. With few exceptions, definitions were satisfactory. 
    1. 1. Candidates should be advised to show all working clearly, especially where they are asked to derive a given quantity. In a significant number of answers, it was not possible to decide whether the factor of 0.0010 had been written in the numerator or in the denominator of the stated expression. 
      2. The use of g = 10ms–2 should be discouraged. The data supplied in the question paper should be employed. A significant minority gave an answer of 17.2 ms–2 because the candidate had not made allowance for the weight of the load. 
    2. 1. Although there were many correct answers, it was not uncommon to find that the tension was assumed to be that when the weight was accelerating.
      2. The calculation of the gain in potential energy presented very few problems.
    3. Most candidates did use the expression P = Fv. Some then confused this power with the input power. A significant minority calculated the kinetic energy of the mass and then used this in an expression for power. This kinetic energy did not represent any change in energy. 
NO. 137题号：34149
  1. Distinguish between gravitational potential energy and electric potential energy.
    .................................................................... [2]
  2. A body of mass m moves vertically through a distance h near the Earth's surface. Use the defining equation for work done to derive an expression for the gravitational potential energy change of the body. [2]

  3. Water flows down a stream from a reservoir and then causes a water wheel to rotate, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

    As the water falls through a vertical height of 120 m, gravitational potential energy is converted to different forms of energy, including kinetic energy of the water. At the water wheel, the kinetic energy of the water is only 10% of its gravitational potential energy at the reservoir.
    1. Show that the speed of the water as it reaches the wheel is 15 m s–1. [2]

    2. The rotating water wheel is used to produce 110 kW of electrical power. Calculate the mass of water flowing per second through the wheel, assuming that the production of electric energy from the kinetic energy of the water is 25% efficient.

      mass of water per second = ......................... kg s–1 [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper2_1/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a electrical potential energy (stored) when charge moved and gravitational potential energy (stored) when mass moved
due to work done in electric field and work done in gravitational field		 B1
B1		 [2]
b work done = force × distance moved (in direction of force)
and force = mg
mg × h or mg × ∆h
M1
A1		 [2]
c.i 0.1 × mgh = ½ mv2
0.1 × m × 9.81 × 120 = 0.5 × m × v2
v = 15.3ms–1		 B1
B1
A0		 [2]
c.ii P = 0.5 m v2 / t
m / t = 110 × 103 / [0.25 × 0.5 × (15.3)2]
        = 3740 kg s–1		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
  1. electrical potential energy (stored) when charge moved and gravitational potential energy (stored) when mass moved
    due to work done in electric field and work done in gravitational field
  2. work done = force × distance moved (in direction of force) and force = mg
    mg × h or mg × ∆h
    1. 0.1 × mgh = ½ mv2
      0.1 × m × 9.81 × 120 = 0.5 × m × v2
      v = 15.3 ms–1
    2. P = 0.5 m v2 / t
      m / t = 110 × 103 / [0.25 × 0.5 × (15.3)2]
            = 3740 kgs–1
  1. The majority of candidates were unable to explain the difference between the two types of potential energy. It was expected that candidates should know that the key elements for the different potential energies were mass and charge. 
  2. The derivations often lacked any explanation. Candidates should be encouraged to give solutions with an explanation of the symbols used and a statement between each step. 
    1. There were a number of good solutions. A significant number of candidates found difficulty with the calculation involving a percentage. 
    2. Very few candidates obtained the correct answer. Again the efficiency calculation caused difficulty for the majority of candidates. Candidates would benefit from greater emphasis being placed on the application of basic principles to everyday situations.
