A level PHYSICS 2006/Winter/Paper2/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i product of force and distance moved
(by force) in the direction of the force		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii work (done) per unit time (idea of ratio needed) B1 [1]
b either work/time or power = (force × distance)/time
to give power = force × velocity		 M1
A1		 [2]
c.i kinetic energy (= ½mv2) = ½ × 1900 × 272
power = 692550 / 8.1 = 8.55 × 104 W		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.ii either for equal increments of speed, increments of EK are different
  so longer time (to increase speed) at high speeds 		 M1
A1		 [2]
or air resistance increases with speed (M1)
  so driving force (and acceleration) reduced (A1)		  
or P (= Fv) = mav (M1)
  (P and m constant) so when v increases, a decreases (A1) 		  
    1. product of force and distance moved
      (by force) in the direction of the force
    2. work (done) per unit time (idea of ratio needed)
  2. either work/time or power = (force × distance)/time
    to give power = force × velocity
    1. kinetic energy (= ½mv2) = ½ × 1900 × 272
      power = 692550 / 8.1 = 8.55 × 104 W
    2. either   for equal increments of speed, increments of EK are different
               so longer time (to increase speed) at high speeds
      or  air resistance increases with speed
           so driving force (and acceleration) reduced
      or  P (= Fv) = mav
      (P and m constant) so when v increases, a decreases
    1. A common omission was to give the definition as force × distance which could have applied equally to moment of a force. The majority of candidates did make reference to distance moved or displacement but frequently, the direction of movement or displacement was not made clear. 
    2. Most definitions included a reference to work done and time taken although the essential detail regarding the ratio was often omitted. 
  2. Most candidates successfully developed the definitions given in (a) in order to derive the expression. 
    1. Most candidates did calculate the final kinetic energy and then divided this quantity be the elapsed time. However, a significant number assumed a constant acceleration and hence a constant accelerating force. Rather than multiply this force by the average speed, they calculated the power by multiplying by the final speed. 
    2. This was answered poorly. Many candidates did not seem to appreciate that this question still relates to the acceleration during the first 8.1 s of the motion. Instead, they discussed changing road surfaces and gradients, cornering etc. An alarming number stated that the acceleration could not be constant simply because the speed is increasing, without mentioning the constraint of constant power. There were very few clearly developed explanations, based on sound principles of physics.

    ..........................................................................[2]
  2. Using your answer to (a), derive an expression for the increase in gravitational potential energy ΔEp when an object of mass m is raised vertically through a distance Δh near the Earth's surface.
    The acceleration of free fall near the Earth's surtace is g. [2]

A level PHYSICS 2002/Winter/Paper2/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a force  × distance moved
in the direction of the force		 M1
A1		 [2]
b weight / force = mg
ΔEp  = mg × Δh
(mo marks for quote of mgΔh)		 M1
A1		 [2]
  1. force  × distance moved
    in the direction of foce
  2. weight x distance moved vertically = changge of gravitational potential energy;
    weight / force = mg
    ΔEp  = mg × Δh
    (mo marks for quote of mgΔh)
  1. weight = mg Most answers included a mention of the product of 'force' and 'distance'. However, only a minority made it clear that the 'distance' is the distance through which the force moves in the direction of the force. 
  2. Candidates were expected to derive the expression, rather than quote it. Frequently, there was confusion between 'height (above ground)' and 'change in height'. It was pleasing to see that in some scripts, a clear link was made between work done against the gravitational force and the resulting change in gravitational potential energy.

      For the ball rising to this height, calculate

A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_1/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a loss in potential energy due to decrease in height (as P.E. = mgh)
gain in kinetic energy due to increase in speed (as K.E. = ½ mv2)
 special case 'as PE decreases KE increases' (1/2)
increase in thermal energy due to work done against air resistance
loss in P.E. equals gain in K.E. and thermal energy  (max. 3)		 (B1)
(B1)

(B1)
(B1)		 [3]
b.i kinetic energy = ½ mv2
  = ½ × 0.150 × (25)2 
  = 46.875 = 47J		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
b.ii 1. potential energy (= mgh) = 0.150 × 9.81 × 21
   loss = KE – mgh = 46.875 – (30.9)
     = 15.97 = 16J		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
2. work done = 16J
   work done = force × distance
   F = 16 / 21 = 0.76N
C1
A1		 [2]
  1. loss in potential energy due to decrease in height (as P.E. = mgh)
    gain in kinetic energy due to increase in speed (as K.E. = ½ mv2)
    special case ‘as PE decreases KE increases’ (1/2)
    increase in thermal energy due to work done against air resistance
    loss in P.E. equals gain in K.E. and thermal energy
    1. kinetic energy = ½ mv2
      = ½ × 0.150 × (25)2
      = 46.875 = 47 J
    2. 1. potential energy (= mgh) = 0.150 × 9.81 × 21
          loss = KE – mgh = 46.875 – (30.9)
          = 15.97 = 16 J
      2. work done = 16 J
          work done = force × distance
          F = 16 / 21 = 0.76 N
  1. There were very few complete answers. Many candidates merely stated that, as the object falls, potential energy is converted into kinetic energy. At this level, it was expected that reduction in gravitational potential energy would be related to decrease in height, kinetic energy would be related to increase in speed and increase in thermal energy would be related to work done against air resistance.
    1. There were many correct answers. The usual errors were either associated with powers of ten or a failure to square the speed.  
    2. 1. A significant number of candidates gave the change in energy as being equal to the change in potential energy.
      2. A majority of answers were based on the energy loss being equated to the product of the frictional force and the distance moved. A significant number of candidates gave their answer as the weight of the object.
NO. 141题号：34140
  1. Explain what is meant by work done.
    ............................................................................. [1]
  2. A car is travelling along a road that has a uniform downhill gradient, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

    The car has a total mass of 850 kg. The angle of the road to the horizontal is 7.5°.
    Calculate the component of the weight of the car down the slope

    component of weight = ............................................. N [2]
  3. The car in (b) is travelling at a constant speed of 25 m s–1. The driver then applies the brakes to stop the car. The constant force resisting the motion of the car is 4600 N.
    1. Show that the deceleration of the car with the brakes applied is 4.1 m s–2. [2]

    2. Calculate the distance the car travels from when the brakes are applied until the car comes to rest.

      distance = ............................................. m [2]
    3. Calculate
      1. the loss of kinetic energy of the car,

         loss of kinetic energy = ............................... J [2]
      2. the work done by the resisting force of 4600 N.

         work done = .............................................. J [1]
    4. The quantities in (iii) part 1 and in (iii) part 2 are not equal. Explain why these two quantities are not equal.
      .......................................................................... [1]

Q2/9702/21/M/J/11

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper2_1/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a work done is the force × the distance moved / displacement in the direction of the force
or
work is done when a force moves in the direction of the force		 B1 [1]
b component of weight = 850 × 9.81 × sin 7.5°
= 1090 N
(use of incorrect trigonometric function, 0/2)		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.i ΣF = 4600 – 1090 = (3510)
deceleration = 3510 / 850
                     = 4.1 ms–2		 M1
A1
A0		 [2]
c.ii v2 = u2 + 2as
0 = 252 + 2 × – 4.1 × s
s = 625 / 8.2
   = 76 m
(allow full credit for calculation of time (6.05 s) & then s)
C1

A1

 [2]
c.iii 1. kinetic energy = ½ mv2
     = 0.5 × 850 × 252
     = 2.7 × 105 J		 C1

A1		 [2]
2. work done = 4600 × 75.7
                      = 3.5 × 105 J		 A1 [1]
c.iv difference is the loss in potential energy (owtte) B1 [1]
  1. work done is the force × the distance moved / displacement in the direction of the
    force
    or
    work is done when a force moves in the direction of the force
  2. component of weight = 850 × 9.81 × sin 7.5° = 1090 N
    (use of incorrect trigonometric function, 0/2)
    1. Σ F = 4600 – 1090 = (3510)
      deceleration = 3510 / 850 = 4.1 ms–2
    2. v2 = u2 + 2as
      0 = 252 + 2 × – 4.1 × s
      s = 625 / 8.2 = 76 m
      (allow full credit for calculation of time (6.05 s) & then s)
    3. 1. kinetic energy = ½ mv2
           = 0.5 × 850 × 252
           = 2.7 × 105 J
      2. work done = 4600 × 75.7 = 3.5 × 105 J
    4. difference is the loss in potential energy (owtte)
  1. Most candidates attempted to define work done, rather than explain its meaning. This approach was acceptable. In many answers there was a reference to the product of force and distance without making it clear that the distance is that moved in the direction of the force.
  2. In most answers, it was realised that a trigonometrical function of the angle is involved but there was widespread confusion between the use of sin 7.5° and cos 7.5°. 
    1. In most answers, the component of the weight was subtracted from the force resisting motion before determining the acceleration. This calculation involved arriving at a given answer. The method and the substitution were equally important. No benefit is gained from quoting the correct answer when the working is inappropriate. 
    2. This calculation was completed successfully by most candidates. 
    3. Apart from power-of-ten errors, these two calculations gave rise to very few problems.
    4. Very few responses made any reference to the loss in gravitational potential energy. The usual answers were energy loss due to either 'friction' or 'heat'. 
NO. 142题号：34112

Two planks of wood AB and BC are inclined at an angle of 15° to the horizontal. The two wooden planks are joined at point B, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

A small block of metal M is released from rest at point A. It slides down the slope to B and up the opposite side to C. Points A and C are 0.26 m above B. Assume frictional forces are negligible.

    1. Describe and explain the acceleration of M as it travels from A to B and from B to C.
      .................................................................. [3]
    2. Calculate the time taken for M to travel from A to B.

      time = ............................................. s [3]
    3. Calculate the speed of M at B.

      speed = ...................................... m s–1 [2]
  2. The plank BC is adjusted so that the angle it makes with the horizontal is 30°. M is released from rest at point A and slides down the slope to B. It then slides a distance along the plank from B towards C.
    Use the law of conservation of energy to calculate this distance. Explain your working.

    distance = ............................................ m [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper2_3/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a.i accelerations (A to B and B to C) are same magnitude
accelerations (A to B and B to C) are opposite directions
or both accelerations are toward B
(A to B and B to C) the component of the weight down the slope provides the acceleration		 B1

B1
B1		 [3]
a.ii acceleration = gsin15°
s = 0 + ½ at2  s = 0.26 / sin 15° = 1.0
 t = 0.89 s		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
a.iii v = 0 + g sin15t  or  v2 = 0 + 2gsin15 × 1.0
v = 2.26 ms–1
(using loss of GPE = gain KE can score full marks) 		 C1
A1

 [2]
b loss of GPE at A = gain in GPE at C  or  loss of KE at B = gain in GPE at C
h1 = h2 = 0.26m or ½ mv2 = mgh   h2 = 0.5 × (2.26)2 / 9.81 = 0.26m
x = 0.26 / sin 30° = 0.52m		 B1

A1		 [2]
    1. accelerations (A to B and B to C) are same magnitude
      accelerations (A to B and B to C) are opposite directions
      or both accelerations are toward B
      (A to B and B to C) the component of the weight down the slope provides the acceleration
    2. acceleration = g sin15°
      s = 0 + ½ at2     s = 0.26 / sin 15° = 1.0 
    3. v = 0 + gsin15t   or   v2 = 0 + 2gsin15 × 1.0
      v = 2.26 ms–1
      (using loss of GPE = gain KE can score full marks)
  2. loss of GPE at A = gain in GPE at C or loss of KE at B = gain in GPE at C
    h1 = h2 = 0.26m  or  ½ mv2 = mgh      h2 = 0.5 × (2.26)2 / 9.81 = 0.26 m
    x = 0.26 / sin 30° = 0.52 m
    1. It was very common to find that candidates thought that the acceleration would increase from A to B and then decrease from B to C, rather than display constant acceleration and constant deceleration. Despite the instruction to describe and explain, most answers were restricted to a description. Few made reference to the equal magnitudes of the acceleration and deceleration as a result of the component of the weight of M down the slope. 
    2. There were some correct responses but many indicated an acceleration of g down a slope of length 0.26m. 
    3. This calculation could be completed successfully either by considering motion down the incline or by using energy changes for a vertical fall of 0.26m. There were many answers based on incorrect working in (a)(ii) that were given credit. 
  2. Candidates were expected to explain their working. Where some explanation was given, this was frequently inadequate, being a statement of conservation of energy. Candidates were expected to appreciate that the gravitational potential energy would be the same before and after the motion. Hence, the block would rise to the same vertical height of 0.26 m.
NO. 143题号：34111
  1. State Newton's second law.
    .....................................................................[1]
  2. A ball of mass 65 g hits a wall with a velocity of 5.2 ms–1 perpendicular to the wall.
    The ball rebounds perpendicularly from the wall with a speed of 3.7 ms–1. The contact time of the ball with the wall is 7.5 ms.
    Calculate, for the ball hitting the wall,
    1. the change in momentum,

      change in momentum = ............................... N s [2]
    2. the magnitude of the average force.

      force = ....................................... N [1]
    1. For the collision in (b) between the ball and the wall, state how the following apply:
      1. Newton's third law,
        ....................................................................[2]
      2. the law of conservation of momentum.
        ....................................................................[1]
    2. State, with a reason, whether the collision is elastic or inelastic.
      ..................................................................[1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper2_2/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a (resultant) force = rate of change of momentum / allow proportional to or change in momentum / time (taken) B1 [1]
b.i ∆p = (–) 65 × 10–3 (5.2 + 3.7)
    = (–) 0.58 N s		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii F = 0.58 / 7.5 × 10–3
  = 77(.3) N		 A1 [1]
c.i 1. force on the wall from the ball is equal to the force on ball from the wall
   but in the opposite direction
(statement of Newton's third law can score one mark) 		 M1
A1

 [2]
2. momentum change of ball is equal and opposite to momentum change of the wall / change of momentum of ball and wall is zero B1 [1]
c.ii kinetic energy (of ball and wall) is reduced / not conserved so inelastic
(Allow relative speed of approach does not equal relative speed of separation.) 		 B1 [1]
  1. (resultant) force = rate of change of momentum / allow proportional to or change in momentum / time (taken)
    1. ∆p = (–) 65 × 10–3 (5.2 + 3.7) =  (–) 0.58 N s 
    2. F = 0.58 / 7.5 × 10–3 = 77(.3) N 
    1. 1. force on the wall from the ball is equal to the force on ball from the wall
          but in the opposite direction
          (statement of Newton’s third law can score one mark)
      2. momentum change of ball is equal and opposite to momentum change of the wall / change of momentum of ball and wall is zero
    2. kinetic energy (of ball and wall) is reduced / not conserved so inelastic
      (Allow relative speed of approach does not equal relative speed of separation.)

The majority of candidates found this question difficult. 

  1. There were many answers that are unacceptable at this level, such as 'force is proportional to acceleration' or 'force equals mass × acceleration'. 
    1. The majority of candidates either subtracted the two speeds or calculated the rate of change of momentum. The vector nature of momentum was ignored by many candidates who did not include the change in direction and failed to add the two speeds. 
    2. The correct answer was only obtained by the very strong candidates. Some achieved a mark through error carried forward from (b)(i). A significant number made errors with powers of ten either with the time or the mass or both.
    1. 1. The majority of answers lacked the necessary precision. The question asked for an answer in terms of the collision between the ball and the wall. Often the answer given was generalised and therefore did not answer the question. Many candidates gave action being equal to reaction. This statement is not acceptable at this level. 
      2. The answers given were generally very poor with little or no reference being made to momentum changes of the ball and the wall or how these were related. A statement of the law of conservation of momentum did not, on its own, answer the question. 
    2. The correct answer with a reason was given by the majority of candidates.
NO. 144题号：34110
    1. Define acceleration.
      ................................................................ [1]
    2. State Newton's first law of motion.
      ................................................................ [1]
  2. The variation with time t of vertical speed v of a parachutist falling from an aircraft is shown in Fig. 1.1.

    1. Calculate the distance travelled by the parachutist in the first 3.0 s of the motion.

      distance = ............................................ m [2]
    2. Explain the variation of the resultant force acting on the parachutist from t = 0 (point A) to t = 15 s (point C).
      ................................................................ [3]
    3. Describe the changes to the frictional force on the parachutist
      1. at t = 15 s (point C),
         ................................................................... [1]
      2. between t = 15s (point C) and t = 22 s (point E).
         ................................................................... [1]
    4. The mass of the parachutist is 95 kg.
      Calculate, for the parachutist between t = 15 s (point C) and t = 17 s (point D),
      1. the average acceleration,

         acceleration = ................................ m s–2 [2]
      2. the average frictional force.

         frictional force = ............................... N [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper2_1/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i acceleration = change in velocity / time (taken)
or acceleration = rate of change of velocity		 B1 [1]
b.ii a body continues at constant velocity unless acted on by a resultant force B1 [1]
b.i distance is represented by the area under graph
distance = ½ × 29.5 × 3 = 44.3m (accept 43.5m for 29 to 45 m for 30)		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii resultant force = weight – frictional force
frictional force increases with speed
at start frictional force = 0 / at end weight = frictional force		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
b.iii 1. frictional force increases B1 [1]
2. frictional force (constant) and then decreases B1 [1]
b.iv 1. acceleration = (v2 – v1) / t = (20 – 50) / (17 – 15)
   = (–) 15 m s–2		 C1
A1		 [2]
2. W – F = ma
   W = 95 × 9.81 (= 932)
   F = (95 × 15) + 932 = 2400 (2360) (2357)N		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
    1. acceleration = change in velocity / time (taken)
      or acceleration = rate of change of velocity
    2. a body continues at constant velocity unless acted on by a resultant force
    1. distance is represented by the area under graph
      distance = ½ × 29.5 × 3 = 44.3 m  (accept 43.5m for 29 to 45 m for 30)
    2. resultant force = weight – frictional force
      frictional force increases with speed
      at start frictional force = 0 / at end weight = frictional force
    3. 1. frictional force increases
      2. frictional force (constant) and then decreases
    4. 1. acceleration = (v2 – v1) / t = (20 – 50) / (17 – 15) = (–) 15 m s–2
      2. W – F = ma
          W = 95 × 9.81 (= 932)
          F = (95 × 15) + 932 = 2400 (2360) (2357)N
    1. The definition of acceleration was only stated in the acceptable form by a minority of candidates. 
    2. The required statement was given by a very small number of candidates. 
    1. The majority of answers were correct. There were a surprising number of candidates who misread the graph or did not know the method of obtaining the distance travelled from a speed against time graph. 
    2. The majority of answers did not relate to the question. Candidates tended to describe the variation of the speed with time as shown on the graph rather than explain the variation in the resultant force as asked in the question. 
    3. Candidates often tried to explain the reasons for the changes in the frictional force rather than just describing the changes, and so would have benefited from more careful reading of the question. 
    4. A significant number obtained the correct answer for the acceleration. The majority of candidates did not consider the resultant force to be the frictional force minus the weight when using F = ma. 
NO. 145题号：34109
  1. Distinguish between scalars and vectors.
    ..........................................................................[1]
  2. Underline all the vector quantities in the list below. [2]
    acceleration    kinetic energy   momentum   power   weight 
  3. A force of 7.5 N acts at 40° to the horizontal, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

    Calculate the component of the force that acts
    1. horizontally,

      horizontal component = ............................ N [1]
    2. vertically.

      vertical component = ............................. N [1]
  4. Two strings support a load of weight 7.5 N, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

    One string has a tension T1 and is at an angle 50° to the horizontal. The other string has a tension T2 and is at an angle 40° to the horizontal. The object is in equilibrium.
    Determine the values of T1 and T2 by using a vector triangle or by resolving forces.

    T1 = .................................................. N
    T2 = .................................................. N
    [4]

Q1/9702/23/O/N/11

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper2_3/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a scalar has magnitude/size, vector has magnitude/size and direction B1 [1]
b acceleration, momentum, weight
(–1 for each addition or omission but stop at zero)		 B2 [2]
c.i horizontally: 7.5cos40° / 7.5sin50° = 5.7(45) / 5.75 not 5.8N A1 [1]
c.ii vertically: 7.5sin40° / 7.5cos50° = 4.8(2)N A1 [1]
d either correct shaped triangle
   correct labelling of two forces, three arrows and two angles
or  correct resolving: T2 cos40° = T1 cos50°
   T1 sin50° + T2 sin40° = 7.5
T1 = 5.7(45) (N)
T2 = 4.8 (N)
(allow ± 0.2 N for scale diagram)		 M1
A1
(B1)
(B1)
A1
A1

 [4]
  1. scalar has magnitude/size, vector has magnitude/size and direction
  2. acceleration, momentum, weight
    (–1 for each addition or omission but stop at zero)
    1. horizontally: 7.5 cos40° / 7.5 sin50° = 5.7(45) / 5.75 not 5.8N
    2. vertically: 7.5 sin40° / 7.5 cos50° = 4.8(2)N
  4. either correct shaped triangle
             correct labelling of two forces, three arrows and two angles
    or   correct resolving: T2 cos40° = T1 cos50°
          T1 sin50° + T2 sin40° = 7.5
    T1 = 5.7(45) (N)
    T2 = 4.8 (N)
    (allow ± 0.2 N for scale diagram)
  1. This was generally well answered with references to both magnitude and direction. 
  2. The most common misconceptions were that power was included as a vector and that weight was thought to be a scalar quantity.
  3. Most answers were correct. Candidates should be encouraged to give some explanation, rather than merely writing down the answer.
  4. The great majority of answers were obtained by calculation, rather than by drawing. There were many sound answers where explanation was good. Most candidates did show clearly resolution in the horizontal and in the vertical directions. This did, subsequently, involve some mathematics when deriving the answers. A minority realised that the strings are normal to one another and thus, by resolving along each string, mathematical manipulation was reduced to a minimum. 
NO. 146题号：34107
  1. Define the torque of a couple.
    ................................................................ [2] 
  2. A uniform rod of length 1.5 m and weight 2.4 N is shown in Fig. 2.1.

    The rod is supported on a pin passing through a hole in its centre. Ropes A and B provide equal and opposite forces of 8.0 N.
    1. Calculate the torque on the rod produced by ropes A and B.

      torque = .......................................... N m [1]
    2. Discuss, briefly, whether the rod is in equilibrium.
      .................................................................... [2]
  3. The rod in (b) is removed from the pin and supported by ropes A and B, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

    Rope A is now at point P 0.30 m from one end of the rod and rope B is at the other end.
    1. Calculate the tension in rope B. 

      tension in B = ..................................... N [2]
    2. Calculate the tension in rope A.

      tension in A = ..................................... N [1]

A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper2_1/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a torque is the product of one of the forces and the distance between forces
the perpendicular distance between the forces		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i torque = 8 × 1.5 = 12Nm A1 [1]
b.ii there is a resultant torque / sum of the moments is not zero
(the rod rotates) and is not in equilibrium		 M1
A1		 [2]
c.i B × 1.2 = 2.4 × 0.45
B = 0.9(0) N		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.ii A = 2.4 – 0.9 = 1.5 N / moments calculation A1 [1]
  1. torque is the product of one of the forces and the distance between forces
    the perpendicular distance between the forces
    1. torque = 8 × 1.5 = 12 Nm
    2. there is a resultant torque / sum of the moments is not zero
      (the rod rotates) and is not in equilibrium
    1. B × 1.2 = 2.4 × 0.45
      B = 0.9(0) N
    2. A = 2.4 – 0.9 = 1.5 N / moments calculation
  1. The majority of candidates did not give enough detail in their definition. Candidates should be reminded that a precise definition is needed in order to obtain full credit. 
    1. This was generally well answered by the well prepared candidates. 
    2. A significant number of candidates recognised that the rod was not in equilibrium. The explanations given did not always describe the reasons in detail. 
    1. The majority of candidates did not take moments about one point. Candidates should be encouraged to practise questions where there are two unknown forces to be determined.  
    2. A number of candidates were able to gain credit by realising that the resultant force in the vertical direction was zero.
NO. 147题号：34105
  1. State the relation between force and momentum.
    ................................................................ [1]
  2. A rigid bar of mass 450 g is held horizontally by two supports A and B, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

    The support A is 45 cm from the centre of gravity C of the bar and support B is 25 cm from C.
    A ball of mass 140 g falls vertically onto the bar such that it hits the bar at a distance of 50 cm from C, as shown in Fig. 3.1.
    The variation with time t of the velocity v of the ball before, during and after hitting the bar is shown in Fig. 3.2.

    For the time that the ball is in contact with the bar, use Fig. 3.2
    1. to determine the change in momentum of the ball,

      change = .................................. kg m s–1
    2. to show that the force exerted by the ball on the bar is 33 N. [1]

  3. For the time that the ball is in contact with the bar, use data from Fig. 3.1 and (b)(ii) to calculate the force exerted on the bar by
    1. the support A,

      force = ............................................ N
    2. the support B.

      force = ............................................ N
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper2_1/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a force = rate of change of momentum  (allow symbols if defined) B1 [1]
b.i ∆ρ = 140 × 10–3 × (5.5 + 4.0)
     = 1.33 kg m s–1		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii force = 1.33 / 0.04
     = 33.3 N		 M1
A0		 [1]
c.i taking moments about B
(33 × 75) + (0.45 × g × 25) = FA × 20
FA = 129 N		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
c.ii FB = 33 + 129 + 0.45g
   = 166 N		 C1
A1		 [2]
  1. force = rate of change of momentum (allow symbols if defined)
    1. ∆ρ = 140 × 10–3 × (5.5 + 4.0) = 1.33 kg m s–1
    2. force = 1.33 / 0.04 = 33.3 N
    1. taking moments about B
      (33 × 75) + (0.45 × g × 25) = FA × 20
      FA = 129 N
    2. FB = 33 + 129 + 0.45g = 166 N
  1. A minority of candidates were able to give the standard relationship between force and momentum. 
    1. There were very few correct answers. The main error made by those candidates who knew the correct equation for momentum was to ignore the change in direction of the ball after it made contact with the bar. Other errors made were to mis-read the initial velocity from the graph or to fail to convert the mass into kilograms.
    2. There were very few correct answers. A solution to this problem depended on the candidates obtaining an answer to (b)(i) and knowing the relationship asked for in (a). Only the able and well-prepared candidates completed this part successfully. 
  3. There were very few correct answers. A number of candidates attempted to obtain an answer using moments. However, the majority did not take moments about a suitable pivot point and/or did not include the weight of the bar. 
NO. 148题号：34101

A trolley of mass 930 g is held on a horizontal surface by means of two springs, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

The variation with time t of the speed v of the trolley for the first 0.60 s of its motion is shown in Fig. 4.2.

  1. Use Fig. 4.2 to determine
    1. the initial acceleration of the trolley,

      acceleration = ………………………. m s–2 [2]
    2. the distance moved during the first 0.60 s of its motion.

      distance = ………….………………… m [3]
    1. Use your answer to (a)(i) to determine the resultant force acting on the trolley at time t = 0.

      force = …………………………….. N [2]
    2. Describe qualitatively the variation with time of the resultant force acting on the trolley during the first 0.60 s of its motion. 
      .................................................................... [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2005/Winter/Paper2/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a.i use of tangent at time t = 0
acceleration = 42 ± 4 cm s-2		 B1
A1		 [2]
a.ii use of area of loop
distance = 0.031 ± 0.001 m
allow 1 mark if 0.031 ± 0.002 m)		 B1
B2		 [3]
b.i F = ma
= 0.93 × 0.42  {allow e.c.f. from (a)(i)}
= 0.39 N		 C1

A1		 [2]
b.ii force reduces to zero in first 0.3 s
then increases again in next 0.3 s
in the opposite direction		 B1
M1
A1		 [3]
    1. use of tangent at time t = 0
      acceleration = 42 ± 4 cm s-2
    2. use of area of loop
      distance = 0.031 ± 0.001 m
      allow 1 mark if 0.031 ± 0.002 m)
    1. F = ma
      = 0.93 × 0.42      {allow e.c.f. from (a)(i)}
      = 0.39 N
    2. force reduces to zero in first 0.3 s
      then increases again in next 0.3 s
      in the opposite direction
    1. Many answers for the initial acceleration were derived from the co-ordinates of a point on the curve within the first 0.1 s of the motion. Usually, such answers failed to explain that this is an approximation to the gradient at time t = 0. Very few candidates stated that what is required is the gradient of the tangent at the origin. 
    2. There were some good clear calculations based on the area below the curve. However, many did not make it clear how they were attempting to find the distance. Others used the equations for uniformly accelerated motion. 
    1. Almost all candidates were able to calculate the acceleration, based on their answer to (a)(i). The most common error was a failure to convert the mass in g to kg.
    2. There were some good descriptions where candidates correctly related the variation of the resultant force to the acceleration of the trolley, as evidenced by the gradient of the tangent. Unfortunately, some did not read the question and described the variation of the acceleration, not the force. A significant number, however, thought that the force would increase from time t = 0 to time t = 0.3 s and then would subsequently decrease. 
NO. 149题号：34100

A stone on a string is made to travel along a horizontal circular path, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

The stone has a constant speed.

  1. Define acceleration. 
    ........................................................................ [1]
  2. Use your definition to explain whether the stone is accelerating. 
    ........................................................................ [2]
  3. The stone has a weight of 5.0 N. When the string makes an angle of 35° to the vertical, the tension in the string is 6.1 N, as illustrated in Fig. 3.2.
         
    Determine the resultant force acting on the stone in the position shown.

    magnitude of force = ……………..…..……. N
    direction of force….………………..………….. [4]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2005/Winter/Paper2/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a change in velocity/time (taken) B1 [1]
b velocity is a vector/velocity has magnitude & direction
direction changing so must be accelerating		 B1
B1		 [2]
c either 6.1 × cos35 = 4.99 N 
  so no resultant vertical force
  6.1 sin35 = 3.5 N
  horizontally
or scale shown
  triangle of correct shape
  resultant = 3.5 ± 0.2 N 
  horizontal ± 3°		 B1
B1
B1
B1




 [4]
allow answer based on centripetal force:
resultant is centripetal force (which is horizontal)
resultant is horizontal component of tension
6.1 sin35 = 3.5 N
horizontally
(B1)
(B1)
(B1)
(B1)		  
  1. change in velocity/time (taken)
  2. velocity is a vector/velocity has magnitude & direction
    direction changing so must be accelerating
  3. either 6.1 × cos35 = 4.99 N     or scale shown
    so no resultant vertical force      triangle of correct shape
    6.1 sin35 = 3.5 N     resultant = 3.5 ± 0.2 N
    horizontally      horizontal ± 3°

    allow answer based on centripetal force:
    resultant is centripetal force (which is horizontal)
    resultant is horizontal component of tension
    6.1 sin35 = 3.5 N
    horizontally
  1. Most candidates correctly defined acceleration, with few confusing velocity and speed.
  2. Although most candidates explained, with varying degrees of clarity, that the stone is accelerating because the direction is changing continuously and that velocity has magnitude and direction, there were many who decided that the stone is not accelerating because the speed is constant. 
  3. There were some very clear correct solutions based on either scale drawings or vertical and horizontal resolution or the use of the cosine and sine rules. Many candidates ignored completely the components of forces in the vertical direction and offered no justification for the assumption that the resultant would be in the horizontal direction. A common error was to quote an angle on the answer line that could not be identified from any diagram e.g. 55°. 
NO. 150题号：34098
  1. Define the moment of a force.
    .......................................................................... [2]
  2. State the two conditions necessary for a body to be in equilibrium.
    1. ......................................................................
    2. ...................................................................... [2]
  3. Two parallel strings S1 and S2 are attached to a disc of diameter 12 cm, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

    The disc is free to rotate about an axis normal to its plane. The axis passes through the centre C of the disc.|
    A lever of length 30 cm is attached to the disc. When a force F is applied at right angles to the lever at its end, equal forces are produced in S1 and S2. The disc remains in equilibrium.
    1. On Fig. 3.1, show the direction of the force in each string that acts on the disc. [1]
    2. For a force F of magnitude 150 N, determine
      1. the moment of force F about the centre of the disc,

         moment = …………………………………… N m
      2. the torque of the couple produced by the forces in the strings,

         torque = …………………………………… N m
      3. the force in S1. 

         force = ……………………………………. N
      [4]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2003/Winter/Paper2/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a force x perpendicular distance
(of the force) from the pivot		 M1
A1		 [2]
b no resultant force (in any direction)
no resultant moment (about any point)		 B1
B1		 [2]
c.i correct direction in both B1 [1]
c.ii 1. moment = 150 × 0.3 = 45 N m (1 sig. fig. -1) A1 [4]
2. torque = 45 N m i.e. same is (i) A1
3. 45 = 0.12 × T
    T = 375 N		 C1
A1
  1. force x perpendicular distance
    (of the force) from the pivot
  2. no resultant force (in any direction)
    no resultant moment (about any point)
    1. correct direction in both
    2. 1. moment = 150 × 0.3 = 45 N m (1 sig. fig. -1)
      2. torque = 45 N m i.e. same is (i)
      3. 45 = 0.12 × T
          T = 375 N
  1. Frequently, moment was defined as being the product of force and distance. This is indistinguishable from an equally vague definition of work done. Those who did make a reference to perpendicular distance often failed to define what is meant by perpendicular distance or confused the point of application of the force with the pivot point. 
  2. The conditions for equilibrium were generally well known. A common mistake was to state that, for translational equilibrium, 'the sum of the upward forces must equal the sum of the downward forces', completely ignoring any horizontal forces.
    1. Nearly half the candidates showed the forces in the wrong directions.
    2. In general, the calculations were disappointing. Many candidates correctly calculated the moment of the force about the centre of the disc. However, they then failed to equate the torque provided by the strings to the moment of this force. In many answers there was frequent confusion of units and a failure to understand how to calculate the magnitude of one of the forces making up a couple. 
NO. 151题号：34096
    1. State the principle of conservation of momentum.

      .....................................................................................................................................................
      .....................................................................................................................................................[2]
    2. State the difference between an elastic and an inelastic collision.

      .....................................................................................................................................................[1]
  2. An object A of mass 4.2 kg and horizontal velocity 3.6 m s–1 moves towards object B as shown in Fig. 3.1.

    Object B of mass 1.5 kg is moving with a horizontal velocity of 1.2 m s–1 towards object A.
    The objects collide and then both move to the right, as shown in Fig. 3.2.

    Object A has velocity v and object B has velocity 3.0 m s–1.
    1. Calculate the velocity v of object A after the collision.





      velocity = ........................................ m s–1 [3]
    2. Determine whether the collision is elastic or inelastic.

      .....................................................................................................................................................
      .....................................................................................................................................................
      .....................................................................................................................................................[3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_3/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a.i the total momentum of a system (of interacting bodies) remains constant 
provided there are no resultant external forces / isolated system		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii elastic: total kinetic energy is conserved, inelastic: loss of kinetic energy
[allow elastic: relative speed of approach equals relative speed of separation]		 B1 [1]
b.i initial mom: 4.2 × 3.6 – 1.2 × 1.5 (= 15.12 – 1.8 = 13.3)
final mom: 4.2 × v + 1.5 × 3
v = (13.3 – 4.5) / 4.2 = 2.1ms–1		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
b.ii initial kinetic energy = ½ mA(vA)2 + ½ mB(vB)2
   = 27.21 + 1.08 = 28(.28)
final kinetic energy = 9.26 + 6.75 = 16
initial KE is not the same as final KE hence inelastic
provided final KE less than initial KE
[allow in terms of relative speeds of approach and separation]
M1
M1
A1


 [3]
    1. the total momentum of a system (of interacting bodies) remains constant
      provided there are no resultant external forces / isolated system
    2. elastic: total kinetic energy is conserved, inelastic: loss of kinetic energy
      [allow elastic: relative speed of approach equals relative speed of separation]
    1. initial mom: 4.2 × 3.6 – 1.2 × 1.5 (= 15.12 – 1.8 = 13.3)
      final mom: 4.2 × v + 1.5 × 3
      v = (13.3 – 4.5) / 4.2 = 2.1 ms–1
    2. initial kinetic energy = ½ mA(vA)2 + ½ mB(vB)2
      = 27.21 + 1.08 = 28(.28)
      final kinetic energy = 9.26 + 6.75 = 16
      initial KE is not the same as final KE hence inelastic
      provided final KE less than initial KE
      [allow in terms of relative speeds of approach and separation]

The calculations were generally well presented. The statements given for (a) were often not given in the detail required.

    1. The accepted statement of the principle of conservation of momentum was given by a minority of candidates. Candidates should learn the standard definitions required for this syllabus.
    2. The majority of candidates gave unacceptable answers. The conservation of energy or momentum was given for elastic collisions. The conservation of total kinetic energy was required for elastic collisions and the loss of kinetic energy for inelastic collisions. 
    1. The correct solution was given by a significant number of candidates. The addition of the initial momentum of the two objects was determined without reference to the fact that they were travelling in opposite directions by some candidates. 
    2. The correct comparison of the total kinetic energy before and after the collision was made by a large number of candidates. There were some candidates who subtracted the two initial kinetic energies presumably considering the opposite directions of the two objects as a factor. A significant number of candidates gave no conclusion after making the calculations, or gave an answer having made no calculations. The number of marks available should indicate to candidates the amount of detail required. 
NO. 152题号：34093
  1. Distinguish between mass and weight.
    mass: ..........................................................................
    weight: ....................................................................... [2]
  2. An object O of mass 4.9 kg is suspended by a rope A that is fixed at point P. The object is pulled to one side and held in equilibrium by a second rope B, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

    Rope A is at an angle θ to the horizontal and rope B is horizontal. The tension in rope A is 69 N and the tension in rope B is T.
    1. On Fig. 2.1, draw arrows to represent the directions of all the forces acting on object O. [2]

    2. Calculate
      1. the angle θ, 

      θ = ................................................° 
      2. the tension T. 

      T = .............................................. N
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_1/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a mass is the property of a body resisting changes in motion / quantity of matter in a body / measure of inertia to changes in motion B1 [2]
weight is the force due to the gravitational field/force due to gravity or gravitational force B1
Allow 1/2 for 'mass is scalar weight is vector'  
b.i arrow vertically down through O
tension forces in correct direction on rope		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.ii 1. weight = mg = 4.9 × 9.81 (= 48.07) 
 69 sin θ = mg 
 θ = 44.(1)°   scale drawing allow ± 2° 
 use of cos or tan 1/3 only 		 C1
C1
A1

 [3]
2. T = 69 cos θ
     = 49.6 / 50N  scale drawing 50 ±2 (2/2)  50 ±4 (1/2)		 C1
A1		 [2]
correct answers obtained using scale diagram or triangle of forces will score full marks
cos in 1. then sin in 2. (2/2)		    
  1. mass is the property of a body resisting changes in motion / quantity of matter in a body / measure of inertia to changes in motion
    weight is the force due to the gravitational field/force due to gravity or gravitational force
    Allow 1/2 for 'mass is scalar weight is vector'
    1. arrow vertically down through O
      tension forces in correct direction on rope
    2. 1. weight = mg = 4.9 × 9.81 (= 48.07)
          69 sin θ = mg
          θ = 44.(1)°      scale drawing allow ± 2°
          use of cos or tan 1/3 only
      2. T = 69 cos θ = 49.6 / 50 N
          scale drawing 50 ±2 (2/2) 50 ±4 (1/2)
      correct answers obtained using scale diagram or triangle of forces will score full marks
      cos in 1. then sin in 2. (2/2)
  1. Candidates should be advised to learn the meanings of such terms. Many merely mentioned scalar and vector quantities. Others referred to "gravity" rather than gravitational force.
    1. This was generally answered correctly. A minority did not show the 69N force acting along the rope. Rather, they showed vertical and horizontal components, many without explanation, and consequently did not answer the question. 
    2. The majority of answers were correct, although some confused sine with cosine. Candidates should be advised to use the data provided on page 2 of the question paper. The use of the approximation g = 10ms–2 should be avoided unless the question states specifically that this value is to be used. 
    3. This was generally answered well. Most used 69cos θ, but a minority correctly used Pythagoras' theorem. 
NO. 153题号：34092

A motor drags a log of mass 452 kg up a slope by means of a cable, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

The slope is inclined at 14.0° to the horizontal.

  1. Show that the component of the weight of the log acting down the slope is 1070 N. [1]


  2. The log starts from rest. A constant frictional force of 525 N acts on the log. The log accelerates up the slope at 0.130 m s–2.
    1. Calculate the tension in the cable.



      tension = ............................................. N [3]
    2. The log is initially at rest at point S. It is pulled through a distance of 10.0 m to point P.
      Calculate, for the log,
      1. the time taken to move from S to P,


         time = .............................................. s  [2]
      2. the magnitude of the velocity at P.


       velocity = ........................................ m s–1  [1]

  3. The cable breaks when the log reaches point P. On Fig. 2.2, sketch the variation with time t of the velocity v of the log. The graph should show v from the start at S until the log returns to S. [4]

[Total: 11]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_3/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a weight = 452 × 9.81
component down the slope = 452 × 9.81 × sin14°
= 1072.7 = 1070N
M1
A0		 [1]
b.i F = ma
T – (1070 + 525) = 452 × 0.13
T = 1650 (1653.76)N any forces missing 1/3		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
b.ii 1. s = ut + ½at2 hence 10 = 0 + ½ × 0.13t2
    t = [(2 × 10) / 0.13]1/2 = 12.4 or 12s		 C1
A1		 [2]
2. v = (0 + 2 × 0.13 × 10)1/2 = 1.61 or 1.6ms–1 A1 [1]
c straight line from the origin
line down to zero velocity in short time compared to stage 1
line less steep negative gradient
final velocity larger than final velocity in the first part – at least 2×		 B1
B1
B1
B1		 [4]
  1. weight = 452 × 9.81
    component down the slope = 452 × 9.81 × sin14°
    = 1072.7 = 1070 N
    1. F = ma
      T – (1070 + 525) = 452 × 0.13
      T = 1650 (1653.76) N   any forces missing 1/3
    2. 1. s = ut + ½at2   hence 10 = 0 + ½ × 0.13t2
          t = [(2 × 10) / 0.13]1/2 = 12.4 or 12 s
      2. v = (0 + 2 × 0.13 × 10)1/2 = 1.61 or 1.6ms–1
  3. straight line from the origin
    line down to zero velocity in short time compared to stage 1
    line less steep negative gradient
    final velocity larger than final velocity in the first part – at least 2×

The majority of well prepared candidates gave good answers to most parts of this question.

  1. Many candidates were able to show the value required for the component of the weight. The inappropriate practice of assuming g = 10 ms–2 was avoided to a great extent as this did not give the value stated in the question.
    1. The determination of the resultant force was poorly answered, with the majority of candidates only gaining credit for the statement F = ma. The calculations for the resultant force F presented by many candidates did not include the component of the weight calculated in (a) or the frictional force.
    2. This was generally well answered. Candidates applied the equations of constant acceleration correctly.
  3. The majority of candidates were able to show on the graph the initial constant acceleration from zero velocity until the cable breaks. The two later stages should have shown the log slowing to zero velocity, and then accelerating in the opposite direction. The majority of candidates were unable to interpret and then draw these two stages correctly on the graph. 
NO. 154题号：34091
  1. Explain the differences between the quantities distance and displacement.
    .............................................................................[2]
  2. State Newton's first law.
    .............................................................................[1]
  3. Two tugs pull a tanker at constant velocity in the direction XY, as represented in Fig. 1.1.

    Tug 1 pulls the tanker with a force T1 at 25.0° to XY. Tug 2 pulls the tanker with a force of T2 at 15.0° to XY. The resultant force R due to the two tugs is 25.0 × 103 N in the direction XY.
    1. By reference to the forces acting on the tanker, explain how the tanker may be described as being in equilibrium.
      ...........................................................................[2]
    2. 1. Complete Fig. 1.2 to draw a vector triangle for the forces R, T1 and T2.


      2. Use your vector triangle in Fig. 1.2 to determine the magnitude of T1 and of T2.

      T1 = ................................................... N
      T2 = .................................................. N
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_3/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a displacement is a vector, distance is a scalar
displacement is straight line between two points / distance is sum of lengths moved / example showing difference
(either one of the definitions for the second mark) 		 B1
B1		 [2]
b a body continues at rest or at constant velocity unless acted on by a resultant (external) force B1 [1]
c.i sum of T1 and T2 equals frictional force
these two forces are in opposite directions
(allow for 1/2 for travelling in straight line hence no rotation / no resultant torque)		 B1
B1

 [2]
c.ii 1. scale vector triangle with correct orientation / vector triangle with correct
orientation both with arrows
scale given or mathematical analysis for tensions		 B1
B1		 [2]
2. T1 = 10.1 × 103 (± 0.5 × 103)N
    T2 = 16.4 × 103 (± 0.5 × 103)N		 A1
A1		 [2]
  1. displacement is a vector, distance is a scalar
    displacement is straight line between two points / distance is sum of lengths moved / example showing difference
    (either one of the definitions for the second mark)
  2. a body continues at rest or at constant velocity unless acted on by a resultant (external) force
    1. sum of T1 and T2 equals frictional force
      these two forces are in opposite directions
      (allow for 1/2 for travelling in straight line hence no rotation / no resultant torque)
    2. 1. scale vector triangle with correct orientation / vector triangle with correct orientation both with arrows
         scale given or mathematical analysis for tensions
      2. T1 = 10.1 × 103 (± 0.5 × 103) N
          T2 = 16.4 × 103 (± 0.5 × 103) N

This question was well answered by the well prepared candidates. 

  1. The majority of candidates correctly distinguished between distance and displacement by indicating that one is a scalar and the other a vector. The explanation of displacement involving the distance of the straight line between two points was given by a small minority of candidates.
  2. Many statements lacked the required precision. References to constant motion rather than constant velocity, or no external force instead of zero resultant force, were not allowed at this level. 
    1. Candidates often gave Newton's first law as their explanation and did not refer to the forces acting on the tanker. Very few candidates described the need for a force in the opposite direction to that of the resultant force produced by the two tugs in order to produce the condition of equilibrium. 
    2. There were some very good scale diagrams drawn. Candidates who used this method to determine the magnitude of the forces then generally obtained the correct values. A number of candidates, however, demonstrated poor physics, equating the resolved component for each of the two tugs in the direction XY with the given resultant force in the direction XY. 
NO. 155题号：34090
  1. State Newton's first law.
    .............................................................................[1]
  2. A log of mass 450 kg is pulled up a slope by a wire attached to a motor, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

    The angle that the slope makes with the horizontal is 12°. The frictional force acting on the log is 650 N. The log travels with constant velocity.
    1. With reference to the motion of the log, discuss whether the log is in equilibrium.
      ..........................................................................[2]
    2. Calculate the tension in the wire.

      tension = ............................................. N [3]
    3. State and explain whether the gain in the potential energy per unit time of the log is equal to the output power of the motor.
      ..........................................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_2/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a A body continues at rest or constant velocity unless acted on by a resultant
 (external) force		 B1 [1]
b.i constant velocity/zero acceleration and therefore no resultant force
no resultant force (and no resultant torque) hence in equilibrium		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.ii component of weight = 450 × 9.81 × sin 12° (= 917.8)
tension = 650 + 450 g sin12° = (650 + 917.8)
             = 1600 (1570)N		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
b.iii work done against frictional force or friction between log and slope
output power greater than the gain in PE / s		 M1
A1		 [2]
  1. A body continues at rest or constant velocity unless acted on by a resultant (external) force
    1. constant velocity/zero acceleration and therefore no resultant force
      no resultant force (and no resultant torque) hence in equilibrium
    2. component of weight = 450 × 9.81 × sin 12° (= 917.8)
      tension = 650 + 450 g sin12°
                = (650 + 917.8)
                = 1600 (1570) N
    3. work done against frictional force or friction between log and slope
      output power greater than the gain in PE / s
  1. The law was generally stated in an unacceptable form at this level. Very few stated 'constant velocity' and 'zero resultant force'. 
    1. A small minority of candidates were able to link the constant velocity of the log with a zero resultant force and hence equilibrium. A significant number suggested the log was not in equilibrium as it was moving with constant velocity. 
    2. A significant number of candidates calculated the component of the weight of the log acting down the slope. Many candidates then equated their value to the tension in the wire without any reference to the frictional force, or subtracted the frictional force from their value. Despite having used 9.81ms–2 in Question 2(a), a significant number of candidates used g = 10ms–2 in this part.
    3. Well prepared candidates were able to explain the difference between the power produced by the motor and the gain in potential energy per second by describing the work done against the frictional force. Answers that merely stated that energy is lost to friction or heat were not given credit. Some candidates, ignoring the effects of the frictional force, suggested that the two were equal as the kinetic energy was constant.
NO. 156题号：34089

A ball is thrown vertically down towards the ground with an initial velocity of 4.23 m s–1. The ball falls for a time of 1.51 s before hitting the ground. Air resistance is negligible.

    1. Show that the downwards velocity of the ball when it hits the ground is 19.0 m s–1.  [2]

    2. Calculate, to three significant figures, the distance the ball falls to the ground.

      distance = ............................................. m [2]
  2. The ball makes contact with the ground for 12.5 ms and rebounds with an upwards velocity of 18.6 m s–1. The mass of the ball is 46.5 g.
    1. Calculate the average force acting on the ball on impact with the ground.

      magnitude of force = .................................................. N
      direction of force ......................................................  [4]
    2. Use conservation of energy to determine the maximum height the ball reaches after it hits the ground. 

      height = ............................................. m [2] 
  3. State and explain whether the collision the ball makes with the ground is elastic or inelastic.
    .............................................................................[1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_1/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a.i v = u + at
   = 4.23 + 9.81 × 1.51
   = 19.0(4) ms–1  (Allow 2 s.f.)
(Use of –g max 1/2. Use of g = 10 max 1/2. Allow use of 9.8. Allow 19 ms–1)		 C1
M1
A0

 [2]
a.ii either s = ut + ½ at2 (or v2 = u2 + 2as etc.)
   = 4.23 × 1.51 + 0.5 × 9.81 × (1.51)2
   = 17.6m (or 17.5m)
(Use of –g here wrong physics (0/2))
C1 
A1

 [2]
b.i F = ∆P / ∆t  need idea of change in momentum
   = [0.0465 × (18.6 + 19)] / 12.5 × 10–3
   = 140N
(Use of – sign max 2/4. Ignore –ve sign in answer)
Direction: upwards		 C1
C1

B1		 [4]

   = 17.6 m (2 s.f. –1)
(Use of 19 ms–1, 0/2 wrong physics)		 C1
A1

 [2]
c either  kinetic energy of the ball is not conserved on impact
or  speed before impact is not equal to speed after hence inelastic		 B1 [1]
    1. v = u + at
      = 4.23 + 9.81 × 1.51
      = 19.0(4) ms–1 (Allow 2 s.f.)
      (Use of –g max 1/2.   Use of g = 10 max 1/2.   Allow use of 9.8. Allow 19 ms–1)
    2. either s = ut + ½ at2    (or v2 = u2 + 2as etc.)
      = 4.23 × 1.51 + 0.5 × 9.81 × (1.51)2
      = 17.6m (or 17.5m)
      (Use of –g here wrong physics (0/2))
    1. F = ∆P / ∆t need idea of change in momentum
      = [0.0465 × (18.6 + 19)] / 12.5 × 10–3
      = 140 N
      (Use of – sign max 2/4. Ignore –ve sign in answer)
      Direction: upwards
    2. h = ½ × (18.6)2 / 9.81
         = 17.6 m (2 s.f. –1)
      (Use of 19 ms–1, 0/2 wrong physics)
  3. either    kinetic energy of the ball is not conserved on impact
    or     speed before impact is not equal to speed after hence inelastic
NO. 157题号：34088

A helicopter has a cable hanging from it towards the sea below, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

A man of mass 80 kg rescues a child of mass 50.5 kg. The two are attached to the cable and are lifted from the sea to the helicopter. The lifting process consists of an initial uniform acceleration followed by a period of constant velocity and then completed by a final uniform deceleration.

  1. Calculate the combined weight of the man and child.

    weight = ............................................. N [1]
  2. Calculate the tension in the cable during
    1. the initial acceleration of 0.570 m s–2,

      tension = ............................................. N [2]
    2. the period of constant velocity of 2.00 m s–1.

      tension = ............................................. N [1]
  3. During the final deceleration the tension in the cable is 1240 N. Calculate this deceleration.

    deceleration = ........................................ m s–2 [2]
    1. Calculate the time over which the man and child are
      1. moving with uniform acceleration,

         time = .............................................. s [1]
      2. moving with uniform deceleration.

         time = .............................................. s [1]
    2. The time over which the man and child are moving with constant velocity is 20 s.
      On Fig. 3.2, sketch a graph to show the variation with time of the velocity of the man and child for the complete lifting process. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper2_3/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a weight = m × g
           = 130.5 × 9.81 = 1280 N		 A1 [1]
b.i F = ma
T – 1280 = 130.5 × 0.57 
T = 1280 + 74.4 = 1350 N
C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii 1280 N A1 [1]
c 1240 – 1280 = 130.5 × a
                 a = (–) 0.31ms–2		 C1
A1		 [2]
d.i 1. 3.5 s
2. 6.5 s		 A1
A1		 [1]
[1]
d.ii basic shape
basic shape		 M1
A1		 [2]
  1. weight = m × g
    = 130.5 × 9.81 = 1280 N
    1. F = ma
      T – 1280 = 130.5 × 0.57
      T = 1280 + 74.4 = 1350 N
    2. 1280 N
  3. 1240 – 1280 = 130.5 × a
    a = (–) 0.31 ms–2
    1. 1. 3.5 s
      2. 6.5 s
    2. basic shape
      correct points
  1. The majority of candidates were able to correctly calculate the weight from the given mass.
    1. The majority of candidates proposed that the tension produced the acceleration. A minority of candidates considered the resultant force to be the tension minus the weight. 
    2. The majority of candidates gave the correct answer. A significant number of candidates did not associate a zero resultant force with the constant velocity. 
  3. The majority of candidates again ignored the effect of the weight on the resultant force.  
    1. 1. A small minority of candidates used the value given for the acceleration to calculate the time taken to reach constant velocity.  
      2. A small minority of candidates were able to calculate the time taken to decelerate. 
      Candidates should be encouraged to use the equations of uniform acceleration when the term 'uniform' is stated in the question.
    2. The candidates with correct answers for (d)(i) generally drew accurate graphs. There were some candidates who made errors when reading the time scale. The values given on the time axis and the time given for the journey at constant velocity should have given candidates a guide to the expected graph.
NO. 158题号：34087

A climber id supported by a rope on a vertical wall. as shown in Fig.2.1.

The weight W of the climber is 520 N. The rope, of negligible weight, is attached to the climber and to a fixed point P where it makes an angle of 18° to the vertical. The reaction force R acts at right-angles to the wall.
The climber is in equilibrium.

  1. State the conditions necessary for the climber to be in equilibrium.
    ..............................................................................[2]
  2. Complete Fig. 2.2 by drawing a labelled vector triangle to represent the forces acting on the climber. [2]
  3. Resolve forces or use your vector triangle to calculate
    1. the tension T in the rope,

      T = ............................................. N [2]
    2. the reaction force R.

      R = ............................................. N [1]
  4. The climber moves up the wall and the angle the rope makes with the vertical increases.
    Explain why the magnitude of the tension in the rope increases.
    ................................................................................[1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper2_3/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a resultant moment = zero / sum of clockwise moments = sum of anticlockwise moments
resultant force = 0		 B1
B1		 [2]
b shape and orientation correct and forces labelled and arrows correct
angles correct / labelled		 M1
A1		 [2]
c.i T cos18° = W                               Scale diagram:
          T = 520 / cos18° = 547 N          ± 20 N		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.ii R = T sin18°
   = 169 N                                          ± 20 N		 A1 [1]
d θ is larger hence cosθ is smaller, T = W / cosθ
hence T is larger 		 M1
A0		 [1]
  1. resultant moment = zero / sum of clockwise moments = sum of anticlockwise moments
    resultant force = 0
  2. shape and orientation correct and forces labelled and arrows correct
    angles correct / labelled
    1. T cos18° = W    Scale diagram: ± 20 N 
      T = 520 / cos18° = 547 N
    2. R = T sin18° = 169 N         Scale diagram: ± 20 N 
  4. θ is larger hence cos θ is smaller, T = W / cos θ
    hence T is larger

There were many good responses to this question. 

  1. Candidates were generally able to give at least one of the conditions required for equilibrium. Credit was not obtained by candidates who did not refer to the resultant force being zero or to the sum of the clockwise moments being equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.
  2. The vector triangle was drawn with the correct orientation and labels by the majority of candidates. Credit was not obtained by candidates with triangles that were not labelled with the forces and/or the angles. A small minority gave the forces in the wrong direction. 
    1. The vector triangle was used correctly by the majority of candidates.
    2. A significant number of candidates made an error with the trigonometrical function chosen to relate the forces represented by the sides of the triangle and hence obtained an incorrect answer for R. 
  4. Candidates who quoted the equation from their working in (c)(i) to calculate the tension produced good explanations. In general the answers given needed a greater amount of detail to gain full credit. 
NO. 159题号：34086
  1. Explain what is meant by centre of gravity.
    ................................................................................. [2]
  2. Define moment of a force.
    ................................................................................. [1]
  3. A student is being weighed. The student, of weight W, stands 0.30 m from end A of a uniform plank AB, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

    The plank has weight 80 N and length 2.0 m. A pivot P supports the plank and is 0.50 m from end A.
    A weight of 70 N is moved to balance the weight of the student. The plank is in equilibrium when the weight is 0.20 m from end B.
    1. State the two conditions necessary for the plank to be in equilibrium.
      1. ......................................................................................
      2. ...................................................................................... [2]
    2. Determine the weight W of the student.

      W = ............................................. N [3]
    3. If only the 70 N weight is moved, there is a maximum weight of student that can be determined using the arrangement shown in Fig. 3.1. State and explain one change that can be made to increase this maximum weight.
      ......................................................................... [2]

Q3/9702/21/M/J/11

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper2_1/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a point where the weight of an object / gravitational force
may be considered to act		 M1
A1		 [2]
b product of the force and the perpendicular distance (to the pivot) B1 [1]
c.i 1. sum / net / resultant force is zero B1 [2]
2. net / resultant moment is zero
  sum of clockwise moments = sum of anticlockwise moments		 B1
c.ii W × 0.2 = 80 × 0.5 + 70 × 1.3
     = 40 + 91
W = 655 N
(allow 2/3 for one error in distance but 0/3 if two errors)		 C1
C1
C1		 [3]
c.iii move pivot to left
gives greater clockwise moment / smaller
anticlockwise moment 
or
move W to right 
gives smaller anticlockwise moment		 (M1)

(A1)

(M1)
(A1)		 [2]
  1. point where the weight of an object / gravitational force
    may be considered to act
  2. product of the force and the perpendicular distance (to the pivot)
    1. 1. sum / net / resultant force is zero
      2. net / resultant moment is zero
      sum of clockwise moments = sum of anticlockwise moments
    2. W × 0.2 = 80 × 0.5 + 70 × 1.3
                = 40 + 91
      W     = 655 N
      (allow 2/3 for one error in distance but 0/3 if two errors)
    3. move pivot to left
      gives greater clockwise moment / smaller
      anticlockwise moment
      or
      move W to right
      gives smaller anticlockwise moment
  1. It was expected that candidates would realise that the centre of gravity is the point where the whole weight of the body appears to act. In a significant number of scripts, the weight was said to be concentrated at this point. A small number of candidates referred to mass, rather than weight. 
  2. It was expected that candidates would refer to perpendicular distance, rather than merely distance.
    1. In most scripts, reference was made both to forces and to moments. The essential feature that it is the sum or the resultant that is zero was frequently omitted. Statements such as 'clockwise moment equals anticlockwise moment' were common. 
    2. There were many correct solutions that were given with adequate explanation. Common errors were to take moments about the pivot and then to either not include the moment due to the weight of the plank or to give the distance of the student from the pivot as 0.3 m.
    3. It would appear that a significant number of candidates misread the question in that they suggested that the 70 N weight should be moved. 
NO. 160题号：34085
  1. State the two conditions that must be satisfied for a body to be in equilibrium.
    1. .....................................................................
    2. ..................................................................... [2]
  2. Three co-planar forces act on a body that is in equilibrium.
    1. Describe how to draw a vector triangle to represent these forces.
      .......................................................................[3]
    2. State how the triangle confirms that the forces are in equilibrium.
      .......................................................................[1]
  3. A weight of 7.0 N hangs vertically by two strings AB and AC, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

    For the weight to be in equilibrium, the tension in string AB is T1 and in string AC it is T2.
    On Fig. 2.1, draw a vector triangle to determine the magnitudes of T1 and T2.
    T1 = ................................................... N
    T2 = ................................................... N [3]
  4. By reference to Fig. 2.1, suggest why the weight could not be supported with the strings AB and AC both horizontal.
    ...............................................................................[2]

Q2/9702/23/M/J/10

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper2_3/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a no resultant force/sum of forces zero
no resultant moment/torque/sum of moments/torques zero		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.i each force is represented by the side of a triangle/by an arrow
in magnitude and direction
arrows joined, head to tail
(could be shown on a sketch diagram)		 M1
A1
B1

 [3]
b.ii if the triangle is 'closed' (then the forces are in equilibrium) B1 [1]
c triangle drawn with correct shape (incorrect arrows loses this mark)
T1 = 5.4 ± 0.2N
T2 = 4.0 ± 0.2N 		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
d forces in strings would be horizontal
(so) no vertical force to support the weight		 B1
B1		 [2]
  1. no resultant force/sum of forces zero
    no resultant moment/torque/sum of moments/torques zero
    1. each force is represented by the side of a triangle/by an arrow
      in magnitude and direction
      arrows joined, head to tail
      (could be shown on a sketch diagram)
    2. if the triangle is ‘closed’ (then the forces are in equilibrium)
  3. triangle drawn with correct shape (incorrect arrows loses this mark)
    T1 = 5.4 ± 0.2N
    T2 = 4.0 ± 0.2N
  4. forces in strings would be horizontal
    (so) no vertical force to support the weight

Candidates found many parts of this question difficult.

  1. The statements required for equilibrium were generally given correctly. Common errors were to state that all the forces must be equal, or to fail to state that it is the sum of the anticlockwise moments and the sum of the clockwise moments about the same point that have to be equal. 
    1. The majority of candidates were able to draw a triangle of lines and arrows to represent three forces. Very few were able to explain that the sides of the triangle represented the force in magnitude and direction. A significant number of candidates suggested that the triangle had to be an equilateral triangle for equilibrium. 
    2. The majority of good candidates were able to describe how the triangle confirmed the condition of equilibrium for the three forces. 
  3. This part was poorly answered by the majority of candidates. Very few followed the instruction to draw a vector triangle on Fig. 2.1. The vast majority considered the triangle had to have a right angle between T1 and T2. A significant number of candidates tried to draw triangles for the tension forces that apparently resolved these forces into components vertically and horizontally using the length of the lines representing the strings that were given on the diagram. 
  4. Only the good candidates realised that with the strings horizontal there would not be any component in the vertical direction to support the weight. 
NO. 161题号：34077

A rod AB is hinged to a wall at A. The rod is held horizontally by means of a cord BD, attached to the rod at end B and to the wall at D, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

The rod has weight W and the centre of gravity of the rod is at C. The rod is held in equilibrium by a force T in the cord and a force F produced at the hinge.

  1. Explain what is meant by
    1. the centre of gravity of a body,
      ................................................................................. [2]
    2. the equilibrium of a body.
      ................................................................................. [2]
  2. The line of action of the weight W of the rod passes through the cord at point P
    Explain why, for the rod to be in equilibrium, the force F produced at the hinge must also pass through point P.
    ........................................................................................... [2]
  3. The forces F and T make angles α and β respectively with the rod and AC = 2/3AB, as shown in Fig. 2.1.
    Write down equations, in terms of F, W, T, α and β, to represent
    1. the resolution of forces horizontally,
      .......................................................................... [1]
    2. the resolution of forces vertically,
      .......................................................................... [1]
    3. the taking of moments about A.
      .......................................................................... [1]

Q2/9702/02/M/J/06

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Summer/Paper1/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a.i point at which whole weight of body
may be considered to act		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii sum of forces in any direction is zero
sum of moments about any point is zero		 B1
B1		 [2]
b either:
T and W have zero moment about P
so F must have zero moment, i.e. pass through P
or:
if all pass through P, distance from P is zero for all forces  (M1)
so sum of moments about P is zero  (A1)
M1
A1



 [2]
c.i Fcosα = Tcosβ B1 [1]
c.ii W = Fsinα + Tsinβ B1 [1]
c.iii 2W = 3Tsinβ B1 [1]
    1. point at which whole weight of body
      may be considered to act
    2. sum of forces in any direction is zero
      sum of moments about any point is zero
  2. either:
    T and W have zero moment about P
    so F must have zero moment, i.e. pass through P
    or
    if all pass through P, distance from P is zero for all forces
    so sum of moments about P is zero
    1. Fcosα = Tcosβ
    2. W = Fsinα + Tsinβ
    3. 2W = 3Tsinβ
    1. Most candidates did give an adequate explanation for centre of gravity. 
    2. As is often the case, a significant number of candidates considered only linear motion. Answers were marred by imprecise statements such as 'equal and opposite forces' when 'the resultant force is zero' would have been correct. 
  2. It became obvious that very few candidates realised why the three forces must pass through a single point. Common suggestions were 'to complete the triangle of forces' and 'since W and T start at P, then F must start at P'. Very few answers included a mention of moments and that, since W and T pass through P and therefore have zero moment about P, then F must also have zero moment about P. Hence it must pass through P. All three forces passing through P does not imply translational equilibrium.
  3. The most common mistake in this section was a failure to give equations. In most scripts, components of forces were given. Where equations were given, then these were usually correct. 
NO. 162题号：34076

A bullet of mass 2.0 g is fired horizontally into a block of wood of mass 600 g. The block is suspended from strings so that it is free to move in a vertical plane.

The bullet buries itself in the block. The block and bullet rise together through a vertical distance of 8.6 cm, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

    1. Calculate the change in gravitational potential energy of the block and bullet.

      change = ............................................. J [2]
    2. Show that the initial speed of the block and the bullet, after they began to move off together, was 1.3 m s–1. [1]

  2. Using the information in (a)(ii) and the principle of conservation of momentum, determine the speed of the bullet before the impact with the block.

    speed = ....................................... m s–1 [2]
    1. Calculate the kinetic energy of the bullet just before impact.

      kinetic energy = .............................................. J [2]
    2. State and explain what can be deduced from your answers to (c)(i) and (a)(i) about the type of collision between the bullet and the block. [2]

Q3/9702/02/M/J/05

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2005/Summer/Paper2/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a.i ∆Ep = mg∆h
     = 0.602 × 9.8 × 0.086
     = 0.51 J
(do not allow g = 10, m = 0.600 or answer 0.50 J)		 C1

A1

 [1]
b.ii v2 = (2gh =) 2 × 9.8 × 0.086   or   (2 × 0.51)/0.602
v = 1.3 (m s-1)		 M1
A0		 [1]
b 2 × V = 602 × 1.3 (allow 600)
V = 390 m s-1		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.i Ek = ½mv2
    = ½ × 0.002 × 3902
    = 152 J or 153 J or 150 J		 C1

A1		 [2]
c.ii Ek not the same/changes
or Ek before impact>Ek after/Ep after
so must be inelastic collision
(allow 1 mark for 'bullet embeds itself in block' etc.)		 M1
A1		 [2]
    1. ∆Ep = mg∆h
           = 0.602 × 9.8 × 0.086
           = 0.51 J
