      (do not allow g = 10, m = 0.600 or answer 0.50 J)
    2. v2 = (2gh =) 2 × 9.8 × 0.086   or   (2 × 0.51)/0.602
      v = 1.3 (m s-1)
  2. 2 × V = 602 × 1.3 (allow 600)
    V = 390 m s-1
    1. Ek = ½mv2
      = ½ × 0.002 × 3902
      = 152 J or 153 J or 150 J
    2. Ek not the same/changes
      or Ek before impact>Ek after/Ep after
      so must be inelastic collision
      (allow 1 mark for 'bullet embeds itself in block' etc.)
    1. Most candidates were able to calculate the change in energy. Errors were mostly due to inappropriate units for mass and/or vertical displacement.
    2. In most answers, the change in gravitational potential energy was associated correctly with the kinetic energy of the block and bullet. A few candidates obtained the correct answer by unjustified use of equations representing uniform motion in a straight line. 
  2. Candidates were instructed to use the principle of conservation of momentum and consequently, most answers were correct.
    1. Very few candidates failed to calculate a value for the kinetic energy, based on their answers to (b).
    2. The majority of answers included a correct deduction that there would be a loss of kinetic energy and thus the collision is inelastic. However, some asserted that the evidence for a loss of kinetic energy was that some had been converted into potential energy of the block and bullet.

Answers: (a)(i) 0.51 J; (b) 390 ms–1; (c)(i) 152 J.

NO. 163题号：34075

Two forces, each of magnitude F, form a couple acting on the edge of a disc of radius r, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

  1. The disc is made to complete n revolutions about an axis through its centre, normal to the plane of the disc. Write down an expression for
    1. the distance moved by a point on the circumference of the disc, 

      distance = .........................................................
    2. the work done by one of the two forces. 

      work done = ..........................................................  [2]
  2. Using your answer to (a), show that the work W done by a couple producing a torque T when it turns through n revolutions is given by W = 2πnT. [2]
  3. A car engine produces a torque of 470 N m at 2400 revolutions per minute. Calculate the output power of the engine.

    power = .................................. W [2]

Q5/9702/02/M/J/04

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2004/Summer/Paper2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i distance = 2πnr B1 [2]
a.ii work done = F × 2 πnr (accept e.c.f.) B1
b total work done = 2 × F × 2πnr
but torque T = 2Fr
hence work done = T × 2πn		 B1
B1
A0		 [2]
c power = work done/time (= 470 × 2π × 2400)/60)
           = 1.2 × 105 W		 A1 [2]
  Total   [6]
    1. distance = 2πnr
    2. work done = F × 2 πnr (accept e.c.f.)
  2. total work done = 2 × F × 2πnr
    but torque T = 2Fr
    hence work done = T × 2πn
  3. power = work done/time (= 470 × 2π × 2400)/60)
               = 1.2 × 105 W
  1. A surprisingly large number of candidates failed to write down the distance as being equal to n times the circumference of the disc. Furthermore, a large number failed to multiply the force by their answer for the distance. 
  2. This section was very poorly answered. The vast majority considered the work done by one force only and then contrived to arrive at the answer by defining torque as the product of the magnitude of one force and the radius. 
  3.  The majority of candidates did use the formula given in (b) to find the work done per unit time. A surprising number did, however, appear to ignore this formula and used the given values of torque and r.p.m. in apparently quite arbitrary ways. Work done was sometimes equated to torque and time to r.p.m. 

Answer: (c) 1.2 × 105 W.

NO. 164题号：34074

A ball has mass m. It is dropped onto a horizontal plate as shown in Fig. 4.1.

Just as the ball makes contact with the plate, it has velocity v, momentum p and kinetic energy Ek.

    1. Write down an expression for momentum p in terms of m and v.
    2. Hence show that the kinetic energy is given by the expression
           Ek = p2 / 2m.
      [3]
  2. Just before impact with the plate, the ball of mass 35 g has speed 4.5 m s–1. It bounces from the plate so that its speed immediately after losing contact with the plate is 3.5 m s–1. The ball is in contact with the plate for 0.14 s.
    Calculate, for the time that the ball is in contact with the plate,
    1. the average force, in addition to the weight of the ball, that the plate exerts on the ball,

      magnitude of force = .................................... N
      direction of force = ........................................  [4]
    2. the loss in kinetic energy of the ball. 

      loss = ....................................... J  [2]
  3. State and explain whether linear momentum is conserved during the bounce. [3]

Q4/9702/02/M/J/04

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2004/Summer/Paper2/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a.i (p =) mv B1  
a.ii Ek = ½mv2
algebra leading to
Ek = p2 / 2m		 B1
M1
A0		 [3]
b.i ∆p = 0.035 (4.5 + 3.5)  OR  a = (4.5 + 3.5)/0.14 = 
      = 0.28 N s                        = 57.1 m s-2
force = ∆p/ ∆t (= 0.28/0.14)  or  F = ma (= 0.035 × 575.1) (allow e.c.f.)
         = 2.0 N
Note: candidate may add mg = 0.34 N to this answer, deduct 1 mark upwards		 C1

C1
A1
B1		 [4]
b.ii loss = ½ × 0.035 (4.52 – 3.52)
       = 0.14 J
(No credit for 0.282/(2 × 0.035) = 1.12 J)		 C1
A1

  
c e.g. plate (and Earth) gain momentum
i.e. discusses a 'system'
equal and opposite to the change for the ball
i.e. discusses force/momentum
so momentum is conserved
i.e. discusses consequence
B1

M1

A1		 [3]
  Total    [12]
    1. (p =) mv
    2. Ek = ½mv2
      algebra leading to
      Ek = p2 / 2m
    1. ∆p = 0.035 (4.5 + 3.5)  = 0.28 N s
      OR  a = (4.5 + 3.5)/0.14 = = 57.1 m s-2
      force = ∆p/ ∆t (= 0.28/0.14) = 2.0 N
      or  F = ma (= 0.035 × 575.1) (allow e.c.f.)
      Note: candidate may add mg = 0.34 N to this answer, deduct 1 mark upwards
    2. loss = ½ × 0.035 (4.52 – 3.52) = 0.14 J
      (No credit for 0.282/(2 × 0.035) = 1.12 J)
  3. e.g. plate (and Earth) gain momentum
    i.e. discusses a 'system'
    equal and opposite to the change for the ball
    i.e. discusses force/momentum
    so momentum is conserved
    i.e. discusses consequence
  1. Most candidates knew the formulae for both momentum and kinetic energy and were able to make the simple substitution to arrive at the expression given. However, the presentation of this proof was frequently illogical and difficult to follow. 
    1. In most answers, the calculation began with an attempt to determine either the change in momentum or the average acceleration experienced by the ball whilst in contact with the plate. It was very common to find that the vector nature of the velocities was ignored. Other common errors were either to fail to convert the mass to an appropriate unit or to use the weight of the ball, rather than its mass, when calculating the average force. Most did realise that the plate would exert an upward force on the ball. 
    2. The majority of calculations were correct. However, a significant minority assumed that (v2 – u2) is equal to (v – u)2. 
  3. There were very few good answers to this section. Many confused momentum and kinetic energy, stating that momentum is not conserved because the collision is inelastic. Others merely stated that momentum is always conserved in a collision. Very few argued that momentum is only conserved in an isolated system and then discussed what constitutes the isolated system in this example. 

Answers: (b)(i) 2.0 N upwards, (ii) 0.14 J. 

NO. 165题号：34073
  1. State the difference between a scalar quantity and a vector quantity.
    scalar: .......................................................................................
    vector: ...................................................................................... [2]
  2. Two forces of magnitude 6.0 N and 8.0 N act at a point P. Both forces act away from point P and the angle between them is 40°.
    Fig. 1.1 shows two lines at an angle of 40° to one another.


    On Fig. 1.1, draw a vector diagram to determine the magnitude of the resultant of the two forces.

    magnitude of resultant = ...................................... N [4]

Q1/9702/02/M/J/04

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2004/Summer/Paper2/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a scalar: magnitude only 
vector: magnitude and direction (allow scalar with direction)
(allow 1 mark for scalar has no direction, vector has direction)		 B1
B1

 [2]
b diagram has correct shape
with arrows in correct directions
resultant = 13.2 ± 0.2 N   (allow 2 sig. fig)
 (for 12.8 → 13.0 and 13.4 → 13.6, allow 1 mark)
(calculated answer with a correct sketch, allow max 4 marks)
(calculated answer with no sketch – no marks)		 M1
A1
A2



 [4]
  Total   [6]
  1. scalar: magnitude only
    vector: magnitude and direction (allow scalar with direction)
    (allow 1 mark for scalar has no direction, vector has direction)
  2. diagram has correct shape
    with arrows in correct directions
    resultant = 13.2 ± 0.2 N    (allow 2 sig. fig)
    (for 12.8 → 13.0 and 13.4 → 13.6, allow 1 mark)
    (calculated answer with a correct sketch, allow max 4 marks)
    (calculated answer with no sketch – no marks)
  1. Almost all candidates stated satisfactorily the difference between scalar and vector quantities. Candidates should be encouraged to use correct terminology. For example, 'magnitude' rather than 'size' or 'value'. 
  2. Most candidates did construct a parallelogram or a triangle with directional arrows on the vectors. There were some very good, accurately drawn figures but many wrongly assumed that the lengths of the given dotted lines were appropriate for the sides of the parallelogram or triangle. They then gave the answer as the length of the 'resultant', without any regard for scale. A significant number calculated the resultant, having drawn an appropriate diagram. Others, however, disregarded the instruction and calculated the resultant, without drawing even a sketch diagram. 

Answer: (b) 13.2 ± 0.2 N. 

NO. 166题号：34048
  1. Define power.
    ...................................................................... [1]
  2. A cyclist travels along a horizontal road. The variation with time t of speed v is shown in Fig. 3.1.

    The cyclist maintains a constant power and after some time reaches a constant speed of 12 m s–1.
    1. Describe and explain the motion of the cyclist.
      ................................................................. [3]
    2. When the cyclist is moving at a constant speed of 12 m s–1 the resistive force is 48 N. Show that the power of the cyclist is about 600 W. Explain your working. [2]

    3. Use Fig. 3.1 to show that the acceleration of the cyclist when his speed is 8.0 m s–1 is about 0.5 m s–2. [2]

    4. The total mass of the cyclist and bicycle is 80 kg. Calculate the resistive force R acting on the cyclist when his speed is 8.0 m s–1. Use the value for the acceleration given in (iii).

      R = ............................................ N [3]
    5. Use the information given in (ii) and your answer to (iv) to show that, in this situation, the resistive force R is proportional to the speed v of the cyclist. [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper2_3/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a power is the rate of doing work or power = work done / time (taken) or
power = energy transferred / time (taken) 		 B1 [1]
b.i as the speed increases drag / air resistance increases
resultant force reduces hence acceleration is less
constant speed when resultant force is zero
(allow one mark for speed increases and acceleration decreases)		 B1
B1
B1

 [3]
b.ii force from cyclist = drag force / resistive force
P = 12 × 48
P = 576W		 B1
M1
A0		 [2]
b.iii tangent drawn at speed = 8.0ms–1
gradient values that show acceleration between 0.44 to 0.48ms–2		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.iv F – R = ma
600 / 8 – R = 80 × 0.5   [using P = 576] 576 / 8 – R = 80 × 0.5 
R = 75 – 40 = 35 N    R = 72 – 40 = 32N		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
b.v at 12 ms–1 drag is 48N, at 8 ms–1 drag is 35 or 32N
R / v calculated as 4 and 4 or 4.4
and consistent response for whether R is proportional to v or not		 B1 [1]
  1. power is the rate of doing work or power = work done / time (taken) or
    power = energy transferred / time (taken)
    1. as the speed increases drag / air resistance increases
      resultant force reduces hence acceleration is less
      constant speed when resultant force is zero
      (allow one mark for speed increases and acceleration decreases)
    2. force from cyclist = drag force / resistive force
      P = 12 × 48
      P = 576W
    3. tangent drawn at speed = 8.0 ms–1
      gradient values that show acceleration between 0.44 to 0.48ms–2
    4. F – R = ma
      600 / 8 – R = 80 × 0.5    [using P = 576] 576 / 8 – R = 80 × 0.5
      R = 75 – 40 = 35 N     R = 72 – 40 = 32N
    5. at 12 ms–1 drag is 48N, at 8ms–1 drag is 35 or 32N
      R / v calculated as 4 and 4 or 4.4
      and consistent response for whether R is proportional to v or not
  1. In such definitions, it is necessary that the nature of the ratio is made clear. Candidates should be advised that power does involve a transfer of energy and therefore, defining power as being ‘energy/time’ is not appropriate. For both the numerator and the denominator of the expression, the change in each quantity should be shown. 
    1. Candidates do need to gain experience as to the interpretation of such graphs. In many instances, statements were limited to a discussion of the gradient of the graph. It was expected that the reduction in the magnitude of the acceleration would be related to resultant force and hence to the resistive forces. 
    2. Most answers did include appropriate working. However, explanation was lacking in many.
    3. Where a tangent is to be drawn, then care needs to be taken to ensure that the line drawn is, by eye, acceptable. There were many instances where the 'tangent' cut the curve or did not touch it at the relevant point. It was pleasing to note that there were few instances where the graph-grid was not read correctly. 
    4. In some answers, the driving force was confused with the weight of the cyclist and, in others, the force was calculated as the product of mass and the acceleration determined in (b)(ii). Most candidates did, however, attempt to relate driving force to resistance and resultant force. 
    5. Despite being instructed to use answers from previous parts, there were many answers which did not include any form of numerical analysis. Candidates were expected to relate resistance to speed at 12ms–1 and at 8ms–1, and hence come to a valid conclusion. 
NO. 167题号：34047
  1. The drag force D on an object of cross-sectional area A, moving with a speed v through a fluid of density ρ, is given by
                  D = CρAv2
    where C is a constant.
    Show that C has no unit. [2]

  2. A raindrop falls vertically from rest. Assume that air resistance is negligible.
    1. On Fig. 1.1, sketch a graph to show the variation with time t of the velocity v of the raindrop for the first 1.0 s of the motion. [1]
    2. Calculate the velocity of the raindrop after falling 1000 m.

      velocity = ........................................ m s–1 [2]
  3. In practice, air resistance on raindrops is not negligible because there is a drag force.
    This drag force is given by the expression in (a).
    1. State an equation relating the forces acting on the raindrop when it is falling at terminal velocity.  [1]
    2. The raindrop has mass 1.4 × 10–5 kg and cross-sectional area 7.1 × 10–6 m2. The density of the air is 1.2 kg m–3 and the initial velocity of the raindrop is zero. The value of C is 0.60.
      1. Show that the terminal velocity of the raindrop is about 7 m s–1. [2]

      2. The raindrop reaches terminal velocity after falling approximately 10m. On Fig. 1.1, sketch the variation with time t of velocity v for the raindrop. The sketch should include the first 5 s of the motion. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper2_2/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a units for D identified as kg m s–2
all other units shown: units for A: m2 units for v2: m2 s–2 units for ρ: kg m–3
with cancelling / simplification to give C no units 		 M1

A1		 [2]
b.i straight line from (0,0) to (1,9.8) ± half a square B1 [1]
b.ii ½ mv2 = mgh   or using v2 = 2 as
v = (2 × 9.81 × 1000)1/2 = 140m s–1		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.i weight = drag (D) (+ upthrust)
Allow mg or W for weight and D or expression for D for drag		 B1 [1]
c.ii 1. mg = 1.4 ×10–5 × 9.81
   1.4 × 10–5 × 9.81 = 0.5 × 0.6 × 1.2 × 7.1 × 10–6 × v2
   v = 7.33ms–1		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
2. line from (0,0) correct curvature to a horizontal line at velocity of 7ms–1
   line reaches 7ms–1 between 1.5s and 3.5s		 M1
A1		 [1]
  1. units for D identified as kg m s–2
    all other units shown: units for A: m2 units for v2 : m2 s–2 units for ρ: kg m–3
    with cancelling / simplification to give C no units
    1. straight line from (0,0) to (1,9.8) ± half a square
    2. ½ mv2 = mgh   or   using v2 = 2 as
      v = (2 × 9.81 × 1000)1/2 = 140m s–1
    1. weight = drag (D) ( + upthrust)
      Allow mg or W for weight and D or expression for D for drag
    2. 1. mg = 1.4 ×10–5 × 9.81
         1.4 × 10–5 × 9.81 = 0.5 × 0.6 × 1.2 × 7.1 × 10–6 × v2
         v = 7.33 ms–1
      2. line from (0,0) correct curvature to a horizontal line at velocity of 7ms–1
         line reaches 7ms–1 between 1.5s and 3.5s

The question was well answered by the adequately prepared candidates. 

  1. The majority of candidates obtained at least one mark. The answers from some of the candidates were poorly presented and the working was difficult to follow. 
    1. The correct answer was given by the majority of candidates. A significant number either drew a curve or an attempted straight line without a ruler to an incorrect speed.
    2. A straightforward question that caused little difficulty for the majority of candidates. A small number of candidates lost credit for using g = 10ms–2 rather than the value of 9.81 ms–2 given on page 2 of the question paper. 
    1. Many answers did not relate the two forces acting on the raindrop when it is falling at terminal velocity. Some answers gave weight – drag = ma but did not indicate that in this situation the acceleration is zero.
    2. 1. This question was generally well answered. There were a number of candidates who did not present all the steps in their calculation. In a ‘show that’ calculation, all steps in the derivation must be explicitly stated. 
      2. The majority of sketches were incorrect. The initial section that was meant to be a smooth curve with a gradually decreasing gradient was often poorly drawn or given as a straight line. The horizontal section was frequently not drawn at 7 ms–1. The point between the curve and the horizontal section was drawn with an abrupt change of gradient. A significant number of candidates tried to draw a separate sketch in the space on page 5 rather than follow the instructions to draw a sketch on Fig. 1.1. 
NO. 168题号：34046

The variation with time t of velocity v of a car is shown in Fig. 2.1.

At time t = 0, the driver sees an obstacle in the road. A short time later, the driver applies the brakes. The car travels in two stages, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

  1. Use Fig. 2.1 to describe the velocity of the car in
    1. stage 1,
    ................................................................ [1]
    2. stage 2.
    ................................................................ [1]
    1. Calculate the distance travelled by the car from t = 0 to t = 3.5 s.

      total distance = .................................. m [2]
    2. The car has a total mass of 1250 kg. Determine the total resistive force acting on the car in stage 2.

      force = ............................................. N [3]
  3. For safety reasons drivers are asked to travel at lower speeds. For each stage, describe and explain the effect on the distance travelled for the same car and driver travelling at half the initial speed shown in Fig. 2.1.
    1. stage 1:
      ...................................................................... [1]
    2. stage 2:
      ....................................................................... [2]

Q2/9702/23/O/N/11

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper2_3/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a 1. constant velocity / speed B1 [1]
2. either constant / uniform decrease (in velocity/speed)
    or constant rate of decrease (in velocity/speed)		 B1 [1]
b.i distance is area under graph for both stages
stage 1: distance (18 × 0.65) = 11.7 (m)
stage 2: distance = (9 × [3.5 – 0.65]) = 25.7 (m)
total distance = 37.(4)m
(–1 for misreading graph)
{for stage 2, allow calculation of acceleration (6.32ms–2)
and then s = (18 × 2.85) + ½ × 6.32 (2.85)2 = 25.7m}		 C1


A1



 [2]
b.ii either  F = ma             or  EK = ½mv2
a = (18 – 0)/(3.5 – 0.65)    EK = ½ × 1250 × (18)2
F = 1250 × 6.3 =7900N  or F = ½ × 1250 × (18)2 / 25.7 = 7900N		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
or initial momentum = 1250 × 18
  F = change in momentum / time taken
  F = (1250 × 18) / 2.85 = 7900		 (C1)
(C1)
(A1)		  
c.i stage 1: either half / less distance as speed is half / less
or half distance as the time is the same
or sensible discussion of reaction time		 B1 [1]
c.ii stage 2: either same acceleration and s = v2 / 2a  or  v2 is ¼
             ¼ of the distance		 B1
B1		 [2]
  1. 1. constant velocity / speed
    2. either constant / uniform decrease (in velocity/speed)
       or constant rate of decrease (in velocity/speed)
    1. distance is area under graph for both stages
      stage 1: distance (18 × 0.65) = 11.7 (m)
      stage 2: distance = (9 × [3.5 – 0.65]) = 25.7 (m) 
      total distance = 37.(4)m
      (–1 for misreading graph)
      {for stage 2, allow calculation of acceleration (6.32ms–2)
      and then s = (18 × 2.85) + ½ × 6.32 (2.85)2 = 25.7m}
    2. either F = ma                or        EK = ½mv2
              a = (18 – 0)/(3.5 – 0.65)    EK = ½ × 1250 × (18)2
      F = 1250 × 6.3 =7900N   or   F = ½ × 1250 × (18)2 / 25.7 = 7900N
      or initial momentum = 1250 × 18
         F = change in momentum / time taken
         F = (1250 × 18) / 2.85 = 7900
    1. stage 1: either half / less distance as speed is half / less
                or half distance as the time is the same
                or sensible discussion of reaction time
    2. stage 2: either same acceleration and s = v2 / 2a or v2 is ¼
                 ¼ of the distance
  1. For stage 1, most answers did include a reference to constant velocity. However, for stage 2, although it was realised that the velocity is decreasing, the fact that the decrease is constant was not included. 
    1. With few exceptions, the area between the line and the t-axis was calculated. There were relatively few errors when reading values for t from the graph. 
    2. In most answers, it was realised that the acceleration should be calculated and then substituted into the formula F = ma. It was not uncommon to find that, when calculating the acceleration, an incorrect value for the elapsed time was substituted. 
    1. Most statements were adequate. It was expected that candidates would realise that the distance is reduced because the speed is less.
    2. In general, the answer given was that the distance would be halved. Most candidates did not realise that, not only is the initial speed halved but also, the time to come to a halt is reduced. Very few candidates attempted to answer the question by reference to an equation of motion. Most attempted a verbal argument rather than invoke the equation v2 = u2 + 2as.
NO. 169题号：34043

A student takes measurements to determine a value for the acceleration of free fall. Some of the apparatus used is illustrated in Fig. 4.1.

The student measures the vertical distance d between the base of the electromagnet and the bench. The time t for an iron ball to fall from the electromagnet to the bench is also measured.
Corresponding values of t2 and d are shown in Fig. 4.2.

  1. On Fig. 4.2, draw the line of best fit for the points. [1]

  2. State and explain why there is a non-zero intercept on the graph of Fig. 4.2.
    ....................................................................... [2]
  3. Determine the student's value for
    1. the diameter of the ball,

      diameter = ........................................ cm [1]
    2. the acceleration of free fall. 

      acceleration = ..................................... m s–2 [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper2_3/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a acceptable straight line drawn  (touching every point) B1 [1]
b the distance fallen is not d
d is the distance fallen plus the diameter of the ball 
('d is not measured to the bottom of the ball' scores 2/2)		 C1
A1

 [2]
c.i diameter: allow 1.5 ± 0.5cm (accept one SF)
no ecf from (a)		 A1

 [1]
c.ii gradient = 4.76, ± 0.1 with evidence that origin has not been used
gradient = g / 2
g = 9.5m s–2		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
  1. acceptable straight line drawn (touching every point)
  2. the distance fallen is not d
    d is the distance fallen plus the diameter of the ball
    ('d is not measured to the bottom of the ball' scores 2/2)
    1. diameter: allow 1.5 ± 0.5cm (accept one SF)
      no ecf from (a)
    2. gradient = 4.76, ± 0.1 with evidence that origin has not been used
      gradient = g / 2
      g = 9.5m s–2
  1. With few exceptions, candidates drew an acceptable line using a straight edge.
  2. In general, it was realised that the diameter of the ball was involved. The nature of this involvement was not always made clear.
    1. Apart from those answers where the scale had been read incorrectly, a value for the diameter was given within acceptable limits.  
    2. The vast majority of answers did involve the calculation of a gradient. The attention of candidates should be drawn to the fact that, when determining a gradient, the co-ordinates of two widely separated points on the line should be used. All too often, one point was used, thus assuming the line passes through the origin. 
      A common misconception was to assume that the gradient of the line is the acceleration.
NO. 170题号：34041

A ball is thrown horizontally from the top of a building, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

The ball is thrown with a horizontal speed of 8.2 m s–1. The side of the building is vertical. At point P on the path of the ball, the ball is distance x from the building and is moving at an angle of 60° to the horizontal. Air resistance is negligible.

  1. For the ball at point P,
    1. show that the vertical component of its velocity is 14.2 m s–1, [2]

    2. determine the vertical distance through which the ball has fallen, 

      distance = ....................................... m [2]
    3. determine the horizontal distance x.

      x = ............................................ m
  2. The path of the ball in (a), with an initial horizontal speed of 8.2 m s–1, is shown again in Fig. 2.2.

    On Fig. 2.2, sketch the new path of the ball for the ball having an initial horizontal speed
    1. greater than 8.2 m s–1 and with negligible air resistance (label this path G), [2]
    2. equal to 8.2 m s–1 but with air resistance (label this path A). [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper2_1/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a.i horizontal speed constant at 8.2 m s–1
vertical component of speed = 8.2 tan 60°
   = 14.2 m s–1		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
a.ii 14.22 = 2 × 9.8 × h (using g = 10 then –1)
vertical distance = 10.3 m		 C1
A1		 [2]
a.iii time of descent = 14.2 / 9.8 = 1.45 s
x = 1.45 × 8.2
   = 11.9 m		 C1

A1		 [2]
b.i smooth path curved and above given path
hits ground at more acute angle		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.ii smooth path curved and below given path
hits ground at steeper angle		 M1
A1		 [2]
    1. horizontal speed constant at 8.2 m s–1
      vertical component of speed = 8.2 tan 60° = 14.2 m s–1
    2. 14.22 = 2 × 9.8 × h (using g = 10 then –1)
      vertical distance = 10.3 m
    3. time of descent = 14.2 / 9.8 = 1.45 s
      x = 1.45 × 8.2 = 11.9 m
    1. smooth path curved and above given path
      hits ground at more acute angle
    2. smooth path curved and below given path
      hits ground at steeper angle

Candidates need to be aware that the horizontal and vertical motion of a projectile in a gravitational field can be analysed in two separate calculations. 

    1. A significant number of candidates realised that the horizontal component of the ball’s velocity would remain constant as the ball moved towards the ground. However, very few were then able to use a right-angled triangle to obtain the relationship between the horizontal and vertical components of the velocity at point P. 
    2. The application of an equation for constant acceleration was carried out by some of the wellprepared candidates. The majority of candidates did not use the correct component of velocity or were unable to obtain a solution using a valid equation. 
    3. The majority of candidates were unable to obtain a correct answer for this problem. There were a number of candidates who did not realise that there was no acceleration in the horizontal direction. The intermediate step required a calculation of the time taken to reach point P. This caused difficulty for the majority of candidates. 
    1. This part enabled some of the weaker candidates to score at least partial credit. The majority realised that the ball would reach a greater horizontal distance. However, further credit was often not awarded owing to poor or inaccurate drawing of the curve. Some of the curves were drawn going upwards at the start and some had the angle the curve made with the ground greater than that of the original.
    2. The majority of candidates were able to score partial credit for a curve that reached the ground before the original. Again further credit was often not awarded owing to poorly drawn curves. 
NO. 171题号：34036

A student investigates the speed of a trolley as it rolls down a slope, as illustrated in Fig. 2.1.

The speed v of the trolley is measured using a speed sensor for different values of the time t that the trolley has moved from rest down the slope.

Fig. 2.2 shows the variation with t of v.

  1. Use Fig. 2.2 to determine the acceleration of the trolley at the point on the graph where t = 0.80 s.

    acceleration = ………………………… m s–2 [4]
    1. State whether the acceleration is increasing or decreasing for values of t greater than 0.6 s. Justify your answer by reference to Fig. 2.2.
      ...................................................................... [2]
    2. Suggest an explanation for this change in acceleration.
      ...................................................................... [1]
  3. Name the feature of Fig. 2.2 that indicates the presence of
    1. random error,
      ...................................................................... [1]
    2. systematic error.
      ...................................................................... [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Winter/Paper2/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a uses a tangent (anywhere), not a single point
draws tangent at correct position
acceleration = 1.7 ± 0.1
(outside 1.6 → 1.8 but within 1.5 → 1.9, allow 1 mark)		 C1
B1
A2

 [4]
b.i because slope (of tangent of graph) is decreasing
acceleration is decreasing		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.ii e.g. air resistance increases (with speed)
(angle of) slope of ramp decreases		 B1 [1]
c.i scatter of points about line B1 [1]
c.ii intercept / line does not go through origin B1 [1]
  1. uses a tangent (anywhere), not a single point
    draws tangent at correct position
    acceleration = 1.7 ± 0.1
    (outside 1.6 → 1.8 but within 1.5 → 1.9, allow 1 mark)
    1. because slope (of tangent of graph) is decreasing
      acceleration is decreasing
    2. e.g. air resistance increases (with speed)
      (angle of) slope of ramp decreases
    1. scatter of points about line
    2. intercept / line does not go through origin
  1. Approximately one half of all candidates correctly attempted to find the acceleration by drawing a tangent to the curve at the specified time. These tangents were drawn with varying degrees of precision but most were within acceptable limits. Of the remaining candidates, some did find a gradient by using the co-ordinates of two points on the curve but a surprisingly large number merely found the ratio of speed and time at the specified time. 
    1. Most did relate acceleration to gradient but many found difficulty in expressing the idea that, as time increases, the gradient decreases. Many referred to the line as 'flattens out' or 'bends downwards' or 'becomes less steep'. 
    2. There were very few correct suggestions such as increasing air resistance or changing slope of the ramp. Many candidates stated that friction would cause the trolley to decelerate. Others thought that the trolley had run off the end of the slope. 
  3. In a significant number of answers, there was a failure to observe the instructions. Rather than name the features of Fig. 2.2 that indicate the presence of the two types of error, there were lengthy explanations as to what is meant by these terms, with no reference to the graph. Many candidates did relate a systematic error with an intercept. The feature identifying random error was less positively identified in that the scatter of points was not related to their distribution about the curve.
NO. 172题号：34033

A girl stands at the top of a cliff and throws a ball vertically upwards with a speed of 12 m s–1, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1.

At the time that the girl throws the ball, her hand is a height h above the horizontal ground at the base of the cliff.
The variation with time t of the speed v of the ball is shown in Fig. 3.2.

Speeds in the upward direction are shown as being positive. Speeds in the downward direction are negative.

  1. State the feature of Fig. 3.2 that shows that the acceleration is constant.
    ....................................................................... [1]
  2. Use Fig. 3.2 to determine the time at which the ball
    1. reaches maximum height,

      time = ………………………………. s
    2. hits the ground at the base of the cliff.

      time = ………………………………. s
      [2]
  3. Determine the maximum height above the base of the cliff to which the ball rises.

    height = …………………………… m [3]
  4. The ball has mass 250 g. Calculate the magnitude of the change in momentum of the ball between the time that it leaves the girl’s hand to time t = 4.0 s.

    change = …………………………… N s [3]
    1. State the principle of conservation of momentum.
      ............................................................... [2]
    2. Comment on your answer to (d) by reference to this principle.
      ............................................................... [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2004/Winter/Paper2/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a constant gradient/straight line B1 [1]
b.i 1.2 s A1 [2]
b.ii 4.4 s A1
c either use of area under line or h = average speed x time
h = ½ × (4.4 – 1.2) × 32
   = 51.2 m
(allow 2/3 marks for determination of h = 44 m or h =58.4 m
allow 1/3 marks for answer 7.2 m)		 C1
C1
A1


 [3]
d ∆p = m∆v OR p = mv
     = 0.25 × (28 + 12)
     = 10 N s
(answer 4 N s scores 2/3 marks)		 C1
C1
A1

 [3]
e.i total/sum momentum before = total/sum momentum after
in any closed system		 B1
B1		 [2]
e.ii either the system is the ball and Earth
   momentum of Earth changes by same amount
   but in the opposite direction		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
or Ball is not an isolated system/there is a force on the ball (B1) 
    Gravitational force acts on the ball (B1)
    causes change in momentum/law does not apply here (B1)
    (if explains in terms of air resistance, allow first mark only) 		  
  1. constant gradient/straight line
    1. 1.2 s
    2. 4.4 s
  3. either use of area under line or h = average speed x time
       h = ½ × (4.4 – 1.2) × 32 C1
          = 51.2 m
    (allow 2/3 marks for determination of h = 44 m or h =58.4 m
    allow 1/3 marks for answer 7.2 m)
  4. ∆p = m∆v OR p = mv
         = 0.25 × (28 + 12)
         = 10 N s
    (answer 4 N s scores 2/3 marks)
    1. total/sum momentum before = total/sum momentum after
      in any closed system
    2. either the system is the ball and Earth
               momentum of Earth changes by same amount
               but in the opposite direction
      or Ball is not an isolated system/there is a force on the ball
          Gravitational force acts on the ball
          causes change in momentum/law does not apply here
          (if explains in terms of air resistance, allow first mark only)
  1. The vast majority of candidates did give an acceptable answer by making reference to either constant gradient or a straight line.
  2. Interpreting the graph to read off the times presented very few problems.
  3. The problem could be approached by considering either the areas of triangles on the graph or by using the equations of motion. Regardless of the approach, this question was, in general, poorly answered. Despite relevant times being given in (b), very few used those answers in the calculation. Very many calculated the area of the smaller triangle and thus determined the maximum height above the girl’s hand. Others either found the sum or the difference of the areas of the two triangles. Rarely was there any explanation as to what the candidate was attempting. 
  4. Candidates were much more successful in finding the magnitude of the change in momentum. The neatest solutions were in those scripts where change in momentum was equated to the impulse applied to the ball, realising that the gravitational force (weight) acted for 4.0 s. Candidates adopting this approach also avoided the common pitfall of failing to recognise the vector nature of momentum. 
    1. Most candidates had some idea as regards the principle but ideas were poorly expressed. Many gave their statements in terms of colliding bodies, rather than the general interaction of bodies within an isolated system. Frequently, statements did not include the fact that the system must be 'isolated' or that there must be no resultant external force acting on it. 
    2. Logical comment was limited to a minority of answers. Two approaches were acceptable. First, the ball and the Earth could be identified as the closed system to which the principle could be applied. Second, it could be argued that the principle does not apply to the ball because it is not an isolated system. Many answers were inadequate in that they were not based on a full statement of the principle. A common answer was to state that the principle does not apply because the ball is not suffering a collision.

Answers: (b)(i) 1.2 s, (ii) 4.4 s; (c) 51.2 m; (d) 10 Ns.

NO. 173题号：34032
  1. One of the equations of motion may be written as 
                  v2 = u2 + 2as.
    1. Name the quantity represented by the symbol a.
      .........................................................................
    2. The quantity represented by the symbol a may be either positive or negative. State the significance of a negative value.
      .......................................................................... 
      [2]
  2. A student investigates the motion of a small polystyrene sphere as it falls from rest alongside a vertical scale marked in centimetres. To do this, a number of flash photographs of the sphere are taken at 0.1 s intervals, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

    The first photograph is taken at time t = 0.
    By reference to Fig. 1.1,
    1. briefly explain how it can be deduced that the sphere reaches a constant speed,
      .......................................................................
    2. determine the distance that the sphere has fallen from rest during a time of
      1. 0.7 s,

         distance = …………………………………. cm
      2. 1.1 s.

         distance = …………………………………. cm
      [4]
  3. The student repeats the experiment with a lead sphere that falls with constant acceleration and does not reach a constant speed.
    Determine the number of flash photographs that will be observed against the 160 cm scale.
    Include in your answer the photograph obtained at time t = 0.

    number = …………………………………. [3]

Q1/9702/2/O/N03

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2003/Winter/Paper2/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i acceleration (allow a definition of acceleration) B1 [2]
a.ii the velocity is decreasing or force/acceleration is in negative
direction – accept 'body is decelerating'/'slowing down'		 B1
b.i e.g. separation of dots becomes constant/does not continue to increase (must make a reference to the diagram) B1 [4]
b.ii 1. distance = 132 cm B1
2. at constant speed, distance travelled in 0.1 s = 25 cm
   (allow ± 1 cm)
   distance = 132 + (4 × 25)
                 = 232 cm
C1

A1
c s = ut + ½at2
1.6 = ½ × 9.8 × t2 (allow g = 10 m s-2
t = 0.57 s
hence 6 photographs ('bald' answer scores 2 marks only)
C1
C1
A1		 [3]
    1. acceleration (allow a definition of acceleration)
    2. the velocity is decreasing or force/acceleration is in negative direction – accept ‘body is decelerating’/‘slowing down’
    1. e.g. separation of dots becomes constant/does not continue to increase (must make a reference to the diagram)
    2. 1. distance = 132 cm
      2. at constant speed, distance travelled in 0.1 s = 25 cm
      (allow ± 1 cm)
      distance = 132 + (4 × 25) = 232 cm
  3. s = ut + ½at2
    1.6 = ½ × 9.8 × t2     (allow g = 10 m s-2
      t = 0.57 s
    hence 6 photographs (‘bald’ answer scores 2 marks only)
    1. With very few exceptions, a was associated with acceleration. 
    2. Many correctly associated a negative value with deceleration, decreasing velocity or acceleration in the opposite direction to that which was defined as positive. However, a significant number thought that the acceleration would be in the opposite direction to the direction of motion or that the speed would be decreasing. Neither of these suggestions is necessarily correct. 
    1. Most candidates related constant speed to equal distances covered in equal time intervals but many then failed to relate this fact to the diagram.
    2. In (i) most candidates were able to read off the required distance and then add the distance travelled at constant speed in part (ii). However, a significant minority calculated an average speed for the first 0.7 s and then applied this speed to the whole time of 1.1 s. Others assumed a constant acceleration, either g or one calculated for the first 0.7 s. 
  3. Most candidates recognised that the sphere could be considered to be in free fall with acceleration g. However, many who correctly calculated the time then failed to determine the correct number of flashes. It was not uncommon to find that the distance was not converted to metres for the calculation using g = 9.8 m s-2. 
NO. 174题号：34031

A ball falls from rest onto a flat horizontal surface. Fig. 3.1 shows the variation with time t of the velocity v of the ball as it approaches and rebounds from the surface.

Use data from Fig. 3.1 to determine

  1. the distance travelled by the ball during the first 0.40 s, 

    distance = ……………………………………. m [2]
  2. the change in momentum of the ball, of mass 45 g, during contact of the ball with the surface,

    change = ………………………………….. N s [4]
  3. the average force acting on the ball during contact with the surface.

    force = ……………………………………. N [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2002/Winter/Paper2/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a v2 = u2 + 2as   OR   use of triangle etc
4.02 = 2 × 9.8 × s    OR    s = ½ × 4.0 × 0.4
s = 0.82 m   OR   0.80 m		 C1

A1		 [2]
b Δp = m(v – u)   OR  p = mv
speeds are 4.2 ms–1 and 3.6 m s–1
Δp = 0.045 (4.2 + 3.6) (2/4 only if speeds not added)
     = 0.35 N s
(1 mark only if only one speed used)		 C1
C1
C1
A1

 [4]
c any time between 0.14 s and 0.17 s
force = Δp / Δt = 0.35 / 0.14 (allow e.c.f.)
       = 2.5 N		 C1

A1		 [2]
  1. v2 = u2 + 2as   OR   use of triangle etc
    4.02 = 2 × 9.8 × s    OR    s = ½ × 4.0 × 0.4
    s = 0.82 m   OR   0.80 m
  2. Δp = m(v - u)   OR  p = mv
    speeds are 4.2 ms-1 and 3.6 m s-1
    Δp = 0.045 (4.2 + 3.6) (2/4 only if speeds not added)
         = 0.35 Ns
    (1 mark only if only one speed used)
  3. any time between 0.14 s and 0.17 s
    force = Δp / Δt = 0.35 / 0.14 (allow e.c.f.)
           = 2.5 N
  1. This part of the question was done well. Most candidates used either the appropriate area on the graph or an equation for linear motion. Where a value for the acceleration was required, either that deduced from the graph or the acceleration of free fall was considered to be acceptable.
  2. In general, answers here were poor. The majority of candidates either failed to identify correctly the region of the graph for which the ball was in contact with the plate or failed to take into account the change in direction when calculating the change in velocity of the ball.
  3. It was common to find that, where candidates attempted to find the average rate of change of momentum, they used an incorrect value for the time of contact. Some calculations were based on use of the formula F = ma. Although this may be appropriate, many answers involved the acceleration of free fall or only the acceleration during the linear change of velocity during contact.
NO. 175题号：34030
  1. A student walks from A to B along the path showm in Fig. 2.1.

    The student takes time t to walk from A to B.
    1. State the quantity, apart from t, that must be measured in order to determine the average value of
      1. speed,
      ......................................................................................... [1]
      2. velocity.
      ......................................................................................... [1]
    2. Define acceleration.
      ......................................................................................... [1]
  2. A girl falls vertically onto a trampoline, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

    The trampoline consists of a central section supported by springy material. At time t = 0 the girl starts to fall. The girl hits the trampoline and rebounds vertically. The variation with time t of velocity v of the girl is illustrated in Fig. 2.3.

    For the motion of the girl, calculate
    1. the distance fallen between time t = 0 and when she hits the trampoline,

      distance = ............................................. m [2]
    2. the average acceleration during the rebound.

      acceleration = ........................................ m s–2 [2]
    1. Use Fig. 2.3 to compare, without calculation, the accelerations of the girl before and after the rebound. Explain your answer.
      ........................................................................... [2]
    2. Use Fig. 2.3 to compare, without calculation, the potential energy of the girl at t = 0 and t = 1.85 s. Explain your answer.
      ........................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_3/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a.i 1. distance of path / along line AB B1 [1]
2. shortest distance between AB / distance in straight line between AB
  or displacement from A to B		 B1 [1]
a.ii acceleration = rate of change of velocity A1 [1]
b.i distance = area under line or (v/2)t or s = (8.8)2 / (2 × 9.81)
  = 8.8 / 2 × 0.90 = 3.96m or s = 3.95m = 4(.0)m		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii acceleration = (– 4.4 – 8.8) / 0.50
  = (–) 26(.4) m s–2		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.i the accelerations are constant as straight lines
the accelerations are the same as same gradient or
no air resistance as acceleration is constant or
change of speed in opposite directions (one speeds up one slows down)		 B1


B1		 [2]
c.ii area under the lines represents height
or KE at trampoline equals PE at maximum height
second area is smaller / velocity after rebound smaller hence KE less
hence less height means loss in potential energy
B1
B1
A0		 [2]
    1. 1. distance of path / along line AB.
      2. shortest distance between AB / distance in straight line between AB or displacement from A to B.
    2. acceleration = rate of change of velocity
    1. distance
      = area under line or (v/2)t or s = (8.8)2 / (2 × 9.81)
      = 8.8 / 2 × 0.90 = 3.96m or s = 3.95m = 4(.0)m
    2. acceleration = (– 4.4 – 8.8) / 0.50 = (–) 26(.4)ms–2 
    1. the accelerations are constant as straight lines

      the accelerations are the same as same gradient or
      no air resistance as acceleration is constant or
      change of speed in opposite directions (one speeds up one slows down)

    2. area under the lines represents height
      or KE at trampoline equals PE at maximum height

      second area is smaller / velocity after rebound smaller hence KE less
      hence less height means loss in potential energy

There was a lack of detail and accuracy given in answers to many parts of this question. 

    1. The answers required a specific reference to the detail given in the question. The majority of answers were not linked to the path shown in Fig. 2.1. 
    2. The accepted definition of acceleration was given by a minority of candidates. Candidates should learn the standard definitions required for this syllabus.
    1. The majority of candidates correctly calculated the distance fallen by determining the area under the line on the graph shown in Fig. 2.3. The graph axis for either the velocity or the time was misread by a significant number of candidates. A small number made the error of using the final velocity instead of the average velocity in their calculation.
    2. There were a significant number of correct solutions for the average acceleration. Candidates would benefit from practice involving calculations were the initial and final velocities are in opposite directions. A minority of candidates did not read the question and determined the instantaneous acceleration by calculating the gradient of a line drawn as a tangent to the curve. 
    1. The majority of candidates did not read the question and use information from Fig. 2.3 to explain their answer. A comparison between the two straight lines on the graph before and after the rebound was seldom described by candidates.
    2. The majority of candidates did not read the question and use information from Fig. 2.3 to explain their answer. A comparison between the two areas on the graph before and after the rebound was seldom described by candidates. 
NO. 176题号：33999
  1. State two SI base units other than the kilogram, metre and second.
    1. ..........................................................
    2. .......................................................... [2]
  2. A metal wire has original length l0. It is then suspended and hangs vertically as shown in Fig. 1.1.

    The weight of the wire causes it to stretch. The elastic potential energy stored in the wire is E.
    1. Show that the SI base units of E are kg m2 s-2. [2]

    2. The elastic potential energy E is given by E = Cρ2g2Al03
      where ρ is the density of the metal,
                g is the acceleration of free fall,
                A is the cross-sectional area of the wire
      and    C is a constant.
      Determine the SI base units of C.

      SI base units of C .....................................[3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Winter/Paper2_1/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a kelvin / K
ampere / amp / A
[allow mole / mol and candela / Cd]  		 B1
B1

 [2]
b.i energy OR work = force × distance [allow any energy expression]
units: kg m s–2 × m   OR   kg (m s–1)2 for ½ mv2 or mc2
    (ignore any numerical factor)
= kg m2 s–2		 C1
M1

A0		 [2]
b.ii units: ρ: kgm–3   g: m s–2   A: m2   l0: m
C: kg m2 s–2 / kg2 m–6 m2 s–4m2 m3   [any subject]
= kg–1ms2  (allow ms2 / kg)		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
  1. kelvin / K
    ampere / amp / A 
    [allow mole / mol and candela / Cd]
    1. energy OR work = force × distance [allow any energy expression]
      units: kg m s–2 × m   OR   kg (m s–1)2 for ½ mv2 or mc2
      (ignore any numerical factor)
      units: = kg m2 s–2
    2. units: ρ: kgm–3
      g: m s–2
      A: m2
      l0: m 
      C: kg m2 s–2 / kg2 m–6 m2 s–4m2 m3   [any subject]
      = kg–1 m s2      (allow ms2 / kg)

This question was answered well by nearly all well prepared candidates. 

  1. This was a straightforward introductory question to help the candidates settle into the examination and which caused little difficulty for the average candidate. Kelvin and ampere were the most common answers, although candela and mole were also stated by some candidates. 
    1. This was generally answered correctly. A variety of correct energy equations were used by the candidates. A very small minority thought that work done was equal to force/weight multiplied by length. 
    2. This question differentiated the candidates. A good starting point was to list the base units for each of the terms involved in the given equation. A number of candidates did not include the powers for some of the terms in the equation. The processing of the indices proved difficult for some candidates. Occasionally, the cancelling of units was poorly presented, making it difficult for the candidates to keep track of what base units had been cancelled. The division of units with negative indices also caused some difficulty. For example s–2/s–4 was often stated as s–2 instead of s2.
NO. 177题号：33998
  1. The spacing between two atoms in a crystal is 3.8 × 10–10 m.  State this distance in pm.

    spacing = .........................................pm [1]
  2. Calculate the time of one day in Ms.

    time = .......................................... Ms [1]
  3. The distance from the Earth to the Sun is 0.15 Tm. Calculate the time in minutes for light to travel from the Sun to the Earth.

    time = ......................................... min [2]
  4. Underline all the vector quantities in the list below. [1]
      distance    energy     momentum   weight     work
  5. The velocity vector diagram for an aircraft heading due north is shown to scale in Fig. 1.1. There is a wind blowing from the north-west.

    The speed of the wind is 36 m s–1 and the speed of the aircraft is 250 m s–1.
    1. Draw an arrow on Fig. 1.1 to show the direction of the resultant velocity of the aircraft. [1]

    2. Determine the magnitude of the resultant velocity of the aircraft.

      resultant velocity = ...................................... m s–1 [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper2_3/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a spacing = 380 or 3.8 × 102 pm B1 [1]
b time = 24 × 3600
time = 0.086 (0.0864)Ms		 B1 [1]
c time = distance / speed =
        = 500(s) = 8.3min		 C1
A1		 [2]
d momentum and weight B1 [1]
e.i arrow to the right of plane direction (about 4° to 24°) B1 [1]
e.ii scale diagram drawn
or use of cosine formula v2 = 2502 + 362 – 2 × 250 × 36 × cos45°
or resolving v = [(36cos45°)2 + (250 – 36sin45°)2]1/2		 C1 [2]
resultant velocity = 226 (220 – 240 for scale diagram)m s–1
allow one mark for values 210 to 219 or 241 to 250ms–1
or use of formula (v2 = 51068) v = 230 (226)ms–1		 A1
  1. spacing = 380 or 3.8 × 102pm
  2. time = 24 × 3600
    time = 0.086 (0.0864)Ms
  3. time = distance / speed = (1.5 ×1011) / (3 × 108)
    = 500 (s) = 8.3 min
  4. momentum and weight
    1. arrow to the right of plane direction (about 4° to 24°)
    2. scale diagram drawn
      or use of cosine formula v2 = 2502 + 362 – 2 × 250 × 36 × cos45°
      or resolving v = [(36cos45°)2 + (250 – 36sin45°)2]1/2

      resultant velocity = 226 (220 – 240 for scale diagram) m s–1
      allow one mark for values 210 to 219 or 241 to 250ms–1
      or use of formula (v2 = 51068) v = 230 (226) ms–1
  1. Generally, the correct answer was given. 
  2. Where a candidate did not give the correct answer in (a), then usually an incorrect response was also given in (b). 
  3. Most answers were correct, with the answer being given, appropriately, as a decimal to two or three significant figures. 
  4. The majority of answers were correct but a surprisingly large number included either work or distance as a vector, omitting weight. 
  5. Many diagrams were drawn without careful thought as to direction. In these situations, an arrow was drawn to the right of the centre line at highly inappropriate angles. Conversely, there was a minority of carefully-drawn scale diagrams. The cosine formula was used correctly in a minority of scripts. Where candidates attempted to calculate two perpendicular components for the resultant velocity of the aircraft, many failed to apply correctly the components of the wind speed. 
NO. 178题号：33996
    1. Distinguish between vector quantities and scalar quantities.
      ...................................................................... [2] 
    2. State whether each of the following is a vector quantity or a scalar quantity.
      1. temperature 
        .............................................................[1]
      2. acceleration of free fall 
        .............................................................[1]
      3. electrical resistance 
        .............................................................[1]
  2. A block of wood of weight 25 N is held stationary on a slope by means of a string, as shown in Fig.1.1.

    The tension in the string is T and the slope pushes on the block with a force R that is normal to the slope.
    Either by scale drawing on Fig.1.1 or by calculation, determine the tension T in the string.

    T = .............................................. N [3] 
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper2_2/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i scalar quantity has magnitude (allow size)
vector quantity has magnitude and direction		 B1
B1		 [2]
a.ii 1. temperature: scalar B1 [1]
2. acceleration: vector B1 [1]
3. resistance: scalar B1 [1]
b either  triangle / parallelogram with correct shape
  tension = 14 .3N  (allow ± 0.5 N)		 C1
A2		 [3]
  (if > ±0.5N but ≤ ±1N, allow 1 mark)
or R = 25 cos 35°
   T = R tan 35°
   T = 14.3N
or T = 25 sin 35°
   T = 14.3N
or R and T resolved vertically and horizontally
   leading to T = 14.3 N
(C1)
(C1)
(A1)
(C2)
(A1)
(C2)
(A1)		  
    1. scalar quantity has magnitude (allow size)
      vector quantity has magnitude and direction
    2. 1. temperature: scalar
      2. acceleration: vector
      3. resistance: scalar
  2. either     triangle / parallelogram with correct shape
               tension = 14 .3N   (allow ± 0.5 N) 
    (if > ±0.5N but ≤ ±1N, allow 1 mark)
    or R = 25 cos 35°
        T = R tan 35° 
        T = 14.3N
    or T = 25 sin 35°
        T = 14.3N
    or R and T resolved vertically and horizontally
        leading to T = 14.3N

This proved to be a good introductory question with many candidates scoring full credit in (a).

    1. The majority of candidates distinguished clearly between vector and scalar quantities. A small minority of candidates concentrated on the requirement of a direction for a vector quantity and omitted the need for a magnitude to describe both quantities. 
    2. Most answers were correct. A few candidates incorrectly considered temperature or electrical resistance to be vector quantities.
  2. A large number of candidates obtained the correct answer for the tension. The majority of candidates attempted the question by calculation. The most common successful answer resolved the forces in a direction parallel to the slope. Some candidates attempted to resolve vertically and horizontally but few completed the long calculation successfully. Very few used a scale diagram. Those who did draw a scale diagram tended to draw a very small vector triangle which was often of the wrong shape. 
NO. 179题号：33995
  1. Two of the SI base quantities are mass and time. State three other SI base quantities.

    1. ......................................................................................................................................
    2. ......................................................................................................................................
    3. ......................................................................................................................................
    [3]

  2. A sphere of radius r is moving at speed v through air of density ρ. The resistive force F acting on the sphere is given by the expression
                                                             F = Br2ρvk
    where B and k are constants without units.
    1. State the SI base units of F, ρ and v.

      F       ..............................................................................................................................
      ρ ..............................................................................................................................
      v ..............................................................................................................................
      [3]

A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper2_1/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a length, current, temperature, amount of substance, (luminous intensity)
 any three, 1 each 		 B3 [3]
b.i F: kg m s–2
ρ: kg m–3
v: m s–1		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
b.ii some working e.g. kg m s–2 = m2 kg m–3 (m s–1)k 
hence k = 2		 M1

  1. length, current, temperature, amount of substance, (luminous intensity) any three, 1 each
    1. F: kg m s–2
      ρ: kg m–3
      v: m s–1
    2. some working e.g. kg m s–2 = m2 kg m–3 (m s–1)k
      hence k = 2

Candidates need to learn all the base quantities. They should then be able to express all derived quantities in terms of these base quantities. 

  1. A minority of candidates were able to give three SI base quantities. Candidates need to be able to recall all the quantities that are fundamental to this course.
    1. There were some very poor answers given for the SI base units of force, density and velocity. Some of the answers suggested a lack of understanding of base quantities and derived quantities. 
    2. A minority of candidates were able to check the base units in the equation given for the resistive force and obtain a correct answer. 
NO. 180题号：33994

A simple pendulum may be used to determine a value for the acceleration of free fall g. Measurements are made of the length L of the pendulum and the period T of oscillation.

The values obtained, with their uncertainties, are as shown.

T = (1.93 ± 0.03) s
L = (92 ± 1) cm

  1. Calculate the percentage uncertainty in the measurement of
    1. the period T,

      uncertainty = ............................................ % [1]
    2. the length L.

      uncertainty = ............................................ % [1]
  2. The relationship between T, L and g is given by
                     
    Using your answers in (a), calculate the percentage uncertainty in the value of g.

    uncertainty = ............................................ % [1]
  3. The values of L and T are used to calculate a value of gas 9.751 m s–2.
    1. By reference to the measurements of L and T, suggest why it would not be correct to quote the value of g as 9.751 m s-2.
      ............................................................... [1]
    2. Use your answer in (b) to determine the absolute uncertainty in g.
      Hence state the value of g, with its uncertainty, to an appropriate number of significant figures.

      g = .......................... ± ........................ m s–2 [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper2_2/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i either 1.55%  or  1.6% …(not 1.5 or 2) A1 [1]
a.ii either 1.09%  or  1.1% …(not 1.0 or 1)  A1 [1]
b answer of {(ii) + 2 × (i)} to any number of sig. fig.
either 4.2%  or  4.3%		 A1 [1]
c.i either the value has more significant figures than the data
or uncertainty of ±0.4 renders more than 2 s.f. meaningless)		 B1 [1]
c.ii uncertainty in g = ±0.41 / ±0.42 to any number of s.f.
g = (9.8 ± 0.4) m s-2		 C1
A1		 [2]
    [Total: 6]
    1. either 1.55% or 1.6%  …(not 1.5 or 2)
    2. either 1.09% or 1.1%  …(not 1.0 or 1)
  2. answer of {(ii) + 2 × (i)} to any number of sig. fig.
    either 4.2% or 4.3%
    1. either the value has more significant figures than the data
      or uncertainty of ±0.4 renders more than 2 s.f. meaningless)
    2. uncertainty in g = ±0.41 / ±0.42 to any number of s.f.
      g = (9.8 ± 0.4) m s-2
  1. With few exceptions, candidates were able to calculate the percentage uncertainties. However, there were frequent errors as regards 'rounding down' of the number of decimal places. 
  2. In general, this was completed successfully. However, a significant minority merely added the percentage uncertainties as calculated in (a). 
    1. Many answers included a reference to significant figures or decimal places. Unfortunately, this reference was frequently confined to a statement regarding the number of significant figures in the value of g, rather than comparing this number with the number in the raw data. A minority of answers were based on the difference between the measured value of g and the accepted value of 9.81 ms–2. 
    2. This part of the question was answered correctly by only a small minority of candidates. In nearly all answers, the uncertainty was calculated correctly. However, candidates did not appreciate that this uncertainty should be quoted to only one significant figure. This significant figure then determines the number of allowable decimal places in the value for g. 
NO. 181题号：33993

The volume of fuel in the tank of a car is monitored using a meter as illustrated in Fig. 1.1.

The meter has an analogue scale. The meter reading for different volumes of fuel in the tank is shown in Fig. 1.2.

The meter is calibrated in terms of the fraction of the tank that remains filled with fuel.

  1. The car uses 1.0 litre of fuel when travelling 14 km. The car starts a joumey with a full tank of fuel.
    1. Calculate the volume of fuel remaining in the tank after a journey of 210 km.

       volume = ...................................... litres [2]
    2. Use your answer to (i) and Fig. 1.2 to determine the change in the meter reading during the 210 km journey.

      from full to ............................. [1]
  2. There is a systematic error in the meter.
    1. State the feature of Fig. 1.2 that indicates that there is a systematic error.
      ................................................................... [1]
    2. Suggest why, for this meter, it is an advantage to have this systematic error. 
      ................................................................... [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper2_1/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i car uses 210 / 14 = 15 litres of fuel
volume reading = 45 litres		 C1
A1		 [2]
a.ii from 'full' to '3/4' mark B1 [1]
b.i line/graph does not pass through ('empty, 0) / there is an intercept
(do not allow 'non-linear')		 B1 [1]
b.ii (meter shows zero fuel when there is some left in the tank so) 
acts as a 'reserve'		 B1 [1]
    [Total: 5]
    1. car uses 210 / 14 = 15 litres of fuel
      volume reading = 45 litres
    2. from ‘full’ to ‘3/4’ mark
    1. line/graph does not pass through (‘empty, 0) / there is an intercept
      (do not allow ‘non-linear’)
    2. (meter shows zero fuel when there is some left in the tank so)
      acts as a ‘reserve’
    1. This part was generally well answered. A significant number of candidates calculated the fuel used as 15 litres and left this as their answer for the fuel remaining in the tank. 
    2. This part was again generally well answered. A few tried to give incorrect fractions, which had been obtained from reading the graph, rather than giving a change in the meter reading.
    1. The correct answer was given by good candidates. However, a number of candidates stated that the feature that showed a systematic error was either the line not going through zero or that the line was non-linear. These were not given any credit. 
    2. The majority of candidates were able to give the required answer for this part. Some answers for which no credit was given suggested the car would never run out of fuel.

    1. With very few exceptions, a correct expression was given.

    2. This part of the question did produce a number of difficulties. Principally, candidates attempted an answer without writing out the equation in terms of base units. Of those who did write down an equation, many included m s-1, rather than (m s-1)k. 
NO. 183题号：33991
  1. Distinguish between systematic errors and random errors.
    systematic errors .......................................................
    random errors ............................................................. [2]
  2. A cylinder of length L has a circular cross-section of radius R, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

    The volume V of the cylinder is given by the expression
                V = πR2L.
    The volume and length of the cylinder are measured as
              V = 15.0 ± 0.5 cm3
              L = 20.0 ± 0.1 cm.
    Calculate the radius of the cylinder, with its uncertainty.

    radius = ........................ ± ........................ cm [5]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2007/Winter/Paper2/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a systematic: e.g. constant error (in all readings)
   cannot be eliminated by averaging
   error in measuring instrument		 B1 [2]
random: e.g. readings scattered (equally) about true value
  error due to observer
  can be eliminated by averaging
  (only if averaging not included for systematic)		 B1
b 15 = π × R2 × 20
R = 0.4886 cm (accept any number of s.f.)
% uncertainty in V = 3.3 % (or 0.5/15)
% uncertainty in L = 0.5 % (or 0.1/20)
% uncertainty in R = 1.9 % (i.e. one half of the sum)
R = 0.489 ± 0.009 cm
C1
C1
C1
C1
A1		 [5]
  1. systematic:
    e.g. constant error (in all readings)
    cannot be eliminated by averaging
    error in measuring instrument

    random:
    e.g. readings scattered (equally) about true value
    error due to observer
    can be eliminated by averaging
    (only if averaging not included for systematic)

  2. 15 = π × R2 × 20
    R = 0.4886 cm (accept any number of s.f.)
    % uncertainty in V = 3.3 % (or 0.5/15)
    % uncertainty in L = 0.5 % (or 0.1/20)
    % uncertainty in R = 1.9 % (i.e. one half of the sum)
    R = 0.489 ± 0.009 cm
  1. Candidates chose various criteria by which to distinguish between systematic and random errors. Arguments based on instrumental/experimental errors, constant/scattered errors or reducible/irreducible by averaging were all acceptable. The quoting of examples of errors, without further explanation, was unacceptable. 
  2. It was pleasing to note that most candidates had some idea as to how to determine the uncertainty. Generally, the fractional uncertainties in V and L were found. Many then either added these fractional uncertainties, rather than calculating the difference, or failed to halve their result to find the fractional uncertainty in R. Most did convert correctly their calculated fractional uncertainty into the absolute uncertainty. However, there was considerable confusion as to how to express the final answer. The uncertainty should be given to one significant figure and the value of R to the corresponding number of decimal places.
NO. 184题号：33990
    1. Define pressure.
      .............................................................................. [1]
    2. State the units of pressure in base units.
      .............................................................................. [1]
  2. The pressure p at a depth h in an incompressible fluid of density ρ is given by
              p = ρgh,
    where g is the acceleration of free fall.
    Use base units to check the homogeneity of this equation.
    ........................................................................................ [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2005/Winter/Paper2/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i force per unit area (ratio idea essential) B1 [2]
a.ii kg m-1 s-2 B1
b.i ρ has base unit kg m-3
g has base unit m s-2
hρg has base unit m × kg m-3 × m s-2
same as pressure QED		 B1
B1
M1
A0		 [3]
    1. force per unit area (ratio idea essential)
    2. kg m-1 s-2
  2. ρ has base unit kg m-3
    g has base unit m s-2
    hρg has base unit m × kg m-3 × m s-2
    same as pressure QED
  1. Most candidates gave adequate definitions of pressure, although some used expressions such as ‘force on unit area' which fail to identify the ratio essential to the definition. The base units of pressure were given in most scripts, although there were some where the units were given as 'Pa' or 'Nm–2'. 
  2. Most candidates correctly identified the base units of density, acceleration and depth. These were combined appropriately to obtain the base units of pressure. However, many failed to draw a clear conclusion from their working. 
NO. 185题号：33989

A student takes readings to measure the mean diameter of a wire using a micrometer screw gauge.

  1. Make suggestions, one in each case, that the student may adopt in order to
    1. reduce a systematic error in the readings,
      ....................................................................
    2. allow for a wire of varying diameter along its length,
      ....................................................................
    3. allow for a non-circular cross-section of the wire.
      ....................................................................
      [3]
  2. The mean diameter of the wire is found to be 0.50 ± 0.02 mm. Calculate the percentage uncertainty in
    1. the diameter,

      uncertainty = …………………………………. %
    2. the area of cross-section of the wire.

      uncertainty = …………………………………. %
      [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2004/Winter/Paper2/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i e.g. check for zero error (on micrometer)/zero the micrometer B1 [3]
a.ii take readings along the length of the wire/at different points B1
a.iii take readings spirally/around the wire B1
b.i 4% A1 [2]
b.ii 8% A1
    1. e.g. check for zero error (on micrometer)/zero the micrometer
    2. take readings along the length of the wire/at different points
    3. take readings spirally/around the wire
    1. 4%
    2. 8%
    1. In most answers, reference was made to a zero error although some candidates did think that taking the mean of several readings would reduce this error. 
    2. Most answers could be interpreted as calculating the mean of several readings along the length of the wire. However, frequently ideas were expressed rather poorly.
    3. Far fewer candidates mentioned that either the screw gauge or the wire should be rotated between successive readings. 
    1. Most candidates were able to calculate the uncertainty in the diameter. 
    2. Very few realised that the squaring of the diameter in order to calculate the area would simply mean that the uncertainty in the area would be double that in the diameter. Some attempts were based on calculations of areas using extreme, and average, values of the diameter. Frequently, these attempts lead to very unrealistic answers. 

Answers: (b)(i) 4%, (ii) 8%.

NO. 186题号：33988

A student uses a metre rule to measure the length of an elastic band before and after stretching it.

The lengths are recorded as

length of band before stretching, L0 = 50.0 ± 0.1 cm
length of band after stretching, LS = 51.6 ± 0.1 cm.

Determine

  1. the change in length (LS − L0), quoting your answer with its uncertainty,

    (LS − L0) = ………………...………… cm [1]
  2. the fractional change in length, ,

    fractional change = ………………........… [1]
  3. the uncertainty in your answer in (b).

    uncertainty = ………………………………… [3]

Q2/9702/2/O/N/02

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2002/Winter/Paper2/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a 1.6 ± 0.2 cm B1 [1]
b 1.6 / 50 = 0.032   ...(ignore any unctaineies) B1 [1]
c idea of adding fractional uncertainties
(0.2 / 1.6) + (0.1 / 50)
= 0.127  OR  12.7%   ...( -2 marks if uncertainties not added)
actual uncertainty = (±) 0.004
(do not allow more than 2 sig. fig)		 C1

A1
A1

 [3]
  1. 1.6 ± 0.2 cm
  2. 1.6 / 50 = 0.032   ...(ignore any unctaineies)
  3. idea of adding fractional uncertainties
    (0.2 / 1.6) + (0.1 / 50)
    = 0.127  OR  12.7%   ...( -2 marks if uncertainties not added).
    actual uncertainty = (±) 0.004
    (do not allow more than 2 sig. fig)
  1. The uncertainty was frequently given as  0.1 cm, failing to realise that when two quantities are added or subtracted, the uncertainty in the result is found by summing the individual uncertainties.
  2. Most candidates were successful with this calculation.
  3. There were few correct answers here. In general there was a failure to appreciate that, when quantities are multiplied together or divided, then the uncertainty in the result is found by adding the fractional uncertainties of the individual quantities. Of those who did find a fractional uncertainty in the result, a significant number then failed to convert the fractional uncertainty into an actual uncertainty. 
NO. 187题号：33987
    1. Define density.
      ............................................................................
    2. State the base units in which density is measured.
      ............................................................................
      [2]
  2. The speed v of sound in a gas is given by the expression

    where p is the pressure of the gas of density ρ. γ is a constant.
    Given that p has the base units of kg m−1 s−2, show that the constant γ has no unit. [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2002/Winter/Paper2/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i mass / volume  ...(ratio must be clear) B1 [2]
a.ii kg m-3  OR  kg/m3 B1
B v has unit of m s-1 B1 [3]
p/ρ has unit of kg m-1 s-2 / kg m-3 (no e.c.f. from (a)) M1
√(p/ρ) has unit of ms-1 A1
LHS = RHS so γ has no unit  A0
    1. mass / volume  ...(ratio must be clear)
    2. kg m-3  OR  kg/m3
  2. v has unit of m s-1
    p/ρ has unit of kg m-1 s-2 / kg m-3 (no e.c.f. from (a))
    √(p/ρ) has unit of ms-1
    LHS = RHS so γ has no unit
  1. Density was defined correctly by most candidates and correct units were given. However, there is a tendency amongst weaker candidates to refer to 'mass in a certain volume'. For a complete definition, the ratio must be made clear.
  2. In most scripts, the units of the quantities involved were given. However, the final step to show that  has no unit was rarely clear. In many instances, this final step involved nothing other than the crossing out of units, frequently obliterating the original indices. Clear statements making reference to the homogeneity of the equation were seldom seen.
NO. 188题号：33986
  1. State the SI base units of force.
    ...............................................................................[1]
  2. Two wires each of length l are placed parallel to each other a distance x apart, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

    Each wire carries a current I. The currents give rise to a force F on each wire given by
       
    where K is a constant.
    1. Determine the SI base units of K.

      units of K ................................................. [2]
    2. On Fig. 1.2, sketch the variation with x of F. The quantities I and l remain constant. [2]
    3. The current I in both of the wires is varied.
      On Fig. 1.3, sketch the variation with I of F. The quantities x and l remain constant. [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_3/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a force: kg m s–2 A1 [1]
b.i I2: A2   l: m   x: m
K: kg m s–2 A–2		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii curve of the correct shape (for inverse proportionality)
clearly approaching each axis but never touching the axis		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.iii curving upwards and through origin A1 [1]
  1. force: kg m s–2
    1. I2: A2
      l: m
      x: m
      K: kg m s–2 A–2
    2. curve of the correct shape (for inverse proportionality)
      clearly approaching each axis but never touching the axis
