    3. curving upwards and through origin

The knowledge of SI base units was generally good. The sketches of relationships that were not straight line graphs seemed to cause problems for the majority of candidates. 

  1. The vast majority of candidates gave the correct response to this straightforward introduction to the paper.
    1. The majority of candidates were able to determine the base units of K by introducing the correct base unit for current. Incorrect answers were a result of introducing charge as a base unit or with candidates making arithmetic errors when rearranging the equation. 
    2. The majority of candidates were unable to represent the relationship for the variation of distance x with force F in graphical form. Many candidates considered the variation to be a straight line with negative gradient. 
    3. A minority of candidates gave the correct sketch. Candidates should be encouraged to improve their knowledge with practice involving relationships that do not give straight line graphs.
NO. 189题号：33984

Energy is stored in a metal wire that is extended elastically.

  1. Explain what is meant by extended elastically.
    ................................................................................ [2]
  2. Show that the SІ units of energy per unit volume are kg m–1 s–2. [2]

  3. For a wire extended elastically, the elastic energy per unit volume X is given by
                X = Cε2E
    where C is a constant,
             ε is the strain of the wire,
    and E is the Young modulus of the wire.

    Show that C has no units. [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_1/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a the wire returns to its original length (not 'shape')
when the load is removed		 M1
A1		 [2]
b energy: N m / kg m2 s–2 and volume m3
energy / volume: kgm2s–2 / m3
energy / volume: kgm–1 s–2		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
c ε has no units
E: kg m s–2 m–2
units of RHS: kgm–1 s–2 = LHS units / satisfactory conclusion to show C has no units		 B1
M1
A1		 [3]
  1. the wire returns to its original length (not 'shape')
    when the load is removed
  2. energy: N m / kg m2 s–2 and volume m3
    energy / volume: kgm2s–2 / m3
    energy / volume: kgm–1 s–2
  3. ε has no units
    E: kg m s–2 m–2
    units of RHS: kgm–1 s–2 = LHS units / satisfactory conclusion to show C has no units
  1. A common answer was based on extension being proportional to force. Reference should have been made to the wire returning to its original length on removal of the load. Candidates often used imprecise or unsuitable terms such as "size", "shape", "position" and "state".
  2. The final expression for the SI units of energy per unit volume was given. Many candidates did derive the units of energy. Others lost credit by just giving an expression for the units of energy, without any explanation. In "show that" questions candidates should be advised that full details of the procedure are vital. 
  3. This proof required that candidates should derive the units for the Young modulus and also state that strain has no unit. A common error was to quite correctly state that strain is the ratio of extension and original length but then to go on to give the unit of strain as '0' or '1'. 
NO. 190题号：33983

The volume V of liquid flowing in time t through a pipe of radius r is given by the equation

 where P is the pressure difference between the ends of the pipe of length l, and C depends on the frictional effects of the liquid.

An experiment is performed to determine C. The measurements made are shown in table.

(V/t) / 10-6m3s-1 P / 103Nm-2 r / m l / m
1.20 ± 0.01 2.50 ± 0.05 0.75 ± 0.01 0.250 ± 0.001
  1. Calculate the value of C.

    C = ..................................... N s m–2 [2]
  2. Calculate the uncertainty in C.

    uncertainty = ..................................... N s m–2 [3]
  3. State the value of C and its uncertainty to the appropriate number of significant figures.

    C = ........................................... ± ........................................... N s m–2 [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_2/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a
C = [π × 2.5 × 103 × (0.75 × 10–3)4] / (8 × 1.2 × 10–6 × 0.25)
   = 1.04 × 10–3 N s m–2
C1
A1		 [2]
b 4 × %r
%C = %P + 4 × %r + %V/t + %l
    = 2% + 5.3% + 0.83% + 0.4% (= 8.6%)
∆C = ± 0.089 × 10–3 N s m–2		 C1

A1
A1		 [3]
c C = (1.04 ± 0.09) × 10–3 N s m–2 A1 [1]

  1. C = [π × 2.5 × 103 × (0.75 × 10–3)4] / (8 × 1.2 × 10–6 × 0.25)
    = 1.04 × 10–3 N s m–2
  2. 4 × %r
    %C = %P + 4 × %r + %V/t + %l
        = 2% + 5.3% + 0.83% + 0.4% (= 8.6%)
    ∆C = ± 0.089 × 10–3 N s m–2
  3. C = (1.04 ± 0.09) × 10–3 N s m–2

Candidates who presented their work clearly often obtained the correct answers and full credit. Calculation errors often occurred as a result of poor presentation of working. 

  1. The majority of candidates made errors in the calculation. The main errors were to omit one or all of the required powers-of-ten from three of the substitutions made from Fig. 1.1 or to omit the power of four for the radius. Some made a rounding error in the answer for C, giving 1.03×10–3 instead of 1.04×10–3.
  2. A significant number of candidates included the fractional or percentage uncertainties for the four terms involved. Errors were made by not adding all four percentage uncertainties, or by including the power-of-ten in the denominator (the quantity), but not in the numerator (the actual uncertainty). The factor of four in the fractional uncertainty for the radius was included by a large number of candidates. A significant minority gave the percentage uncertainty as their final answer. These candidates did not apply their answer to (a) to obtain the uncertainty in C.
  3. The answer was often given incorrectly with more than one significant figure for the uncertainty or the powers-of-ten included in one term but not the other.
NO. 191题号：33982
    1. State the SI base units of volume.

      base units of volume ................................................ [1]
    2. Show that the SI base units of pressure are kg m–1 s–2. [1]

  2. The volume V of liquid that flows through a pipe in time t is given by the equation
       
    where P is the pressure difference between the ends of the pipe of radius r and length l.
    The constant C depends on the frictional effects of the liquid.
    Determine the base units of C.

    base units of C ................................................ [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper2_1/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i V units: m3 (allow metres cubed or cubic metres) A1 [1]
a.ii Pressure units: kgms–2 / m2 (allow use of P = ρgh)
Units: kgm–1 s–2		 M1
A0		 [1]
b V / t units: m3 s–1
Clear substitution of units for P, r4 and l

Units: kgm–1 s–1
(8 or π in final answer –1. Use of dimensions max 2/3)		 B1
M1



A1		 [3]
    1. V units: m3 (allow metres cubed or cubic metres)
    2. Pressure units: kgms–2 / m2 (allow use of P = ρgh)
      Units: kgm–1 s–2
  2. V / t units: m3 s–1
    Clear substitution of units for P, r4 and l

    Units: kgm–1 s–1
    (8 or π in final answer –1. Use of dimensions max 2/3)

The majority of candidates found this question a straightforward start to the examination.

    1. This was answered correctly by almost all candidates.
    2. The majority of answers were expressed clearly. Credit was lost where candidates changed the power of units by crossing out or altering what they had written, making their final answer illegible.
  2. Candidates should be advised to give the base units of each quantity in the form of an equation without any change of power. Only then should simplification take place, but on a different line of working. The usual errors were associated with either missing out the factor of r4 or failing to give the power of four. 
NO. 192题号：33981
  1. For each of the following, tick [✓] one box to indicate whether the experimental technique would reduce random error, systematic error or neither. The first row has been completed as an example. [2]
  2. The measurement of a particular time interval is repeated many times. The readings are found to vary. The results are shown in Fig. 1.1.

    The true value of the time interval is 10.1 s
    1. State how the readings on Fig. 1.1 show the presence of
      1. a systematic error,
      ...................................................................... [1]
      2. a random error.
      ...................................................................... [1]
    2. State the expected changes to Fig. 1.1 for experimental measurements that are
      1. more accurate
      ...................................................................... [1]
      2. more precise.
      ...................................................................... [1]

Q1/9702/23/M/J/11

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper2_3/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a 2nd row random, 3rd row neither, 4th row systematic all correct
two correct scores 1 only		 B2 [2]
b.i 1. systematic error: the average / peak is not the true value / the readings are not centred around the true value B1 [1]
2. random error: readings have positive and negative values around the peak value / values are scattered / wide range B1 [1]
b.ii 1. accurate: peak / average value moves towards the true value B1 [1]
2. precise: lines are closer together / sharper peak B1 [1]
  1. 2nd row random, 3rd row neither, 4th row systematic all correct two correct scores 1 only
    1. 1. systematic error: the average / peak is not the true value / the readings are not centred around the true value
      2. random error: readings have positive and negative values around the peak value / values are scattered / wide range
    2. 1. accurate: peak / average value moves towards the true value
      2. precise: lines are closer together / sharper peak

The majority of candidates made a good start to the paper showing a good understanding of experimental errors. A significant minority showed a lack of preparedness in this part of the syllabus.  

  1. The majority of candidates obtained full credit. There were a significant number who confused systematic and random errors. The use of a linear scale also suggested to some candidates that there would be a reduction in the systematic error. 
    1. 1. This part reinforced the candidates' understanding of systematic errors and there were many good responses. 
      2. This part reinforced the candidates' understanding of random errors and there were many good responses. 
    2. 1. There were a significant number of candidates who clearly understood the difference between accuracy and precision. They were also able to describe the changes that would be observed in results if the readings were more accurate. Many candidates were unable to state the changes to the results and hence the changes to Fig. 1.1 if the readings were more accurate.
      2. The answers given by a significant number of candidates described a modification to the experimental technique or the choice of measuring instrument. They did not answer the question and describe the changes that would occur to Fig. 1.1. The changes to the readings when the results are more precise were known by only a small number of candidates.
NO. 193题号：33979

Measurements made for a sample of metal wire are shown in Fig. 1.1.

  1. State the appropriate instruments used to make each of these measurements.
    1. length
      .......................................................................... [1]
    2. diameter
      .......................................................................... [1]
    3. resistance
      .......................................................................... [1]
    1. Show that the resistivity of the metal is calculated to be 4.86 × 10–7Ω m. [2]

    2. Calculate the uncertainty in the resistivity.

      uncertainty = ± .......................................... Ω m [4]
  3. Use the answers in (b) to express the resistivity with its uncertainty to the appropriate number of significant figures.

    resistivity = ......................... ± ....................... Ω m [1]

Q1/9702/21/M/J/11

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper2_1/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i metre rule / tape (not 'rule') B1 [1]
a.ii micrometer (screw gauge) / digital caliper B1 [1]
a.iii ammeter and voltmeter / ohmmeter / multimeter on 'ohm' setting B1 [1]
b.i resistivity = RA / L
= [7.5 × π × (0.38 × 10–3)2 / 4] / 1.75
= 4.86 × 10–7 Ω m		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
b.ii (uncertainty in R =)   [0.2 / 7.5] × 100 = 2.7%
and (uncertainty in L =)   [3 / 1750] × 100 = 0.17%
(uncertainty in A =)   2 × (0.01 / 0.38) × 100 = 5.3 %
total = 8.13%
C1
C1
C1		 [4]
uncertainty = 0.395 × 10–7 (Ω m) 
(missing 2 factor in uncertainty in A, then allow max 3/4)		 A1
c resistivity = (4.9 × 10–7 ± 0.4 × 10–7) Ω m A1 [1]
    1. metre rule / tape (not ‘rule’)
    2. micrometer (screw gauge) / digital caliper
    3. ammeter and voltmeter / ohmmeter / multimeter on ‘ohm’ setting
    1. resistivity = RA / L 
      = [7.5 × π × (0.38 × 10–3)2/ 4] / 1.75
      = 4.86 × 10–7 Ω m
    2. (uncertainty in R =)       [0.2 / 7.5] × 100 = 2.7%
      and (uncertainty in L =)    [3 / 1750] × 100 = 0.17%
      (uncertainty in A =)        2 × (0.01 / 0.38) × 100 = 5.3 %
      total = 8.13% C1
      uncertainty = 0.395 × 10–7 (Ω m)
      (missing 2 factor in uncertainty in A, then allow max 3/4)
  3. resistivity = (4.9 × 10–7 ± 0.4 × 10–7) Ω m
  1. Appropriate instruments included a metre rule for the length, a micrometer screw gauge for the diameter and an ammeter and voltmeter for the resistance. Many suggested vernier calipers for the diameter. It was surprising that a common answer for the resistance was 'a resistor', suggesting perhaps that candidates had misread the question. 
    1. Most candidates quoted a correct expression for resistivity. The most common error was in the calculation of the cross-sectional area.  
    2. It was common to find that the calculated uncertainty was many times greater than the actual value for the resistivity. Candidates should be encouraged to explain their work and to write it down in a neat and logical manner. Credit can not be awarded if it is not possible to understand how answers have been derived.
      There were comparatively few answers where the fractional uncertainty in the diameter was doubled in order to determine the fractional uncertainty in the area.
  3. When quoting final answers, candidates should give the uncertainty to one significant figure. The resistivity should then be given to the same number of decimal places as the quoted uncertainty.  
NO. 194题号：33978

A digital voltmeter with a three-digit display is used to measure the potential difference across a resistor. The manufacturers of the meter state that its accuracy is ±1% and ±1 digit.
The reading on the voltmeter is 2.05 V

  1. For this reading, calculate, to the nearest digit,
    1. a change of 1% in the voltmeter reading,

      change = ..............................................V [1]
    2. the maximum possible value of the potential difference across the resistor.

      maximum value = ..............................................V [1]
  2. The reading on the voltmeter has high precision. State and explain why the reading may not be accurate.
    .............................................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper2_3/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i 1% of ±2.05 is ±0.02 A1 [1]
a.ii max. value is 2.08 V A1 [1]
b there may be a zero error/calibration error/systematic error
which makes all readings either higher or lower than true value		 M1
A1		 [2]
    1. 1% of ±2.05 is ±0.02
    2. max. value is 2.08 V
  2. there may be a zero error/calibration error/systematic error
    which makes all readings either higher or lower than true value

The majority of candidates did not score high marks on this question. Often this seemed to be due to the candidates not reading carefully the information given in the question. 

    1. The majority of candidates were able to calculate 1% of the reading. However, a significant number gave the voltmeter reading and the change in the reading as their answer. The weaker candidates gave the change in reading to 4 decimal places and not to the nearest digit. 
    2. A significant number of candidates did not include the uncertainty of ±1 digit in their answer. 
  2. The majority of candidates gave a correct answer of systematic or zero error but only the good candidates went on to explain how this might affect the accuracy of the reading. The question asked for a statement and an explanation. 
NO. 195题号：33975

A unit is often expressed with a prefix. For example, the gram may be written with the prefix 'kilo' as the kilogram. The prefix represents a power-of-ten. In this case, the power-of-ten is 103.

Complete Fig. 1.1 to show each prefix with its symbol and power-of-ten. [4]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper2_1/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
1 10–9 B1 [4]
c B1
mega B1
tera B1

The majority of candidates scored full marks in this question. However, a significant minority gave the prefix for T as 'tetra', rather than 'tera'. Another common error was to state the symbol for 'centi' as cm, rather than c. 

NO. 196题号：33973
  1. State the most appropriate instrument, or instruments, for the measurement of the following.
    1. the diameter of a wire of diameter about 1 mm
      ............................................................. [1]
    2. the resistance of a filament lamp
      ............................................................. [1]
    3. the peak value of an alternating voltage
      ............................................................. [1]
  2. The mass of a cube of aluminium is found to be 580 g with an uncertainty in the measurement of 10 g. Each side of the cube has a length of (6.0 ± 0.1) cm.
    Calculate the density of aluminium with its uncertainty. Express your answer to an appropriate number of significant figures.

    density = ................ ± ................ g cm–3 [5]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Summer/Paper2_1/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i micrometer (screw gauge) / travelling microscope B1 [1]
a.ii either  ohm-meter or voltmeter and ammeter
or  multimeter/avo on ohm setting		 B1 [1]
a.iii either (calibrated) c.r.o. or a.c. voltmeter and × √2 B1 [1]
b density = mass / volume
  = 580 / 63 = 2.685 g cm-3 …(allow 2.68, 2.69, 2.7)
% uncertainty in mass = (10 / 580) × 100 = 1.7%
% uncertainty in volume = 3 × (0.1 / 6) × 100 = 5.0%
uncertainty in density = 0.18 g cm-3 
density = 2.7 ± 0.2 g cm-3
(answer 2.69 ± 0.09 g cm-3 scores 4 marks)		 C1
A1

C1
C1
A1

 [5]
    1. micrometer (screw gauge) / travelling microscope 
    2. either ohm-meter or voltmeter and ammeter
      or multimeter/avo on ohm setting 
    3. either (calibrated) c.r.o. or a.c. voltmeter and × √2 
  2. density = mass / volume 
    = 580 / 63
    = 2.685 g cm-3 …(allow 2.68, 2.69, 2.7) 

    % uncertainty in mass = (10 / 580) × 100 = 1.7% 
    % uncertainty in volume = 3 × (0.1 / 6) × 100 = 5.0% 
    uncertainty in density = 0.18 g cm-3
    density = 2.7 ± 0.2 g cm-3
    (answer 2.69 ± 0.09 g cm-3 scores 4 marks)
    1. In the great majority of scripts, a micrometer (screw gauge) was correctly suggested.
    2. Surprisingly, comparatively few answers included both an ammeter and a voltmeter or an ohm-meter. Many answers made reference only to a voltmeter.
    3. A c.r.o. would have been appropriate. Very few realised that an a.c. voltmeter would not give the peak reading and thus the r.m.s. value would have to be multiplied by √2. Many candidates merely suggested 'a voltmeter'.
  2. Most candidates were able to calculate the density to various numbers of significant figures. The vast majority could proceed with the determination of the uncertainty no further than a calculation of the fractional uncertainty in the mass.
NO. 197题号：33970
  1. Derive the SI base unit of force.

    SI base unit of force = ........................................... [1]
  2. A spherical ball of radius r experiences a resistive force F due to the air as it moves through the air at speed v.
    The resistive force F is given by the expression 
               F = crv,
    where c is a constant.
    Derive the SI base unit of the constant c.

    SI base unit of c = ………………………………… [1]
  3. The ball is dropped from rest through a height of 4.5 m.
    1. Assuming air resistance to be negligible, calculate the final speed of the ball.

      speed = …………………………… m s-1 [2]
    2. The ball has mass 15 g and radius 1.2 cm.
      The numerical value of the constant c in the equation in (b) is equal to 3.2 × 10-4 when measured using the SI system of units.
      Show quantitatively whether the assumption made in (i) is justified. [3]

Q1/9702/02/M/J/06

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Summer/Paper2/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a kg m s–2 B1 [1]
b kg m–1 s–1 B1 [1]
c.i v2 = 2gs
= 2 × 9.8 × 4.5
v = 9.4 m s–1
C1
A1		 [2]
c.ii either
F (= 3.2 × 10–4 × 1.2 × 10–2 × 9.4) = 3.6 × 10–5 N
weight of sphere (= mg = 15 × 10–3 × 9.8) = 0.15 N
3.6 × 10–5 << 0.15, so justified
or
mg = crvT (M1)
terminal speed = 3.8 × 104 m s–1 (M1)
9.4 << 3.8 × 104, so justified (A1)
M1
M1
A1





 [3]
  1. kg m s-2
  2. kg m-1 s-1
    1. v2 = 2gs
      = 2 × 9.8 × 4.5
      v = 9.4 m s-1
    2. either
      F (= 3.2 × 10-4 × 1.2 × 10-2 × 9.4) = 3.6 × 10-5 N
      weight of sphere (= mg = 15 × 10-3 × 9.8) = 0.15 N
      3.6 × 10-5 << 0.15, so justified
      or
      mg = crvT
      terminal speed = 3.8 × 104 m s-1
      9.4 << 3.8 × 104, so justified
  1. Most candidates did give the SI base unit of force. Some weaker candidates quoted the derived unit N.
  2. Where the unit had been given as N in (a) then, mostly, a mixture of derived and base units was given here. However, most answers were correct.
    1. This calculation presented very few problems. Candidates should be advised to use data as provided on page 2 of the Paper. The substitution of 10 m s-2 for g is not acceptable unless an answer to one significant figure is required.
    2. The impression gained from most answers was that little or no thought went into what candidates were doing. Substitutions and calculations, without any words of explanation and leading to a totally unjustified conclusion were common.
      A frequently seen approach was to calculate a force using the equation F = crv and the value of v calculated in (a). Most then said that the value of this force is small and can be ignored. Very few explained the significance of F (the air resistance that would be experienced at the speed calculated in (a)) and that this air resistance is much less than the weight mg of the ball and so can justifiably be ignored. Other candidates offered similarly unexplained and incomplete arguments based on the terminal speed of the ball.
NO. 198题号：33969

Make estimates of the following quantities.

  1. the speed of sound in air

    speed = .............................................. [1]
  2. the density of air at room temperature and pressure

    density = ........................................... [1]
  3. the mass of a protractor

    mass = ................................................ [1]
  4. the volume, in cm3, of the head of an adult person

    volume = ............................................ cm3 [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2005/Summer/Paper2/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a allow 100 m s-1 → 900 m s-1 B1 [1]
b allow 0.5 kg m-3 → 1.5 kg m-3 B1 [1]
c allow 5 g → 50 g B1 [1]
d allow 2 × 103 cm3 → 9 × 103 cm3 B1 [1]
  1. allow  100 ms-1   →   900 m s-1
  2. allow    0.5 kg m-3   →   1.5 kg m-3
  3. allow   5g  →   50g
  4. allow   2 × 103 cm3  →  9 × 103 cm3

The speed of sound produced the most reasonable estimates and the density of air the least. For all four quantities there was a very wide range of inadequate estimates, many of which showed that the candidates had little or no appreciation for the physical magnitudes of the various quantities.

  1. Estimates ranged from 1.5 m s–1 to 3 × 1022 m s–1.
  2. Estimates ranged from 1.7 × 10–31 kg m–3 to 8 × 1023 kg m–3. 
  3. Estimates ranged from 0.5 mg to 800 kg.
  4. Estimates ranged from 10–6 cm3 to 1012 cm3.
NO. 199题号：33968

A student has been asked to determine the linear acceleration of a toy car as it moves down a slope. He sets up the apparatus as shown in Fig.3.1.

The time t to move from rest through a distance d is found for different values of d. A graph of d (y-axis) is plotted against t2 (x-axis) as shown in Fig. 3.2.

  1. Theory suggests that the graph is a straight line through the origin.
    Name the feature on Fig. 3.2 that indicates the presence of
    1. random error,
      ........................................................................................
    2. systematic error.
      ........................................................................................ [2]
    1. Determine the gradient of the line of the graph in Fig. 3.2.
      gradient = ............................................... [2]
    2. Use your answer to (i) to calculate the acceleration of the toy down the slope.
      Explain your working.
      acceleration = ........................................ m s-2 [3]

Q3/9702/02/M/J/04

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2004/Summer/Paper2/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a.i scatter of points (about the line) B1 [2]
a.ii intercept (on t2 axis)
(note that answers must relate to the graph)		 B1
b.i gradient = ∆y/ ∆x = (100 – 0)/(10.0 – 0.6)
gradient = 10.6 (cm s-2) (allow ±0.2)
(Read points to within ± 1/2 square. Allow 1 mark for 11 cm s-2
i.e. 2 sig fig, -1. Answer of 10 scores 0/2 marks)		 C1
A1


 [2]
b.ii s = ut + 1/2 at2
so acceleration = 2 × gradient
acceleration = 0.212 m s-2		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
    1. scatter of points (about the line)
    2. intercept (on t2 axis)
      (note that answers must relate to the graph)
    1. gradient = ∆ y/ ∆ x = (100 – 0)/(10.0 – 0.6)
      gradient = 10.6 (cm s-2) (allow ±0.2)
      (Read points to within ± 1/2 square. Allow 1 mark for 11 cm s-2
      i.e. 2 sig fig, -1. Answer of 10 scores 0/2 marks)
    2. s = ut + 1/2 at2
      so acceleration = 2 × gradient
      acceleration = 0.212 m s-2
  1. Some candidates attempted to explain what they understood by 'random' and 'systematic' without making the required reference to the features of the graph. Of those who did refer to the graph, the majority adequately associated random error with the scatter of the plotted points about the straight line. Many did associate a systematic error with an intercept although statements tended to be imprecise, such as 'the time does not start from zero'.
    1. Most candidates read correctly the co-ordinates of two well-spaced points on the line and hence calculated the gradient. The most common errors were either mis-reading the scales or using plotted points, rather than points on the line.
    2. The majority of candidates thought that the gradient represented the acceleration and all that was necessary was to adjust the units. Comparatively few attempted to use an appropriate equation of motion to show that the acceleration is, in fact, twice the gradient of the line.

Answers: (b)(i) 10.6 cm, s-2, (ii) 0.212 ms-2.

NO. 200题号：33967
  1. State the difference between a scalar quantity and a vector qiantity.
    scalar: ..............................................................................
    vector: ............................................................................. [2]
  2. Two force of magnitude 6.0N and 8.0N act at a point P. Both forces act away from point P and the angle between them is 40°.
    Fig. 1.1 shows two lines at an angle of 40° to one another.


    On Fig. 1.1, draw a vector diagram to determine the magnitude of the resultant of the two forces.

    magnitude of resultant = ...................................... N [4]

Q1/9702/02/M/J/04

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2004/Summer/Paper2/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a scalar: magnitude only 
vector: magnitude and direction (allow scalar with direction)
(allow 1 mark for scalar has no direction, vector has direction)		 B1
B1

 [2]
b diagram has correct shape
with arrows in correct directions
resultant = 13.2 ± 0.2 N   (allow 2 sig. fig)
 (for 12.8 → 13.0 and 13.4 → 13.6, allow 1 mark)
(calculated answer with a correct sketch, allow max 4 marks)
(calculated answer with no sketch – no marks)		 M1
A1
A2



 [4]
  Total   [6]
  1. scalar: magnitude only
    vector: magnitude and direction (allow scalar with direction)
    (allow 1 mark for scalar has no direction, vector has direction)
  2. diagram has correct shape
    with arrows in correct directions
    resultant = 13.2 ± 0.2 N (allow 2 sig. fig)
    (for 12.8 → 13.0 and 13.4 → 13.6, allow 1 mark)
    (calculated answer with a correct sketch, allow max 4 marks)
    (calculated answer with no sketch – no marks)
  1. Almost all candidates stated satisfactorily the difference between scalar and vector quantities. Candidates should be encouraged to use correct terminology. For example, 'magnitude' rather than 'size' or 'value'. 
  2. Most candidates did construct a parallelogram or a triangle with directional arrows on the vectors. There were some very good, accurately drawn figures but many wrongly assumed that the lengths of the given dotted lines were appropriate for the sides of the parallelogram or triangle. They then gave the answer as the length of the 'resultant', without any regard for scale. A significant number calculated the resultant, having drawn an appropriate diagram. Others, however, disregarded the instruction and calculated the resultant, without drawing even a sketch diagram. 

Answer: (b) 13.2 ± 0.2 N. 

NO. 201题号：33943

Uranium-234 is radioactive and emits α-particles at what appears to be a constant rate.

A sample of Uranium-234 of mass 2.65 µg is found to have an activity of 604 Bq.

  1. Calculate, for this sample of Uranium-234,
    1. the number of nuclei,

      number = ………………………… [2]
    2. the decay constant,

      decay constant = ………………………… s–1 [2]
    3. the half-life in years.

      half-life = ………………………… years [2]
  2. Suggest why the activity of the Uranium-234 appears to be constant.
    ......................................................................... [1]
  3. Suggest why a measurement of the mass and the activity of a radioactive isotope is not an accurate means of determining its half-life if the half-life is approximately one hour.
    ......................................................................... [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Winter/Paper4/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a.i either number = 6.02 × 1023 × ({2.65 × 10–6}/234)
or number = (2.65 × 10–9)/(234 × 1.66 × 10–27)
                  = 6.82 × 1015		 C1
A1		 [2]
a.ii A = λ N
604 = λ × 6.82 × 1015
λ = 8.86 × 10–14 s–1		 C1

A1		 [2]
a.iii T½ = ln2/ λ
     = 7.82 × 1012 s
     = 2.48 × 105 years
C1
A1		 [2]
b half-life is (very) long (compared with time of counting) B1 [1]
c there would be appreciable decay of source during the taking of measurements B1 [1]
    1. Idea of moles: [(2.65 × 10-6)/234] × 6.02 × 1023 = 6.82 × 1015

    2. A = λN

      ∴ 604 = λ(6.82 × 1015)

      ∴ λ = 8.86 × 10-14 s-1

    3. λt1/2 = ln2

      ∴ t1/2 = ln2/λ

      = ln2/(8.86 × 10-14)

      = 7.82 × 1012 s

      ÷ (3600 × 24 × 365) = 2.48 × 105 years

      Half-life = 2.48 × 105 years
  2. It has a very long half-life (compared with the time of crunting)

  3. There would be appreciable decay of the source during the taking of measurements.
    1. There were many correct answers here although a minority failed to include either NA or 234 in the calculation. 
    2. Generally, this calculation was completed successfully, with candidates using their answer from (i).
    3. Despite being instructed to give the half-life in years (and the unit on the answer line being years), many left their answers in seconds. 
  2. Most candidates did realise that the count-rate would appear to be constant because the half-life is long. 
  3. Unfortunately, those who gave good answers in (b) seemed not to appreciate the consequence of having a short half-life. Very few candidates realised that the mass and/or the count-rate would change significantly while measurements were being made.
NO. 202题号：33937

The controlled reaction between deuterium (21H) and tritium (31H) has involved ongoing research for many years. The reaction may be summarised as

where Q = 17.7 MeV.

Binding energies per nucleon are shown in Fig. 8.1.

  1. Suggest why binding energy per nucleon for the neutron is not quoted.
    ....................................................................... [1]
  2. Calculate the mass defect, in kg, of a helium 42He nucleus.

    mass defect = .......................................... kg [3]
    1. State the name of the type of reaction illustrated by this nuclear equation.
      .................................................................. [1]
    2. Determine the binding energy per nucleon, in MeV, of tritium (31H).

      binding energy per nucleon = ....................... MeV [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper4_1/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a neutron is a single nucleon / particle B1 [1]
b binding energy = 4 × 7.07 × 1.6 × 10-13
                         = 4.52 × 10-12 J
binding energy = c2 ∆m
4.52 × 10-12 = (3.0 × 108)2 × ∆m
∆m = 5.03 × 10-29 kg		 C1

C1

A1		 [3]
c.i fusion ……(do not allow fussion) B1 [1]
c.ii (2 × 1.12) + 3x = 28.28
…... –17.7
x = 2.78 MeV per nucleon
(use of +17.7 gives x = 14.6 MeV, allow 1 mark only)		 C1
C1
A1

 [3]
    [Total: 8]
  1. A neutron is a single particle.
  2. Binding energy = 4 × 7.07 × 1.6 × 10-13 = 4.52 × 10-12 J

    Binding energy = ∆mc2

    ∴ ∆m = (4.52 × 10-12)/(3 × 108)2 = 5.0276 × 10-29 kg
    1. Fusion
    2. L.H.S. = 2(1.12) + 3x, x = binding energy per nucleon of 31H

      R.H.S = 4(7.07) - 17.7

      So 2(1.12) + 3x = 4(7.07) - 17.7

      x = 2.78 MeV
  1. The expected answer was that a neutron is a single particle. Some candidates attempted an explanation by considering a neutron to be a nucleus. This may have arisen from the common problem of distinguishing between the terms neutron, nucleus and nuclide.
  2. Most answers included the equation E = mc2 . However, there was much confusion as to the energy, in MeV. It was common to find that candidates used binding energy per nucleon as the total binding energy of the nucleus. This problem was also observed in (c)(ii). 
    1. A surprising number of candidates gave the answer as fussion. Perhaps they were hoping that this would be taken as a spelling error for both fusion and fission. 
    2. As already mentioned, there was widespread confusion between binding energy of a nucleus and binding energy per nucleon. Furthermore, many candidates were unsure as to how to include the 17.7 MeV in the energy equation. 
NO. 203题号：33933
  1. The variation with nucleon number A of the binding energy per nucleon BE of nuclei is shown in Fig. 8.1.

    On Fig. 8.1, mark the approximate positions of
    1. iron-56 (label this point Fe),  [1] 
    2. zirconium-97 (label this point Zr),  [1] 
    3. hydrogen-2 (label this point H).  [1] 
    1. State what is meant by nuclear fission.
      ....................................................................[2]
    2. By reference to Fig. 8.1, explain how fission is energetically possible.
      ....................................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper4_1/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a.i Fe shown near peak A1 [1]
a.ii Zr shown about half-way along plateau A1 [1]
a.iii H shown at less than 0.4 of maximum height A1 [1]
b.i heavy / large nucleus breaks up / splits
into two nuclei / fragments of approximately equal mass		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.ii binding energy of nucleus = BE × A
binding energy of parent nucleus is less than sum of binding energies of fragments		 B1
B1		 [2]
    1. It is the breakup of a heavy nucleus into 2 lighter nuclei of roughly equal mass.
      • Binding energy of nucleus = BEA
      • The binding energy of the parent nucleus is less than the sum of the binding energies of the fragments.
  1. Candidates need to improve their understanding of the graph of binding energy per nucleon against nucleon number. Many had little appreciation as to how to locate the approximate positions of the given isotopes. 
    1. In nuclear fission a 'heavy' nucleus is split into two 'lighter' nuclei of approximately equal mass. Candidates should use the correct terms in their statements. A nucleus should not be confused with an element, atom, nucleon or nuclide. 
    2. In order to provide a comprehensive answer, candidates needed to first explain what is meant by binding energy. It was then necessary to explain that nuclear fission is energetically possible because the binding energy of the parent nucleus is less than the sum of the binding energies of the two product nuclei. 
NO. 204题号：33930

Radon-222 is a radioactive element having a half-life of 3.82 days.

Radon-222, when found in atmospheric air, can present a health hazard. Safety measures should be taken when the activity of radon-222 exceeds 200 Bq per cubic metre of air.

    1. Define radioactive decay constant.
      .................................................................. [2]
    2. Show that the decay constant of radon-222 is 2.1×10–6 s–1. [1]

  2. A volume of 1.0 m3 of atmospheric air contains 2.5×1025 molecules.
    Calculate the ratio
     
    for the minimum activity of radon-222 at which safety measures should be taken.

    ratio = ................................................. [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper4_3/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a.i probability of decay (of a nucleus)
per unit time		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii λt½ = ln 2
λ = ln 2/(3.82 × 24 × 3600)
= 2.1 × 10–6 s–1
M1
A0		 [1]
b A = λN
200 = 2.1 × 10–6 × N
N = 9.5 × 107
ratio = (2.5 × 1025)/(9.5 × 107)
   = 2.6 × 1017		 C1
C1


A1		 [3]
    1. It is the probability per unit time that a nucleus will undergo decay

    2. t1/2 = ln2/λ

      ∴ λ = ln2/t1/2 = ln2/(3.82 × 24 × 3600) = 2.1 × 10-6 s-1
  2. Use A = λN

    A = 200, λ = 2.1 × 10-6

    ∴ N = 200/(2.1 × 10-6) = 9.5 × 107

    ∴ Ratio = (2.5 × 1025)/(9.5 × 107) = 2.63 × 1017
    1. Most candidates were able to define the decay constant as being the probability per unit time of the decay of a nucleus. Some answers wrongly made reference to an atom (rather than a nucleus) and to 'probability in unit time' (rather than 'probability per unit time').
    2. Almost without exception, a correct answer was given.
  2. A significant minority of candidates introduced the Avogadro constant into their calculation when this was not necessary.  
NO. 205题号：33925
  1. State what is meant by a nuclear fusion reaction.
  2. One nuclear reaction that takes place in the core of the Sun is represented by the equation
         
    Data for the nuclei are given in Fig. 8.1.

    1. Calculate the energy, in joules, released in this reaction.

      energy = .............................................. J [3]
    2. The temperature in the core of the Sun is approximately 1.6 × 107 K.
      Suggest why such a high temperature is necessary for this reaction to take place.
      .......................................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper4_1/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a two (light) nuclei combine
to form a more massive nucleus		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i ∆m = (2.01410u + 1.00728u) – 3.01605u
      = 5.33 × 10–3 u
energy = c2 × ∆m
    = 5.33 × 10–3 × 1.66 × 10–27 × (3.00 × 108)2
    = 8.0 × 10–13 J
C1
C1

A1		 [3]
b.ii speed/kinetic energy of proton and deuterium must be very large
so that the nuclei can overcome electrostatic repulsion		 B1
B1		 [2]
  1. Nuclear fusion is the joining together of two light nuclei to form a heavier nucleus.
    1. L.H.S = 2.01410 + 1.00728 = 3.02138 u

      R.H.S = 3.01605

      ∴ ∆m = (3.02138 - 3.01605) × 1.66 × 10-27 kg

      E = ∆mc2

      = 5.33 × 10-3 × 1.66 × 10-27 × (3 × 108)2

      = 7.96 × 10-13 J

    2. With high temperature, the kinetic energy of the proton and deuterium would be very high. With this high kinetic energy. The nuclei can overcome electrostatic repulsion and fusion can take place.
  1. In nuclear fusion, two light nuclei combine to form a more massive nucleus. Candidates should use the correct terms in their statements. A nucleus should not be confused with an element, molecule, atom, nucleon or nuclide.
    1. Most answers correctly calculated the change of mass in u and also stated the equation E = mc2. However, the calculation of the released energy often contained arithmetic errors or omitted the conversion of the mass units from u to kg. 
    2. The reason for needing a high temperature was seldom understood. It is to ensure that the kinetic energies of the proton and the deuterium nucleus are large enough to enable them to overcome their mutual electrostatic repulsion. 
NO. 206题号：33923

One possible nuclear fission reaction is

Barium-141 (14156 Ba) and krypton-92 (9236 Kr) are both β-emitters.
Barium-141 has a half-life of 18 minutes and a decay constant of 6.4 × 10–4 s–1.
The half-life of krypton-92 is 3.0 seconds.

  1. State what is meant by decay constant.
    ......................................................................[2]
  2. A mass of 1.2 g of uranium-235 undergoes this nuclear reaction in a very short time (a few nanoseconds).
    1. Calculate the number of barium-141 nuclei that are present immediately after the reaction has been completed.

      number = ................................................ [2]
    2. Using your answer in (b)(i), calculate the total activity of the barium-141 and the krypton-92 a time of 1.0 hours after the fission reaction has taken place.

      activity = ........................................... Bq [4]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Winter/Paper4_3/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a probability of decay (of a nucleus)/fraction of number of nuclei in sample that decay
per unit time
(allow λ =(dN / dt) / N with symbols explained – (M1), (A1) ) 		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i number = (1.2 × 6.02 × 1023) / 235
              = 3.1 × 1021		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii N = N0 e–λt
negligible activity from the krypton
for barium, N = (3.1 × 1021) exp(–6.4 × 10–4 × 3600) 
                      = 3.1 × 1020
activity = λN
   = 6.4 × 10–4 × 3.1 × 1020
   = 2.0 × 1017 Bq
B1

C1

C1
A1		 [4]
  1. It is the probability per unit time that a nucleus will undergo decay.
    1. No. of barium-141 = (1.2/235) × 6.02 × 1023 = 3.07 × 1021

      Idea: make sure you know about moles.

    2. Use N = N0e-λt

      N = (3.1 × 1021)e-(6.4 × 10-4)3600 = 3.1 × 1020

      For Barium → Negligible activity from the krypton (half  life = 3 s)

      Activity, A = λN

      = 6.4 × 10-4 × 3.1 × 1020

      = 2 × 1017 Bq
  1. Most answers correctly defined the decay constant as the probability of decay of a nucleus per unit time. Candidates should refer to a nucleus rather than to an atom, nucleon or isotope. Similarly it is incorrect to state "per second" rather than "per unit time". Quantities are defined in terms of other quantities and not in terms of units. 
    1. The calculation was usually performed successfully. 
    2. Many able candidates scored all of the available marks. The best answers explicitly explained that the krypton-92 had negligible activity after 1.0 hour. Weaker candidates often confused the initial activity of the barium-141 with its final activity. Many candidates needed to improve the presentation of their calculation so that each step is clearly shown.
NO. 207题号：33918

The power for a space probe is to be supplied by the energy released when plutonium-236 decays by the emission of α-particles.

The α-particles, each of energy 5.75 MeV, are captured and their energy is converted into electrical energy with an efficiency of 24%.

  1. Calculate
    1. the energy, in joules, equal to 5.75 MeV,

      energy = .......................................... J [1]
    2. the number of α-particles per second required to generate 1.9 kW of electrical power.

      number per second = ..................................... s–1 [2]
  2. Each plutonium-236 nucleus, on disintegration, produces one α-particle.
    Plutonium-236 has a half-life of 2.8 years.
    1. Calculate the decay constant, in s–1, of plutonium-236.

      decay constant = ................................... s–1 [2]
    2. Use your answers in (a)(ii) and (b)(i) to determine the mass of plutonium-236 required for the generation of 1.9 kW of electrical power.

      mass = .......................................... g [4]
  3. The minimum electrical power required for the space probe is 0.84 kW.
    Calculate the time, in years, for which the sample of plutonium-236 in (b)(ii) will provide sufficient power.

    time = ........................................... years [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2015/Summer/Paper4_2/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a.i energy = 5.75 × 1.6 × 10–13
            = 9.2 × 10–13 J		 A1 [1]
a.ii number = 1900/(9.2 × 10–13 × 0.24)
             = 8.6 × 1015 s–1		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.i decay constant = 0.693/(2.8 × 365 × 24 × 3600)
    = 7.85 × 10–9 s–1 (allow 7.8 or 7.9 to 2 s.f.)		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii A = λN
8.6 × 1015 = 7.85 × 10–9 × N
N = 1.096 × 1024
mass = (1.096 × 1024 × 236)/(6.02 × 1023)
         = 430g
C1
C1
M1
A1		 [4]
c 0.84 = 1.9 exp(–7.85 × 10–9 t)
t = 1.04 × 108 s
  = 3.3 years		 C1

A1		 [2]
    1. 1 MeV = 1.6 × 10-13 J

      ∴ 5.75 ⇒ 5.75 × 1.6 × 10-13 = 9.2 × 10-13 J
    2. η = 24% ⇒ η = 0.24

      Generate (in 1 second) 1900 W (Note: 1 W = 1J/s)

      ∴ 1900/(0.24 × 9.2 × 10-13) = 8.6 × 1015 per second
    1. We know λ = ln2/t1/2

      = (ln2)/(2.8 × 365 × 24 × 3600)

      = 7.85 × 10-9 s-1
    2. We know A = λN

      ∴ N = A/λ

      = (8.6 × 1015)/(7.85 × 10-9)

      = 1.096 × 1024

      ∴ Mass = (1.096 × 1024 × 236)/(6.02 × 1023) = 429.7 g
  3. idea: N = N0e-λt



    (1.04 × 108)/(24 × 365 × 3600) = 3.297 years

    Time = 3.3 years
    1. Most candidates showed a correct conversion but a significant minority confused eV either with keV or with MeV. 
    2. Many answers were correct but a significant number of candidates did not take into consideration the efficiency of the process. 
    1. There was some confusion as to the number of days in 1.0 years. This is usually accepted to be 365 (to 3 significant figures). Some candidates used 360 days, perhaps because of confusion with angular degrees.
    2. This calculation was found to be difficult. Using the decay constant in (b)(i) and the activity from (a)(ii), it was expected that the number of nuclei would be calculated and hence the mass. Many candidates used the activity in (a)(ii) as the number of nuclei.
  3. Very few candidates related the initial and final powers to the equation for the exponential decay of a radioactive source. A large number of candidates attempted to answer this question using a linear relationship. 
NO. 208题号：33915

The photoelectric effect may be summarised in terms of the word equation

photon energy = work function energy + maximum kinetic energy of emitted electrons.

  1. Explain
    1. what is meant by a photon,
      ............................................................................ [2]
    2. why most electrons are emitted with kinetic energy less than the maximum.
      ............................................................................ [2]
  2. Light of constant intensity is incident on a metal surface, causing electrons to be emitted.
    State and explain why the rate of emission of electrons changes as the frequency of the incident light is increased.
    ............................................................................ [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Winter/Paper4/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i quantum/packet/discrete amount of energy
electromagnetic mentioned		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii max. k.e. corresponds to electron emitted from surface
energy is required to bring electron to surface		 B1
B1		 [2]
b at higher frequency, fewer photons (per second) for same intensity
so rate of emission decreases
(allow argument based on photoelectric efficiency)		 M1
A1		 [2]
    1. A photon is a packet of energy of electromagnetic radiation.
      • Maximum k.e. electrons are those emitted from the surface.
      • For electrons below the surface, energy is required to bring them to the surface. Hence k.e. less than the maximum.
  2. When the frequency is increased at constant intersity, each photon will have more energy but the number of photons incident per unit time on unit area will be smaller. Therefore the rate of emission decreases.
    1. This was answered well by many. Some failed to mention that a photon is associated with electromagnetic radiation.
    2. Very few candidates appeared to appreciate that the maximum kinetic energy is associated with an electron emitted from the surface and that, where an electron is below the surface, then energy is expended in bringing the electron to the surface, thus reducing its kinetic energy. 
  2. Many argued that, with increased photon energy, each photon would be able to emit more electrons. The fact that the intensity is constant was ignored by most. Candidates are expected to realise that, when the frequency of the radiation is increased at constant intensity, then each photon will have more energy but the number of photons incident per unit time on unit area will be smaller. 
NO. 209题号：33896
  1. By reference to the photoelectric effect, state what is meant by the threshold frequency.
    ....................................................................... [2]
  2. The surface of a zinc plate has a work function of 5.8×10–19 J.
    In a particular laboratory experiment, ultraviolet light of wavelength 120 nm is incident on the zinc plate. A photoelectric current I is detected.
    In order to view the apparatus more clearly, a second lamp emitting light of wavelength 450 nm is switched on. No change is made to the ultraviolet lamp.
    Using appropriate calculations, state and explain the effect on the photoelectric current of switching on this second lamp.
    .......................................................................... [4]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper4_3/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a minimum frequency for electron to be emitted (from surface)
of electromagnetic radiation / light / photons		 M1
A1		 [2]
b E = hc / λ  or  E = hf   and  c = fλ
either  threshold wavelength = (6.63 × 10–34 × 3.0 × 108) / (5.8 × 10–19)
  = 340 nm
or  energy of 340 nm photon = 4.4 × 10–19 J
or  threshold frequency = 8.7 × 1014 Hz
or  450 nm → 6.7 × 1014 Hz
appropriate comment comparing wavelengths / energies / frequencies
so no effect on photo-electric current		 C1




A1
B1
B1		 [4]
  1. The threshold frequency of a metal surface is the lowest frequency of electromagnetic radiation that gives rise to the emission of electrons from the surface.
  2. f0 = (5.8 × 10-19)/(6.63 × 10-34) = 8.7 × 1014 Hz (Using Φ = hf0)

    Compare with 2nd light of 450 nm, use c = fλ,

    f = c/λ = (3 × 108)/(450 × 10-9) = 6.7 × 1014 Hz

    This is less than 8.7 × 1014 Hz (the threshold frequency)

    ∴ therefore there is no effect on the photoelectric current.
  1. Some candidates stated that the threshold frequency is the minimum frequency for an electron to be emitted, without making it clear that it is the minimum frequency of electromagnetic radiation or light. 
  2. Candidates chose a variety of ways to answer this part of the question. Some compared the wavelength of the second lamp with the threshold wavelength of the zinc plate. Others compared the frequency with the threshold frequency or compared the photon energy with the work function. A small minority of candidates added the energy of a photon from the first lamp to the energy of a photon from the second lamp and then incorrectly compared their total energy to the work function of the zinc plate. 
NO. 210题号：33804

An explanation of the photoelectric effect includes the terms photon energy and work function energy.

  1. Explain what is meant by
    1. a photon,

      ..................................................................................................................................
      ..................................................................................................................................
      ............................................................................................................................. [2]

    2. work function energy.

      ..................................................................................................................................
      ............................................................................................................................. [1]

  2. In an experiment to investigate the photoelectric effect, a student measures the wavelength λ of the light incident on a metal surface and the maximum kinetic energy Emax of the emitted electrons. The variation with Emax of 1/λ is shown in Fig. 7.1.


    1. The work function energy of the metal surface is Φ.

      State an equation, in terms of λ, Φ and Emax, to represent conservation of energy for the photoelectric effect. Explain any other symbols you use.

      ..................................................................................................................................
      ..................................................................................................................................
      ............................................................................................................................. [2]

    2. Use your answer in (i) and Fig. 7.1 to determine
      1. the work function energy Φ of the metal surface,





        Φ = ............................................. J [2]

      2. a value for the Planck constant.







        Planck constant = ........................................... J s [3]

[Total: 10]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper4_3/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i packet/quantum of energy 
of electromagnetic radiation		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii minimum energy to cause emission of an electron (from surface) B1 [1]
b.i hc/λ = Φ + Emax
c and h explained		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.ii 1. either  when 1/λ = 0, Φ = –Emax
or  evidence of use of x-axis intercept from graph
or  chooses point close to the line and substitutes values of 1/λ and
     Emax into hc/λ = Φ + Emax
Φ = 4.0 × 10–19 J (allow ±0.2 × 10–19 J)


C1
A1		 [2]
2. either  gradient of graph is 1/hc
  gradient = 4.80 × 1024 → 5.06 × 1024 
 h = 1/(gradient × 3.0 × 108)
   = 6.6 × 10–34 J s → 6.9 × 10–34 J s		 C1
M1

A1		 [3]
or  chooses point close to the line and substitutes values of 1/λ and
  Emax into hc/λ = Φ + Emax
  values of 1/λ and Emax are correct within half a square 
  h = 6.6 × 10–34 J s → 6.9 × 10–34 J s 
(Allow full credit for the correct use of any appropriate method)
(Do not allow 'circular' calculations in part 2 that lead to the same value of Planck constant that was substituted in part 1) 
(C1)
(M1)
(A1)
    1. A photon is a packet of energy of electromagnetic radiation
    2. Work function energy is the minimum energy required to remove an electron from a metal surface.
    1. Emax + Φ = hf

      ∴ h(c/λ) = Φ + Emax

      c = speed of light, h = Planck constant
      1. From (i)

        1/λ = (1/hc)Φ + (1/hc)Emax

        Set 1/λ = 0,

        Φ = -Emax = -(-4 × 10-19 J) = 4 × 10-19 J

        (See where line cuts the 'x' axis)
      2. From (1) above gradient of graph = 1/hc

        gradient from graph = (4 × 106)/(4.13 × 10-19 + 4 × 10-19) = 4.92 × 1024

        ∴ 1/hc = 4.92 × 1024

        ∴ h = 1/(4.92 × 1024 × 3 × 108) = 6.77 × 10-34 Js

        Planck constant = 6.8 × 10-34 Js
    1. Although most answers included a reference to a quantum or 'packet' of energy, many did not mention that this was associated with electromagnetic radiation. 
    2. It was expected that candidates would refer to the minimum energy required to remove an electron from the surface of a metal. Of those answers that were recognisable as being concerned with photoelectric emission, many did not include a mention of minimum energy. 
    1. Many candidates were unable to state the photoelectric equation, and would have benefited from further experience of using this equation. A common error was to express one of the terms with an incorrect sign. 
    2. 1. There were various methods of determining the work function energy. The simplest was to use the value of the x-axis intercept from the graph. The most common method involved substituting a pair of values from a point on the graph into the photoelectric equation. 
      2. Different methods were used to determine a value for the Planck constant. It was expected that candidates would calculate the gradient of the graph and then equate this to 1/hc. Weaker candidates often made power of ten errors when taking readings from the graph and when using those readings in subsequent calculations. A small minority performed a 'circular' calculation to give the same value of Planck constant that they had previously substituted from the datasheet in their earlier calculation of the work function energy in part 1. Such 'circular' calculations were not credited. 
NO. 211题号：33762
  1. Explain what is meant by a photon.
    .................................................................................. [3]
  2. An emission spectrum is seen as a series of differently coloured lines on a black background.
    Suggest how this observation provides evidence for discrete electron energy levels in atoms.
    .................................................................................. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper4_1/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a packet/quantum/discrete amount of energy
of electromagnetic radiation
(allow 1 mark for 'packet of electromagnetic radiation')
energy = Planck constant × frequency (seen here or in b)		 M1
A1

B1		 [3]
b each (coloured) line corresponds to one wavelength/frequency
energy = Planck constant × frequency
implies specific energy change between energy levels
so discrete levels		 B1

B1
A0		 [2]
  1. A photon is a quantum of energy in the form of electromagnetic radiation. The energy E carried in each quantum is given by E = hf, where h is the planck constant and f is the frequency of radiation.
    • Each coloured line corresponds to one frequency
    • We know E = hf i.e. energy = Planck constant × frequency of radiation which implies there is a specific energy change between energy levels
    • ∴ We have discrete electron energy levels in atoms.
  1. Most candidates could recall that a photon is a quantum of energy of electromagnetic radiation. Only a small minority explained that this energy is equal to the Planck constant multiplied by the frequency. A statement of the algebraic expression needed to be accompanied by an explanation of all symbols. 
  2. When describing the process of photon emission, candidates must distinguish between energy levels and the change between energy levels. Many candidates incorrectly associate a photon of a specific wavelength to a specific energy level. 
NO. 212题号：33754
  1. State what is meant by the de Broglie wavelength.
    .......................................................................[2]
  2. An electron is accelerated from rest in a vacuum through a potential difference of 4.7 kV.
    1. Calculate the de Broglie wavelength of the accelerated electron.

      wavelength = ............................................ m [5]
    2. By reference to your answer in (i), suggest why such electrons may assist with an understanding of crystal structure.
      ...............................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper4_3/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a wavelength associated with a particle
that is moving		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i kinetic energy = 1.6 × 10–19 × 4700
  = 7.52 × 10–16 J
either energy = p2/2m  or  EK = ½mv2 and p = mv
p = √(7.52 × 10–16 × 2 × 9.1 × 10–31) 
  = 3.7 × 10–23N s
λ = h/p
  = (6.63 × 10–34) / (3.7 × 10–23)
  = 1.8 × 10–11m		 C1

C1
C1

C1

A1		 [5]
b.ii wavelength is about separation of atoms
can be used in (electron) diffraction		 B1
B1		 [2]
  1. The de Broglie wavelength is the wavelength associated with a moving particle.
    1. KE = ev = 1.6 × 10-19 × 4.7 × 103 = 7.52 × 10-16 J

      E = (1/2)mv2

      But p = mv

      ∴ v = p/m

      ∴ E = (1/2)m(p/m)2 = p2/2m

      ∴ p = √(2mE) = √(2 × 9.11 × 10-31 × 7.52 × 10-16) = 3.7015 × 10-23 Ns

      λ = h/p = (6.63 × 10-34)/(3.7015 × 10-23) = 1.79 × 10-11 m
      • de Broglie wavelength is similar in value to the separation of atoms in the crystal
      • Therefore electrons would be diffracted by the crystal (i.e. electron diffraction can be seen)
  1. The de Broglie wavelength is the wavelength associated with a particle that is moving. In many scripts, the formula λ=h/p was quoted and then the symbols h and p were explained. The question asked for a statement as to what is meant by the de Broglie wavelength and so consequently this approach was not given credit.
    1. The calculation of the de Broglie wavelength involved several steps that presented few problems for the more able candidates. Weaker candidates were usually able to calculate the kinetic energy of the electron, but often made the mistake of substituting this value of energy into the formula E = hf. 
    2. Very few candidates appreciated that the electrons would be diffracted by the crystal because their de Broglie wavelength was similar in value to the separation of the atoms in the crystal. Many answers alluded, quite incorrectly, to the frequency associated with the electron being similar in value to the natural frequency of the crystal so that resonance would occur. 
NO. 213题号：33735

Some data for the work function energy Φ and the threshold frequency f0 of some metal surfaces are given in Fig. 7.1.

    1. State what is meant by the threshold frequency.
      ..........................................................................[2]
    2. Calculate the threshold frequency for platinum.

      threshold frequency = ............................................ Hz [2]
  2. Electromagnetic radiation having a continuous spectrum of wavelengths between 300 nm and 600 nm is incident, in turn, on each of the metals listed in Fig. 7.1.
    Determine which metals, if any, will give rise to the emission of electrons.
    ................................................................................[2]
  3. When light of a particular intensity and frequency is incident on a metal surface, electrons are emitted.
    State and explain the effect, if any, on the rate of emission of electrons from this surface for light of the same intensity and higher frequency.
    .................................................................................[3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper4_1/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i lowest frequency of e.m. radiation 
giving rise to emission of electrons (from the surface) 		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii E = hf
threshold frequency = (9.0 × 10–19) / (6.63 × 10–34)
     = 1.4 × 1015Hz		 C1
A1

 [2]
b either 300nm ≡ 1.0 × 1015Hz (and 600nm ≡ 5.0 × 1014Hz)
or 300nm ≡ 6.6 × 10–19 J (and 600nm ≡ 3.3 × 10–19 J)
or zinc λ0 = 340nm, platinum λ0 = 220nm (and sodium λ0 = 520nm)
emission from sodium and zinc

M1
A1		 [2]
c each photon has larger energy
fewer photons per unit time
fewer electrons emitted per unit time		 M1
M1
A1		 [3]
    1. The threshold frequency of a metal surface is the lowest frequency of electromagnetic radiation that gives rise to the emission of electrons from the surface.
    2. E = hf0

      ∴ 9 × 10-19 = 6.63 × 10-34f0

      ∴ f0 = 1.357 × 1015 Hz
  2. Zinc: λ0 = v/f0 = (3 × 108)/(8.8 × 1014) = 341 nm

    Sodium: λ0 = v/(5.8 × 1014) = (3 × 108)/(5.8 × 1014) = 517 nm

    Platinum: λ0 = (3 × 108)/(1.4 × 1015) = 214 nm

    ∴ Emission from sodium and zinc
    • Higher frequency

      ∴ Each photon has larger energy
    • To maintain same intensity, we have fewer photons per unit time
    • Therefore there is a decrease in the rate of emission of electrons

      i.e. fewer electrons emitted per unit time
    1. Many candidates stated that the threshold frequency is the minimum frequency for an electron to be emitted from the surface, without making it clear that it is the minimum frequency of electromagnetic radiation. 
    2. The vast majority of calculations were successful.
  2. A variety of approaches were possible. Some candidates calculated the frequency corresponding to a wavelength of 300 nm and compared this to the threshold frequencies of the metals. Others calculated the energy of a 300 nm photon and compared this to the work function energies of the metals. A small minority successfully calculated the threshold wavelengths of the metals and compared these to the wavelength of 300 nm. 
  3. Although many candidates realised that a higher frequency would result in each photon having more energy, very few of these candidates went on to deduce that there must be fewer photons per unit time in order to maintain the same intensity. Thus, there is a decrease in the rate of emission of electrons. Most candidates had the false impression either that the rate of emission of electrons would stay the same because the light intensity is the same or that the rate of emission of electrons would increase because the electrons are emitted with more kinetic energy. 
NO. 214题号：33119
  1. Explain what is meant by a photon.
    ..............................................................................[2]
  2. An X-ray photon of energy 3.06×10–14 J is incident on an isolated stationary electron, as illustrated in Fig. 6.1.

    The photon is deflected elastically by the electron through angle θ. The deflected photon has a wavelength of 6.80×10–12 m.
    1. On Fig. 6.1, draw an arrow to indicate a possible initial direction of motion of the electron after the photon has been deflected. [1]
    2. Calculate
      1. the energy of the deflected photon,

        photon energy = ........................................ J [2]
      2. the speed of the electron after the photon has been deflected.

        speed = ............................................. m s–1 [3]
  3. Explain why the magnitude of the final momentum of the electron is not equal to the change in magnitude of the momentum of the photon.
    ............................................................................. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2015/Summer/Paper4_2/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a packet/quantum/discrete amount of energy
of electromagnetic energy/radiation/waves		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i arrow below axis and pointing to right B1 [1]
b.ii 1. E = hc /λ
    = (6.63 × 10–34 × 3.0 × 108)/(6.80 × 10–12)
    = 2.93 × 10–14J (accept 2 s.f.)		 C1
A1		 [2]
2. energy of electron = (3.06 – 2.93) × 10–14
             = 1.3 × 10–15 J
   speed =
             = 5.4 × 107ms–1
C1
C1
A1		 [3]
c momentum is a vector quantity
either must consider momentum in two directions
or direction changes so cannot just consider magnitude		 B1

B1		 [2]
  1. A photon is a packet of energy when the energy is in the form of electromagnetic radiation
      1. E = hc/λ = (6.63 × 10-34 × 3 × 108) / (6.8 × 10-12) = 2.925 × 10-14 J
      2. Use (1/2)mv2 = E



        Note:

        E = energy of electron

        i.e. the difference of the incident and the deflected photon
  3. • Momentum is a vector quantity (has both direction and magnitude)
    • The direction changes, therefore cannot just consider magnitude
  1. Most answers were correct.
    1. Many candidates found it difficult to show the correct direction. 
    2. 1. This calculation was generally carried out correctly. 
      2. Many candidates did not calculate the energy change of the photon but instead used the initial photon energy. Others considered the electron to be a photon and used an incorrect expression for kinetic energy. 
  3. There were very few candidates who considered momentum in their answers. Many attempted to give an explanation in terms of loss of energy, despite the statement that the collision is elastic. 
NO. 215题号：33105

A photon of wavelength 6.50×10−12 m is incident on an isolated stationary electron, as illustrated in Fig. 8.1.

The photon is deflected elastically by the electron of mass me. The wavelength of the deflected photon is 6.84×10−12 m.

  1. Calculate, for the incident photon,
    1. its momentum,




      momentum = ........................................... N s [2]

    2. its energy.




      energy = ...................................................... J [2]

  2. The angle θ through which the photon is deflected is given by the expression
    where Δλ is the change in wavelength of the photon, h is the Planck constant and c is the speed of light in free space.
    1. Calculate the angle θ.




      θ = ...................................................... ° [2]

    2. Use energy considerations to suggest why Δλ must always be positive.

      ...........................................................................................................................................
      ...........................................................................................................................................
      ...........................................................................................................................................
      ...................................................................................................................................... [3]

[Total: 9]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2015/Summer/Paper4_1/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a.i p = h / λ
   = (6.63 × 10–34)/(6.50 × 10–12)
   = 1.02 × 10–22Ns		 C1
A1		 [2]
a.ii E = hc / λ or E = pc
   = (6.63 × 10–34 × 3.00 × 108)/(6.50 × 10–12)
   = 3.06 × 10–14 J		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.i 0.34 × 10–12 = (6.63 × 10–34)/(9.11 × 10–31 × 3.0 × 108) × (1 – cos θ)
θ = 30.7°		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii deflected electron has energy
this energy is derived from the incident photon
deflected photon has less energy, longer wavelength (so ∆λ always positive) 		 M1
A1
B1		 [3]
    1. λ = h/P
      ∴ P = h/λ = (6.63 × 10-34)/(6.5 × 10-12) = 1.02 × 10-22 Ns

    2. E = hf = hc/λ
         = (6.63 × 10-34 × 3 × 108)/(6.5 × 10-12)
         = 3.06 × 10-14 J

    1. ∆λ = 6.84 × 10-12 - 6.50 × 10-12 = 3.4 × 10-13
      1 - cosθ = ∆λmec/h
      ∴ cosθ = 1 - (∆λmec/h)
      = 1 - [(3.4 × 10-13 × 9.11 × 10-31 × 3 × 108)/(6.63 × 10-34)]
      = 0.8598
      ∴ θ = 30.7°

    2. • The deflected electron has energy
      • This energy is derived from the incident photon
      • The deflected photon has less energy (and since E = hc/λ) and longer wavelength
      ∴ ∆λ is always positive
    1. Candidates who realised that the de Broglie equation was required then carried out the calculation with few problems. Some others attempted to use momentum = mv and used the mass of the electron. This could not be awarded credit. A tiny minority used the wrong wavelength.
    2. Candidates who knew and used the correct expression answered this question well. Again, the mass of the electron appeared for those candidates who used the kinetic energy formula, and this could not be awarded credit.
    1. Most candidates were able to use the formula provided. Some candidates substituted one wavelength instead of the change and some were unable to carry out the manipulation correctly to lead to the angle after the substitution.
    2. This was a challenging question. If the collision is elastic and the photon has lost energy (because its wavelength has increased) then it must have given that energy to the electron. Very few candidates realised this. Some weaker candidates were unable to link the longer wavelength with a reduction in photon energy. 
NO. 216题号：33085

An alternating supply of frequency 50 Hz and having an output of 6.0 V r.m.s. is to be rectified so as to provide direct current for a resistor R. The circuit of Fig. 6.1 is used.

The diode is ideal. The Y-plates of a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.) are connected between points A and B.

    1. Calculate the maximum potential difference across the diode during one cycle.

      potential difference = ………………… V [2]
    2. State the potential difference across R when the diode has maximum potential difference across it. Give a reason for your answer.
      ...................................................................... [1]
  2. The Y-plate sensitivity of the c.r.o. is set at 2.0 V cm–1 and the time-base at 5.0 ms cm–1.
    On Fig. 6.2, draw the waveform that is seen on the screen of the c.r.o. [3]
  3. A capacitor of capacitance 180 µF is connected into the circuit to provide smoothing of the potential difference across the resistor R.
    1. On Fig. 6.1, show the position of the capacitor in the circuit. [1]

    2. Calculate the energy stored in the fully-charged capacitor.

      energy = ………………………… J [3]
    3. During discharge, the potential difference across the capacitor falls to 0.43V0, where V0 is the maximum potential difference across the capacitor.
      Calculate the fraction of the total energy that remains in the capacitor after the discharge.

      fraction = ………………………… [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Winter/Paper4/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i peak voltage = 6√2
peak voltage = 8.48 V		 C1
A1		 [2]
a.ii zero because  either no current in circuit (and V = IR)
      or all p.d. across diode		 B1 [1]
b waveform: half-wave rectification
      peak height at about 4.25 cm
      half-period spacing of 2.0 cm
(allow ±¼ square for height and half-period)		 B1
B1
B1

 [3]
c.i capacitor shown in parallel with resistor B1 [1]
c.ii either energy = ½CV2 or = ½QV and Q = CV
    = ½ × 180 × 10–6 × (6√2)2
    = 6.48 × 10–3 J		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
c.iii either fraction = 0.432 or final energy = 1.2 mJ
fraction = 0.18		 C1
A1		 [2]
    1. VP/√2 = Vr.m.s.

      ∴ VP = Vr.m.s. × √2

      = 6 × √2

      = 8.48 V
    2. Zero. All the potential difference is across the diode
    2. Use energy = (1/2)CV2

      C = 180 × 10-6

      V = 6√2

      ∴ E = (1/2) × 180 × 10-6 × (6√2)2

      = 6.48 × 10-3 J
    3. Final: (1/2)CV2 = (1/2) × 180 × 10-6 × [0.43 × (6√2)]2 = 1.198 × 10-3 J

      ∴ Fraction of total energy that remain = (1.198 × 10-3)/(6.48 × 10-3) = 0.18
    1. With few exceptions, candidates realised that a factor of √2 was involved. However, a significant number arrived at the answer of 4.2 V – a maximum value less than the r.m.s. value! 
    2. There were very few correct statements, and even fewer with some explanation. In most scripts, the answer given was the same as that in (i), rather than zero. 
  2. Disappointingly, many drew a sinusoidal wave. Full-wave rectification was also common. Usually, the period was correct. 
    1. In approximately 50% of scripts, the capacitor was shown in an appropriate position. 
    2. Generally, this calculation caused few problems although a significant minority substituted the r.m.s. voltage, rather than the peak. 
    3. Very few candidates realised that the fraction could be calculated using 0.432. Most laboriously calculated the energy remaining and then found the ratio. There were numerous errors here. Many took the voltage to be 0.43 V, rather than 0.43 V0. Others assumed that the charge in (ii) and (iii) would be the same. 
NO. 217题号：33069

A metal disc is swinging freely between the poles of an electromagnet, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

When the electromagnet is switched on, the disc comes to rest after a few oscillations.

    1. State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction and use the law to explain why an e.m.f. is induced in the disc.
      ..................................................................... [2]
    2. Explain why eddy currents are induced in the metal disc.
      ..................................................................... [2]
  2. Use energy principles to explain why the disc comes to rest after a few oscillations.
    ..................................................................... [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Winter/Paper4/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i (induced) e.m.f proportional/equal to rate of change of flux (linkage)
(allow 'induced voltage, induced p.d.)
flux is cust as the disc moves
hence inducing an e.m.f		 B1

M1
A0		 [2]
a.ii field in disc is not uniform/rate of cutting not same/speed of disc not same (over whole disc) 
so different e.m.f.'s in different parts of disc
lead to eddy currents		 B1
M1
A0		 [2]
b eddy currents dissipate thermal energy in disc
energy derived from oscillation of disc
energy of disc depends on amplitude of oscillations		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
    1. FLEI states that the induced e.m.f. is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux linkage. As the disc moves, it cuts the flux, there by inducing an e.m.f.
    2. The rate of cutting of the flux is not the same over the whole disc. Therefore different e.m.f. are induced in different parts of the disc. This leads to the formation of eddy currents.
    • The eddy currents dissipate thermal energy in the disc
    • This energy is derived from the oscillation of the disc
    • The energy of the disc depends on the amplitude of the oscillations.
    1. It was pleasing to note that most candidates could give a satisfactory statement and were able to explain why an e.m.f. would be induced.
    2. Very few candidates scored any marks here. Most answers were vague and gave the impression that they were unaware as to why eddy currents would be formed. It was sufficient for candidates to realise that the rate of change of flux would not be the same over the whole of the disc, thus the e.m.f. would have different magnitudes in different parts of the disc. 
  2. Some candidates did not read the question carefully and consequently attempted an answer in terms of forces, rather than energy. Of those who did discuss energy, most realised that the eddy currents would dissipate thermal energy in the disc. However, the links between this energy conversion and the disc coming to rest were rarely expressed convincingly. 
NO. 218题号：33029

You are provided with a coil of wire, a bar magnet and a sensitive ammeter.

Outline an experiment to verify Lenz's law.

........................................................................... [6]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Summer/Paper4/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
7 coil in series with meter (do not allow inclusion of a cell) B1 [6]
push known pole into coil  B1
observe current direction (not reading)  B1
(induced) field / field from coil repels magnet B1
either  states rule to determine direction of magnetic field in coil
or  reversing magnet direction gives opposite deflection on meter		 B1
direction of induced current such as to oppose the change producing it B1

  • Connect the coil in series with the meter (shown above)
  • Push the known pole (say North pole) into the coil
  • Observe the current direction (by observing the deflection)
  • Direction will be such that the induced field repels the magnet (that is end A above for the coil is also the North Pole)
  • Now reverse magnet direction i.e. pull it away from the coil. There will be a deflection in the ammeter in the opposite direction i.e. the end A of the coil will now act as a south pole.

    ∴ The direction of the induced current is such so as to oppose the change producing it (Lenz's Law)

Most answers did show a coil connected in series with the meter and the magnet, with known pole, being pushed into the coil.
