However, many did not concentrate on the direction of the current but, rather, on its magnitude. They did, however, refer to 'current in the opposite direction' when the direction of motion of the magnet is reversed. The rule by which the field in the coil is determined was frequently omitted. Statements of Lenz's law frequently lacked clarity in that it was not stated that the induced current gives rise to effects that oppose the change that produces it. 

NO. 219题号：32968

A sinusoidal alternating voltage is to be rectified.

  1. Suggest one advantage of full-wave rectification as compared with half-wave rectification.
    ........................................................................ [1] 
  2. The rectification is produced using the circuit of Fig. 7.1.

    All the diodes may be considered to be ideal.
    The variation with time t of the alternating voltage applied to the circuit is shown in Fig. 7.2 and in Fig. 7.3.

     
    1. On the axes of Fig. 7.2, draw a graph to show the variation with time t of the potential difference across diode A. [1]
    2. On the axes of Fig. 7.3, draw a graph to show the variation with time t of the potential difference across diode B. [1]

    1. On Fig. 7.1, draw the symbol for a capacitor, connected into the circuit so as to provide smoothing. [1]
    2. Fig. 7.4 shows the variation with time t of the smoothed potential difference across the resistor R in Fig. 7.1.

      1. State how the amount of smoothing may be increased.
        ................................................................. [1]
      2. On Fig. 7.4, draw the variation with time t of the potential difference across resistor R for increased smoothing. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper4_1/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a e.g. more (output) power available
e.g. less ripple for same smoothing capacitor
any sensible suggestion		 B1 [1]
b.i curve showing half-wave rectification B1 [1]
b.ii similar to (i) but phase shift of 180° B1 [1]
c.i correct symbol, connected in parallel with R B1 [1]
c.ii 1. larger capacitor / second capacitor in parallel with R
   (not increase R)		 B1 [1]
2. same peak values
   correct shape giving less ripple		 B1
B1		 [2]
    [Total: 7]
  1. More output power available when using full wave rectification
      1. Provide a larger capacitor
  1. In general, some reference was made to 'more continuous' current or voltage. 
    1. Many candidates did not seem to realise that, for an ideal diode that is forward biased, the potential difference across it would be zero. There were many poorly-drawn sketches with peak values shown above those on Fig. 7.2.
    2. There were very few correct responses here. In many answers, an inverted voltage was indicated. 
    1. A significant number of candidates showed the capacitor as being in series with the load resistor. 
    2. 1. The majority of answers were correct. However, a significant minority merely stated 'use another capacitor', without indicating where the capacitor should be connected. 
      2. Again, many lost marks as a result of poor sketches. It was expected that the capacitor discharge would be shown correctly. In many sketches, the capacitor discharge was shown as a concave shape rather than being exponential. 
NO. 220题号：32954

A student is asked to design a circuit by which a direct voltage of peak value 9.0 V is obtained from a 240 V alternating supply.
The student uses a transformer that may be considered to be ideal and a bridge rectifier incorporating four ideal diodes.
The partially completed circuit diagram is shown in Fig. 6.1.

  1. On Fig. 6.1, draw symbols for the four diodes so as to produce the polarity across the load as shown on the diagram. [2]

  2. Calculate the ratio
     

    ratio = ................................................ [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper4_1/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a all four diodes correct to give output, regardless of polarity
connected for correct polarity		 M1
A1		 [2]
b NS / NP = VS / VP
V0 = √2 × Vrms
ratio = 9.0 / (√2 × 240)
     = 1/38 or 1/37 or 0.027		 C1
C1

A1		 [3]
  2. Note: VP/√2 = Vr.m.s.

    NS/NP = VS/VP = 9/[(√2) × 240] = 0.027

    Ratio = 0.027 : 1
  1. The diodes were usually drawn in the correct configuration. However, it was disappointing to see that a small minority of candidates were unable to recall the correct diode symbol.
  2. There were very few fully correct calculations. The most common mistake was a failure to undertake the necessary conversion between the peak and the root-mean-square values of voltage. 
NO. 221题号：32919
  1. A constant current is maintained in a long straight vertical wire. A Hall probe is positioned a distance r from the centre of the wire, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

    1. Explain why, when the Hall probe is rotated about the horizontal axis XY, the Hall voltage varies between a maximum positive value and a maximum negative value.
      .....................................................................[2]
    2. The maximum Hall voltage VH is measured at different distances r.
      Data for VH and the corresponding values of r are shown in Fig. 5.2.

      It is thought that VH and r are related by an expression of the form
         
      where k is a constant.
      1. Without drawing a graph, use data from Fig. 5.2 to suggest whether the expression is valid. [2]

      2. A graph showing the variation with 1/r or VH is plotted.
        State the features of the graph that suggest that the expression is valid.
        ........................................................................[1] 
  2. The Hall probe in (a) is now replaced with a small coil of wire connected to a sensitive voltmeter. The coil is arranged so that its plane is normal to the magnetic field of the wire.
    1. State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction and hence explain why the voltmeter indicates a zero reading.
      ..........................................................................[3]
    2. State three different ways in which an e.m.f. may be induced in the coil.
      1. .........................................................................
      2. .........................................................................
      3. ......................................................................... [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper4_1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i VH depends on angle between (plane of) probe and B-field
either  VH max when plane and B-field are normal to each other 
or  VH zero when plane and B-field are parallel
or  VH depends on sine of angle between plane and B-field		 B1


B1		 [2]
a.ii 1. calculates VHr at least three times
   to 1 s.f. constant so valid or approx constant so valid
   or to 2 s.f., not constant so invalid		 M1

A1		 [2]
2. straight line passes through origin B1 [1]
b.i e.m.f. induced is proportional / equal to
rate of change of (magnetic) flux (linkage)
constant field in coil / flux (linkage) of coil does not change		 M1
A1
B1		 [3]
b.ii e.g. vary current (in wire) / switch current on or off / use a.c. current rotate coil
move coil towards / away from wire (1 mark each, max 3)		 B3 [3]
      • VH depends on the angle between the plane of probe and the B field
      • VH is maximum when the plane and the B field are normal to each other
    2. VH = k/r, where k is a constant

      ∴ VHr = k (constant)
      1. 0.29 × 1 = 0.29 ≈ 0.3

        0.19 × 1.5 = 0.285 ≈ 0.3

        0.14 × 2 = 0.28 ≈ 0.3

        To 1 sig fig constant

        ∴ VH = k/r is valid
      2. A straight line that passes through the origin
      • FLEI states that the induced e.m.f. is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux linkage
      • Zero reading because the flux linkage of the coil does not change
      1. Use an alternating current
      2. Rotate the coil
      3. Move coil towards the wire
    1. The Hall effect was not understood by many candidates. The Hall voltage depends on the angle between the plane of the probe and the magnetic field, so that it is a maximum when they are normal to each other and a minimum when they are parallel to each other. A common misconception was that the Hall voltage was caused by the rate of change of magnetic flux linkage of the probe.
    2. 1. It was expected that (VH × r) would be calculated a minimum of 3 times. These calculated values could then be used as the basis for suggesting whether the expression was valid or not. 
      2. Frequently, a straight line feature was identified. However, very few candidates went on to correctly state that the straight line would pass through the origin.
    1. Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction was usually quoted correctly.
    2. Many answers lacked precision. For example, it was commonly suggested that an e.m.f. could be induced in the coil by moving it, without indicating the necessary direction of movement. Many candidates also decided to introduce into their answers extra pieces of apparatus such as magnets and solenoids. Such answers were outside the context of the question. 
NO. 222题号：32898

The variation with time t of the current I in a resistor is shown in Fig. 6.1.

The variation of the current with time is sinusoidal.

  1. Explain why, although the current is not in one direction only, power is converted in the resistor.
    ........................................................................ [2]
  2. Using the relation between root-mean-square (r.m.s.) current and peak current, deduce the value of the ratio
     

    ratio = ................................................ [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper4_3/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a power / heating depends on I2
so independent of current direction		 M1
A1		 [2]
b either  maximum power = I02R  or  average power = IRMS2R
I0 = √2 × IRMS
maximum power = 2 × average power
ratio = 0.5		 M1
M1

A1		 [3]
    • Power depends on the square of I i.e. I2
    • Therefore it is independent of current direction
  2. Maximum power = I0R, where I0 = peak current





    Ratio = 1 : 2
  1. Many answers were only partially correct. Power depends upon the square of the current, so it will be independent of current direction because the square is always positive. 
  2. It was common to see the symbol for current used without any clear explanation as to whether it represented the root-mean-square current or the peak value of current. Good answers carefully explained all the terms that were used and methodically presented each of the distinct steps that lead up to the final answer. 
NO. 223题号：32889

A transformer is illustrated in Fig. 6.1.

    1. Explain why the coils are wound on a core made of iron.
      ..........................................................................[1]
    2. Suggest why thermal energy is generated in the core.
      ...........................................................................[2]
    1. State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction.
      ...........................................................................[2]
    2. Use Faraday's law to explain why the potential difference across the load and the e.m.f. of the supply are not in phase.
      ...........................................................................[2]
  3. Electrical energy is usually transmitted using alternating current. Suggest why the transmission is achieved using
    1. high voltages,
      ...........................................................................[2]
    2. alternating current.
      ...........................................................................[1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper4_1/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i to concentrate the (magnetic) flux / reduce flux losses B1 [1]
a.ii changing flux (in core) induces current in core
currents in core give rise to a heating effect		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i e.m.f. induced proportional to
rate of change of (magnetic) flux (linkage)		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.ii magnetic flux in phase with / proportional to e.m.f. / current in primary coil
e.m.f. / p.d. across secondary proportional to rate of change of flux
so e.m.f. of supply not in phase with p.d. across secondary		 M1
M1
A0		 [2]
c.i for same power (transmission), high voltage with low current
with low current, less energy losses in transmission cables		 B1
B1		 [2]
c.ii voltage is easily / efficiently changed  B1 [1]
    1. This is done to concentrate the magnetic flux
    2. The changing magnetic flux in the core induces currents in the core

      The currents in the core give rise to the heating effect
    1. FLEI states that the e.m.f. induced is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux linkage
      • The magnetic flux is in phase with the current in the primary coil
      • The e.m.f. across the secondary coil is proportional to the rate of change of flux
      • Therefore the e.m.f. of the supply is not in phase with the potential difference across the secondary coil
    1. For the same power transmitted, with high voltage we have low current. Therefore we have less energy losses in the transmission cables (Power loss = I2R, I is small)
    2. The voltage is easily changed with the use of transformers voltage can be stepped up or stepped down
    1. Candidates need to understand that the coils are wound on a core made of iron in order to concentrate the flux and reduce the flux losses.
    2. While many answers referred to current in the core producing heating, few made it clear that this current is induced because of the changing flux in the core. A common misconception was that all the heat energy in the core had been conducted into it from the transformer coils.
    1. Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction was correctly quoted by the vast majority of candidates.
    2. There is a phase difference because the magnetic flux is in phase with the e.m.f. across the primary coil, whereas the potential difference across the load is proportional to the rate of change of flux. The question asked for an explanation that uses Faraday's law and so explanations that used Lenz's law were not awarded any credit. One misconception was that the phase difference was caused by the primary coil having a different number of turns to the secondary coil. 
    1. It was generally appreciated that high voltages are used in order to reduce energy losses. It was expected that candidates would refer to lower current at higher voltage for the same power transmission. This lower current then results in lower energy losses in the transmission cables. 
    2. Only a minority of candidates appreciated that alternating current is used for transmission in order to allow the voltage to be changed easily and efficiently. 
NO. 224题号：32867

The components for a bridge rectifier are shown in Fig. 5.1.

  1. Complete the circuit of Fig. 5.1 by showing the connections of the supply and of the load to the diodes. [2]

  2. Suggest one advantage of the use of a bridge rectifier, rather than a single diode, for the rectification of alternating current.
    ...................................................................... [1]
  3. State
    1. what is meant by smoothing,
      ...................................................................... [1]
    2. the effect of the value of the capacitance of the smoothing capacitor in relation to smoothing.
      ...................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper4_3/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a supply connected correctly (to left & right)
load connected correctly (to top & bottom)		 B1
B1		 [2]
b e.g. power supplied on every half-cycle
  greater average/mean power
(any sensible suggestion, 1 mark) 		 B1 [1]
c.i reduction in the variation of the output voltage/current B1 [1]
c.ii larger capacitance produces more smoothing
either product RC larger
or for the same load		 M1

A1		 [2]
  2. Power is supplied on every half cycle.
    1. Due to smoothing, the potential difference does not fall to zero.
    2. A larger capacitance produces more soothing for the same load
  1. This part of the question proved to be straightforward for many candidates. However, weaker candidates often failed to take into account the orientation of the network of diodes.
  2. An advantage of bridge rectifiers is that they produce output power on every half-cycle so that there is a greater average power output. Few candidates appreciated this point. Rather, they attempted to involve smoothing. 
    1. It was expected that candidates would state that smoothing is the reduction of the variation of the output voltage or output current. 
    2. The majority of candidates understood that a larger capacitance produces more smoothing for the same load. A common misconception is that the value of the capacitance changes during the smoothing process. 
NO. 225题号：32846

A bridge rectifier consists of four ideal diodes A, B, C and D, connected as shown in Fig. 6.1.

An alternating supply is applied between the terminals X and Y.

    1. On Fig. 6.1, label the positive (+) connection to the load resistor R. [1]

    2. State which diodes are conducting when terminal Y of the supply is positive.

      diode .................... and diode ....................[1]
  2. The variation with time t of the potential difference V across the load resistor R is shown in Fig. 6.2.

    The load resistor R has resistance 2700 Ω.
    1. Use Fig. 6.2 to determine the mean power dissipated in the resistor R.

      power = ............................................ W [3]
    2. On Fig. 6.1, draw the symbol for a capacitor, connected so as to increase the mean power dissipated in the resistor R. [1]

  3. The capacitor in (b)(ii) is now removed from the circuit.
    The diode A in Fig. 6.1 stops functioning, so that it now has infinite resistance.
    On Fig. 6.2, draw the variation with time t of the new potential difference across the resistor R. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper4_3/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i connection to 'top' of resistor labelled as positive B1 [1]
a.ii diode B and diode D B1 [1]
b.i VP = 4.0V
mean power = VP2/2R
= 42 / (2 × 2700)
= 2.96 × 10–3W		 C1
C1

A1		 [3]
b.ii capacitor, correct symbol, connected in parallel with R B1 [1]
c graph: half-wave rectification
same period and same peak value		 M1
A1		 [2]
    2. Diode B and diode D.
    1. Mean power <P> = VP2/2R

      VP = 4V

      R = 2700 Ω

      ∴ <P> = 42/(2 × 2700) = 2.96 × 10-3 W
  3. Let me draw it here (you please draw it on 6.2)



    Note:
    • Half wave rectification
    • Same period and same peak value
    1. The positive connection to the load resistor was usually identified correctly.
    2. The majority of candidates realised that diodes B and D were conducting. 
    1. Two methods of calculation were used. The most common method was to calculate the r.m.s. voltage across the resistor and then use this to find the mean power dissipated. The other method was to use the peak voltage across the resistor to calculate the peak power dissipated, which was then halved to get the mean power. There were many calculations where there was confusion between the peak power and the mean power. 
    2. The capacitor was usually positioned correctly in the circuit, although sometimes it was wrongly placed in series with the resistor. 
  3. The entire graph line needed to be shown. This included the parts of the graph line that lie along the time axis where there is zero potential difference. A small minority of candidates ignored the instruction to draw on Fig. 6.2 and instead drew their graph on a blank area of the page. This made it very difficult to show that the half-wave rectification occurs with the same period and the same peak value of potential difference as the full-wave rectification. 
NO. 226题号：32835
  1. State the relation between magnetic flux density B and magnetic flux Φ, explaining any other symbols you use.
    .......................................................................[2]
  2. A large horseshoe magnet has a uniform magnetic field between its poles. The magnetic field is zero outside the space between the poles.
    A small Hall probe is moved at constant speed along a line XY that is midway between, and parallel to, the faces of the poles of the magnet, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

    An e.m.f. is produced by the Hall probe when it is in the magnetic field.
    The angle between the plane of the probe and the direction of the magnetic field is not varied.
    On the axes of Fig. 5.2, sketch a graph to show the variation with time t of the e.m.f. VH produced by the Hall probe. [2]

      ....................................................................[2]
    2. The Hall probe in (b) is replaced by a small flat coil of wire. The coil is moved at constant speed along the line XY. The plane of the coil is parallel to the faces of the poles of the magnet.
      On the axes of Fig. 5.3, sketch a graph to show the variation with time t of the e.m.f. E induced in the coil. [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper4_3/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a either ϕ = BA sinθ
where A is the area (through which flux passes)
θ is the angle between B and (plane of) A
or
ϕ = BA
where A is area normal to B		 M1

A1

(M1)
(A1)		 [2]
b graph: VH constant and non zero between the poles and zero outside
sharp increase/decrease at ends of magnet		 M1
A1		 [2]
c.i (induced) e.m.f. proportional to
rate of change of (magnetic) flux (linkage)		 M1
A1		 [2]
c.ii short pulse on entering and on leaving region between poles
pulses approximately the same shape but opposite polarities
e.m.f. zero between poles and outside		 M1
A1
A1		 [3]
  1. Φ = BA

    Where A is the area normal to B

    (Note: the area A is normal to the lines of flux)

    1. FLEI states that the induced e.m.f. is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux linkage.
  1. There were many satisfactory answers, although some candidates confused magnetic flux with magnetic flux linkage. 
  2. For the award of credit, the entire graph line needed to be shown. This included the parts of the graph line that lie along the time axis where there is zero e.m.f.
    1. Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction was usually quoted correctly. 
    2. Few candidates appreciated that a short 'pulse' of e.m.f. would be produced by the probe both on entering and leaving the magnetic field. Even fewer realised that the e.m.f. of these two pulses would be in opposite directions. 
NO. 227题号：32817

A simple transformer is illustrated in Fig. 6.1.

  1. State
    1. why the iron core is laminated,
      ........................................................................[2]
    2. what is meant by an ideal transformer.
      ........................................................................[1]
  2. An ideal transformer has 300 turns on the primary coil and 8100 turns on the secondary coil.
    The root-mean-square input voltage to the primary coil is 9.0 V.
    Calculate the peak voltage across the load resistor connected to the secondary coil.

    peak voltage = .............................................. V [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper4_3/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i to reduce power loss in the core
due to eddy currents/induced currents		 B1
B1		 [2]
a.ii either  no power loss in transformer
or  input power = output power		 B1 [1]
b either  r.m.s. voltage across load = 9.0 × (8100 / 300)
   peak voltage across load = √2 × 243
             = 340V		 C1

A1		 [2]
or peak voltage across primary coil = 9.0 × √2
    peak voltage across load = 12.7 × (8100/300)
             = 340V		 (C1)

(A1)		  
    1. The iron core is laminated to reduce power loss in the core due to eddy currents
    2. In an ideal transformer, power input = power output

      i.e. the transformer is 100% efficient.
  2. VP = Vr.m.s.√2 = 9√2

    Using VP/VS = NP/NS

    VS = VP(NS/NP)

    = (9√2) × (8100/300)

    = 343.65 V

    Peak voltage = 340 V
    1. Candidates were expected to refer to the reduction of power loss in the core due to eddy currents. A common error was to believe that power loss and eddy currents are prevented rather than reduced.
    2. An ideal transformer is one that has no power loss, so that the input power is equal to the output power.
  2. The calculation was usually done correctly, although a significant minority of candidates did not convert the root-mean-square voltage to a peak voltage.
NO. 228题号：32816
  1. Define the tesla.
    ......................................................................... [2]
  2. A long solenoid has an area of cross-section of 28 cm2,  as shown in Fig. 5.1.
     
    A coil C consisting of 160 turns of insulated wire is wound tightly around the centre of the solenoid.
    The magnetic flux density B at the centre of the solenoid is given by the expression
                       B = μ0nI
    where I is the current in the solenoid, n is a constant equal to 1.5 × 103 m–1 and μ0 is the permeability of free space.
    Calculate, for a current of 3.5A in the solenoid,
    1. the magnetic flux density at the centre of the solenoid,

      flux density = .............................................. T [2]
    2. the flux linkage in the coil C.

      flux linkage = ........................................... Wb [2]
    1. State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction.
      .............................................................................[2]
    2. The current in the solenoid in (b) is reversed in direction in a time of 0.80 s.
      Calculate the average e.m.f. induced in coil C.

      e.m.f. = .............................................. V [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper4_1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a (uniform magnetic) flux normal to long (straight) wire carrying a current of 1 A
(creates) force per unit length of 1 Nm–1		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i flux density = 4π × 10–7 × 1.5 × 103 × 3.5
                   = 6.6 × 10–3T		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii flux linkage = 6.6 × 10–3 × 28 × 10–4 × 160
                   = 3.0 × 10–3Wb		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.i (induced) e.m.f. proportional to rate of
change of (magnetic) flux (linkage)		 M1
A1		 [2]
c.ii e.m.f. = (2 × 3.0 × 10–3) / 0.80
         = 7.4 × 10–3V		 C1
A1		 [2]
  1. One tesla is the uniform magnetic flux density which acting normal to a long straight wire carrying a current of 1 A causes a force per unit length of 1 N/m on the conductor.
    1. μ0 = 4π × 10-7

      n = 1.5 × 103

      I = 3.5

      ∴ B = (4π × 10-7)(1.5 × 103) × 3.5 = 6.597 × 10-3 T

      Flux density = 6.6 × 10-3 T
    2. Φ = flux linkage = BAN

      = 6.6 × 10-3 × 28 × 10-4 × 160 (change cm2 to m2)

      = 2.95 × 10-3 Wb
    1. FLEI states that the induced e.m.f. is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux linkage
    2. e.m.f. = -d(NΦ)/dt

      Here the average e.m.f. = (change in flux linkage)/time

      = (2 × 2.95 × 10-3)/0.8

      = 7.4 × 10-3 V
  1. Candidates need to be able to distinguish between the definition of a quantity and the definition of a unit. The tesla is a unit and so it should be defined in terms of the metre, the newton and the ampere. Candidates should also refer to force per unit length being one newton per metre, rather than a force of one newton on one metre length of wire.
    1. Almost all answers were fully correct, although a small minority confused the permeability of free space with the permittivity of free space.
    2. Some candidates were not able to distinguish between flux linkage and flux.
    1. Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction was usually quoted correctly.
    2. The most common error was to calculate an average e.m.f. that corresponded to the current in the solenoid being switched off, rather than being reversed.
NO. 229题号：32741

In many distribution systems for electrical energy, the energy is transmitted using alternating current at high voltages.

Suggest and explain an advantage, one in each case, for the use of

  1. alternating voltages,
    ............................................................................. [2]
  2. high voltages.
    ............................................................................. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2015/Summer/Paper4_1/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a can change (output) voltage efficiently or to suit different consumers/appliances
by using transformers		 B1
B1		 [2]
b for same power, current is smaller
less heating in cables/wires
or thinner cables possible
or less voltage loss in cables		 B1


B1		 [2]
  1. Alternating voltages allow the change of voltage output to suit different consumer requirements by the use of transformers
  2. To reduce power loss due to heating in the cables. For the same power, the current (I) is smaller and hence less power loss due to heating in the cables.
  1. The most common answer was the fact that the voltage can be changed "easily", rather than efficiently.
  2. The idea of current being smaller was well understood, but many candidates did not also say that this could occur while the power transmitted remains the same. Likewise, the idea of power loss being smaller, or less heating occurring, was also popular but very few candidates related this to the cables or wires.
NO. 230题号：32740

A proton is moving with constant velocity v. It enters a uniform magnetic field that is normal to the initial direction of motion of the proton, as shown in Fig. 8.1.



A uniform electric field is applied in the same region as the magnetic field so that the proton passes undeviated through the fields.

  1. On Fig. 8.1, draw an arrow labelled E to show the direction of the electric field. [1]

  2. The proton is replaced by other particles. The electric and magnetic fields remain unchanged.
    State and explain the deviation, if any, of the following particles in the region of the fields.
    1. an α-particle with initial velocity v
      ............................................................................. [3]
    2. an electron with initial velocity 2v
      ............................................................................. [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Summer/Paper4/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a arrow labelled E pointing down the page B1 [1]
b.i Bqv = qE
forces are independent of mass and charge 'cancels' 
so no deviation		 M1
M1
A1		 [3]
b.ii magnetic force > electric force
so deflects
'downwards'		 M1
M1
A1		 [3]
      • No deviation
      • From Bqv = qE, the force are independent of mass and "q" the charge cancels
    2. The magnetic force is greater than the electric force

      ∴ There is a deflection downwards
  1. The majority of candidates did indicate the correct direction for the electric field. There were, however, some responses that indicated a total lack of appreciation of the situation.
    1. There were some very good answers, based on a quote of the formulae for the force due to each field. However, the majority failed to appreciate that both fields exert a force. A common answer was to state that 'the α-particle will deflect, but because it is four times more massive than a proton, the deflection will be small'.
    2. Once again, well-described correct answers were rare. Generally, it was thought that the forces due to both fields would be in the same direction.
NO. 231题号：32736
  1. Describe what is meant by a magnetic field.
    .............................................................................[3]
  2. A small mass is placed in a field of force that is either electric or magnetic or gravitational.
    State the nature of the field of force when the mass is
    1. charged and the force is opposite to the direction of the field,
      ...................................................................[1]
    2. uncharged and the force is in the direction of the field,
      ...................................................................[1]
    3. charged and there is a force only when the mass is moving,
      ...................................................................[1]
    4. charged and there is no force on the mass when it is stationary or moving in a particular direction.
      ...................................................................[1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2008/Winter/Paper4/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a region (of space) / area where
a force is experienced by
current-carrying conductor / moving charge / permanent magnet		 B1
M1
A1		 [3]
b.i electric B1 [1]
b.ii gravitational B1 [1]
b.iii magnetic B1 [1]
b.iv magnetic B1 [1]
  1. A magnetic field is a region of space where a current carrying conductor experiences a force
    1. electric
    2. gravitational
    3. magnetic
    4. magnetic
  1. There were some very good answers. The most common error was to make reference to force on a charge, without making it clear that the force is experienced only when the charge is moving.
  2. More-able candidates usually gave all four correct answers. However, the answers given by weaker candidates gave the impression that their attempts were not based on scientific thinking.
NO. 232题号：32734

The current in a long, straight vertical wire is in the direction XY, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

  1. On Fig. 6.1, sketch the pattern of the magnetic flux in the horizontal plane ABCD due to the current-carrying wire. Draw at least four flux lines. [3]

  2. The current-carrying wire is within the Earth's magnetic field. As a result, the pattern drawn in Fig. 6.1 is superposed with the horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic field.
    Fig. 6.2 shows a plan view of the plane ABCD with the current in the wire coming out of the plane.

    The horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic field is also shown.
    1. On Fig. 6.2, mark with the letter P a point where the magnetic field due to the current-carrying wire could be equal and opposite to that of the Earth. [1]

    2. For a long, straight wire carrying current I, the magnetic flux density B at distance r from the centre of the wire is given by the expression
         
      where μ0 is the permeability of free space.
      The point P in (i) is found to be 1.9 cm from the centre of the wire for a current of 1.7 A.
      Calculate a value for the horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic flux density.

      flux density = ............................................ T [2]
  3. The current in the wire in (b)(ii) is increased. The point P is now found to be 2.8 cm from the wire.
    Determine the new current in the wire.

    current = ............................................ A [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper4_1/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a concentric circles …(at least three lines)
with increasing separation
correct direction clear		 M1
A1
B1		 [3]
b.i correct position to left of wire B1 [1]
b.ii B = (4π × 10-7 × 1.7) / (2π × 1.9 × 10-2)
   = 1.8 × 10-5 T		 C1
A1		 [2]
c distance ∝ current
current = (2.8 / 1.9) × 1.7
            = 2.5 A		 C1

A1		 [2]
    [Total: 8]
    2. μ0 = 4π × 10-7

      I = 1.7

      r = 1.9 × 10-2

      ∴ B = (4π × 10-7 × 1.7)/(2π × 1.9 × 10-2) = 1.789 × 10-5 T
  3. From μ0I = B2πr

    I ∝ r

    ∴ I/1.7 = 2.8/1.9

    ∴ I = 2.505

    Current = 2.5 A
  1. As is usually the situation where candidates are asked to draw field lines, insufficient care was taken. Most drew lines that, with some imagination, could be considered to be concentric circles. However, very few showed increasing separation with distance from the wire. Candidates should realise that the spacing of field lines does have significance.
    1. Most drawings showed the position as being to the left of the wire, but precision was frequently lacking. 
    2. Apart from power-of-ten errors, the calculation presented few problems. 
  3. There were many correct answers. However, most did actually carry out a full calculation involving the answer in (b)(ii), rather than solve the problem using proportionality. 
NO. 233题号：32732

Negatively-charged particles are moving through a vacuum in a parallel beam. The particles have speed v.
The particles enter a region of uniform magnetic field of flux density 930 μT. Initially, the particles are travelling at right-angles to the magnetic field. The path of a single particle is shown in Fig. 7.1.



The negatively-charged particles follow a curved path of radius 7.9 cm in the magnetic field.

A uniform electric field is then applied in the same region as the magnetic field. For an electric field strength of 12 kV m–1, the particles are undeviated as they pass through the region of the fields.

  1. On Fig. 7.1, mark with an arrow the direction of the electric field. [1]

  2. Calculate, for the negatively-charged particles,
    1. the speed v,

      v = ....................................... m s–1 [3]
    2. the ratio

      ratio = .................................... C kg–1 [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper4_1/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a arrow pointing up the page B1 [1]
b.i Eq = Bqv
v = (12 × 103) / (930 × 10–6) 
   = 1.3 × 107 m s–1		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
b.ii Bqv = mv2 / r
q/m = (1.3 × 107) / (7.9 × 10–2 × 930 × 10–6)
= 1.8 × 1011 C kg–1		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
    1. Use FE = FB

      Eq = Bqv

      ∴ v = E/B = (12 × 103)/(930 × 10-6)

      = 1.29 × 107
    2. Use Bqv = mv2/r

      ∴ Bq = mv/r

      ∴ q/m = v/Br = (1.3 × 107)/(930 × 10-6 × 7.9 × 10-2) = 1.77 × 1011
  1. The direction of the electric field was usually identified correctly.
    1. The correct calculation involved equating the force on a charged particle due to the magnetic field with the force on it due to the electric field. However, a significant minority of candidates attempted calculations that required the values of both the charge and the mass of the particles to be known. Since those values were not known, no credit was given for such calculations. 
    2. The correct calculation was based on an understanding that the centripetal force is provided by the force on the charged particles due to the magnetic field. However, a minority of candidates attempted a different calculation that assumed that the particles had the charge and mass of an electron. Since this assumption could not be justified, no credit was given for that type of calculation. 
NO. 234题号：32729

Electrons are moving through a vacuum in a narrow beam. The electrons have speed v.
The electrons enter a region of uniform magnetic field of flux density B. Initially, the electrons are travelling at a right-angle to the magnetic field.
The path of a single electron is shown in Fig. 7.1.

The electrons follow a curved path in the magnetic field.

A uniform electric field of field strength E is now applied in the same region as the magnetic field.
The electrons pass undeviated through the region of the two fields.
Gravitational effects may be neglected.

  1. Derive a relation between v, E and B for the electrons not to be deflected. Explain your working.
    ......................................................................... [3]
  2. An α-particle has speed v and approaches the region of the two fields along the same path as the electron. Describe and explain the path of the α-particle as it passes through the region of the two fields.
    ......................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper4_3/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a force due to E-field is equal and opposite to force due to B-field
Eq = Bqv
v = E/B		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
b either  charge and mass are not involved in the equation in (a)
or  FE and FB are both doubled
or  E, B and v do not change
so no deviation

M1
A1		 [2]
    • The force due to the electric field is equal and opposite to the force due to the magnetic field
    • So we write FE = FM i.e. Eq = Bqv
    • v = E/B
  2. No deviation

    E, B and v do not change

    ∴ No deviation
  1. Most derivations included a statement that the force due to the electric field is equal in magnitude to the force due to the magnetic field, but omitted the necessary condition that these two forces must also be opposite in direction.  
  2. Key details were missing from most explanations. Although the particle entering the crossed fields now has a different charge and mass, these quantities are not involved in the expression v = E/B. The magnitudes of v, E and B have not changed and therefore there will be no deviation. 
NO. 235题号：32728
  1. State what is meant by a magnetic field.
    ............................................................................[2]
  2. A charged particle of mass m and charge +q is travelling with velocity v in a vacuum. It enters a region of uniform magnetic field of flux density B, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

    The magnetic field is normal to the direction of motion of the particle. The path of the particle in the field is the arc of a circle of radius r.
    1. Explain why the path of the particle in the field is the arc of a circle.
      .............................................................................[2]
    2. Show that the radius r is given by the expression
           [2]
  3. A thin metal foil is placed in the magnetic field in (b).
    A second charged particle enters the region of the magnetic field. It loses kinetic energy as it passes through the foil. The particle follows the path shown in Fig. 5.2.

    1. On Fig. 5.2, mark with an arrow the direction of travel of the particle. [1]

    2. The path of the particle has different radii on each side of the foil. 
      The radii are 7.4 cm and 5.7 cm. 
      Determine the ratio
       
      for the particle as it passes through the foil.

      ratio = ................................................ [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper4_1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a region (of space) where there is a force
either  on / produced by magnetic pole
or  on / produced by current carrying conductor / moving charge		 M1

A1		 [2]
b.i force on particle is (always) normal to velocity / direction of travel
speed of particle is constant		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.ii magnetic force provides the centripetal force
mv2 / r = Bqv
r = mv / Bq		 B1
M1
A0		 [2]
c.i direction from 'bottom to top' of diagram B1 [1]
c.ii radius proportional to momentum
ratio = 5.7 / 7.4
= 0.77
(answer must be consistent with direction given in (c)(i))		 C1

A1

 [2]
  1. A magnetic field is the region of space where there is a force on a magnetic pole placed in it.
      • The force on the particle (travelling at constant speed) is always normal to the direction of motion.
      • This magnetic force provides the centripetal force for circular motion
    2. Use Bqv = mv2/r

      ∴ r = mv2/Bqv = mv/Bq
    2. The radius is proportional to the momentum



      = r2/r1

      = 5.7/7.4

      = 0.77

      Ratio = 0.77 : 1
  1. There were many good answers. Some referred to the force on a charge, without making it clear that the force is experienced only when the charge is moving.
    1. While some candidates realised that the force on the particle is always normal to the direction of its travel, only a few mentioned that the speed of the particle remains constant. Weaker candidates sometimes confused the magnetic field with a uniform electric field and referred to a constant downward force or a parabolic path.
    2. Most answers simply equated the centripetal force to the magnetic force. This gives the impression that there is an equilibrium situation and so candidates need to explain that the centripetal force is provided by the magnetic force.  
    1. Many candidates appeared to guess the direction of travel. The charged particle loses kinetic energy as it passes through the foil, which causes a reduction in the radius of its path. 
    2. Generally, it was appreciated that the ratio of the momenta is equal to the ratio of the radii. However, some candidates inverted the correct ratio or gave a ratio that was not consistent with the direction of travel indicated in (i). 
NO. 236题号：32726
  1. Define the tesla.
    ......................................................................... [3]
  2. A charged particle of mass m and charge +q is travelling with velocity v in a vacuum. It enters a region of uniform magnetic field of flux density B as shown in Fig. 6.1.

    The magnetic field is normal to the direction of motion of the particle. The path of the particle in the field is the arc of a circle of radius r.
    1. Explain why the path of the particle in the field is the arc of a circle.
      ............................................................... [2]
    2. Show that the radius r is given by the expression 
                [1]

  3. A uniform magnetic field is produced in the region PQRS, as shown in Fig. 6.2.

    The magnetic field is normal to the page.
    At point X, a gamma-ray photon interaction causes two particles to be formed. The paths of these particles are shown in Fig. 6.2.
    1. Suggest, with a reason, why each of the paths is a spiral, rather than the arc of a circle.
      ............................................................... [2] 
    2. State and explain what can be deduced from the paths about
      1. the charges on the two particles,
        ................................................................ [2]
      2. the initial speeds of the two particles.
        ................................................................ [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper4_3/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a unit of magnetic flux density
field normal to (straight) conductor carrying current of 1 A
force per unit length is 1 Nm–1		 B1
M1
A1		 [3]
b.i force on particle always normal to direction of motion
(and speed of particle is constant)
magnetic force provides the centripetal force		 M1

A1		 [2]
b.ii mv2/r = Bqv
r = mv/Bq		 M1
A0		 [1]
c.i the momentum/speed is becoming less
so the radius is becoming smaller		 M1
A1		 [2]
c.ii 1. spirals are in opposite directions
   so oppositely charged		 M1
A1		 [2]
2. equal initial radii 
   so equal (initial) speeds		 M1
A1		 [2]
  1. One tesla is the uniform magnetic flux density which, acting normally to a long straight wire carrying a current of 1 A causes a force per unit length of 1 N/m on the conductor
      • The force on the particle (travelling at constant speed) is always normal to the direction of motion
      • This magnetic force provides the centripetal force for circular motion
    2. Use Bqv = mv2/r

      ∴ r = mv2/Bqv = mv/Bq
      • The momentum is decreasing
      • Therefore the radius is becoming smaller
        • The spirals are in opposite directions
        • Therefore the two particles are oppositely charged
        • Initially the radii are equal
        • Therefore the initial speed are equal
  1. It is important that candidates distinguish clearly between the definition of a quantity and that of a unit. The tesla is the unit of magnetic flux density and should be defined in terms of the metre, the newton and the ampere. Candidates need to be encouraged to improve their recall of standard definitions.
    1. Only a small minority of candidates could explain that the force on the particle is always normal to the direction of motion. This magnetic force provides the centripetal force that is necessary for the particle to move along the arc of a circle. A common error was to state that the force on the particle was always downwards. 
    2. The great majority of answers were correct. 
    1. Although many candidates made reference to the path having a decreasing radius, comparatively few could explain that this was due to the decreasing speed of the particles. Some candidates thought that the particles producing the spiral paths were gamma-ray photons, suggesting a mis-reading of the question stem. 
    2. Where a question asks for a statement with an explanation, candidates should appreciate that, for the award of full credit, the explanation is essential. In part 1, the particles must be oppositely charged because the spirals are in opposite directions. Weaker candidates often thought, quite wrongly, that the particles were repelling each other and so must have the same charge. In part 2, the particles must have equal initial speeds because their paths have equal initial radii. 
NO. 237题号：32722

A proton of mass m and charge +q is travelling through a vacuum in a straight line with speed v.
It enters a region of uniform magnetic field of magnetic flux density B, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

The magnetic field is normal to the direction of motion of the proton.

  1. Explain why the path of the proton in the magnetic field is an arc of a circle.
    ........................................................................[2]
  2. The angular speed of the proton in the magnetic field is ω.
    Derive an expression for ω in terms of B, q and m. [4]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper4_3/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a force on proton is normal to velocity and field
provides centripetal force (for circular motion)		 M1
A1		 [2]
b magnetic force = Bqv
centripetal force = mrω2 or mv2/r
v = rω
Bqv = Bqrω = mrω2
ω = Bq/m		 B1
B1
B1

A1		 [4]
  1. The force on the proton is normal to the velocity and the field. This force provides the centripetal force for circular motion.
  2. Use Bqv = mv2/r

    or Bqv = mrω2

    But v = rω

    ∴ Bqrω = mrω2

    ∴ ω = Bqr/mr = Bq/m
  1. Candidates needed to explain that the force on the proton is normal to both the proton's velocity and to the direction of the magnetic field. This force provides the centripetal force needed for circular motion. 
  2. The majority of candidates were able to equate the two appropriate expressions for the force on the proton. All steps in a derivation must be clearly shown and so it was necessary to explicitly name the centripetal force and the magnetic force when first introducing their corresponding expressions. 
NO. 238题号：32717

A Hall probe is placed a distance d from a long straight current-carrying wire, as illustrated in Fig. 5.1.

The direct current in the wire is 4.0 A. Line XY is normal to the wire.

The Hall probe is rotated about the line XY to the position where the reading VH of the Hall probe is maximum.

  1. The Hall probe is now moved away from the wire, along the line XY.
    On the axes of Fig. 5.2, sketch a graph to show the variation of the Hall voltage VH with distance x of the probe from the wire. Numerical values are not required on your sketch. [2]
  2. The Hall probe is now returned to its original position, a distance d from the wire.
    At this point, the magnetic flux density due to the current in the wire is proportional to the current.
    For a direct current of 4.0 A in the wire, the reading of the Hall probe is 3.5 mV.
    The direct current is now replaced by an alternating current of root-mean-square (r.m.s.) value 4.0 A. The period of this alternating current is T.
    On the axes of Fig. 5.3, sketch the variation with time t of the reading of the Hall voltage VH for two cycles of the alternating current. Give numerical values for VH, where appropriate.   [3]
  3. A student suggests that the Hall probe in (a) is replaced with a small coil connected in series with a millivoltmeter. The constant current in the wire is 4.0 A.
    In order to obtain data to plot a graph showing the variation with distance x of the magnetic flux density, the student suggests that readings of the millivoltmeter are taken when the coil is held in position at different values of x.
    Comment on this suggestion. 
    ............................................................................. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2014/Summer/Paper4_2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a only curve with decreasing gradient
acceptable value near x = 0 and does not reach zero
(if graph line less than 4.0 cm do not allow A1 mark)
(no credit if graph line has positive and negative values of VH)		 M1
A1


 [2]
b graph: from 0 to 2T, two cycles of a sinusoidal wave
all peaks above 3.5mV
peaks at 4.95/ 5.0 mV (allow 4.8mV to 5.2mV)		 M1
C1
A1		 [3]
c e.m.f. induced in coil when magnetic field/flux is changing/ cutting
either at each position, magnetic field does not vary
so no e.m.f. is induced in the coil/ no reading on the millivoltmeter
or at each position, switch off current and take millivoltmeter reading
or at each position, rapidly remove coil from field and take meter reading		 B1



B1		 [2]


  2. Peak voltage = (√2) × 3.5 = 4.95 ≈ 5 mV
    • An e.m.f. is induced in the coil when the magnetic flux is changing
    • At each position, the magnetic field does not vary

      ∴ No e.m.f. is induced in the coil (so no reading on the millivoltmeter)
  1. It was expected that a smooth curve would be drawn, starting at x = d and not reaching the x-axis. Candidates found this difficult and many drew sinusoidal waves. Where a smooth curve was drawn, this frequently either had a finite value at x = 0 (i.e. displaced to the left by d relative to the correct curve) or cut the x-axis. 
  2. Most sketches did indicate a sine wave with the correct period. The most common error was to draw the curve with an inappropriate amplitude. 
  3. This was a challenging question. It would appear that a significant number of candidates have not experienced the use of a search coil and were not able to use their knowledge of Faraday's law to predict its behaviour. Of those who did realise that the suggestion is faulty, many merely quoted Faraday's law as it would apply to the coil. They did not go on to give any detail such as why there would not be an induced e.m.f. or how the procedure could be modified to provide readings.
NO. 239题号：32715

A stiff straight copper wire XY is held fixed in a uniform magnetic field of flux density 2.6 × 10−3 T, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

The wire XY has length 4.7 cm and makes an angle of 34° with the magnetic field.

  1. Calculate the force on the wire due to a constant current of 5.4 A in the wire.

    force = ..................................................... N [2]
  2. The current in the wire is now changed to an alternating current of r.m.s. value 1.7 A.
    Determine the total variation in the force on the wire due to the alternating current.

    variation in force = .............................. N [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2014/Winter/Paper4_1/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a F = BILsinθ
  = 2.6 × 10–3 × 5.4 × 4.7 × 10–2 × sin 34°
  = 3.69 × 10–4N
(allow 1 mark for use of cos 34°)		 C1

A1

 [2]
b peak current = 1.7 × √2
  = 2.4A		 C1 [3]
max. force = 2.6 × 10–3 × 2.4 × 4.7 × 10–2 × sin 34°
  = 1.64 × 10–4N		 C1
variation = 2 × 1.64 × 10–4
  = 3.3 × 10–4N		 A1
  1. Use F = BIlsinθ

    So F = (2.6 × 10-3) × 5.4 × 4.7 × 10-2 sin34 = 3.69 × 10-4 N
  2. Peak current = (Ir.m.s.)√2 = 1.7√2

    ∴ Maximum force = Using BIlsinθ

    = (2.6 × 10-3) × (1.7√2) × 4.7 × 10-2sin34

    = 1.64 × 10-4 N

    ∴ Variation = 2 × 1.64 × 10-4 = 3.29 × 10-4 N

    Note: Variation = Twice the maximum force
  1. In most scripts, this calculation was completed correctly. Common errors were either to omit the angle function or to use an incorrect angle function. 
  2. Most candidates calculated the peak current along with the force associated with this current. There were few answers where the force associated with the peak current was doubled. Many determined the difference between this force and that calculated in (a).
NO. 240题号：32713
  1. State the type of field, or fields, that may cause a force to be exerted on a particle that is
    1. uncharged and moving,
      ......................................................................... [1]
    2. charged and stationary,
      ......................................................................... [1]
    3. charged and moving at right-angles to the field.
      ......................................................................... [2]
  2. A particle X has mass 3.32×10−26 kg and charge +1.60×10−19 C.
    The particle is travelling in a vacuum with speed 7.60×104 m s−1. It enters a region of uniform magnetic field that is normal to the direction of travel of the particle. The particle travels in a semicircle of diameter 12.2 cm, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

    For the uniform magnetic field,
    1. state its direction,
      ........................................................................ [1]
    2. calculate the magnetic flux density.

      magnetic flux density = ................................... T [3]
  3. A second particle Y has mass less than that of particle X in (b) and the same charge.
    It enters the region of uniform magnetic field in (b) with the same speed and along the same initial path as particle X.
    On Fig. 6.1, draw the path of particle Y in the region of the magnetic field. [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2015/Summer/Paper4_1/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i gravitational B1 [1]
a.ii gravitational and electric B1 [1]
a.iii magnetic and one other field given
magnetic, graviational and electric		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.i out of (plane of) paper/page (not "upwards")  B1 [1]
b.ii B = mv /qr
   = (3.32 × 10–26 × 7.6 × 104)/(1.6 × 10–19 × 6.1 × 10–2)
   = 0.26 T		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
c sketch: semicircle with diameter < 12.2cm  B1 [1]
    1. Gravitational field
    2. Gravitational and electric fields
    3. Magnetic, gravitational and electric fields
    1. Out of the plane of paper
    2. Use Bqv = mv2/r

      ∴ B = mv/qr = (3.32 × 10-26 × 7.6 × 104)/[1.6 × 10-19 × (12.2/2) × 10-2] = 0.2585

      Magnetic flux density = 0.26 T
  3. Use the idea from Bqv = m1v2/r

    ∴ r1 = m1v/Bq, m1 < m, q same, v same, B same

    ∴ r1 must be less than 6.1 × 10-2 m



    The dashed semicircle with radius < 6.1 × 10-2 m

    Note: I drew it here so as not to clutter up fig 6.1
  1. Many candidates responded with only one force for each situation. Candidates need to realise that a particle will have mass.  
  2. Very few candidates determined the correct direction of the magnetic field. The calculation part of this question proved relatively straightforward.
  3. Very few candidates realised that the particle would be undergoing circular motion with a smaller radius of curvature. Candidates should be encouraged to take care with the drawing of diagrams.
NO. 241题号：32712
  1. Define potential at a point in an electric field. [2]

  2. An isolated metal sphere of radius r carries a charge +Q. The charge may be assumed to be concentrated at the centre of the sphere.  [3]
    1. State, in terms of r and Q, the electric potential V at the surface of the sphere. Identify any other symbols you use.
    2. Write down the relationship between capacitance C, charge Q and potential V.
    3. Hence show that the capacitance C of the sphere is given by C = 4πε0r.

  3. The sphere in (b) has a radius of 15 cm and carries a charge of 2.0 × 10–6C. [4]
    Calculate
    1. the capacitance of the sphere,
    2. the energy stored on the sphere.
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2002/Summer/Paper4/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a work done in moving unit (positive) charge
from infinity to the point and charge is positive		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i V = Q/4πε0r  where ε0 is permittivity (of free space) B1 [3]
b.ii C = Q/V B1
b.iii hence C = 4πε0r B1
c.i C = 4π × 8.85 × 10–11 × 0.15
   = 1.67 × 10–5 µF		 B1 [4]
c.ii energy = ½CV2  or  ½QV
potential = (2.0 × 10–6) / (1.67 × 10–11) = 1.2 × 105 V
energy = ½ × 1.67 × 10–11 × (1.2 × 105)2
            = 0.12 J		 C1
C1

A1
  1. The electric potential at a point in an electric field is defined as the work done in bringing unit positive charge from infinity to that point.
    1. V = Q/4πε0r
    2. C = Q/V
    3. V = Q/4πε0r

      ∴ Q/V = 4πε0r

      ∴ C = 4πε0r
    1. C = 4π(8.85 × 10-12)(15 × 10-2)

      = 1.67 × 10-11 F

      = 1.67 × 10-5 μF
    2. V = Q/C = (2 × 10-6)/(1.67 × 10-11)

      Energy = (1/2)QV = (1/2) × 2 × 10-6 × [(2 × 10-6)/(1.67 × 10-11)] = 0.1197 J

      Energy = 0.12 J
  1. With few exceptions, reference was made to work done. However, many failed to mention either that unit charge must be considered or that the charge is positive.
  2. This section of the question was done well by most candidates. It was pleasing that in the majority of scripts, the explanation given in part (iii) was more than adequate.
  3. In part (i), many candidates calculated correctly the capacitance in farads but were then unable to convert the value into µF. In (ii), a correct expression for the energy was usually given. However, many calculations involved finding the potential of the sphere, resulting in arithmetical errors. It may have been preferable to use the expression E = Q2/2C.

Answers: (c)(i) 1.7 × 10-5 µF, (ii) 0.12 J.

NO. 242题号：32711
  1. State one function of capacitors in simple circuits.
    ..............................................................................[1]
  2. A capacitor is charged to a potential difference of 15 V and then connected in series with a switch, a resistor of resistance 12 kΩ and a sensitive ammeter, as shown in Fig.5.1.

    The switch is closed and the variation with time t of the current I in the circuit is shown in Fig.5.2.

    1. State the relation between the current in a circuit and the charge that passes a point in the circuit.
      ....................................................................[1]
    2. The area below the graph line of Fig.5.2 represents charge.
      Use Fig.5.2 to determine the initial charge stored in the capacitor.

      charge = ............................................ µC [4]
    3. Initially, the potential difference across the capacitor was 15 V.
      Calculate the capacitance of the capacitor.

      capacitance = ............................................ µF [2]
  3. The capacitor in (b) discharges one half of its initial energy. Calculate the new potential difference across the capacitor.

    potential difference = ........................................V [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2007/Winter/Paper4/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a e.g. separate charges, store energy, smoothing circuit. etc.
(allow 'stores charge') 		 B1 [1]
b.i charge = current × time B1 [1]
b.ii area is 21.2 cm2  (allow ±0.5 cm2)
(allow 1 mark if outside ±0.5 cm2 but within ±1.0 cm2)
1.0 cm2 represents (0.125 × 10-3 × 1.25 =) 156 µC
charge = 3300 µC		 C2

C1
A1		 [4]
b.iii capacitance = Q/V
= (3300 × 10-6) / 15 
= 220 µF		 C1

A1		 [2]
c either energy = ½CV2 or energy = ½QV and C = Q/V
½ × C × 152 = 2 × ½ × C × V2
V = 10.6 V		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
  1. Capacitors are used to store electrical energy
    1. Charge = current × time (i.e. Q = It)
    2. One way:

      1 square (little) represents 6.25 × 10-6 C

      For a total of about 528 squares

      ∴ 528 × 6.25 × 10-6 = 3.3 × 10-3 C = 3300 μC

      There are ather ways to estimate the area
    3. Use C = Q/V = (3300 × 10-6)/15 = 2.2 × 10-4 F = 220 μF
    4. Initial energy: E = (1/2)CV2 = (1/2) × C × 152

      Final energy: E = (1/2)(1/2)C × 152 (because half has been discharged)

      ∴ (1/2)(1/2)C × 152 = (1/2)CV2 (here V means potential difference)

      ∴ V2 = 152/2

      ∴ V = 10.6 V
  1. Most candidates referred to storage of either energy or charge. 
    1. The most efficient means of answering this question was to give a word equation. A surprising number of candidates stated that 'current is proportional to charge'. 
    2. Successful candidates either counted squares or used a series of vertical strips. The conversion of the area to a charge presented few problems apart from a power-of-ten error. A significant number of candidates found the area of a single strip near to the origin on the x-axis. Presumably they thought that this initial strip would represent the initial charge stored in the capacitor. 
    3. Most answers to this part of the question were correct, when allowance was made for the candidates' answers in (ii). 
  3. Most candidates quoted a correct expression for the stored energy. However, a majority assumed that the energy would be proportional to the potential difference, ignoring the fact that the charge on the capacitor would change.
NO. 243题号：32705
    1. State what is meant by electric potential at a point.
      ................................................................. [2]
    2. Define capacitance.
      .................................................................. [1]
  2. The variation of the potential V of an isolated metal sphere with charge Q on its surface is shown in Fig. 4.1.

    An isolated metal sphere has capacitance. 
    Use Fig. 4.1 to determine
    1. the capacitance of the sphere,

      capacitance = ...................................... F [2]
    2. the electric potential energy stored on the sphere when charged to a potential of 150 kV.

      energy = ............................................. J [2]

    energy = ............................................. J [2]

A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper4_3/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a.i work done moving unit positive charge
from infinity to the point		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii charge / potential (difference)  (ratio must be clear) B1 [1]
b.i capacitance = (2.7 × 10–6) / (150 × 103)
(allow any appropriate values)
capacitance = 1.8 × 10–11   (allow 1.8 ±0.05)		 C1

A1		 [2]
b.ii either energy = ½CV2  or  energy = ½QV  and  Q = CV
energy = ½ × 1.8 × 10–11 × (150 × 103)2 or ½ × 2.7 × 10–6 × 150 × 103
   = 0.20 J		 C1

A1		 [2]
c either  since energy ∝ V2, capacitor has (½)2 of its energy left
or  full formula treatment
energy lost = 0.15 J		 C1
A1		 [2]
    1. The electric potential at a point in an electric field is defined as the work done in bringing unit positive charge from infinity to that point.
    2. Capacitance is the ratio of the electric charge (Q) to the potential difference V across a capacitor
    1. C = Q/V ⇒ from graph

      Q = 1.0 μC, V = 55 KV

      ∴ C = (1 × 10-6)/(55 × 103) = 1.82 × 10-11 F
    2. Use E, energy = (1/2)CV2

      = (1/2) × 1.8 × 10-11 × (150 × 103)2

      = 0.2025 J

      Energy = 0.20 J
  3. Energy lost = (1/2)CV2

    = (1/2) × 1.8 × 10-11 × [(150 × 103)2 - (75 × 103)2] = 0.15 J
    1. Some answers missed out key words. It is the work done in bringing a unit positive charge from infinity to the point.
    2. With few exceptions, a correct definition was given.
    1. The capacitance was usually calculated correctly. Some candidates made power-of-ten errors or thought that the capacitance was represented by the gradient of the graph.
    2. The calculation presented very few problems.
  3. The energy lost was usually calculated correctly by subtracting the final electric potential energy from the initial electric potential energy of the sphere. 
NO. 244题号：32703
  1. State two functions of capacitors in electrical circuits.
    1. ....................................................................
    2. .................................................................... [2]
  2. Three uncharged capacitors of capacitance C1, C2 and C3 are connected in series, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

    A charge of +Q is put on plate A of the capacitor of capacitance C1.
    1. State and explain the charges that will be observed on the other plates of the capacitors.
      You may draw on Fig. 4.1 if you wish.
      .............................................................. [2]
    2. Use your answer in (i) to derive an expression for the combined capacitance of the capacitors. [2]

  3. A capacitor of capacitance 12 μF is charged using a battery of e.m.f. 9.0 V, as shown in Fig. 4.2.

    Switch S1 is closed and switch S2 is open.
    1. The capacitor is now disconnected from the battery by opening S1.
      Calculate the energy stored in the capacitor.

      energy = ............................................. J [2]
    2. The 12 μF capacitor is now connected to an uncharged capacitor of capacitance 20 μF by closing S2. Switch S1 remains open.
      The total energy now stored in the two capacitors is 1.82 × 10–4 J.
      Suggest why this value is different from your answer in (i).
      ............................................................... [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper4_3/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a e.g. storing energy
 separating charge
 blocking d.c.
 producing electrical oscillations
 tuning circuits
 smoothing
 preventing sparks
 timing circuits
(any two sensible suggestions, 1 each, max 2)		 B2 [2]
b.i –Q (induced) on opposite plate of C1
by charge conservation, charges are –Q, +Q, –Q, +Q, –Q		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.ii total p.d. V = V1 + V2 + V3
Q/C = Q/C1 + Q/C2 + Q/C3
1/C = 1/C1 + 1/C2 + 1/C3		 B1
B1
A0		 [2]
c.i energy = ½CV2 or energy = ½ QV and C = Q/V
  = ½ × 12 × 10–6 × 9.02
  = 4.9 × 10–4 J		 C1

A1		 [2]
c.ii energy dissipated in (resistance of) wire/as a spark B1 [1]
    1. Capacitions are used to store electrical energy
    2. Capacitors are used in smoothing circuits (as current smoothers) to rectify the output of an alternating current
      • -Q (induced) on the opposite plate of C1
      • By the conservation of charge, the charge observed on the other plates q the capacitors are shown above
    2. In series

      ∴ Total potential difference V = V1 + V2 + V3

      But C = Q/V or V = Q/C, Q here is the same

      ∴ Q/CT = (Q/C1) + (Q/C2) + (Q/C3)

      ∴ 1/CT = (1/C1) + (1/C2) + (1/C3)
    1. Use energy = (1/2)CV2

      C = 12 × 10-6, V = 9V

      ∴ Energy = (1/2) × 12 × 10-6 × 92 = 4.86 × 10-4 J

      Energy = 4.9 × 10-4 J
    2. Some energy is dissipated in the wine as the wire has a resistance.
  1. The most commonly stated function, correctly, was 'energy storage'. It should be noted that capacitors give rise to charge separation, rather than charge storage. 
    1. Many candidates referred to the signs of the charges on the other plates without stating that their magnitudes would be the same as the magnitude of the charge on plate A. Very few answers explained that these charges are observed as a consequence of induction and of charge conservation.
    2. The syllabus makes direct reference to this derivation and so, as expected, there were many correct answers. However, less able candidates sometimes omitted a key step or attempted to work backwards from the final expression. 
    1. With very few exceptions, a correct answer was given.
    2. Answers needed to be precise. Energy is dissipated in the resistance of the wires or as a spark at the switch.
NO. 245题号：32702

A sinusoidal alternating voltage supply is connected to a bridge rectifier consisting of four ideal diodes. The output of the rectifier is connected to a resistor R and a capacitor C as shown in Fig. 6.1.

The function of C is to provide some smoothing to the potential difference across R.
The variation with time t of the potential difference V across the resistor R is shown in Fig. 6.2.

  1. Use Fig. 6.2 to determine, for the alternating supply,
    1. the peak voltage,

      peak voltage = ............................................. V [1]
    2. the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) voltage,

      r.m.s. voltage = ............................................. V [1]
    3. the frequency. Show your working.

      frequency = ........................................... Hz [2] 
  2. The capacitor C has capacitance 5.0 μF.
    For a single discharge of the capacitor through the resistor R, use Fig. 6.2 to
    1. determine the change in potential difference,

      change = ............................................. V [1]
    2. determine the change in charge on each plate of the capacitor,

      change = ............................................ C [2]
    3. show that the average current in the resistor is 1.1 × 10–3 A. [2]
  3. Use Fig. 6.2 and the value of the current given in (b)(iii) to estimate the resistance of resistor R.

    resistance = ............................................. Ω [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper4_1/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i peak voltage = 4.0V A1 [1]
a.ii r.m.s. voltage (= 4.0/√2) = 2.8V A1 [1]
a.iii period T = 20 ms
frequency = 1 / (20 × 10–3)
frequency = 50Hz		 M1
M1
A0		 [2]
b.i change = 4.0 – 2.4 = 1.6V A1 [1]
b.ii ∆Q = C∆V or Q = CV
   = 5.0 × 10–6 × 1.6 = 8.0 × 10–6C		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.iii discharge time = 7ms
current = (8.0 × 10–6) / (7.0 × 10–3)
            = 1.1(4) × 10–3A		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
c average p.d. = 3.2V
resistance = 3.2 / (1.1 × 10–3)
                = 2900Ω (allow 2800Ω)		 C1

A1		 [3]
    1. Read from graph peak voltage = 4.0 V
    2. Vr.m.s. = Vp/√2 = 4/√2 = 2√2 V = 2.8 V

      r.m.s. voltage = 2.8 V
    3. Period, T = 20 ms

      Use f = 1/T = 1/(20 × 10-3) = 50 Hz

      Frequency = 50 Hz
    1. From the graph, pick out 2.4 V (from 4 to 2.4)

      ∴ 4 - 2.4 = 1.6

      Charge = 1.6 V
    2. Use Q = CV

      ∴ ∆Q = C∆V = (5 × 10-6) × 1.6 = 8 × 10-6 C
    3. Time of discharge (from graph) = 7 ms

      I = Q/t = (8 × 10-6)/(7 × 10-3) = 1.14 × 10-3 A
  3. Use V = IR

    ∴ R = V/I

    = (average potential difference)/I

    = [(4 + 2.4)/2]/(1.14 × 10-3)

    = 3.2/(1.14 × 10-3)

    = 2807.01 Ω

    Resistance = 2800 Ω
  1. Parts (i) and (ii) were well answered. In part (iii), a common error was to use a period of 10ms.
  2. Parts (i) and (ii) were usually answered successfully. The calculation in part (iii) proved to be more problematic, with few candidates using the correct discharge time of 7 ms. 
  3. Very few candidates realised that, for a single discharge, the average potential difference across the resistor is 3.2V. 
NO. 246题号：32700
  1. State two functions of capacitors connected in electrical circuits.
    1. .......................................................................
    2. ....................................................................... [2]
  2. Three capacitors are connected in parallel to a power supply as shown in Fig. 4.1.

    The capacitors have capacitances C1, C2 and C3. The power supply provides a potential difference V.
    1. Explain why the charge on the positive plate of each capacitor is different.
      ...................................................................[1]
    2. Use your answer in (i) to show that the combined capacitance C of the three capacitors is given by the expression
            C = C1 + C2 + C3. [2]

  3. A student has available three capacitors, each of capacitance 12 μF.
    Draw circuit diagrams, one in each case, to show how the student connects the three capacitors to provide a combined capacitance of
    1. 8 μF, [1]

    2. 18 μF. [1]
