A level PHYSICS 2013/Winter/Paper4_3/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a e.g. store energy (do not allow 'store charge')
 in smoothing circuits
 blocking d.c.
 in oscillators
 any sensible suggestions, one each, max. 2		 B2 [2]
b.i potential across each capacitor is the same and Q = CV B1 [1]
b.ii total charge Q = Q1 + Q2 + Q3
CV = C1V + C2V + C3V
(allow Q = CV here or in (i))
so C = C1 + C2 + C3		 M1
M1

A0		 [2]
c.i A1 [1]
c.ii A1 [1]
    1. Capacitors are used to store electrical energy
    2. Capacitors are used in smoothing circuits (as current smoothers) to rectify the output of an alternating current
      • We know Q = CV
      • Potential across each capacitor is the same (parallel connection)
      • Capacitances are different

        ∴ Charge on the positive plate of each capacitor is different.
    2. V, across each capacitor is the same total charge QT = Q1 + Q2 + Q3

      Let combined capacitance = CT

      ∴ CTV = C1V + C2V + C3V

      Cancel the V

      ∴ CT = C1 + C2 + C3


    1. Combined capacitance ⇒ [(1/12) + (1/24)]-1 = 8 μF


    2. Combined capacitance ⇒ [(1/12) + (1/12)]-1 + 12 = 18 μF
  1. The most common correctly stated functions were for smoothing in rectifier circuits and for storing energy. It should be noted that capacitors store energy by charge separation and that this should be stated rather than "storing charge". 
    1. Candidates needed to explain that the potential difference across each capacitor is the same and then give the relationship between charge and capacitance.
    2. The syllabus makes a direct reference to this derivation and so, as expected, there were many correct answers. 
  3. The vast majority of circuit diagrams were correctly drawn. A small number of candidates did not read the question carefully enough and attempted to draw diagrams incorporating more than three capacitors. 
NO. 247题号：32697

An isolated conducting sphere of radius r is placed in air. It is given a charge +Q. This charge may be assumed to act as a point charge situated at the centre of the sphere.

    1. Define electric field strength.
      ........................................................................... [1]
    2. State a formula for the electric field strength E at the surface of the sphere. Also, state the meaning of any other symbols used.
      ........................................................................... [2]
  2. The maximum field strength at the surface of the sphere before electrical breakdown (sparking) occurs is 2.0 × 106 V m–1. The sphere has a radius r of 0.35 m.
    Calculate the maximum values of
    1. the charge that can be stored on the sphere,

      charge = ………...……………… C [2]
    2. the potential at the surface of the sphere.

      potential = ………...……………… V [2]
  3. Suggest the effect of the electric field on a single atom near the sphere’s surface as electrical breakdown of the air occurs.
    ................................................................................. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Summer/Paper4/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i force per unit positive charge (ratio idea essential) B1 [1]
a.ii E = Q / 4πε0r2
ε0 being the permittivity of free space		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i 2.0 × 106 = Q / (4π × 8.85 × 10-12 × 0.352)
Q = 2.7 × 10-5 C		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii V = (2.7 × 10-5) / (4π × 8.85 × 10-12 × 0.35)
   = 7.0 × 105 V		 C1
A1		 [2]
c electrons are stripped off the atoms
electrons and positive ions move in opposite directions,
(giving rise to a current)		 B1

B1		 [2]
    1. The electric field strength at a point is the force per unit charge acting on a small positive charge placed at that point.
    2. E = Q/4πε0r2

      ε0 = permittivity of free space
    1. Use E = Q/4πε0r2

      ∴ Q = E × 4πε0r2 = 2 × 106 × 4π × 8.85 × 10-12 × 0.352 = 2.725 × 10-5 C

      Charge = 2.7 × 10-5 C
    2. V = Er = 2 × 106 × 0.35 = 7.0 × 105 V
    • Electrons are stripped off the atoms
    • Electrons and positive ions move in opposite directions giving rise to a current
    1. It was pleasing to note that a greater proportion of candidates now define field strength in terms of the ratio of force and charge, rather than the 'force on unit charge'. Candidates should be advised that, in electrostatics, the sign of the charge is important. 
    2. Generally, the formula was quoted correcting and ε0 was identified. Some candidates elected to use the expression kQ/r2. The use of this expression may not be advisable because many of these candidates either stated that k is the permittivity or, in the subsequent calculation, substituted the value of the Boltzmann constant. 
    1. Apart from arithmetical errors, there were very few problems with this calculation.
    2. There is a common misconception that the expression E = V/d may be used in such calculations, with d = r. The expression for a constant field strength in terms of potential gradient may not be used for the non uniform field at the surface of the sphere. If the expression E = Vr is used, then careful explanation is required. 
  3. There were some good explanations. However, many could do little more than mention 'ionisation'. Where a reference was made to oppositely directed forces on the nucleus and the electrons, the impression gained in many cases was that all the electrons would be stripped off the atom. 
NO. 248题号：32693
  1. Define electric potential at a point.

    ..............................................................................................................................................................................
    .............................................................................................................................................................................. [2]
  2. An α-particle is emitted from a radioactive source with kinetic energy of 4.8 MeV.
    The α-particle travels in a vacuum directly towards a gold (197 79Au) nucleus, as illustrated in Fig. 5.1.

    The α-particle and the gold nucleus may be considered to be point charges in an isolated system.
    1. Explain why, as the α-particle approaches the gold nucleus, it comes to rest.

      ..............................................................................................................................................................................
      .............................................................................................................................................................................. [2]
    2. For the closest approach of the α-particle to the gold nucleus determine
      1. their separation,





        separation = ........................................... m [3]
      2. the magnitude of the force on the α-particle.




        force = .......................................... N [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper4_1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a work done per / on unit positive charge
moving charge from infinity to the point		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i α-particle and gold nucleus repel each other
all kinetic energy of α-particle converted into electric potential energy		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.ii 1. potential energy = (79 × 2 × {1.6 × 10-19}2) / (4π × 8.85 × 10-12 × d)
kinetic energy = 4.8 × 1.6 × 10-13 = 7.68 × 10-13 J
equating to give d = 4.7 × 10-14 m		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
b.iii 2. F = Qq / 4πε0d × 1 / d = 7.68 × 10-13 × 1 / (4.7 × 10-14)
      = 16 N		 C1
A1		 [2]
    [Total: 9]
  1. The electric potential at a point in an electric field is defined as the work done in bringing unit positive charge from infinity to that point.
      • The α-particle and the gold nucleus repel each other (or there are repulsive forces between the α-particle and the gold nucleus)
      • All the K.E. of the α-particle is transformed to electric potential energy
      1. K.E. = 4.8 × 1.6 × 10-19 × 106 = 7.68 × 10-13 J

        Electric potential energy = (79 × 1.6 × 10-19 × 2 × 1.6 × 10-19)/(4π × 8.85 × 10-12r) = 3.637 × 10-26/r

        So 7.68 × 10-13 = 3.637 × 10-26/r

        ∴ r = 4.7 × 10-14

        Separation = 4.7 × 10-14 m
      2. From E = Qq/4πε0r (the electric potential energy)

        We can get the force which is Qq/4πε0r2 i.e. take E × (1/r)

        E = 7.68 × 10-13

        r = 4.7 × 10-14

        ∴ F = (7.68 × 10-13)/(4.7 × 10-14) = 16.3 N

        Force = 16 N
  1. The definition presented very few problems for the well-prepared candidate. 
    1. Candidates should be advised always to look at the mark allocated to the question. In this instance, there were two marks but the vast majority did little more than state that repulsion would occur. Candidates were expected to state that all of the kinetic energy of the α-particle would be converted to electric potential energy.
    2. 1. Most answers included a correct calculation of the kinetic energy. However, when substituting into the expression for electric potential energy for the product of the two charges, many failed to include either the 2 factor or the 79 factor, or they failed to use e2 rather than e. 
      2. In general, those who completed (ii)1 successfully were then able to determine the force.
NO. 249题号：32692
  1. Explain what is meant by the potential energy of a body.
    ...................................................................................[2] 
  2. Two deuterium ( 21H) nuclei each have initial kinetic energy EK and are initially separated by a large distance.
    The nuclei may be considered to be spheres of diameter 3.8 × 10–15 m with their masses and charges concentrated at their centres.
    The nuclei move from their initial positions to their final position of just touching, as illustrated in Fig. 4.1.

    1. For the two nuclei approaching each other, calculate the total change in
      1. gravitational potential energy,

        energy = ............................................ J [3]
      2. electric potential energy.

        energy = ............................................ J [3]
    2. Use your answers in (i) to show that the initial kinetic energy EK of each nucleus is 0.19 MeV. [2]

    3. The two nuclei may rebound from each other. Suggest one other effect that could happen to the two nuclei if the initial kinetic energy of each nucleus is greater than that calculated in (ii).
      .............................................................................[1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper4_1/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a ability to do work
as a result of the position/shape, etc. of an object		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.i 1. ∆Egpe = GMm / r
    = (6.67 × 10–11 × {2 × 1.66 × 10–27}2) / (3.8 × 10–15)
    = 1.93 × 10–49 J		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
2. ∆Eepe = Qq / 4πε0r
    = (1.6 × 10–19)2 / (4π × 8.85 × 10–12 × 3.8 × 10–15)
    = 6.06 × 10–14 J		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
b.ii idea that 2EK = ∆Eepe – ∆Egpe
EK = 3.03 × 10–14 J
= (3.03 × 10–14) / 1.6 × 10–13
= 0.19 MeV		 B1

M1
A0		 [2]
b.iii fusion may occur / may break into sub-nuclear particles B1 [1]
  1. The capacity of an object to perform work as a result of its position or shape.
      1. Charge in GPE = GMm/r (note: gravitational potential at infinity = 0)

        So plugging in ∆GPE = [(6.67 × 10-11)(2 × 1.66 × 10-27)2]/(3.8 × 10-15) = 1.9347 × 10-49 J

        Note: Pick the constants out carefully!
      2. ∆εPE = Q1Q2/4πε0r,

        here ∆εPE = (1.6 × 10-19)2/[4π(8.85 × 10-12)(3.8 × 10-15)] = 6.058 × 10-14 J
    2. Each nucleus: Initial K.E = EK

      ∴ 2EK = 6.06 × 10-14 - 1.93 × 10-49 = 6.06 × 10-14

      ∴ EK = 3.03 × 10-14 J

      Charge to eV, ÷ 1.6 × 10-19

      ⇒ 189375 eV

      = 0.189 MeV = 0.19 MeV
    3. Fusion may occur
  1. Very few candidates realised that potential energy is the ability of a body to do work as a result of its position or shape. 
    1. 1. A significant number of candidates used the expression for gravitational potential, rather than gravitational potential energy. Some of those that did use the correct expression then used the wrong value of mass or the wrong value of separation distance. 
      2. Some candidates used an expression for electric potential, rather than electric potential energy. 
    2. Despite the wording in the question, many answers did not use the gravitational potential energy from (i)1 as part of their calculation to find the kinetic energy of each nucleus. Of those that did use it, many failed to express it with the correct sign.
    3. Fusion was often identified correctly. Vague suggestions, such as 'the nuclei stick together', did not get any credit.
NO. 250题号：32453

Two point charges A and B each have a charge of + 6.4 × 10–19 C. They are separated in a vacuum by a distance of 12.0 μm, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

Points P and Q are situated on the line AB. Point P is 3.0 μm from charge A and point Q is 3.0 μm from charge B.

  1. Calculate the force of repulsion between the charges A and B.







    force = .......................................... N [3]

  2. Explain why, without any calculation, when a small test charge is moved from point P to point Q, the net work done is zero.

    ..........................................................................................................................................
    ..........................................................................................................................................
    .................................................................................................................................... [2]

  3. Calculate the work done by an electron in moving from the midpoint of line AB to point P.







    work done = ........................................... J [4]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper4_2/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a force = q1q2 / 4πε0x2
 = (6.4 × 10–19)2 / (4π × 8.85 × 10–12 × {12 × 10–6}2) 
 = 2.56 × 10–17 N		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
b potential at P is same as potential at Q
 work done = q∆V
 ∆V = 0 so zero work done 		 B1
M1
A0		 [2]
c at midpoint, potential is 2 × (6.4 × 10–19) / (4πε0 × 6 × 10–6)
at P, potential is (6.4 × 10–19) / (4πε0 × 3 × 10–6) + (6.4 × 10–19) / (4πε0 × 9 × 10–6)
change in potential = (6.4 × 10–19) / (4πε0 × 9 × 10–6)
energy = 1.6 × 10–19 × (6.4 × 10–19) / (4πε0 × 9 × 10–6)
 = 1.0 × 10–22 J		 C1
C1

C1
A1		 [4]
  1. F = q1q2/4πε0r2

    ∴ F = [(6.4 × 10-19)2]/[4π(8.85 × 10-12)(12 × 10-6)2]

    = 2.557 × 10-17 N

    Force = 2.56 × 10-17 N
  2. P and Q are at the same electric potential (Explanation: A charge at P is affected by the field of 2 charges at A and B, similarly for a charge at Q).
    Work done = q∆V, since ∆V (charge in potential) = 0, the net work done is zero.
  3. Let M be the midpoint of line AB



    ∆V = VP - VM = 6.4 × 10-4

    Work done = q∆V = 1.6 × 10-19 × 6.4 × 10-4 = 1.02 × 10-22

    Careful: VM, there is a +2e because q = 2 charges

    VP, there is also contribution from 2 charges

The majority of candidates did not score any marks in (b) or (c).

  1. The majority of candidates scored full marks. The weaker candidates tended to make arithmetic errors or use the wrong distance. In some cases Boltzmann's constant was used for k in the relationship for the force. The failure to square r was an error made by the weaker candidates even though the correct relationship for force had been given.
  2. A small number of candidates stated that P and Q were at the same potential but very few then went on to explain why the work done would be zero using W = qΔV. The common error was to consider the forces acting and then use W = Fd. 
  3. Very few candidates were able to cope with the two charges and determine the potential change between the two points. A large number did not realise that the potential at each point was the sum of the potentials for each charge. A number of candidates assumed the midpoint was at zero potential or that there was only one charge. A significant number tried to determine the work done using W = Fd or Vq. Very few were able to determine the change in potential between the two points for both charges and then determine the work done on an electron.
NO. 251题号：32439
  1. Define electric potential at a point.
    ...............................................................................[2]
  2. Two small spherical charged particles P and Q may be assumed to be point charges located at their centres. The particles are in a vacuum.
    Particle P is fixed in position. Particle Q is moved along the line joining the two charges, as illustrated in Fig. 4.1.

    The variation with separation x of the electric potential energy EP of particle Q is shown in Fig. 4.2.

    1. State how the magnitude of the electric field strength is related to potential gradient.
      ...........................................................................[1]
    2. Use your answer in (i) to show that the force on particle Q is proportional to the gradient of the curve of Fig. 4.2.
      ...........................................................................[2]
  3. The magnitude of the charge on each of the particles P and Q is 1.6 × 10–19 C. Calculate the separation of the particles at the point where particle Q has electric potential energy equal to –5.1 eV.

    separation = ............................................ m [4]
  4. By reference to Fig. 4.2, state and explain
    1. whether the two charges have the same, or opposite, sign,
      ............................................................................[2]
    2. the effect, if any, on the shape of the graph of doubling the charge on particle P.
      ............................................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper4_1/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a work done in bringing unit positive charge
from infinity (to that point)		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i field strength is potential gradient B1  
b.ii field strength proportional to force (on particle Q)
potential gradient proportional to gradient of (potential energy) graph
so force is proportional to the gradient of the graph		 B1
B1
A0		 [2]
c energy = 5.1 × 1.6 × 10–19 (J)
potential energy = Q1Q2 / 4πε0r
5.1 × 1.6 × 10–19 = (1.6 × 10–19)2 / 4π × 8.85 × 10–12 × r
r = 2.8 × 10–10m		 C1
C1
C1
A1		 [4]
d.i work is got out as x decreases
so opposite sign		 M1
A1		 [2]
d.ii energy would be doubled
gradient would be increased		 B1
B1		 [2]
  1. The electric potential at a point in an electric field is defined as the work done in bringing unit positive charge from infinity to that point.
    1. The magnitude of the electric field strength is equal to the potential gradient.
    2. Electric field strength is proportional to force on Q

      Potential gradient is proportional to the gradient of potential energy

      Therefore force is proportional to the gradient of the graph.
  3. Energy in J = 5.1 × 1.6 × 10-19 = 8.16 × 10-19 J

    Electric potential energy = Q1Q2/4πε0r

    ∴ 8.16 × 10-19 = [(1.6 × 10-19)(1.6 × 10-19)]/[4π(8.85 × 10-12)r]

    Solve, use a calculator, r = 2.82 × 10-10 m

    Separation = 2.8 × 10-10 m
    1. Opposite sign.
      As the separation x decreases, Ep (the potential energy) decreases
    2. Doubling the charge doubles the energy

      ∴ The gradient would increase
  1. Candidates needed to give a comprehensive definition. Many omitted either 'unit' or 'positive' from their description of the charge.  
    1. In most answers, the magnitude of the electric field strength was correctly stated to be equal to the potential gradient. Some candidates attempted to express this relationship as an equation. Candidates should be encouraged to explain all symbols that they use.
    2. Many candidates correctly explained that the force on particle Q is proportional to the electric field strength. It was then necessary to explain the relationship between the electric field strength and the gradient of the curve. Few candidates appreciated that the gradient of the curve was proportional to the electric potential gradient.
  3. Although there were some well-explained calculations, a common mistake was to confuse electric potential energy with electric potential. 
    1. Most answers were mere statements of the sign of the charges without any valid supportive reasoning. Candidates needed to explain how work is got out as the charge separation decreases (or vice versa) and so the charges must have opposite signs.
    2. Many candidates appreciated that doubling the charge on particle P would result in the graph having an increased gradient, although it was seldom explained that this was due to the doubling of the potential energy at a given separation. 
NO. 252题号：32404
  1. Define electric field strength.
    .......................................................................... [1]
  2. An isolated metal sphere is to be used to store charge at high potential. The charge stored may be assumed to be a point charge at the centre of the sphere. The sphere has a radius of 25 cm. Electrical breakdown (a spark) occurs in the air surrounding the sphere when the electric field strength at the surface of the sphere exceeds 1.8 × 104 V cm–1.
    1. Show that the maximum charge that can be stored on the sphere is 12.5 μC. [2]

    2. Calculate the potential of the sphere for this maximum charge.

      potential = ............................................. V [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper4_1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a force per unit positive charge acting on a stationary charge B1 [1]
b.i E = Q / 4πε0r2
Q = 1.8 × 104 × 102 × 4π × 8.85 × 10–12 × (25 × 10–2)2
Q = 1.25 × 10–5C = 12.5µC		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
b.ii V = Q / 4πε0r
   = (1.25 × 10–5) / (4π × 8.85 × 10–12 × 25 × 10–2)
   = 4.5 × 105 V
(Do not allow use of V = Er unless explained)		 C1
A1		 [2]
  1. The electric field strength at a point is the force per unit charge acting on a small positive charge placed at that point
    1. E = Q/4πε0r2

      So plugging in for E and r

      E = 1.8 × 104 × 102 V/m

      r = 25 × 10-2

      ∴ Qmax = 1.8 × 106 × 4π × 8.85 × 10-12 × (25 × 10-2)2

      = 1.25 × 10-5 C
    2. Use V = Q/4πε0r

      = (1.25 × 10-5)/[4π(8.85 × 10-12)(25 × 10-2)]

      = 4.496 × 105 V

      Potential = 4.5 × 105 V
  1. The definition of electric field strength needed to be stated precisely. It is clearly defined in the syllabus as being the force per unit positive charge acting on a stationary point charge. 
    1. A high proportion of the candidates could recall the correct expression for the electric field strength, although the ensuing calculation often contained power-of-ten errors.
    2. The vast majority of candidates correctly used the expression . However, a small minority chose to use the expression . In the general situation, field strength is not equal to the ratio of potential and radius, but rather E = ΔV/Δd. It happens to be that for an isolated point charge the expression is valid, but any candidate wishing to use that expression must clearly explain the reason for its validity.
NO. 253题号：32403
  1. State what is meant by a line of force in
    1. a gravitational field,
      .................................................................[1]
    2. an electric field.
      .................................................................[2]
  2. A charged metal sphere is isolated in space.
    State one similarity and one difference between the gravitational force field and the electric force field around the sphere.
    similarity: ..........................................................
    difference: ........................................................ [3]
  3. Two horizontal metal plates are separated by a distance of 1.8 cm in a vacuum.
    A potential difference of 270 V is maintained between the plates, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

    A proton is in the space between the plates.
    Explain quantitatively why, when predicting the motion of the proton between the plates, the gravitational field is not taken into consideration. [4]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper4_3/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a.i (tangent to line gives) direction of force on a (small test) mass B1 [1]
a.ii (tangent to line gives) direction of force on a (small test) charge
charge is positive		 M1
A1		 [2]
b similarity:
e.g. radial fields
lines normal to surface
greater separation of lines with increased distance from sphere
field strength ∝ 1 / (distance to centre of sphere)2
(allow any sensible answer)		 B1 [3]
difference:
e.g. gravitational force (always) towards sphere
electric force direction depends on sign of charge on sphere / towards or
away from sphere
B1

B1
e.g. gravitational field/force is attractive
electric field/force is attractive or repulsive
(allow any sensible comparison)		 (B1)
(B1)
c gravitational force = 1.67 × 10–27 × 9.81
  = 1.6 × 10–26N
electric force = 1.6 × 10–19 × 270 / (1.8 × 10–2)
  = 2.4 × 10–15N
electric force very much greater than gravitational force
A1
C1
A1
B1		 [4]
    1. A line of force (or the tangent to it) in a gravitational field gives the direction of the force on a small test mass placed in the field
    2. It is an imaginary continuous line or curve drawn in an electric field such that the tangent to it at any point gives the direction of the force due to the field on a small positive test charge.
  2. Similarity: The field strength is inversely proportional to the square of the distance to the centre of the sphere.

    Difference: The gravitational force is attractive

    The electric force can be attractive or repulsive
  3. Note: quantitatively

    ∴ Use numbers

    Electric force = EQ = (V/d) · Q

    = [270/(1.8 × 10-2) × 1.6 × 10-19

    = 2.4 × 10-15 N

    Gravitational force = mg = 1.67 × 10-27 × 9.81 = 1.64 × 10-26 N

    Since the electric force is very much greater than the gravitational force

    ∴ We do not take the gravitational field into consideration
  1. Many candidates did not read the question carefully and therefore stated what was meant by a gravitational field and an electric field, rather than a line of force in these two fields. 
  2. The most commonly stated similarity was that both fields are radial. Many other similarities were stated with insufficient precision for the award of credit. Candidates were more successful in stating a difference between the fields. The most commonly stated difference was that gravitational force always acts towards the sphere whereas electric force can act towards or away from it, depending upon on the sign of the charge on the sphere. 
  3. The motion of the proton between the plates is dictated by the relative sizes of the gravitational force and the electric force. It was expected that candidates would calculate the magnitudes of these two forces and show that the electric force is much greater than the gravitational force. A common error was to compare directly the magnitudes of the gravitational field strength and the electric field strength. Candidates sometimes provided only a qualitative explanation, even though the question asked for a quantitative one. 
NO. 254题号：32401
  1. Define electric potential at a point.
    ..............................................................................[2]
  2. A charged particle is accelerated from rest in a vacuum through a potential difference V.
    Show that the final speed v of the particle is given by the expression
             
    where is the ratio of the charge to the mass (the specific charge) of the particle. [2]

  3. A particle with specific charge +9.58 × 107 C kg–1 is moving in a vacuum towards a fixed metal sphere, as illustrated in Fig. 4.1.

    The initial speed of the particle is 2.5 × 105 m s–1 when it is a long distance from the sphere.
    The sphere is positively charged and has a potential of +470 V.
    Use the expression in (b) to determine whether the particle will reach the surface of the sphere. [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper4_1/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a work done moving unit positive charge
from infinity (to the point)		 M1
A1		 [2]
b (gain in) kinetic energy = change in potential energy
½mv2 = qV leading to v = (2Vq/m)½		 B1
B1		 [2]
c either (2.5 × 105)2 = 2 × V × 9.58 × 107
          V = 330V
          this is less than 470V and so 'no'		 C1
M1
A1		 [3]
or v = (2 × 470 × 9.58 × 107)
    v = 3.0 × 105 ms–1
    this is greater than 2.5 × 105 ms–1 and so 'no'		 (C1)
(M1)
(A1)		  
or (2.5 × 105)2 = 2 × 470 × (q/m)
    (q/m) = 6.6 × 107C kg–1
    this is less than 9.58 × 107C kg–1 and so 'no'		 (C1)
(M1)
(A1)		  
  1. The electric potential at a point in an electric field is defined as the work done in bringing unit positive charge from infinity to that point.
  2. Gain in KE = (1/2)mv2

    Work done = QV = qV

    Careful about speed(v) and potential difference V

    ∴ (1/2)mv2 = qV

    ∴ v2 = 2qV/m

    ∴ v = √(2qV/m)
  3. Use v = √(2qV/m)

    = √(2 × 470 × 9.58 × 107)

    = 3 × 105 m/s > 2.5 × 105 m/s

    ∴ No, will not reach the surface of the sphere
  1. This part of the question presented few problems for the well-prepared candidate. Reference must be made to a "unit positive charge" in the stated definition.
  2. Candidates should always explain any algebraic expressions that are used in a derivation. In this case they needed to explain that the kinetic energy of the charged particle is equal to its loss of potential energy. 
  3. Most candidates used the expression given in (b) to calculate either the particle's speed or the electric potential of the sphere for the condition that the particle just reaches the surface of the sphere. They could then compare the calculated value of their chosen quantity with its actual value stated in the question. The most common approach was to calculate the particle's speed, although this was often wrongly interpreted as being its speed at the surface of the sphere. 
NO. 255题号：32384

An α-particle and a proton are at rest a distance 20 µm apart in a vacuum, as illustrated in Fig.4.1.

    1. State Coulomb's law.
      ................................................................[2]
    2. The α-particle and the proton may be considered to be point charges.
      Calculate the electric force between the α-particle and the proton.

      force = ............................................. N [2]
    1. Define electric field strength.
      ................................................................[2]
    2. A point P is distance x from the α-particle along the line joining the α-particle to the proton (see Fig.4.1). The variation with distance x of the electric field strength Eα. due to the α-particle alone is shown in Fig.4.2.

      The variation with distance x of the electric field strength Ep due to the proton alone is also shown in Fig.4.2.
      1. Explain why the two separate electric fields have opposite signs.
        ................................................................[2]
      2. On Fig.4.2, sketch the variation with x of the combined electric field due to the α-particle and the proton for values of x from 4 µm to 16 µm. [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Winter/Paper4_1/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a.i force proportional to product of (two) charges and inversely proportional to square of separation
reference to point charges		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii F = 2 × (1.6 × 10–19)2 / {4π × 8.85 × 10–12 × (20 × 10–6)2}
  = 1.15 × 10–18 N		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.i force per unit charge
on either a stationary charge
or a positive charge		 M1

A1		 [2]
b.ii 1. electric field is a vector quantity
 electric fields are in opposite directions
 charges repel
 Any two of the above, 1 each		 B2 [2]
2. graph: line always between given lines
 crosses x-axis between 11.0 µm and 12.3 µm
 reasonable shape for curve		 M1
A1
A1		 [3]
    1. The magnitude of the electric force between 2 point charges is directly proportional to the product of the 2 charges and inversely proportional to the square of their distance apart
    2. The α-particle is helium nucleus (+ 2e)

      F = Q1Q2/4πε0r2

      Here Q1 = 2 × 1.6 × 10-19; Q2 = 1.6 × 10-19

      ∴ F = (2 × 1.6 × 10-19 × 1.6 × 10-19)/[4π(8.85 × 10-12)(20 × 10-6)]2 = 1.151 × 10-18 N

      Force = 1.15 × 10-18 N
    1. The electric field strength at a point is the force per unit charge acting on a small positive charge placed at that point
      1. Electric fields are vector quantities and the electric fields are in opposite directions
      2. Note: Eα + EP

        will be < Eα, > EP since EP is negative

        Cross the x-axis at about 11.2 μm
    1. Candidates should be reminded that the law applies to point charges. 
    2. Most candidates did give a correct expression for the force. A common mistake was to write the product of the charges as either 2e or e2. 
    1. The majority did make a clear reference to the ratio, and many included positive charge. Very few mentioned that the charge should be stationary.
    2. 1. The most straightforward explanation is based on the fact that electric field is a vector quantity and that the two charges would repel one another. In some scripts, the difference in sign was incorrectly attributed to either the proton or the α-particle having a negative charge.
      2. There were some sketches that had been drawn with care. Many others realised that the line would lie between the given lines but they either did not realise, or did not draw with sufficient care, where the line should be.
NO. 256题号：32358

An isolated solid metal sphere of radius r is given a positive charge. The distance from the centre of the sphere is x.

  1. The electric potential at the surface of the sphere is V0.
    On the axes of Fig.5.1, sketch a graph to show the variation with distance x of the electric potential due to the charged sphere, for values of x from x = 0 to x = 4r.  [3]
  2. The electric field strength at the surface of the sphere is E0.
    On the axes of Fig.5.2, sketch a graph to show the variation with distance x of the electric field strength due to the charged sphere, for values of x from x = 0 to x = 4r. [3]

A level PHYSICS 2014/Summer/Paper4_1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a graph: straight line at constant potential = V0 from x = 0 to x = r
  curve with decreasing gradient
  passing through (2r, 0.50V0) and (4r, 0.25V0)		 B1
M1
A1		 [3]
b graph: straight line at E = 0 from x = 0 to x = r
  curve with decreasing gradient from (r, E0)
  passing through (2r, ¼E0)
(for 3rd mark line must be drawn to x = 4r and must not touch x-axis)		 B1
M1
A1

 [3]


  1. Curve passes through (2r, v0/2) and (4r, v0/4)

    Horizontal from x = 0 to x = r at v0


  2. Horizontal from x = 0 to x = r at E = 0

    Curve passes through (r, E0) and (2r, E0/4)

The standard of the graphs varied widely. Many candidates drew nothing from x = 0 to x = r, even though the question explicitly asked them to do so. The decrease in the field strength and in the potential outside of the sphere was reasonably well understood. Candidates were required to draw precise curves. Scales were given on both axes and so the curves needed to be drawn carefully through the appropriate points. 

NO. 257题号：32348
  1. Define electric potential at a point.
    ..................................................................................[2]
  2. Two positively charged metal spheres A and B are situated in a vacuum, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

    A point P lies on the line joining the centres of the two spheres and is a distance x from the surface of sphere A.
    The variation with x of the electric potential V due to the two charged spheres is shown in Fig. 5.2.

    1. State how the magnitude of the electric field strength at any point P may be determined from the graph of Fig. 5.2.
      ..............................................................................[1]
    2. Without any calculation, describe the force acting on a positively charged particle placed at point P for values of x from x = 0 to x = 10 cm.
      ..............................................................................[3]
  3. The positively charged particle in (b)(ii) has charge q and mass m given by the expression
         q/m = 4.8 × 107 C/kg–1.
    Initially, the particle is at rest on the surface of sphere A where x = 0. It then moves freely along the line joining the centres of the spheres until it reaches the surface of sphere B.
    1. On Fig. 5.2, mark with the letter M the point where the charged particle has its maximum speed. [1]

      1. Use Fig. 5.2 to determine the potential difference between the spheres.

        potential difference = ................................. V [1]
      2. Use your answer in (ii) part 1 to calculate the speed of the particle as it reaches the surface of sphere B.
        Explain your working.

        speed = ................................................. m s–1 [3]

A level PHYSICS 2015/Summer/Paper4_2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a work done bringing/moving per unit positive charge
from infinity (to the point)		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i slope/gradient (of the line/graph/tangent)
(allow dV/ dx, but not ∆V/∆x or V/ x)
(allow potential gradient)
(negative sign not required)		 B1



 [1]
b.ii maximum at surface of sphere A or at x = 0(cm)
zero at x = 6(cm) 
then increases but in opposite direction
(any mention of attraction max. 2/3) 		 B1
B1
B1

 [3]
c.i M shown between x = 5.5cm and x = 6.5cm B1 [1]
c.ii 1. ∆V = (570 – 230) = 340V (allow 330V to 340V) A1 [1]
2. q(∆)V = ½mv2 or change/loss in PE = change/gain in KE or ∆EK = ∆EP
    4.8 × 107 × 340 = ½v2
    v2 = 3.26 × 1010
    v = 1.8 × 105 ms–1 (not 1 s.f.)		 B1
C1

A1		 [3]
  1. The electric potential at a point in an electric field is defined as the work done in bringing unit positive charge from infinity to that point.
    1. The magnitude of the electric field strength at P is given by the gradient of the graph at that point.
    2. At x = 0 (surface of sphere A), the force is maximum

      At x = 6, it is zero

      x > 6, the force increases but in a opposite direction
      1. From graph the end points.

        570 - 230 = 340 V
      2. Work done (QV) → Gain in KE [(1/2)mv2]

        So q∆v = (1/2)mv2

        v2 = 2 × (q/m)∆v

        = 2(4.8 × 107) × 340

        ∴ v = √v2 = 180665.4 = 1.8 × 105 m/s

        Speed = 1.8 × 105 m/s
  1. Many answers were incomplete as they did not specify unit positive charge being moved from infinity.
    1. In general, this question was answered correctly in terms of the gradient of the line. Candidates should be advised that the expression E = V/x is applicable only to uniform fields (and in this case V and x are not the co-ordinates of a point).
    2. Many answers lacked sufficient detail, and contained only statements that the force decreases and then increases. It was expected that reference would be made to maximum force at x = 0, reducing to zero force at x = 6 cm and then increasing, but in the opposite direction. Some candidates stated that force would be proportional to the potential at a point. 
    1. This question was generally answered correctly. 
    2. 1. There were very few incorrect readings. 
      2. This question asked for an explanation. As a minimum, a recognisable equation indicating the energy changes and with standard symbols was expected. There were many correct solutions, but a significant number of these did not have an explanation. There was some confusion as to the use of specific charge, usually amongst those candidates who had not provided an initial equation as explanation. 
NO. 258题号：32335

A piston moves vertically up and down in a cylinder, as illustrated in Fig. 4.1.



The piston is connected to a wheel by means of a rod that is pivoted at the piston and at the wheel. As the piston moves up and down, the wheel is made to rotate.

    1. State the number of oscillations made by the piston during one complete rotation of the wheel.

      number = ………………………. [1]
    2. The wheel makes 2400 revolutions per minute. Determine the frequency of oscillation of the piston.

      frequency = ………………………. Hz [1]
  2. The amplitude of the oscillations of the piston is 42 mm.
    Assuming that these oscillations are simple harmonic, calculate the maximum values for the piston of
    1. the linear speed,

      speed = …………………………. m s–1 [2]
    2. the acceleration.

      acceleration = …………………………. m s–2 [2]
  3. On Fig. 4.1, mark a position of the pivot P for the piston to have
    1. maximum speed (mark this position S), [1]
    2. maximum acceleration (mark this position A). [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Summer/Paper4/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a.i 1.0 B1 [1]
a.ii 40 Hz B1 [1]
b.i speed = 2πfa
          = 2π × 40 × 42 × 10-3
          = 10.6 m s-1		 C1

A1		 [2]
b.ii acceleration = 4π2f2 a
     = (80π)2 × 42 × 10-3
     = 2650 m s-2		 C1

A1		 [2]
c.i S marked correctly (on 'horizontal line through centre of wheel) B1 [2]
c.ii A marked correctly (on 'vertical line' through centre of wheel) B1
    1. Number = 1.0 (from the graph)
    2. 2400 revolutions in 60 s

      ∴ 2400/60 = 40 rev/s

      ∴ Frequency = 40 Hz
    1. V = ωx0 = 2πfx0

      = 2π(40)(42 × 10-3)

      = 10.555 m/s

      Speed = 10.6 m/s
    2. |amax| = ω2x0

      = (2πf)2x0

      = 4π2f2x0

      = 4π2(40)2(42 × 10-3)

      = 2652.95 m/s2

      Acceleration = 2650 m/s2
    1. Most candidates did realise that one oscillation would be required.
    2. There were many correct answers. However, it was quite common to find that either the period or the angular frequency were calculated.
    1. It was pleasing to note that many candidates could quote a correct expression for the speed. A common error was to fail to use the amplitude in metres or to make an incorrect conversion of mm to m. A disturbing number of weak candidates attempted to use the formula v = fλ, with λ being made equal to the amplitude. 
    2. As in (i), many could give a correct expression and, having made allowance for 'error-carriedforward', arrived at a satisfactory conclusion.
  3. It was unfortunate that many did not read the question carefully. Instead of marking positions of the pivot P on the wheel, they attempted to mark positions of the piston in the cylinder.
NO. 259题号：32329

A spring is hung from a fixed point. A mass of 130 g is hung from the free end of the spring, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

The mass is pulled downwards from its equilibrium position through a small distance d and is released. The mass undergoes simple harmonic motion.
Fig.3.2 shows the variation with displacement x from the equilibrium position of the kinetic energy of the mass.

  1. Use Fig.3.2 to
    1. determine the distance d through which the mass was displaced initially,

      d = ............................................ cm [1] 
    2. show that the frequency of oscillation of the mass is approximately 4.0 Hz. [6]

    1. On Fig.3.2, draw a line to represent the total energy of the oscillating mass. [1]

    2. After many oscillations, damping reduces the total energy of the mass to 1.0 mJ.
      For the oscillations with reduced energy,
      1. state the frequency,

         frequency = .............................................Hz
      2. using the graph, or otherwise, state the amplitude.

         amplitude = ............................................ cm [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2007/Winter/Paper4/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a.i 0.8 cm B1 [1]
a.ii (max.) kinetic energy = 2.56 mJ
v(MAX) = ωa
(max.) kinetic energy = ½mω2a2 or ½mω2 (a2 – x2)
2.56 × 10-3 = ½ × 0.130 × ω2 × (0.8 × 10-2)2
ω = 24.8 rad s-1
f = ω/2π
= 4.0 Hz (3.95 Hz)		 C1
C1
C1
M1
C1
M1
A0		 [6]
b.i line parallel to x-axis at 2.56 mJ B1 [1]
b.ii 1. 4.0 Hz  B1 [2]
2. 0.50 cm  (allow ±0.03 cm) B1
    1. d = 0.8 cm (from the graph, read off 0.8)
    2. From graph, KEmax = 2.56 mJ (read off graph)

      KEmax = (1/2)mω2x02

      m = 0.13 kg

      x0 = 0.8 cm = 8 × 10-3 m

      ∴ 2.56 × 10-3 = (1/2)(0.13)ω2(8 × 10-3)2

      ∴ ω = 24.807 rad/s

      ∴ Using ω = 2πf

      ∴ f = ω/2π = 24.807/2π = 3.95 Hz ≈ 4Hz
      1. The frequency unchanged

        Frequency = 4Hz
      2. E ∝ amP2

        E1/E2 = amP12/amP22

        2.56/1.0 = 0.82/amP22

        ∴ amP22 = 0.25

        ∴ amP2 = √0.25 = 0.5 cm
    1. With very few exceptions, the correct value of d was quoted. 
    2. Most candidates knew how to approach this calculation and there was a pleasing number of correct answers. Common errors were associated with reading the graph for the maximum kinetic energy and with powers-of-ten.
    1. Nearly all candidates gave the impression that they knew where to draw the line but accuracy left much to be desired in many scripts. A ruler should be used when attempting to draw a straight line. 
    2. Many candidates who attempted this part of the question did state a frequency of 4 Hz. However, a fractional reduction in frequency equal to the fractional reduction in total energy was a common misconception. 
      Candidates did not appear to realise that the graph would have the same basic shape, regardless of total energy. Thus, reading the value of x at (2.56 – 1.00) mJ would give the amplitude for a total energy of 1.00 mJ. 
NO. 260题号：32265

The needle of a sewing machine is made to oscillate vertically through a total distance of 22 mm, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

The oscillations are simple harmonic with a frequency of 4.5 Hz.
The cloth that is being sewn is positioned 8.0 mm below the point of the needle when the needle is at its maximum height.

  1. State what is meant by simple harmonic motion.
    ...................................................................................[2]
  2. The displacement y of the point of the needle may be represented by the equation 
                    y = a cosωt.
    1. Suggest the position of the point of the needle at time t = 0.
      ...........................................................................[1]
    2. Determine the values of
      1. a,

        a = .......................................... mm [1]
      2. ω.

        ω = ..................................... rad s–1 [2]
  3. Calculate, for the point of the needle,
    1. its maximum speed,

      speed = ........................................ m s–1 [2]
    2. its speed as it moves downwards through the cloth.

      speed = ........................................ m s–1 [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2008/Winter/Paper4/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a acceleration / force (directly) proportional to displacement
and either directed towards fixed point
       or acceleration & displacement in opposite directions		 M1

A1		 [2]
b.i maximum / minimum height / 8mm above cloth / 14mm below cloth B1 [1]
b.ii 1. a = 11 mm A1 [1]
2. ω = 2πf
        = 2π × 4.5
        = 28.3 rad s–1  (do not allow 1 s.f.)		 C1

A1		 [2]
c.i v = ωa
   = 28.3 × 11 × 10–3
   = 0.31 m s–1  (do not allow 1 s.f.)		 C1

A1		 [2]
c.ii v = ω√(a2 – y2)
y = 3mm
   = 28.3 × 10–3 √(112 – 32)
   = 0.30 m s–1  (allow 1 s.f.)
C1
C1
A1		 [3]
  1. SHM is the motion of an object in which the acceleration of the object is directly proportional to its displacement from a fixed point and is always directed towards that point
    1. 8 mm above cloth
      1. 22 = total distance

        ∴ a = 22/2 = 11 mm
      2. ω = 2πf = 2π(4.5) = 28.27 rad/s

        ω = 28.3 rad/s
    1. V = ωx0 or ωa

      = (28.3)(11 × 10-3)

      = 0.31 m/s
    2. V = ω√(x02 - x2)

      ω = 28.3

      x0 = 11 × 10-3 m

      x = 11 - 8 = 3 mm = 3 × 10-3 m

      ∴ V = 28.3 × √[(11 × 10-3)2 - (3 × 10-3)2] = 0.299 m/s

      Speed = 0.3 m/s
  1. The majority of candidates could give an adequate explanation. Some did, however, refer to 'distance', rather than 'displacement'. Candidates should be advised that if a defining equation is quoted, then all of the symbols in the equation must be clearly identified. 
    1. Incorrect answers were partly due to insufficient detail being given. For example, specifying a distance from the cloth does not indicate whether the point is above or below the cloth.
    2. Surprisingly, many could not quote the amplitude. A common incorrect answer was 22 mm. The calculation of ω was completed successfully in most scripts.
    1. This calculation was completed successfully by most candidates, using the candidates’ values for the amplitude as stated in (b)(ii).
    2. Although most answers did include a quote of the correct expression for the calculation of the speed, there was much confusion as to what to substitute for the values of the amplitude and the displacement. 
NO. 261题号：32241

The variation with time t of the displacement x of the cone of a loudspeaker is shown in Fig. 4.1.

  1. Use Fig. 4.1 to determine, for these oscillations,
    1. the amplitude,

      amplitude = ........................................ mm [1]
    2. the frequency.

      frequency = .......................................... Hz [2]
  2. State two times at which
    1. the speed of the cone is maximum,

      time .......................... ms and time .......................... ms [1]
    2. the acceleration of the cone is maximum.

      time .......................... ms and time .......................... ms [1]
  3. The effective mass of the cone is 2.5 g.
    Use your answers in (a) to determine the maximum kinetic energy of the cone.

    kinetic energy = ...................................... J [3]
  4. The loudspeaker must be designed so that resonance of the cone is avoided.
    1. State what is meant by resonance.
      .................................................................... [2]
    2. State and briefly explain one other situation in which resonance should be avoided.
      .................................................................... [2]

A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper4_1/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a.i amplitude = 0.2 mm A1 [1]
a.ii period = 1.2 ms
frequency = 830 Hz		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.i any two of zero, 0.6 ms and 1.2 ms A1 [1]
b.ii any two of 0.3 ms, 0.9 ms, 1.5 ms A1 [1]
c either  v = ωx0 = 2πfx0
             = 2π × 830 × 0.2 × 10-3 = 1.05 m s-1
or  slope of graph = 1.0 m s-1 ……(allow ± 0.1 m s-1)
EK = ½mv2 
     = ½ × 2.5 × 10-3 × 1.052
     = 1.4 × 10-3 J 


C1

C1
A1		 [3]
d.i large / maximum amplitude of vibration
when impressed frequency equals natural frequency of vibration		 B1
B1		 [2]
d.ii e.g. metal panels on machinery vibrate / oscillat
  motor in machine impresses frequency on panel
e.g. car suspension system vibrates / oscillates
  going over bumps would give large amplitude vibrations
any feasible example, M1 + A1 		 (M1)
(A1)
(M1)
(A1)

 [2]
    [Total: 12]
    1. Amplitude = 0.2 mm (from graph)
    2. f = 1/T

      T = 1.2 ms

      ∴ f = 1/(1.2 × 10-3) = 833.33 Hz

      from graph you can get the period

      Frequency = 830 Hz
    1. The speed of the cone is maximum ⇒ displacement = 0

      Time  0 ms and time  0.6 ms
    2. The accleration of the cone is maximum ⇒ displacement is maximum

      Time  0.3 ms and time 0.9 ms
  3. Maximum KE = (1/2)mω2x02, f = 830 Hz

    m = 2.5/1000

    ω = 2πf = 5215

    x0 = 0.2 × 10-3

    ∴Maximum KE = (1/2)(2.5/1000)(5215)2(0.2 × 10-3)2 = 1.36 × 10-3 J
    1. Resonance occurs when the frequency of the external periodic force that is driving the oscillation is equal to the natural frequency of the oscillator that is being driven into oscillations. When resonance occurs, the amplitude of the resulting oscillations is maximum.
    2. Metal panels on machinery oscillate
      The motor in the machine impresses frequency on the metal panel
      The metal panels can experience resonance and vibrate with maximum amplitude
  1. As expected, these relatively easy questions were completed successfully by most candidates.
  2. Higher-scoring candidates gave correct times. However, many others incorrectly stated times for maximum speed as being at maximum displacement. 
  3. A small number of answers were based, correctly, on the gradient of the line at 0.60 s in Fig. 4.1. Most candidates used equations of simple harmonic motion. The most common error associated with a correct statement of equations was regarding powers-of-ten. 
    1. In general, statements were adequate. 
    2. Most candidates could quote an example. However, many failed to state what would cause the vibrations and that it is vibration which causes the problem. An answer such as 'soldiers must break step when they cross a bridge to avoid it collapsing' does not explain the effect of resonance.
NO. 262题号：32239
  1. State what is meant by
    1. oscillations,

      ...............................................................................................................................................[1]
    2. free oscillations,

      ...............................................................................................................................................[1]
    3. simple harmonic motion.

      ...............................................................................................................................................
      ...............................................................................................................................................
      ...............................................................................................................................................[2]
  2. Two inclined planes RA and LA each have the same constant gradient. They meet at their lower edges, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

    A small ball moves from rest down plane RA and then rises up plane LA. It then moves down plane LA and rises up plane RA to its original height. The motion repeats itself.
    State and explain whether the motion of the ball is simple harmonic.

    ...............................................................................................................................................
    ...............................................................................................................................................
    ...............................................................................................................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper4_1/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a.i to-and-fro / backward and forward motion (between two limits) B1 [1]
a.ii no energy loss or gain / no external force acting / constant energy / constant amplitude B1 [1]
a.iii acceleration directed towards a fixed point
acceleration proportional to distance from the fixed point / displacement		 B1
B1		 [2]
b acceleration is constant (magnitude) 
so cannot be s.h.m.		 M1
A1		 [2]
    1. An oscillation is a to-and-fro motion along a fixed path
    2. In a free oscillation, there is no external force acting on the oscillating system
    3. Motion in which the acceleration of the object is directly proportional to its displacement from a fixed point and is always directed towards that point.
  2. No. It is not simple harmonic

    The magnitude of the acceleration is constant

    Note:

    1. It was generally understood that oscillations represent to-and-fro motion between two limits.
    2. Most candidates knew that free oscillations have no external force acting and so there is no energy loss or gain. 
    3. The majority of candidates gave an adequate explanation. Some did, however, refer to 'distance' rather than 'displacement'. Candidates should be advised that if a defining equation is quoted, then all of the symbols in the equation must be clearly identified. 
  2. Most candidates assumed, quite wrongly, that it was simple harmonic motion because the acceleration always acts towards a fixed point. However, the motion was not simple harmonic because the acceleration of the ball had a constant magnitude.
NO. 263题号：32235
  1. Define simple harmonic motion.

    ..........................................................................................................................................

    ......................................................................................................................................[2]

  2. A tube, sealed at one end, has a total mass m and a uniform area of cross-section A. The tube floats upright in a liquid of density ρ with length L submerged, as shown in Fig. 3.1a.

    The tube is displaced vertically and then released. The tube oscillates vertically in the liquid.
    At one time, the displacement is x, as shown in Fig. 3.1b.

    Theory shows that the acceleration a of the tube is given by the expression






    1. Explain how it can be deduced from the expression that the tube is moving with simple harmonic motion.

      ..................................................................................................................................
      ..................................................................................................................................
      ..............................................................................................................................[2]

    2. The tube, of area of cross-section 4.5 cm2, is floating in water of density 1.0 × 103 kg m–3.
      Calculate the mass of the tube that would give rise to oscillations of frequency 1.5 Hz.






      mass = ............................................. g [4]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper4_1/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a acceleration / force proportional to displacement from a fixed point
acceleration / force (always) directed towards that fixed point / in opposite direction to displacement 		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i Aρg / m is a constant and so acceleration proportional to x
negative sign shows acceleration towards a fixed point / in opposite direction to displacement		 B1

B1		 [2]
b.ii ω2 = (Aρg / m)
ω = 2πf
(2 × π × 1.5)2 = ({4.5 × 10–4 × 1.0 × 103 × 9.81} / m) 
m = 50g		 C1
C1
C1
A1		 [4]
  1. SHM is the motion of an object in which the acceleration of the object is directly proportional to the displacement from a fixed point and is always directed towards that point.
    1. A, ρ, g and m are constante

      ∴ acceleration is directly proportional to x, the displacement

      The negative sign shows that acceleration is in opposite direction to displacement
    2. ω2 = Aρg/m

      ∴ m = Aρg/ω2 = Aρg/[2π(1.5)]2

      = [(4.5 × 10-4)(1 × 103)(9.81)]/[(2π(1.5)]2

      = 0.0497 kg

      = 49.7 g

      Mass = 50 g
  1. It is important that definitions are stated precisely in order to avoid ambiguity. Reference should be made to 'displacement' rather than 'distance'. 
    1. Many candidates realised that Aρg/m is a constant and so the acceleration must be proportional to the displacement. The significance of the minus sign was less well understood. This shows that the acceleration acts in the opposite direction to the displacement and is always towards a fixed point. 
    2. This part of the question was generally well answered. A common error was not converting the area of cross-section from units of cm2 to m2.
NO. 264题号：32234

A bar magnet is suspended vertically from the free end of a helical spring, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

One pole of the magnet is situated in a coil. The coil is connected in series with a high resistance voltmeter.
The magnet is displaced vertically and then released.
The variation with time t of the reading V of the voltmeter is shown in Fig. 5.2.

    1. State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction.
      ........................................................................ [2]
    2. Use Faraday's law to explain why
      1. there is a reading on the voltmeter,
        .................................................................. [1]
      2. this reading varies in magnitude,
        .................................................................. [1]
      3. the reading has both positive and negative values.
        .................................................................. [1]
  2. Use Fig. 5.2 to determine the frequency f0 of the oscillations of the magnet.

    f0 = .......................................... Hz [2]
  3. The magnet is now brought to rest and the voltmeter is replaced by a variable frequency alternating current supply that produces a constant r.m.s. current in the coil.
    The frequency of the supply is gradually increased from 0.7 f0 to 1.3 f0, where f0 is the frequency calculated in (b).
    On the axes of Fig. 5.3, sketch a graph to show the variation with frequency f of the amplitude A of the new oscillations of the bar magnet.
    1. Name the phenomenon illustrated on your completed graph of Fig.5.3.
      .................................................................... [1]
    2. State one situation where the phenomenon named in (i) is useful.
      .................................................................... [1]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper4_2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i (induced) e.m.f. proportional to
rate of change of (magnetic) flux (linkage) / rate of flux cutting		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii 1. moving magnet causes change of flux linkage B1 [1]
2. speed of magnet varies so varying rate of change of flux B1 [1]
3. magnet changes direction of motion (so current changes direction) B1 [1]
b period = 0.75s
frequency = 1.33Hz		 C1
C1		 [2]
c graph: smooth correctly shaped curve with peak at f0
         A never zero		 M1
A1		 [2]
d.i resonance B1 [1]
d.ii e.g. quartz crystal for timing / production of ultrasound A1 [1]
    1. Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction states that the induced e.m.f. is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux linked to the coil.
      1. The motion of the magnet causes a change of flux linkage.
      2. The speed of the magnet varies

        ∴ there is a varying rate of change of flux
      3. The magnet changes direction of motion

        ∴ the current also changes direction
  2. T, period = 0.75 s (from graph)

    ∴ f = 1/T = 1/0.75 = 1.33 Hz
    1. Resonance
    2. The turning circuit of a radio (resonates with incoming radio wave)
    1. Most statements were satisfactory.
    2. It was expected that, in each part, reference would be made to the nature of the motion of the magnet and how this affects the rate of change of flux linkage. There were many good answers but a significant minority described only either the motion of the magnet or the rate of change of flux. 
  2. Completed successfully by nearly all candidates. The use of vulgar fractions in answers should be discouraged.  
  3. Most sketches did indicate a peak in the correct position but the shape of the curve frequently lacked realism. Candidates should be advised to take more care as regards the shape of sketch curves, even to the extent of stressing that such curves are smooth. 
  4. The shape of the curve was identified with resonance. Although many clear examples of resonance were provided, the mere statement of 'child on a swing' was not accepted. This was too vague in that resonance is not always invoked. Candidates should be aware of the fact that the damping system on a car is not an example of resonance. 
NO. 265题号：32231

A ball of mass 37 g is held between two fixed points A and B by two stretched helical springs, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

The ball oscillates along the line AS with simple harmonic motion of frequency 3.5 Hz and amplitude 2.8 cm.

  1. Show that the total energy of the oscillations is 7.0 mJ. 



    [2]

  2. At two points in the oscillation of the ball, its kinetic energy is equal to the potential energy stored in the springs.
    Calculate the magnitude of the displacement at which this occurs.




    displacement = ............................................ cm [3]

  3. On the axes of Fig. 2.2 and using your answers in (a) and (b), sketch a graph to show the variation with displacement x of
    1. the total energy of the system (label this line T), [1]


    2. the kinetic energy of the ball (label this line K), [2]


    3. the potential energy stored in the springs (label this line P). [2]

  4. The arrangement in Fig. 2.1 is now rotated through 90° so that the line AB is vertical and the ball oscillates in a vertical plane.

    Suggest one form of energy, other than those in (c), that must be taken into consideration when plotting new graphs to show energy changes with displacement.

    ......................................................................................................................................[1]

 [Total: 11]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper4_2/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a energy = ½mω2a2 and ω = 2πf 
   = ½ × 37 × 10–3 × (2π × 3.5)2 × (2.8 × 10–2)2
   = 7.0 × 10–3 J
(allow 2π × 3.5 shown as 7π)		 C1
M1
A0

 [2]
Energy = ½ mv2  and v = rω
Correct substitution
Energy = 7.0 × 10–3 J		 (C1)
(M1)
(A0)
b EK = EP
½mω2 (a2 – x2) = ½mω2x2 or EK or EP = 3.5 mJ
x = a/√2 = 2.8 /√2  or EK = ½mω2 (a2 – x2) or EP = ½mω2x2
   = 2.0 cm
(EK or EP = 7.0 mJ scores 0/3)		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
Allow: k = 17.9
    E = ½ kx2
    x = 2.0cm		 (C1)
(C1)
(A1)
c.i graph: horizontal line, y-intercept = 7.0mJ with end-points of line at +2.8 cm and –2.8cm B1 [1]
c.ii graph: reasonable curve 
   with maximum at (0,7.0) end-points of line at (–2.8, 0) and (+2.8, 0)		 B1
B1		 [2]
c.iii graph: inverted version of (ii)
   with intersections at (–2.0, 3.5) and (+2.0, 3.5)
(Allow marks in (iii), but not in (ii), if graphs K & P are not labelled)		 M1
A1		 [2]
d gravitational potential energy B1 [1]
  1. ω = 2πf

    E = (1/2)mω2x02

    = (1/2)(37 × 10-3)(2π × 3.5)2(2.8 × 10-2)2

    = 7.01 × 10-2 J

    = 7.0 mJ
  2. KE = PE

    ∴ PE = (1/2) × 7 = 3.5 mJ

    PE = (1/2)mω2x2

    3.5 × 10-3 = (1/2)(37 × 10-3)(2π × 3.5)2x2

    x = √x2, (we calculator)

    x = 0.0198 m

    Displacement = 2.0 cm


  3. (Note: This graph could have been drawn better with regard to the point (-2, 3.5))
  4. Gravitational potential energy
  1. Candidates who knew the relevant expressions usually gave well-presented answers.  
  2. There were several different approaches to this calculation. Many spotted that one half of the total energy (given) could be equated to the potential energy and thus x could be determined. Others made the calculation more difficult by using expressions that involved both x and x0.
    1. This was expected to be a straightforward start to the graphical work but many drew the line from –3.0 cm to +3.0cm.
    2. Most sketches indicated an acceptable curve for the kinetic energy. The intercepts were frequently indicated with insufficient care.
    3. Usually, this curve was shown as the inverse of the kinetic energy curve. Very few showed the curves crossing at the appropriate points, even when these points had been calculated correctly in (b). 
  4. There were many different answers, apart from gravitational potential energy. Some quoted strain energy and there were a number of other suggestions, some of which were not even forms of energy, such as friction and weight. 
NO. 266题号：32230

A small metal ball is suspended from a fixed point by means of a string, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

The ball is pulled a small distance to one side and then released. The variation with time t of the horizontal displacement x of the ball is shown in Fig. 4.2.

The motion of the ball is simple harmonic.

  1. Use data from Fig. 4.2 to determine the horizontal acceleration of the ball for a displacement x of 2.0 cm.









    acceleration = ....................................... m s–2 [3]

  2. The maximum kinetic energy of the ball is EK.

    On the axes of Fig. 4.3, sketch a graph to show the variation with time t of the kinetic energy of the ball for the first 1.0 s of its motion. 

    [3]

 [Total: 9]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper4_1/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a a = (–)ω2x and ω = 2π/T
T = 0.60 s
a = (4π2 × 2.0 × 10–2) / (0.6)2
   = 2.2 ms–2		 C1
C1

A1		 [3]
b sinusoidal wave with all values positive
all values positive, all peaks at EK and energy = 0 at t = 0
period = 0.30 s		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
  1. T = 0.6 s

    ∴ ω = 2π/T = 10.47 rad/s

    a = -ω2x = -(2π/0.6)2(2 × 10-2) = -2.19 m/s2

    Acceleration = 2.2 m/s2
  1. Most calculations were successful. A small minority confused the displacement of the ball with its amplitude of oscillation. 
  2. There were few fully correct responses. The speed of the ball is a sine function. Squaring this sine function to obtain kinetic energy will result in a sinusoidally shaped wave of double the frequency.
NO. 267题号：32228

A small frictionless trolley is attached to a fixed point A by means of a spring. A second spring is used to attach the trolley to a variable frequency oscillator, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

Both springs remain extended within the limit of proportionality.

Initially, the oscillator is switched off. The trolley is displaced horizontally along the line joining the two springs and is then released.

The variation with time t of the velocity v of the trolley is shown in Fig. 2.2.

    1. Using Fig. 2.2, state two different times at which
      1. the displacement of the trolley is zero,

        time = ................ s and time = ................ s [1]
      2. the acceleration in one direction is maximum.

        time = ................. s and time = ............... s [1]
    2. Determine the frequency of oscillation of the trolley.

      frequency = .............................. Hz [2]
    3. The variation with time of the displacement of the trolley is sinusoidal. The variation with time of the velocity of the trolley is also sinusoidal.
      State the phase difference between the displacement and the velocity.

      phase difference = .............................. [1]
  2. The oscillator is now switched on. The amplitude of vibration of the oscillator is constant.
    The frequency f of vibration of the oscillator is varied.
    The trolley is forced to oscillate by means of vibrations of the oscillator.
    The variation with f of the amplitude a0 of the oscillations of the trolley is shown in Fig. 2.3.
           
    By reference to your answer in (a), state the approximate frequency at which the amplitude is maximum.

    frequency = ........................................... Hz [1]
  3. The amplitude of the oscillations in (b) may be reduced without changing significantly the frequency at which the amplitude is a maximum. State how this may be done and give a reason for your answer.
    You may draw on Fig. 2.1 if you wish.
    ......................................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper4_3/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a.i 1. 0.1s, 0.3 s, 0.5 s, etc (any two) A1 [1]
  2. either 0, 0.4s, 0.8s, 1.2s
   or
   0.2s, 0.6 s, 1.0 s (any two)		 A1 [1]
a.ii period = 0.4s
frequency = (1/0.4 =) 2.5Hz		 C1
A1		 [2]
a.iii phase difference = 90° or ½ π rad B1 [1]
b frequency = 2.4 – 2.5Hz B1 [1]
c e.g. attach sheet of card to trolley
increases damping / frictional force
e.g. reduce oscillator amplitude
reduces power/energy input to system		 M1
A1
(M1)
(A1)		 [2]
      1. Time = 0.1 s and time = 0.3 s (where v is maximum)
      2. time = 0 s and time = 0.4 s

        Note: careful!

        Acceleration in one direction is maximum!
    2. T = 0.4 s (from graph)

      ∴ f = 1/T = 1/0.4 = 2.5 Hz
    3. Phase difference = π/2 rad
  2. Frequency = 2.5 Hz
  3. Attach a (light but rigid) cardboard disc to the trolley

    Increases damping
    1. 1. Only a minority of the candidates appreciated that the displacement of the trolley is zero when the velocity is maximum. 
      2. A common mistake was to state two different times at which the acceleration is maximum in opposite directions, rather than in one direction. Some candidates could have avoided this error by reading the question more carefully. 
    2. With few exceptions, the correct frequency was determined. 
    3. The phase difference between the displacement and the velocity was poorly understood. Many candidates also forgot to include a correct unit with the answer. 
  2. The vast majority of answers were correct. 
  3. It was generally appreciated that the oscillations ought to be damped, but there were few answers that stated how this would be done. Correct answers usually involved attaching something to the trolley that would increase the drag force on it without significantly increasing its mass e.g. a sheet of cardboard. No credit was given for answers that suggested a significant change in the mass of the trolley or a change in the spring constant of the springs. 
NO. 268题号：32226

A ball is held between two fixed points A and B by means of two stretched springs, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

The ball is free to oscillate along the straight line AB. The springs remain stretched and the motion of the ball is simple harmonic.

The variation with time t of the displacement x of the ball from its equilibrium position is shown in Fig. 3.2.

    1. Use Fig. 3.2 to determine, for the oscillations of the ball,
      1. the amplitude,

        amplitude = ........................................... cm [1]
      2. the frequency.

        frequency = ............................................ Hz [2]
    2. Show that the maximum acceleration of the ball is 5.2 m s–2. [2]

  2. Use your answers in (a) to plot, on the axes of Fig. 3.3, the variation with displacement x of the acceleration a of the ball. [2]
  3. Calculate the displacement of the ball at which its kinetic energy is equal to one half of the maximum kinetic energy.

    displacement = ........................................... cm [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper4_1/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a.i 1. amplitude = 1.7cm A1 [1]
2. period = 0.36cm
    frequency = 1/0.36
                     = 2.8Hz		 C1

A1		 [2]
a.ii a = (–)ω2x and ω = 2π/T
acceleration = (2π/0.36)2 × 1.7 × 10–2
                    = 5.2 ms–2		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
b graph: straight line, through origin, with negative gradient
          from (–1.7 × 10–2, 5.2) to (1.7 × 10–2, –5.2)
(if scale not reasonable, do not allow second mark)		 M1
A1

 [2] 
c either  kinetic energy = ½mω2(x02 – x2)
or  potential energy = ½mω2x02 and potential energy = kinetic energy
½mω2 (x0 – x2 ) = ½ × ½mω2 x02 or ½mω2x2 = ½ × ½mω2x02
x02 = 2x2
x = x0 / √2 = 1.7 / √2
   = 1.2cm
B1
C1


A1		 [3]
      1. from graph above

        Amplitude = 1.7 cm
      2. T = 0.36 s (from graph)

        f = 1/T = 1/0.36 = 2.77 Hz

        Frequency = 2.8 Hz
    2. a = -ω2x

      ∴ amax = -ω2xmax

      = -(2π/0.36)2(1.7 × 10-2)

      = -5.178 m/s2

      ∴ amax = 5.2 m/s2
  3. Max K.E. = (1/2)mω2x02

    So KE = (1/2)KEmax

    (1/2)mω2(x02 - x2) = (1/2) · (1/2)mω2x02

    ∴ x02 - x2 = (1/2)x02

    ∴ x2 = (1/2)x02

    ∴ x = x0/√2 = 1.7/√2 = 1.2 cm

    Displacement = 1.2 cm
  1. The vast majority of answers to (i) and (ii) were fully correct.
  2. There were many incorrect graph shapes such as sinusoidal curves. The correct graph is a straight line with a negative gradient that passes through the origin. Candidates needed to ensure that they used reasonable scales and then accurately plotted the end points of the line. 
  3. Different methods of calculation were possible. The simplest was to realise that the kinetic energy would be equal to the potential energy, thus enabling a general expression for potential energy to be equated to an expression for one half of the maximum kinetic energy. Candidates needed to adequately explain their chosen method of calculation.

    Use Fig. 4.1 to determine

    2. the maximum acceleration of oscillator Q,









      maximum acceleration = ........................... m s–2 [2]

A level PHYSICS 2015/Summer/Paper4_2/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a displacement (directly) proportional to acceleration/force
either displacement and acceleration in opposite directions
or acceleration (always) towards a (fixed) point		 M1

A1		 [2]
b.i ⅓π rad or 1.05 rad (allow 60° if unit clear) A1 [1]
b.ii a0 = –ω2 x0
   = (–) (2π / 1.2)2 × 0.030
   = (–) 0.82 ms–2
(special case: using oscillator P gives x0 = 1.7cm and a0 = 0.47 ms–1 for 1/2)		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.iii max. energy ∝ x02
ratio = 3.02 / 1.72
    = 3.1 (at least 2 s.f.)
(if has inverse ratio but has stated max. energy ∝ x02 then allow 1/2)		 C1
A1		 [2]
c graph: straight line through (0,0) with negative gradient
correct end-points (–3.0, +0.82) and (+3.0, –0.82)		 M1
A1		 [2]
  1. SHM is defined as the motion of an object in which the acceleration of the object is directly proportional to its displacement from a fixed point and is always directed towards that point.
    1. ω = 2π/T rad/s

      T = 1.2 s from graph

      ∴ ω = 2π/1.2 rad/s

      Spacing between graphs as t axis = 0.2 s

      ∴ Phase = (2π/1.2) × 0.2 = 1.047 rad

      Phase difference = 1.05 rad
    2. a = -ω2x

      ω = 2π/1.2, for max acceleration, xQ = 3 cm = 3/100 m

      ∴ amax = -(2π/1.2)2(3/100) = -0.822 m/s2

      Maximum acceleration = -0.82 m/s2
    3. Maximum KE ∝ x02

      ∴ Ratio



      = (3.0)2/(1.7)2

      = 3.114

      Ratio = 3.1
  1. This was generally answered correctly. 
    1. Candidates found this difficult and the correct phase angle was given in very few scripts. 
    2. In general, the relevant equation was known. Often, when substituting for angular frequency, ω was not squared in the calculation. Power-of-ten errors were common.
    3. Many candidates were unable to link maximum kinetic energy to the data provided. Others gave different time periods for the two oscillations. 
  3. Most candidates were able to draw a straight line with negative gradient through the origin. Some did not use data from (b) in order to fix the end-points of the line.
NO. 270题号：32219
  1. For an oscillating body, state what is meant by
    1. forced frequency,
      ......................................................................... [1]
    2. natural frequency of vibration,
      ......................................................................... [1]
    3. resonance.
      ......................................................................... [2]
  2. State and explain one situation where resonance is useful.
    ................................................................................... [2]
  3. In some situations, resonance should be avoided. 
    State one such situation and suggest how the effects of resonance are reduced.
    .................................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2015/Summer/Paper4_1/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a.i frequency at which object is made to vibrate/oscillate B1 [1]
a.ii frequency at which object vibrates when free to do so B1 [1]
a.iii maximum amplitude of vibration of oscillating body
when forced frequency equals natural frequency (of vibration)		 B1
B1		 [2]
b e.g. vibration of quartz/piezoelectric crystal (what is vibrating)
  either for accurate timing
  or maximise amplitude of ultrasound waves (why it is useful)		 M1

A1		 [2]
c e.g. vibrating metal panels (what is vibrating)
  either place strengthening struts across the panel
  or change shape/area of panel (how it is reduced)		 M1

A1		 [2]
    1. The frequency at which an object is made to oscillate by an external periodic force
    2. The frequency of a freely oscillating object
    3. Resonance occurs when the forced frequency of an oscillating object equals its natural frequency. When resonance occurs, the amplitude of oscillation is maximum
  2. The tuning circuit in a radio oscillates

    The tuner is adjusted so that its frequency is equal to the frequency of the radio waves of a particular station.

    Forced frequency = natural frequency

    ∴ Resonance occurs Amplitude is maximum. The circuit produces a large amplitude signal for this specific frequency only.
  3. Vibrating rear view mirror in a truck

    Place the mirrors are on mountings to provide damping
