    1. The idea of a driving oscillator was well understood but it was less often coupled to the fact that it would produce a frequency in the driven system. 
    2. When this was answered correctly, it was most often in terms of there being no external force acting.
    3. This part of the question was often answered correctly. The idea of forced frequency being equal to natural frequency was well understood. Fewer candidates made the link to maximum amplitude. 
  2. This is an example of a "state and explain" question. It was essential that the object vibrating was mentioned. Those who did this often then found it difficult to identify exactly why resonance was useful in that case. For example "microwave ovens" are not an example of resonance as there is no statement of what is resonating. The second mark was given for showing why this was useful.
  3. As in (b), "bridges" (for example) are not an example of a situation where resonance should be avoided. "The vibration of bridges" is a better answer. The second mark was given for how to reduce the effect of resonance. Cars going over a bump in the road are not an example of resonance, as there is no forcing frequency. 
NO. 271题号：32211
  1. A student states, quite wrongly, that temperature measures the amount of thermal energy (heat) in a body.
    State and explain two observations that show why this statement is incorrect.
    1. ....................................................................
    2. .................................................................... [4]
  2. A thermometer and an electrical heater are inserted into holes in an aluminium block of mass 960 g, as shown in Fig. 3.1.
       
    The power rating of the heater is 54 W.
    The heater is switched on and readings of the temperature of the block are taken at regular time intervals. When the block reaches a constant temperature, the heater is switched off and then further temperature readings are taken. The variation with time t of the temperature θ of the block is shown in Fig. 3.2.
             
    1. Suggest why the rate of rise of temperature of the block decreases to zero.
      .................................................................... [2]
    2. After the heater has been switched off, the maximum rate of fall of temperature is 3.7 K per minute.
      Estimate the specific heat capacity of aluminium.

      specific heat capacity = .............................. J kg–1 K–1 [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper4_1/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a e.g. two objects of different masses at same temperature
  same material would have different amount of heat
e.g. temperature shows direction of heat transfer
  from high to low regardless of objects
e.g. when substance melts/boils
  heat input but no temperature change 
any two, M1 + A1 each, max 4		 (M1)
(A1)
(M1)
(A1)
(M1)
(A1)

 [4]
b.i energy losses (to the surroundings)
either  increase as the temperature rises
or  rise is zero when heat loss = heat input		 M1

 A1		 [2]
b.ii idea of input power = maximum rate of heat loss
power = m × c × ∆θ / ∆t
54 = 0.96 × c × 3.7 / 60
c = 910 J kg-1 K-1		 C1

C1
A1		 [3]
    [Total: 9]
    1. Two objects of different measures at the same temperature same material would have different amount of thermal energy
    2. Where a substance meets (process of melting) there is heat input (i.e. heat is absorbed) but there is no temperature change.
    1. Energy is lost to the surroundings

      Rate of rise = 0 when the heat input = heat loss
    2. Use pt = mc∆Q

      54 × 1 × 60 = (960/1000) · c · 3.7

      ∴ c = 912.16

      Specific heat capacity = 910 J kg-1K-1
  1. Most answers included only one observation, namely either melting or boiling. Very few discussed temperature difference as indicating the direction of thermal energy transfer or made a reference to either mass or to specific heat capacity. Many answers were a mere statement that temperature measures the 'degree of hotness' of a body.
    1. Answers here were very disappointing. Very few deduced that when the rate of rise is zero, then the power input is equal to the rate of energy loss from the block. Many attributed the constant temperature to the melting of the block. 
    2. There were many correct answers to the calculation, despite a failure to give a sensible explanation in (b)(i).
NO. 272题号：32206
  1. A resistance thermometer and a thermocouple thermometer are both used at the same time to measure the temperature of a water bath.

    Explain why, although both thermometers have been calibrated correctly and are at equilibrium, they may record different temperatures.

    ..........................................................................................................................................
    ..........................................................................................................................................
    ..................................................................................................................................... [2]

  2. State
    1. in what way the absolute scale of temperature differs from other temperature scales,

      ..................................................................................................................................
      ............................................................................................................................. [1]

    2. what is meant by the absolute zero of temperature.

      ..................................................................................................................................
      ............................................................................................................................. [1]

  3. The temperature of a water bath increases from 50.00 °C to 80.00 °C. 
    Determine, in kelvin and to an appropriate number of significant figures,
    1. the temperature 50.00 °C,





      temperature = ..................................... K [1]

    2. the change in temperature of the water bath.





      temperature change = ............................... K [1]

[Total: 6]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper4_3/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a temperature scale calibrated assuming linear change of property with temperature
neither property varies linearly with temperature		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.i does not depend on the property of a substance B1 [1]
b.ii temperature at which atoms have minimum/zero energy B1 [1]
c.i 323.15 K A1 [1]
c.ii 30.00 K  A1 [1]
  1. The temperature scale is calibrated assuming that the thermometric property changes linearly with temperature

    Neither thermometric property varies linearly with temperature

    (Note: Different thermometric properties vary differently with temperature)
    1. The absolute scale is independent of the properties of any substance
    2. It is the temperature at which the atoms have minimum energy. (0 K.E. and minimum P.E.)

      (Note: For ideal gases: absolute zero ⇒ 0 energy, also 0 pressure)
    1. 50 + 273.15 = 323.15 K
    2. 80 + 273.15 = 353.15

      ∴ Change = 353.15 - 323.15 = 30 K
  1. There were few correct responses. It was expected that candidates would explain that the temperature scales of the two thermometers are calibrated assuming a linear change in property with temperature. This means that the thermometers will record different temperatures because neither property varies linearly with temperature.
  2. In (i) only a small minority of candidates understood that the absolute scale of temperature is different from other temperature scales because it does not depend on the property of any particular substance. However, in part (ii), candidates were more successful in explaining that the absolute zero of temperature is the temperature at which atoms have minimum energy. 
  3. Despite being prompted by the question, candidates frequently expressed their answers to an inappropriate number of significant figures. The temperature of the water bath is 323.15 K and its change in temperature is 30.00 K. A common error was to state that the change in temperature is 303.15 K. 
NO. 273题号：32205
  1. State what is meant by the internal energy of a system.
    ...........................................................................[2]
  2. State and explain qualitatively the change, if any, in the internal energy of the following systems:
    1. a lump of ice at 0 °C melts to form liquid water at 0 °C,
      ...........................................................................[3]
    2. a cylinder containing gas at constant volume is in sunlight so that its temperature rises from 25°C to 35 °C.
      ...........................................................................[3] 
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper4_2/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a sum of potential energy and kinetic energy of atoms/molecules/particles
reference to random (distribution)		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i as lattice structure is 'broken'/bonds broken/forces between
molecules reduced (not molecules separate)
no change in kinetic energy, potential energy increases
internal energy increases
B1
M1
A1		 [3]
b.ii either  molecules/atoms/particles move faster/ <c2> is increasing
or  kinetic energy increases with temperature (increases)
no change in potential energy, kinetic energy increases
internal energy increases
B1
M1
A1		 [3]
  1. The internal energy of a system is the sum of the random distribution of the kinetic and potential energies associated with the parlicter of the system
    1. The forces between the molecules are reduced as the bonds are broken

      ∴ The potential energy increases, with no change in kinetic energy (since no change in temperature)

      ∴ Internal energy increases
    2. Molecules move faster

      ∴ Kinetic energy increases

      Kinetic energy increases with no change in potential energy

      ∴ Internal energy increases
  1. In most answers, kinetic energy and potential energy were mentioned. The fact that the energies are associated with molecules, rather than 'the system', and that the kinetic energy is associated with random motion needed to be included.
  2. For credit to be awarded, changes, if any, to both kinetic energy and potential energy had to be identified. In (i), it was common to find that kinetic energy was not mentioned and potential energy was associated with an increase in the separation of molecules. Answers in (ii) were much more comprehensive, with many candidates discussing kinetic, potential and internal energy. Candidates should be advised that it is insufficient to discuss a change. The direction of any such change should be identified.
NO. 274题号：32204
  1. Define specific latent heat.
    ........................................................................... [2]
  2. The heater in an electric kettle has a power of 2.40 kW. 
    When the water in the kettle is boiling at a steady rate, the mass of water evaporated in 2.0 minutes is 106 g. 
    The specific latent heat of vaporisation of water is 2260 J g–1. 
    Calculate the rate of loss of thermal energy to the surroundings of the kettle during the boiling process.

    rate of loss = ............................................ W [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper4_1/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a (numerically equal to) quantity of (thermal) energy required to change the state of unit mass of a substance
without any change of temperature
(Allow 1 mark for definition of specific latent heat of fusion/vaporisation)
M1
A1

 [2]
b either  energy supplied = 2400 × 2 × 60 = 288000J
   energy required for evaporation = 106 × 2260 = 240000J
   difference = 48000J
   rate of loss = 48000 / 120 = 400W		 C1
C1

A1		 [3]
or  energy required for evaporation = 106 × 2260 = 240000J
   power required for evaporation = 240000 / (2 × 60) = 2000W
   rate of loss = 2400 – 2000 = 400W		 (C1)
(C1)
(A1)
  1. It is numerically equal to the quantity of heat energy required to change the state of unit mass of substance without change in temperature.
  2. Energy supplied: pt = 2.4 × 103 × 2 × 60 = 288000 J

    Energy absorbed in evaporation = mL = 106 × 2260 = 239560 J

    ∴ Energy lost = 288000 - 239560 = 48440 J

    ∴ Rate of loss = 48440/(2 × 60) = 403.67 J/s

    Rate of loss = 400 W
  1. A correct definition was usually given. The most common error was to define either specific latent heat of fusion or specific latent heat of vaporisation, rather than specific latent heat in general.
  2. Candidates calculated the final answer in one of two ways. The first way was to find the total loss in energy after two minutes and then convert this to a rate of energy loss. The second way was to find the power needed for evaporation and then subtract this from the power supplied by the kettle.
NO. 275题号：32201
    1. State what is meant by the internal energy of a system. [2]
    2. Explain why, for an ideal gas, the internal energy is equal to the total kinetic energy of the molecules of the gas. [2]
  2. The mean kinetic energy <Ek> of a molecule of an ideal gas is given by the expression
              <Ek> = kT
    where k is the Boltzmann constant and T is the thermodynamic temperature of the gas.
    A cylinder contains 1.0 mol of an ideal gas. The gas is heated so that its temperature changes from 280 K to 460 K.
    1. Calculate the change in total kinetic energy of the gas molecules.

      change in energy = ................................. J [2]
    2. During the heating, the gas expands, doing 1.5 × 103 J of work.
      State the first law of thermodynamics. Use the law and your answer in (i) to determine the total energy supplied to the gas.

      total energy = ............................................. J [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Winter/Paper4_3/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a.i sum of kinetic and potential energies of the molecules
reference to random distribution		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii for ideal gas, no intermolecular forces
so no potential energy (only kinetic)		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i either change in kinetic energy = 3/2 × 1.38 × 10–23 × 1.0 × 6.02 × 1023 × 180
  = 2240 J
or  R = kNA
  energy = 3/2 × 1.0 × 8.31 × 180
             = 2240 J 		 C1
A1

(C1)
(A1)		 [2]
b.ii increase in internal energy = heat supplied + work done on system
2240 = energy supplied – 1500
energy supplied = 3740J		 B1
C1
A1		 [3]
    1. The internal energy of a system is the sum of the random distribution of the kinetic and potential energy associated with the particles of the system.
    2. For an ideal gas, we assume no intermolecular forces

      ∴ No potential energy associated with the molecules

      ∴ I.E. (internal energy) = total K.E. (kinetic energy) of the molecules of the gas
    1. 1 mole: 6.02 × 1023 molecules

      Change in total K.E. = (3/2) × 1.38 × 10-23 × (460 - 280) × 6.02 × 1023 = 2243.052 J

      Change in energy = 2240J
    2. First law: ∆U = Q + W

      ∆U = increase in internal energy, Q = heat energy supplied to system, W = work done on system

      ∆U = Q + W

      2240 = Q + (-1.5 × 103)

      ∴ Q = 2240 + 1.5 × 103 = 3740 J

      Total energy = 3740 J
    1. There were many correct responses. The internal energy of a system is the sum of the kinetic and potential energies of all the molecules, due to their random motion. Candidates needed to explicitly refer to the energies "of the molecules" rather than the energies "of the system".  
    2. Many candidates appreciated that the molecules of an ideal gas have no potential energy. For the award of credit, they also needed to link this to the absence of intermolecular forces. It should be noted that the intermolecular forces of an ideal gas are zero rather than negligible. 
    1. The majority of answers gave the change in kinetic energy of a single molecule. The question clearly asked for the change in total kinetic energy of all the gas molecules. Candidates should be reminded to read carefully, rather than merely scan, each part of a question to ensure that key details are not overlooked. 
    2. The first law of thermodynamics needed to be stated in precise terms. It was common to see incomplete terms such as 'work done' rather than 'work done on the system' and 'change in internal energy' rather than 'increase in internal energy'. During the calculation, weaker candidates sometimes confused the heat energy supplied with the increase in internal energy.
NO. 276题号：32199

A constant mass of an ideal gas has a volume of 3.49×103 cm3 at a temperature of 21.0 °C.
When the gas is heated, 565 J of thermal energy causes it to expand to a volume of 3.87×103 cm3 at 53.0 °C. This is illustrated in Fig. 2.1.

  1. Show that the initial and final pressures of the gas are equal. [2]

  2. The pressure of the gas is 4.20×105 Pa.
    For this heating of the gas,
    1. calculate the work done by the gas,

      work done = ...................................... J [2]
    2. use the first law of thermodynamics and your answer in (i) to determine the change in internal energy of the gas.

      change in internal energy = ...................................... J [2]
  3. Explain why the change in kinetic energy of the molecules of this ideal gas is equal to the change in internal energy. 
    .................................................................................... [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2014/Summer/Paper4_2/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a use of kelvin temperatures
both values of (V/T) correct (11.87), V/T is constant so pressure is constant
(allow use of n =1. Do not allow other values of n.)		 B1
M1

 [2]
b.i work done = p∆V
   = 4.2 × 105 × (3.87 – 3.49) × 103 × 10–6
   = 160 J
(do not allow use of V instead of ∆V
C1
A1

 [2]
b.ii increase/ change in internal energy = heating of system + work done on system
   = 565 – 160
   = 405 J		 C1

A1		 [2]
c internal energy = sum of kinetic energy and potential energy /EK + EP
no intermolecular forces
no potential energy (so ∆U = ∆EK)		 B1
M1
A1		 [3]
  1. Check V/T = constant

    T1 = 21 + 273 = 294 K

    T2 = 53 + 273 = 326 K

    V1/T1 = (3.49 × 103)/294 = 11.87

    V2/T2 = (3.87 × 103)/326 = 11.87

    Since V/T = constant, pressure is constant
    1. Work done = p∆v

      = 4.2 × 105(3.87 × 103 × 10-6 - 3.49 × 103 × 10-6)

      = 159.6 J

      Work done = 160 J
    2. ∆U = Q + W

      W = -160 J (since work is done by the gas system)

      Q = heat supplied = 565 J (positive)

      So ∆U = 565 - 160 = 405 J
  3. Internal energy is the sum of KE and PE of the molecules

    Ideal gases, we assume no intermolecular force

    ∴ no potential energy

    ∴ Change in KE of the molecules = change in internal energy
  1. In most answers, some form of the ideal gas equation was used. Frequently, terms such as n, N and R were omitted. Where a numerical expression was derived for the initial and for the final conditions, many did not write down a conclusion. 
    1. With few exceptions, a correct expression was used. Some candidates made a power-of-ten error in the volume of the gas.
    2. Despite being instructed in (b)(i) to calculate the work done by the gas, it was common to find that the heating and work done were summed.
  3. This part was generally well answered. The most common omission was to state that the potential energy of the gas molecules is zero without mention that there are no intermolecular forces. Candidates should appreciate the difference between stating zero potential energy and constant potential energy. 
NO. 277题号：32197

A fixed mass of gas has an initial volume of 5.00×10−4 m3 at a pressure of 2.40×105Pa and a temperature of 288 K. It is heated at constant pressure so that, in its final state, the volume is 14.5×10−4 m3 at a temperature of 835 K, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1.

  1. Show that these two states provide evidence that the gas behaves as an ideal gas. [3]

  2. The total thermal energy supplied to the gas for this change is 569 J.
    Determine
    1. the external work done,

      work done = .......................................... J [2]
    2. the change in internal energy of the gas. State whether the change is an increase or a decrease in internal energy.

      change in internal energy = .......................... J
       ........................................................................ [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2014/Winter/Paper4_3/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a initially, pV/T = (2.40 × 105 × 5.00 × 10–4)/ 288 = 0.417
finally, pV/T = (2.40 × 105 × 14.5 × 10–4)/ 835 = 0.417
ideal gas because pV/T is constant
(allow 2 marks for two determinations of V/T and then 1 mark for V/T and p constant, so ideal)		 M1
M1
A1

 [3]
b.i work done = p∆V
  = 2.40 × 105 × (14.5 – 5.00) × 10–4
  = 228 J  (ignore sign, not 2 s.f.)
C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii ∆U = q + w = 569 – 228
      = 341 J
increase		 M1
A1		 [2]


  1. Since pv/T = constant, the gas behaves as an ideal gas
    1. External work done = p∆v

      = 2.4 × 105(14.5 × 10-4 - 5 × 10-4)

      = 228J
    2. ∆U = Q + W

      Here using the usual convertions, Q = 569J, W = -228 J

      ∴ ∆U = 569 + (-228) = 341 J

      Since ∆U = positive

      ∴ increase in I.E.(internal energy)

      Change in internal energy = 341 J
  1. There were many different methods used. Commonly, the value of pV/T or the value of n was calculated for both the initial and final states. Candidates should realise that it is appropriate to calculate these values to 3 s.f. as all the data in the question is given to 3 s.f. Candidates also needed to ensure that their calculated values did not contain rounding errors. Some candidates showed a relation between V and T but did not mention the constant P in their summary. The most successful answers clearly explained each step of their calculation and finished with a clear concluding statement. 
    1. Most candidates were able to successfully answer this. A small number did the correct working and then unfortunately wrote down 288J rather than 228 J as their answer.
    2. The gas has expanded and so work is done by the gas. Many candidates did not establish that the work done was therefore negative and they did not subtract 228J from 569J. Some candidates did the correct subtraction, but then because they had subtracted the work they thought there was an overall decrease in internal energy. 
NO. 278题号：32196
  1. Define specific latent heat.

    ...................................................................................................................................................
    ...................................................................................................................................................
    ...............................................................................................................................................[2]

  2. A beaker containing a liquid is placed on a balance, as shown in Fig. 3.1.


    A heater of power 110 W is immersed in the liquid. The heater is switched on and, when the liquid is boiling, balance readings m are taken at corresponding times t.

    A graph of the variation with time t of the balance reading m is shown in Fig. 3.2.


    1. State the feature of Fig. 3.2 which suggests that the liquid is boiling at a steady rate.

      ...........................................................................................................................................
      .......................................................................................................................................[1]

    2. Use data from Fig. 3.2 to determine a value for the specific latent heat L of vaporisation of the liquid.






      L = ................................................ J kg–1 [3]

    3. State, with a reason, whether the value determined in (ii) is likely to be an overestimate or an underestimate of the normally accepted value for the specific latent heat of vaporisation of the liquid.

      ...........................................................................................................................................
      ...........................................................................................................................................
      .......................................................................................................................................[2]

[Total: 8]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2015/Summer/Paper4_2/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a (numerically equal to) quantity of heat/(thermal) energy to change state/phase of unit mass
at constant temperature
(allow 1/2 for definition restricted to fusion or vaporisation)		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i constant gradient/straight line (allow linear/constant slope) B1 [1]
b.ii Pt = mL or power = gradient × L
use of gradient of graph
(or two points separated by at least 3.5 minutes)
110 × 60 = L × (372 – 325) × 10–3 / 7.0
L = 9.80 × 105 J kg–1 (accept 2 s.f.) (allow 9.8 to 9.9 rounded to 2 s.f.)		 C1

M1

A1		 [3]
b.iii some energy/heat is lost to the surroundings or vapour condenses on sides
so value is an overestimate		 M1
A1		 [2]
  1. It is numerically equal to the quantity of heat energy required to change the state of unit mass of substance without change in temperature
    1. The linear relationship (constant gradient) between m and t
    2. Use Q = mL, in this case E = Q

      E = electrical energy

      From the graph:

      t = 0, m = 372 × 10-3

      t = 7, m = 325 × 10-3

      So, t = 7 mins

      ∆ m = (372 - 325) × 10-3 = 47 × 10-3 kg

      ∴ Use pt = mL

      110 × 7 × 60 = (47 × 10-3)L

      ∴ L = specific latent ht of vaporisation = 9.8 × 105 J/kg
    3. Overestimate. Some heat energy is lost to the surroundings
  1. The definition was often given in terms of either "a substance" or "matter" or "a kilogram" rather than the energy required per/for unit mass. The condition that there must be constant temperature should be included. 
    1. This question was generally answered correctly but some discussed mass per unit time being constant, without any reference to the graph.
    2. A correct expression linking specific latent heat to power was quoted in most scripts. In many answers, a single point on the line was used, rather than the gradient. Power-of-ten errors were common. 
    3. There were many correct answers based on "heat lost to the surroundings". Others made inappropriate reference to heat gained by the beaker or the apparatus. These items would remain at constant temperature.
NO. 279题号：32194
  1. State what is meant by internal energy.
    ..................................................................................... [2]
  2. The variation with volume V of the pressure p of an ideal gas as it undergoes a cycle ABCA of changes is shown in Fig. 2.1.

    The temperature of the gas at A is 290 K. The temperature at B is 870 K.
    Determine
    1. the amount, in mol, of gas,

      amount = .................................................. mol [2]
    2. the temperature of the gas at C.

      temperature = ............................................ K [2]
  3. Explain why the change from C to A involves external work and a change in internal energy.
    ............................................................................. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2015/Summer/Paper4_1/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a (sum of) potential energy and kinetic energy of molecules/atoms/particles
mention of random motion/distribution		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i pV = nRT
either at A, 1.2 × 105 × 4.0 × 10−3 = n × 8.31 × 290
or at B, 3.6 × 105 × 4.0 × 10−3 = n × 8.31 × 870
n = 0.20mol 

C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii 1.2 × 105 × 7.75 × 10–3 = 0.20 × 8.31 × T or T = (7.75/4.0) × 290
T = 560 K
(Allow tolerance from graph: 7.7–7.8 × 10–3 m3)		 C1
A1

 [2]
c temperature changes/decreases so internal energy changes/decreases
volume changes (at constant pressure) so work is done		 B1
B1		 [2]
  1. The internal energy of a system is the sum of the random distribution of the kinetic and potential energies associated with the particles of the system.
    1. Use pV = nRT

      At A, p = 1.2 × 105Pa, V = 4 × 10-3 m3 (from graph)

      ∴ n = (1.2 × 105)(4 × 10-3)/(8.31 × 290) = 0.1992

      Amount = 0.2 mol
    2. Again use pV = nRT

      ∴ T = pV/nR

      at C: p = 1.2 × 105, V = 7.75 × 10-3 m3, n = 0.2

      ∴ T = (1.2 × 105)(7.75 × 10-3)/(0.2 × 8.31) = 559.57

      Temperature = 560 K
  3. Volume decreases at constant pressure

    ∴ external work is done

    Temperature decreases

    ∴ There is a decrease in internal energy
  1. The most common mistake was to forget to mention atoms/molecules/particles of a system.
    1. This was generally well calculated, but some candidates lost credit by rounding to 1 s.f. A small number of candidates used the change in pressure and temperature to correctly calculate the correct value. A smaller number spoiled their work by mistakenly using the difference in volume from C to A.
    2. There were few problems here. Some candidates misread the scale on the graph.
  3. Few candidates correctly linked the change in volume to work done and the change in temperature to internal energy. Some candidates who considered the work done thought that the temperature would be increasing. The key point to realise was that work was done on the gas and it was cooling.
NO. 280题号：32193
  1. The equation
                     pV = constant × T
    relates the pressure p and volume V of a gas to its kelvin (thermodynamic) temperature T.
    State two conditions for the equation to be valid.
    1. .............................................................................
    2. ............................................................................. [2]
  2. A gas cylinder contains 4.00 × 104 cm3 of hydrogen at a pressure of 2.50 × 107Pa and a temperature of 290 K.
    The cylinder is to be used to fill balloons. Each balloon, when filled, contains 7.24 × 103 cm3 of hydrogen at a pressure of 1.85 × 105Pa and a temperature of 290 K.
    Calculate, assuming that the hydrogen obeys the equation in (a),
    1. the total amount of hydrogen in the cylinder,

      amount = ……………………….. mol [3]
    2. the number of balloons that can be filled from the cylinder.

      number = ……………………….. [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Summer/Paper4/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a e.g. fixed mass / amount of gas
ideal gas
(any two, 1 each)		 B2 [2]
b.i n = pV / RT
   = (2.5 × 107 × 4.00 × 104 × 10-6) / (8.31 × 290)
   = 415 mol		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
b.ii volume of gas at 1.85 × 105 Pa = (2.5 × 107 × 4.00 × 104) / (1.85 × 105)
                                                   = 5.41 × 106 cm3
so, 5.41 × 106 = 4.00 × 104 + 7.24 × 103 N 
N = 741
(answer 740 or fails to allow for gas in cylinder, max 2/3)
C1
C1
A1

 [3]
    1. fixed mass of gas
    2. Ideal gas
    1. Use pV = nRT

      (2.5 × 107)(4 × 104 × 10-6) = n(8.31)(290)

      ∴ n = 414.95

      Amount = 415 mol
    2. p1V1 = p2V2

      (2.5 × 107)(4 × 104) = (1.85 × 105)V2

      ∴ V2 = 5.41 × 106 cm3  (volume of gas at 1.85 × 105 Pa)

      Let the number of balloons be N

      H2 available = 5.41 × 106 - 4 × 104 = 5.365 × 106 cm3

      ∴ 1 balloon: 7.24 × 103 cm

      ∴ N = (5.365 × 106)/(7.24 × 103) = 741.02

      Number = 741
  1. This part could be answered by reference either to macroscopic or to microscopic properties of a gas. Many answers were given full credit. However, a common misconception is that 'the volume of the gas is negligible compared with the volume of the container'. Weak candidates frequently stated that either temperature or pressure or volume must be held constant. 
    1. Most calculations were correct. It was pleasing to note that many set out their work clearly and logically. The most common error was a failure to convert correctly the volume in cm3 to m3. 
    2. With few exceptions, candidates calculated correctly the amount of gas in a balloon and then divided the total amount of gas by this quantity. Very few made any allowance for the amount of gas that remains in the cylinder. 
NO. 281题号：32189

An ideal gas occupies a container of volume 4.5×103 cm3 at a pressure of 2.5×105 Pa and a temperature of 290 K.

  1. Show that the number of atoms of gas in the container is 2.8 × 1023.







    [2]

  2. Atoms of a real gas each have a diameter of 1.2 × 10–10 m.
    1. Estimate the volume occupied by 2.8 × 1023 atoms of this gas.







      volume = ......................................... m3 [2]

    2. By reference to your answer in (i), suggest whether the real gas does approximate to an ideal gas.

      ..................................................................................................................................
      ..................................................................................................................................
      ............................................................................................................................ [2]

[Total: 6]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper4_1/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a either  pV = NkT  or  pV = nRT  and  n = N / NA
clear correct substitution e.g.
2.5 × 105 × 4.5 × 103 × 10-6 = N × 1.38 × 10-23 × 290
N = 2.8 × 1023
(allow 1 mark for calculation of n = 0.467 mol)		 C1

M1
A0		 [2]
b.i volume = (1.2 × 10-10)3 × 2.8 × 1023 or  (4/3)πr3 × 2.8 × 1023
             = 4.8 × 10-7 m3  or   2.53 × 10-7 m3		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii either 4.5 × 103 cm3 >> 0.48 cm3 or ratio of volumes is about 10-4
justified because volume of molecules is negligible		 B1
B1		 [2]
    [Total: 6]
  1. Use pV = NkT

    ∴ (2.5 × 105)(4.5 × 103 × 10-6) = N(1.38 × 10-23)(290)

    ∴ N = 2.8 × 1023
    1. Volume of sphere = (4/3)πr3

      = (4/3)π(0.6 × 10-10)3

      Total volume = 2.8 × 1023 × (4/3)π(0.6 × 10-10)3

      = 2.53 × 10-7 m3
    2. Volume of container: 4.5 × 103 cm3 (Vc)

      Volume of gas atoms: 2.53 × 10-1 cm3 (Va), so Vc > Va

      i.e. volume of gas atoms is negligible compared to container volume

      ∴ approximates ideal gas
  1. The answer was given to candidates. A clear statement of the relevant equations, together with a correct substitution of the quantities involved, was required. Many lost credit as a result of inappropriate substitutions without a clear statement of the equations.  
    1. It was accepted that the volume occupied by a single atom could be assumed to be either a cube or a sphere. The most common error was to find the product of the Avogadro number and the diameter and then to calculate the cube of this product.
    2. It was expected that a comparison would be made between the volume occupied by the atoms and the volume of the containing vessel. Many answers did not include a comparison. 
NO. 282题号：32188
  1. Some gas, initially at a temperature of 27.2 °C, is heated so that its temperature rises to 38.8 °C.
    Calculate, in kelvin, to an appropriate number of decimal places,
    1. the initial temperature of the gas,

      initial temperature = ............................................. K [2]
    2. the rise in temperature.

      rise in temperature = ............................................ K [1]
  2. The pressure p of an ideal gas is given by the expression
             p = ⅓ρ<c2>
    where ρ is the density of the gas.
    1. State the meaning of the symbol <c2>.
      ......................................................................[1]
    2. Use the expression to show that the mean kinetic energy <EK> of the atoms of an ideal gas is given by the expression
             <EK> = kT.
      Explain any symbols that you use.
      ............................................................................... [4]
  3. Helium-4 may be assumed to behave as an ideal gas. 
    A cylinder has a constant volume of 7.8 × 103 cm3 and contains helium-4 gas at a pressure of 2.1 × 107 Pa and at a temperature of 290 K.

    Calculate, for the helium gas,
    1. the amount of gas,

      amount = ......................................... mol [2]
    2. the mean kinetic energy of the atoms,

      amount = ......................................... mol [2]
    3. the total internal energy.

      amount = ......................................... mol [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper4_1/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a.i 27.2 + 273.15 or 27.2 + 273.2
300.4 K		 C1
A1		 [2]
a.ii 11.6 K A1 [1]
b.i (<c2> is the) mean / average square speed B1 [1]
b.ii ρ = Nm/V with N explained
so, pV = 1/3 Nm<c2>
and pV = NkT with k explained
so mean kinetic energy / <Ek> = ½m<c2> = 3/2 kT		 B1
B1
B1
B1		 [4]
c.i pV = nRT
2.1 × 107 × 7.8 × 10–3 = n × 8.3 × 290
n = 68 mol
C1
A1		 [2]
c.ii mean kinetic energy = 3/2 kT
 = 3/2 × 1.38 × 10–23 × 290
 = 6.0 × 10–21 J
C1
A1		 [2]
c.iii realisation that total internal energy is the total kinetic energy
energy = 6.0 × 10–21 × 68 × 6.02 × 1023
= 2.46 × 105 J		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
    1. 27.2 + 273.15 = 300.35 K
    2. Final temperature: 38.8 + 273.15 = 311.95

      ∆T = 311.95 - 300.35 = 11.6 K
    1. <c2> is the mean square speed
    2. p = (1/3)ρ<c2>, where ρ = Nm/V and N = number of molemules, m = mass of one nolecule and V = volume of gas.

      So p = (1/3)(Nm/V)<c2>

      ∴ pV = (1/3)Nm<c2>, but pV = NkT, k = Boltzman constant with k = R/NA

      So (1/3)Nm<c2> = NkT

      ∴ (1/2)m<c2> = (3/2)kT where (1/2)m<c2> = <EK>

      ∴ <EK> = (3/2)kT
    1. Use pV = nRT

      (2.1 × 107)(7.8 × 103 × 10-6) = n(8.31)(290)

      ∴ n = 67.97 = 68 mol
    2. <EK> = (3/2)kT = (3/2)(1.38 × 10-23)(290) = 6 × 10-21 J
    3. Total internal energy = total kinetic energy (Note: ideal gas)

      Per atom: 6 × 10-21 J

      68 mol: 68 × 6.02 × 1023 atoms

      ∴ total K.E. = 68 × 6.02 × 1023 × 6 × 10-21 = 245616 J = 2.46 × 105 J
    1. Many candidates failed to realise that 273.15, rather than 273, should be added to 27.2 °C so that the final answer expressed to 1 decimal place is 300.4 K.
    2. The vast majority of answers were correct.
    1. Only a minority of candidates understood that the symbol represented mean square speed and a significant number thought that it meant either root mean square speed or mean speed squared.
    2. Most answers were only partially correct. Despite the wording in the question, many did not explain the symbols used or missed out crucial steps in the derivation. Another common mistake was to confuse the mass of the gas with the mass of an atom.
    1. Generally well answered, although some of the less-able candidates made a power-of-ten error with the volume of the gas. 
    2. With few exceptions, a correct answer was given.
    3. Only a minority of candidates multiplied the answers in (i) and (ii) by the Avogadro constant to calculate the total internal energy. Many did not appreciate that the total internal energy of the gas is the total kinetic energy of the atoms, because the atoms of an ideal gas have zero potential energy. 
NO. 283题号：32184

The planet Mars may be considered to be an isolated sphere of diameter 6.79 × 106 m with its mass of 6.42 × 1023 kg concentrated at its centre. 
A rock of mass 1.40 kg rests on the surface of Mars.

For this rock,

    1. determine its weight,

      weight = ............................................ N [3]
    2. show that its gravitational potential energy is –1.77 × 107 J.  [2]

  2. Use the information in (a)(ii) to determine the speed at which the rock must leave the surface of Mars so that it will escape the gravitational attraction of the planet.

    speed = ....................................... m s–1 [3]
  3. The mean translational kinetic energy <Ek> of a molecule of an ideal gas is given by the expression
             <Ek> = kT
    where T is the thermodynamic temperature of the gas and k is the Boltzmann constant.
    1. Determine the temperature at which the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed of hydrogen molecules is equal to the speed calculated in (b).
      Hydrogen may be assumed to be an ideal gas.
      A molecule of hydrogen has a mass of 2 u.

      temperature = ............................................. K [2]
    2. State and explain one reason why hydrogen molecules may escape from Mars at temperatures below that calculated in (i).
      ........................................................................ [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper4_3/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i weight = GMm/r2
 = (6.67 × 10–11 × 6.42 × 1023 × 1.40)/(½ × 6.79 × 106)2
 = 5.20 N		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
a.ii potential energy = –GMm/r
 = –(6.67 × 10–11 × 6.42 × 1023 × 1.40)/(½ × 6.79 × 106)
 = –1.77 × 107 J 		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
b either ½mv2 = 1.77 × 107
  v2 = (1.77 × 107 × 2)/1.40
  v = 5.03 × 103 m s–1		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
or ½mv2 = GMm/r
  v2 = (2 × 6.67 × 10–11 × 6.42 × 1023)/(6.79 × 106/2)
  v = 5.02 × 103 m s–1		 (C1)
(C1)
(A1)		  
c.i ½ × 2 × 1.66 × 10–27 × (5.03 × 103)2 = × 1.38 × 10–23 × T
T = 2030 K		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.ii either because there is a range of speeds
  some molecules have a higher speed
or some escape from point above planet surface
  so initial potential energy is higher		 M1
A1
(M1)
(A1)		 [2]
    1. weight = GMm/r2

      = (6.67 × 10-11 × 6.42 × 1023 × 1.40)/[(1/2) × 6.79 × 106]2

      = 5.20 N
    2. Potential energy = -GMm/r

      = -(6.67 × 10-11 × 6.42 × 1023 × 1.40)/[(1/2) × 6.79 × 106]

      = -1.77 × 107J
  2. either: (1/2)mv2 = 1.77 × 107

    v2 = (1.77 × 107 × 2)/1.40

    v = 5.03 × 103 m/s

    or: (1/2)mv2 = GMm/r

    v2 = (2 × 6.67 × 10-11 × 6.42 × 1023)/[6.79 × 106/2]

    v = 5.03 × 103 m/s
    1. Use (1/2)m<c2> = (3/2)kT

      u = 1.66 × 10-27 kg

      ∴ (1/2) × 2 × 1.66 × 10-27<c2> = (3/2) × 1.38 × 10-23 × T

      Since r.m.s. speed of hydrogen molecules is equal to the speed calculated in (b)

      ∴ c = 5.03 × 103

      ∴ (1/2) × 2 × 1.66 × 10-27<5.03 × 103> = (3/2) × 1.38 × 10-23 × T

      ∴ T = 2028.96 K

      Temperature = 2030 K
    2. There is a range of speeds

      Some molecules have a higher speed
    1. There were many good answers. A common error was to confuse the diameter of the planet with its radius. Some of the weakest candidates incorrectly calculated the weight using g = 9.81 N kg–1.
    2. Although there was a high proportion of good answers, a small minority confused gravitational potential energy with gravitational potential. 
  2. This part of the question was reasonably well answered. A significant minority of candidates misunderstood the question and calculated the speed that the rock would have when placed in a circular orbit about the planet. 
    1. Candidates should be encouraged to write down algebraic equations before substitution of the appropriate data. A common error was to fail to square the speed of the molecules when calculating their mean translational kinetic energy.
    2. The hydrogen molecules have a range of speeds and those with a higher speed can escape at a lower temperature. A few candidates also suggested, quite correctly, that some molecules escape from well above the planet's surface and so these molecules have a higher initial potential energy. 
NO. 284题号：32182
  1. The kinetic theory of gases is based on some simplifying assumptions.
    The molecules of the gas are assumed to behave as hard elastic identical spheres.
    State the assumption about ideal gas molecules based on
    1. the nature of their movement,
      ....................................................................... [1]
    2. their volume.
      ....................................................................... [2]
  2. A cube of volume V contains N molecules of an ideal gas. Each molecule has a component cX of velocity normal to one side S of the cube, as shown in Fig. 2.1.
         
    The pressure p of the gas due to the component cX of velocity is given by the expression
        pV = NmcX2
    where m is the mass of a molecule.
    Explain how the expression leads to the relation
       pV = ⅓Nm<c2>
    where <c2> is the mean square speed of the molecules. [3]

  3. The molecules of an ideal gas have a root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed of 520 m s–1 at a temperature of 27 °C.

    Calculate the r.m.s. speed of the molecules at a temperature of 100 °C.

    r.m.s. speed = ....................................... m s–1 [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper4_1/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a.i either   random motion
or   constant velocity until hits wall/other molecule		 B1 [1]
a.ii (total) volume of molecules is negligible
compared to volume of containing vessel
or
radius/diameter of a molecule is negligible
compared to the average intermolecular distance		 M1
A1

(M1)
(A1)		 [2]
b either  molecule has component of velocity in three directions
or  c2 = cX2 + cY2 + cZ2
random motion and averaging, so <cX2> = <cY2> = <cZ2>
<c2> = 3<cX2>
so, pV = ⅓Nm<c2>
M1
M1
A1
A0		 [3]
c <c2> ∝ T  or crms ∝ √T
temperatures are 300K and 373K
crms = 580 ms–1
(Do not allow any marks for use of temperature in units of ºC instead of K)		 C1
C1
A1

 [3]
    1. Molecules are in random motion
    2. The volume of the molecules is negligible compared to the volume of the containing vessel
  2. Detailed:

    For a molecule moving with velocity c,

    Pythagoras theorem in 3 dimensions gives the relation between c and the three components of velocity cx, cy and cz

    i.e. c2 = cx2 + cy2 + cz2

    Because we are dealing with a large number of molecules in random motion, the average value of the components in the x direction will be the same as for those in the y direction and z direction

    ∴ taking the averages <cX2> = <cY2> = <cZ2> and <cX2> = (1/3)<c2>

    the equation becomes pV = (1/3)Nm<c2>

    Note: <cX2> means average value of cX2.
  3. We know <c2> ∝ T

    ∴ crms ∝ √T

    (Note: <c2> = 3kT/m)



    r.m.s. speed = 580 m/s
    1. With few exceptions, a correct answer was given. 
    2. Candidates needed to make it clear that it is the total volume of all the molecules, rather than the volume of a single molecule, that is negligible compared to the volume of the containing vessel.
  2. Many candidates need to improve their understanding of the kinetic theory of gases. The velocity of a molecule was often confused with a component of its velocity. Few candidates distinguished between the square speed of a single molecule and the mean square speed of all the molecules. 
  3. Although there were many successful calculations, others confused mean square speed with root mean square speed or omitted the conversion of temperature from degrees Celsius to kelvin. 
NO. 285题号：32178

The product of the pressure ρ and the volume V of an ideal gas is given by the expression

pV = Nm<c2>

where m is the mass of one molecule of the gas.

  1. State the meaning of the symbol
    1. N,
      ...............................................................[1]
    2. <c2>
      ................................................................[1]
  2. The product pV is also given by the expression
                             ρV = NkT.
    Deduce an expression, in terms of the Boltzmann constant k and the thermodynamic temperature T, for the mean kinetic energy of a molecule of the ideal gas. [2]

  3. A cylinder contains 1.0 mol of an ideal gas.
    1. The volume of the cylinder is constant.
      Calculate the energy required to raise the temperature of the gas by 1.0 kelvin.

      energy = ............................................ J [2]
    2. The volume of the cylinder is now allowed to increase so that the gas remains at constant pressure when it is heated.
      Explain whether the energy required to raise the temperature of the gas by 1.0 kelvin is now different from your answer in (i).

      ..................................................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Winter/Paper4_1/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a.i N: (total) number of molecules B1 [1]
a.ii <c2>: mean square speed/velocity B1 [1]
b pV = ⅓Nm<c2> = NkT
(mean) kinetic energy = ½m<c2>
algebra clear leading to ½m<c2> = (3/2)kT
C1
A1		 [2]
c.i either energy required = (3/2) × 1.38 × 10–23 × 1.0 × 6.02 × 1023
  = 12.5 J  (12J if 2 s.f.)
or energy = (3/2) × 8.31 × 1.0
  = 12.5 J		 C1
A1
(C1)
(A1)		 [2]
c.ii energy is needed to push back atmosphere/do work against atmosphere
so total energy required is greater		 M1
A1		 [2]
    1. The total number of molecule
    2. The mean square speed
  2. So (1/3)Nm<c2> = NkT

    ∴ <c2> = 3kT/m

    <Ec> = (1/2)m<c2>

    ∴ (1/2)m(3kT/m) = (3/2)kT

    Where <Ek> = mean KE of a molecule
    1. for 1 molecule: Energy = (3/2)KT, T = 1 ∴ (3/2)K = (3/2)(1.38 × 10-23) = 2.07 × 10-23

      1 mole: 6.02 × 1023 molecules

      ∴ Energy required = 6.02 × 1023 × 2.07 × 10-23 = 12.4614 J

      ∴ Energy = 12.5 J
    2. Energy required is greater. This is because energy is needed to do work against the atmosphere.
    1. This was generally answered correctly in terms of the number of molecules, although there were some references to number of moles. 
    2. There was some confusion between mean-square speed, square of the mean speed and rootmean square speed. 
  2. This was generally completed successfully, although a significant minority gave very little evidence of the algebraic and arithmetical manipulation. 
    1. Candidates found this part difficult. It was common to find that the answer given was for one molecule. That is, the factor based on the Avogadro constant had been omitted. Candidates should be encouraged to carry out a quick mental check on the magnitude of their answers, and they could then have realised that the answer given was unrealistic.
    2. There were some correct answers based on the fact that work has to be done by the gas against the external pressure. Many thought that no energy would be required because the final temperature would not be different in the two situations.  
NO. 286题号：32175

The Earth may be considered to be a uniform sphere with its mass M concentrated at its centre.

A satellite of mass m orbits the Earth such that the radius of the circular orbit is r.

  1. Show that the linear speed v of the satellite is given by the expression
                  [2]

  2. For this satellite, write down expressions, in terms of G, M, m and r, for
    1. its kinetic energy,

      kinetic energy = …………………………. [1]
    2. its gravitational potential energy,

      potential energy = …………………………. [1] 
    3. its total energy.

      total energy = …………………………. [2]
  3. The total energy of the satellite gradually decreases.
    State and explain the effect of this decrease on
    1. the radius r of the orbit,

      ............................................................................. [2]
    2. the linear speed v of the satellite.

      ............................................................................. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Summer/Paper4/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a centripetal force is provided by gravitational force
mv2 / r = GMm / r2
hence v = √(GM / r)		 B1
B1
A0		 [2]
b.i EK (= ½mv2) = GMm / 2r B1 [1]
b.ii EP = - GMm / r B1 [1]
b.iii ET = - GMm / r + GMm / 2r
    = - GMm / 2r.		 C1
A1		 [2] 
c.i if ET decreases then - GMm / 2r becomes more negative
or GMm / 2r becomes larger
so r decreases		 M1
A1		 [2]
c.ii EK = GMm / 2r and r decreases
so (EK and) v increases		 M1
A1		 [2]
  1. Centripetal force is provided by the gravitational force

    ∴ GMm/r2 = mv2/r

    ∴ GM/r = v2

    ∴ v = √(GM/r)
    1. EK = (1/2)mv2 = (1/2)m(GM/r) = GMm/2r
    2. EP = -GMm/r
    3. T = EK + EP = (GMm/2r) - (GMm/r)

      = (GMm/r)[(1/2) - 1]

      = -GMm/2r
    1. r decreases.
      As ET, the total energy decreases, -(GMm/2r) becomes more negative i.e. GMm/2r becomes larger

      ∴ r must decrease
    2. v increases.
      When r decreases, EK = GMm/2r increases i.e. the kinetic energy increases

      Since KE = (1/2)mv2, v must increase
  1. Comparatively few candidates justified the equating of the formula for centripetal force with Newton's equation for gravitational force. Many implied an equilibrium situation, rather than the gravitational force providing the centripetal force.
    1. A pleasingly large number of candidates did arrive at a correct expression for the kinetic energy.
    2. There were many answers where the potential energy was given as a positive quantity. Candidates do need to be warned that they should distinguish clearly between upper- and lowercase letters. In this instance, many failed to distinguish between M an m, thus giving a final answer of M2 or m2. 
    3. With very few exceptions, candidates realised that they had to find the sum of the energies in (i) and (ii). Only a minority arrived at the correct expression. 
    1. There were very few correct responses, even amongst those candidates who had arrived at the correct expression in (b)(iii). The majority of candidates did not appreciate that, if the total energy decreases then the expression –GMm/2r becomes more negative and hence GMm/2r becomes larger.
    2. There were even fewer correct answers here. Candidates seemed to be reluctant to believe that a decrease in total energy could lead to an increase in speed.
NO. 287题号：32174

A rocket is launched from the surface of the Earth.

Fig. 4.1 gives data for the speed of the rocket at two heights above the Earth's surface, after the rocket engine has been switched off.

The Earth may be assumed to be a uniform sphere of radius R = 6.38 × 106m, with its mass M concentrated at its centre. The rocket, after the engine has been switched off, has mass m.

  1. Write down an expression in terms of
    1. G, M, m, h1, h2 and R for the change in gravitational potential energy of the rocket,
      ..................................................................... [1]
    2. m, v1and v2 for the change in kinetic energy of the rocket.
      ..................................................................... [1]
  2. Using the expressions in (a), determine a value for the mass M of the Earth.

    M = ………………………… kg [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2006/Winter/Paper4/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a.i GMm {(R + h1)–1 – (R + h2)–1} B1 [1]
a.ii ½m {v12 – v22} B1 [1]
b 2M × 6.67 × 10–11 {(26.28 × 106)–1 – (29.08 × 106)–1} = 53702 – 50902
M × 4.888 × 10–19 = 2.929 × 106
M = 6.00 × 1024 kg
(If equation in (a) is dimensionally unsound, then 0/3 marks in (b), if dimensionally sound but incorrect, treat as e.c.f.) 		 B1
C1
A1


 [3]


  2. Using a calculator M = 5.992 × 1024 = 6.00 × 1024 kg
    1. The majority of candidates appeared to know which formula to use but their mathematics failed them. For example, there is a widespread belief that 1/y + 1/x is equal to 1/(y + x) 
    2. A similar problem as regards mathematical ability arose here. Many candidates gave an incorrect answer as a result of a failure to use basic mathematics. For example, v12 – v22 was assumed to be equal to (v1 – v2)2. 
  2. Candidates were awarded credit here if the formulae quoted in (a) were dimensionally sound. This was an occasion where explained work, despite being numerically incorrect, could be given credit.
NO. 288题号：32168
  1. Define gravitational field strength.
    .......................................................................... [1]
  2. A spherical planet has diameter 1.2 × 104 km. The gravitational field strength at the surface of the planet is 8.6 N kg–1.
    The planet may be assumed to be isolated in space and to have its mass concentrated at its centre.
    Calculate the mass of the planet.

    mass = .......................................... kg [3]
  3. The gravitational potential at a point X above the surface of the planet in (b) is – 5.3 × 107 J kg–1.
    For point Y above the surface of the planet, the gravitational potential is – 6.8 × 107 J kg–1.
    1. State, with a reason, whether point X or point Y is nearer to the planet.
      .................................................................... [2]
    2. A rock falls radially from rest towards the planet from one point to the other. Calculate the final speed of the rock.

      speed = ...................................... m s–1 [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Summer/Paper4/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a force per unit mass (ratio idea essential)  B1 [1]
b g = GM / R2
8.6 × (0.6 × 107)2 = M × 6.67 × 10–11
M = 4.6 × 1024 kg		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
c.i either  potential decreases as distance from planet decreases
or  potential zero at infinity and X is closer to zero
or  potential α –1/r and Y more negative
so point Y is closer to planet.

M1
A1		 [2]
c.ii idea of ∆ϕ = ½v2
(6.8 – 5.3) × 107 = ½v2
v = 5.5 × 103 ms–1		 C1

A1		 [2]
  1. The gravitational field strength at a point is the gravitational force per unit mass at that point
  2. Use GMm/R2 = mg

    ∴ g = GM/R2

    ∴ M = gR2/G

    = [(8.6)(0.6 × 107)2]/(6.67 × 10-4)

    = 4.6417 × 1024 kg
    1. Y is rearer to the planet. That's because potential at infinity = 0 and ∅x is closer to 0
    2. |∆∅| = 6.8 × 107 - 5.3 × 107 = 1.5 × 107 J

      ∆Ep = m∆∅, ∆Ek = (1/2)mv2

      Equating m∆∅ = (1/2)mv2

      ∴ ∆∅ = (1/2)v2

      ∴ v = √(2∆∅) = √(2 × 1.5 × 107) = 5477.22 m/s = 5.5 × 103 m/s
  1. Definitions frequently lacked precision in that field strength was defined as 'force on a unit mass'. Candidates should realise that a ratio is involved and, consequently, give the definition as 'force per unit mass'. 
  2. Most candidates gave a correct mathematical expression for g. A failure either to use the radius, rather than the diameter, or to substitute distance in metres was common.
    1. In most scripts, the answer was given correctly as 'point Y'. However, explanation was sometimes less than adequate. Satisfactory answers involved stating that potential becomes more negative as the planet is approached. 
    2. A minority of candidates appreciated that the change in potential should be equated with ½v2. Others attempted answers that involved only one value of the potential.  
NO. 289题号：32167
  1. The Earth may be considered to be a uniform sphere of radius 6.38×103 km, with its mass concentrated at its centre.
    1. Define gravitational field strength.
      ............................................................... [1]
    2. By considering the gravitational field strength at the surface of the Earth, show that the mass of the Earth is 5.99×1024 kg. [2]

  2. The Global Positioning System (GPS) is a navigation system that can be used anywhere on Earth. It uses a number of satellites that orbit the Earth in circular orbits at a distance of 2.22×104 km above its surface.
    1. Use data from (a) to calculate the angular speed of a GPS satellite in its orbit.

      angular speed = ..................................... rad s–1 [3]
    2. Use your answer in (i) to show that the satellites are not in geostationary orbits. [3]

  3. The planes of the orbits of the GPS satellites in (b) are inclined at an angle of 55° to the Equator.
    Suggest why the satellites are not in equatorial orbits.
    ...................................................................... [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper4_2/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i force per (unit) mass ……(ratio idea essential) B1 [1]
a.ii g = GM / R2
9.81 = (6.67 × 10-11 × M) / (6.38 × 106)2 ……(all 3 s.f)
M = 5.99 × 1024 kg		 C1
M1
A0		 [2]
b.i either  GM = ω2r3  or  gR2 = ω2r3
either  6.67 × 10-11 x 5.99 × 1024 = ω2 × (2.86 × 107)3
or  9.81 × (6.38 × 106)2 = ω2 × (2.86 × 107)3
ω = 1.3 × 10-4 rad s-1
(use of r = 2.22 × 107 m scores max 2 marks)		 C1

C1
A1

 [3]
b.ii period of orbit = 2π / ω
   = 4.8 × 104 s (= 13.4 hours)
period for geostationary satellite is 24 hours (= 8.6 × 104 s)
so no		 C1
A1
A1
A0		 [3]
c satellite can then provide cover at Poles B1 [1]
    1. The gravitational field strength at a point is the gravitational force per unit mass at that point
    2. GMm/R2 = mg

      ∴ g = GM/R2, M = mass of earth

      ∴ M = gR2/G

      = [(9.81)(6.38 × 106)2]/(6.67 × 10-11)

      = 5.987 × 1024

      = 5.99 × 1024 kg
    1. GMm/r2 = mrω2

      ∴ GM = r3ω2, M = mass of earth

      Note: r = 2.22 × 107 + 6.38 × 106 = 28580000



      Angular speed = 1.3 × 10-4 rad/s
    2. ω = 2π/T

      ∴ T = 2π/ω = 2π/(1.3 × 10-4) = 48332 s = 13.4 hours

      Period for geostationary orbit = 24 hours

      ∴ Satellites not in geostationary orbits
  3. So that they can provide coverage at the poles.
    1. Most candidates correctly defined gravitational field strength as 'force per unit mass', although a small minority did not appreciate that a ratio is involved and therefore incorrectly defined it as 'force on a unit mass'. 
    2. Not all candidates realised that in order to calculate the mass of the Earth to 3 significant figures, it is necessary to substitute into the equation the value of the gravitational field strength to 3 significant figures. 
    1. There were few entirely correct answers. Many candidates confused the radius of the satellite's orbit with either the radius of the Earth or the height of the satellite above the Earth's surface. Another common error was a failure to substitute distance in units of metres. 
    2. There are a number of different ways of showing that the GPS satellite is not in a geostationary orbit. Most candidates showed either that it did not have the same angular speed as the Earth or that its period of orbit was not 24 hours. 
  3. Very few candidates appreciated that in order to enable them to provide cover at the Earth's poles, GPS satellites are not in equatorial orbits. 
NO. 290题号：32166
  1. State Newton's law of gravitation.
    ........................................................................ [2]
  2. The Earth may be considered to be a uniform sphere of radius R equal to 6.4 × 106 m.
    A satellite is in a geostationary orbit.
    1. Describe what is meant by a geostationary orbit.
      ............................................................... [3] 
    2. Show that the radius x of the geostationary orbit is given by the expression
               gR2 = x3ω2
      where g is the acceleration of free fall at the Earth's surface and ω is the angular speed of the satellite about the centre of the Earth. [3]

    3. Determine the radius x of the geostationary orbit.

      radius = ........................................... m [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper4_1/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a F ∝ Mm / R2 …..…(words or explained symbols)
either M and m are point masses
or R >> diameter of masses …(do not allow 'size')
 M1

A1		 [2]
b.i equatorial orbit
period 24 hours / same angular speed
from west to east / same direction of rotation
(allow one of the last two marks for 'always overhead' if 2nd or 3rd marks not scored)		 B1
B1
B1

 [3]
b.ii gravitational force provides centripetal force
/ gives rise to centripetal acceleration ….(in 'words')
GM / x2 = xω2
g = GM / R2
to give gR2 = x3ω2
B1
M1
M1
A0		 [3]
b.iii ω = 2π / (24 × 3600) = 7.27 × 10-5 rad s-1
9.81 × (6.4 × 106)2 = x3 × (7.27 × 10-5)2
x3 = 7.6 × 1022
x = 4.2 × 107 m
(use of g = 10 m s-2, loses 1 mark but once only in the Paper)		 C1
C1

A1

 [3]
    [Total: 11]
  1. Newton's law of universal gravitation states that every particle attracts every other particle in the universe with a force which is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between their centers.
    1. A geostationary orbit is directly above the equator, orbiting in the same direction as the earth spins and has an orbital period of 24 hours
    2. Gravitational force supplies the centripetal force

      GMm/x2 = mxω2, M = mass of earth

      ∴ GM = x3ω2

      ∴ gR2 = x3ω2

      GMm/R2 = mg

      ∴ GM = gR2
    3. ω = 2π/T = 2π/(24 × 3600) = 7.272 × 10-5 rad/s

      from x3 = gR2/ω2

  1. With few exceptions, a basic statement of Newton's law was given. However, relatively few answers included the condition that the law applies to point masses. 
    1. It was pleasing to note that few answers were based on a statement that 'the satellite appears to be overhead'. The period and direction of rotation of the satellite were expressed adequately in most scripts. Some candidates had problems when attempting to describe the fact that the satellite orbits in the equatorial plane. 
    2. A common problem was to equate centripetal force to gravitational force, giving the impression that there is an equilibrium situation. Candidates should make it clear that the centripetal force is provided by the gravitational force. Most answers scored either full credit or no credit for the algebra leading the given expression. 
    3. The most common problems were all associated with taking the squares of quantities and taking the square root, rather than the cube root, for the final answer.
NO. 291题号：32164
  1. Define the radian.

    ..........................................................................................................................................
    ..........................................................................................................................................
    ......................................................................................................................................[2]

  2. A stone of weight 3.0 N is fixed, using glue, to one end P of a rigid rod CP, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

    The rod is rotated about end C so that the stone moves in a vertical circle of radius 85 cm.
    The angular speed ω of the rod and stone is gradually increased from zero until the glue snaps. The glue fixing the stone snaps when the tension in it is 18 N.
    For the position of the stone at which the glue snaps,
    1. on the dotted circle of Fig. 1.1, mark with the letter S the position of the stone, [1]


    2. calculate the angular speed ω of the stone.







      angular speed = ................................... rad s–1 [4]

[Total: 7]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper4_1/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a angle (subtended) at centre of circle
(by) arc equal in length to radius		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.i point S shown below C B1 [1]
b.ii (max) force / tension = weight + centripetal force
centripetal force = mrω2
15 = 3.0/9.8 × 0.85 × ω2 
ω = 7.6 rad s–1		 C1
C1
C1
A1		 [4]
  1. Radian is the angle subtended at the centre of a circle by an arc equal in length to the radius





    2. Towards the centre: mrω2

      T - mg = mrω2

      ∴ 18 - 3 = (3/9.81)(85/100)ω2

      ∴ ω = 7.596 rad/s

      Angular speed = 7.6 rad/s
  1. Some candidates attempted to define 'angular displacement' rather than the 'radian'. One radian is that angle subtended at the centre of a circle by an arc equal in length to the radius.
    1. Only a minority of candidates realised that the glue snaps when the stone is vertically below point C. 
    2. Fully correct answers were rare. The most common error was to equate the centripetal force to the tension, without making any allowance for the weight of the stone.
NO. 292题号：32163

A planet of mass m is in a circular orbit of radius r about the Sun of mass M, as illustrated in Fig. 1.1.

The magnitude of the angular velocity and the period of revolution of the planet about the Sun are ω and T respectively.

  1. State
    1. what is meant by angular velocity,
      ....................................................................[2]
    2. the relation between ω and T.
      ....................................................................[2]
  2. Show that, for a planet in a circular orbit of radius r, the period T of the orbit is given by the expression
                  T2 = cr3
    where c is a constant. Explain your working. [4]

  3. Data for the planets Venus and Neptune are given in Fig. 1.2.

    Assume that the orbits of both planets are circular.
    1. Use the expression in (b) to calculate the value of T for Neptune.

      T = ....................................... years [2]
    2. Determine the linear speed of Venus in its orbit.

      speed = ..................................... km s–1 [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper4_3/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i rate of change of angle / angular displacement
swept out by radius		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii ω × T = 2π B1 [1]
b centripetal force is provided by the gravitational force
either  mr(2π/T)2 = GMm/r 2  or  mrω2 = GMm/r2
r3 × 4π2 = GM × T2
GM/4π2 is a constant (c)
T2 = cr3		 B1
M1
A1
A1
A0		 [4]
c.i either  T2 = (45/1.08)3 × 0.6152 or T2 = 0.30 × 453 
T = 165 years		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.ii speed = (2π × 1.08 × 108) / (0.615 × 365 × 24 × 3600)
          = 35 km s–1		 C1
A1		 [2]
    1. For an object moving in a circle, it is the angle swept out in unit time by the radius joining the object to the circle centre.
      It is the rate of change of angle swept out by the radius.
    2. ω = 2π/T
  2. Centripetal force is provided by the gravitational force

    So GMm/r2 = mrω2

    ∴ GM/r2 = r(2π/T)2

    ∴ T2GM = 4π2r3

    ∴ T2 = (4π2/GM)r3

    ∴ T2 = cr3, which c = 4π2/GM
    1. Use T2 = cr3

      ∴ Tv2/rv3 = TN2/rN3

      ∴ TN2 = (rN/rv)3Tv2 = (45/1.08)3(0.615)2

      ∴ TN = 165.4

      T = 165 years
    1. Many answers included statements such as 'angle swept out per unit time' or 'rate of change of angular displacement'. Comparatively few answers made it clear that it is the radius linking the Sun to the planet that creates this angle or angular displacement. 
    2. The correct expression was stated by the vast majority of the candidates.
  2. Most answers simply equated the centripetal force to the gravitational force. This gives the impression that there is an equilibrium situation. Candidates should make it clear that the centripetal force is provided by the gravitational force. 
    1. There were many fully correct answers. The data for Venus needed to have the same units as the data for Neptune when used in the calculation.
    2. This part of the question was generally well answered. The conversion of the period of Venus from units of years to seconds caused a problem for some candidates.  
NO. 293题号：32161
  1. Newton's law of gravitation applies to point masses.
    1. State Newton's law of gravitation.
      ..............................................................................[2]
    2. Explain why, although the planets and the Sun are not point masses, the law also applies to planets orbiting the Sun.
      ..............................................................................[1]
  2. Gravitational fields and electric fields show certain similarities and certain differences. State one aspect of gravitational and electric fields where there is
    1. a similarity,
      ..............................................................................[1]
    2. a difference.
      ..............................................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper4_1/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a.i force proportional to product of masses
force inversely proportional to square of separation		 B1
B1		 [2]
a.ii separation much greater than radius / diameter of Sun / planet B1 [1]
b.i e.g. force or field strength ∝ 1 / r2
potential ∝ 1 / r		 B1 [1]
b.ii e.g. gravitational force (always) attractive
electric force attractive or repulsive		 B1
B1		 [2]
    1. Newton's law of universal gravitation states that every particle attracts every other particle in the universe with a force which is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between their centers.
    2. The distance separating them is much greater than the radius of the sun/planet
    1. Both potentials are ∝ 1/r
    2. Gravitational forces are always attractive

      Electric forces can be attractive or repulsive
    1. There were many good answers. A common error was to refer vaguely to 'distance' rather than the 'distance between masses'. Candidates who attempted to state the law by reference to an equation needed to explain all the symbols used.
    2. Candidates should realise that Newton’s law of gravitation applies because the diameters of a planet and the Sun are very much less than the distance between them.
    1. The similarity was sometimes stated to be an 'inverse square law', but without making it clear what quantity follows this law.
    2. With few exceptions, a correct answer was given. Most candidates identified that gravitational force is always attractive, while electric force can be attractive or repulsive. 
NO. 294题号：32157
  1. Define gravitational potential at a point.
    ............................................................................. [1]
  2. The gravitational potential ϕ at distance r from point mass M is given by the expression
             
    where G is the gravitational constant. 
    Explain the significance of the negative sign in this expression.
    .............................................................................. [2]
  3. A spherical planet may be assumed to be an isolated point mass with its mass concentrated at its centre. A small mass m is moving near to, and normal to, the surface of the planet. The mass moves away from the planet through a short distance h.

    State and explain why the change in gravitational potential energy ΔEP of the mass is given by the expression
              ΔEP = mgh
    where g is the acceleration of free fall.
    .......................................................................... [4]
  4. The planet in (c) has mass M and diameter 6.8 × 103 km. The product GM for this planet is 4.3 × 1013 N m2 kg–1.

    A rock, initially at rest a long distance from the planet, accelerates towards the planet. Assuming that the planet has negligible atmosphere, calculate the speed of the rock as it hits the surface of the planet.

    speed = ....................................... m s–1 [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper4_1/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a work done in bringing unit mass from infinity (to the point) B1 [1]
b gravitational force is (always) attractive
either  as r decreases, object/mass/body does work
or  work is done by masses as they come together		 B1

B1		 [2]
c either force on mass = mg (where g is the acceleration of free fall /gravitational field strength)
g = GM/r2
if r @ h, g is constant
∆EP = force × distance moved
= mgh
B1
B1
B1
M1
A0		 [4]
or  ∆EP = m∆ϕ
     = GMm(1/r1 – 1/r2) = GMm(r2 – r1)/r1r2
     if r2 ≈ r1, then (r2 – r1) = h and r1r2 = r2
     g = GM/r2
     ∆EP = mgh		 (C1)
(B1)
(B1)
(B1)
(A0)		  
d ½mv2 = m∆ϕ
v2 = 2 × GM/r
    = (2 × 4.3 × 1013) / (3.4 × 106)
v = 5.0 × 103 ms–1
(Use of diameter instead of radius to give v = 3.6 × 103 ms–1 scores 2 marks) 
C1
C1
A1

 [3]
  1. The gravitational potential at a point is the work done in moving a unit mass from infinity to that point
  2. Gravitational force is an attractive force

    When r increases, work is done against the attractive force, giving an object a gain in potential energy. The potential at infinity = 0 by convertion.
  3. We know ∆Ep = m∆φ i.e. mass × change in potential (by definition)



  4. Loss in GPE = Gain in KE

    GMm/r = (1/2)mv2

    ∴ v2 = 2GM/r = 2 × 4.3 × 1013/3.4 × 106

    ∴ v = 5.029 × 103 m/s
  1. There were many good answers. A common error was to refer to one kilogram instead of unit mass. 
  2. Many candidates correctly explained that gravitational force is always attractive. However, few went on to explain that a body in the gravitational field will do work as it moves from infinity.
  3. There was more than one method of deriving the correct expression. Most candidates considered the work done to move the small mass by a short distance. In order to gain full credit, candidates needed to show each step in their derivation and fully explain any approximations that are used. Candidates also needed to explain any symbols that were not explained in the stem of the question.
  4. The calculation presented few problems for well-prepared candidates. However, a significant minority equated an expression for the gravitational force to an inappropriate expression of centripetal force. Others confused the planet's radius with its diameter. 
NO. 295题号：32154
  1. State what is meant by a gravitational field.
    ................................................................................[2]
  2. In the Solar System, the planets may be assumed to be in circular orbits about the Sun. Data for the radii of the orbits of the Earth and Jupiter about the Sun are given in Fig. 1.1.

    1. State Newton's law of gravitation.
      ...................................................................................[3]
    2. Use Newton's law to determine the ratio


      ratio = ................................................. [3]
  3. The orbital period of the Earth about the Sun is T.
    1. Use ideas about circular motion to show that the mass M of the Sun is given by
               
      where R is the radius of the Earth's orbit about the Sun and G is the gravitational constant. Explain your working. [3]

    2. The orbital period T of the Earth about the Sun is 3.16 × 107 s. 
      The radius of the Earth's orbit is given in Fig. 1.1. 
      Use the expression in (i) to determine the mass of the Sun.

      mass = ............................................ kg [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper4_1/Q1
Question Answer Marks  
a region of space area / volume
where a mass experiences a force		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.i force proportional to product of two masses
force inversely proportional to the square of their separation
either  reference to point masses or separation >> 'size' of masses		 M1
M1
A1		 [3]
b.ii field strength = GM / x2 or field strength ∝ 1 / x2
ratio = (7.78 × 108)2 / (1.5 × 108)2
        = 27		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
c.i either  centripetal force = mRω2 and ω = 2π / T
or  centripetal force = mv2 / R and v = 2πR /T
gravitational force provides the centripetal force
either GMm / R2 = mRω2 or  GMm / R2 = mv2 / R
M = 4π2R3 / GT2
(allow working to be given in terms of acceleration)
B1
B1
M1
A0

 [3]
c.ii M = {4π2 × (1.5 × 1011)3} / {6.67 × 10–11 × (3.16 × 107)2}
    = 2.0 × 1030 kg		 C1
A1		 [2]
  1. A gravitational field is a region around a body that has mass, in which another body with mass experiences a force
    1. Newton's law of universal gravitation states that every particle attracts every other particle in the universe with a force which is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between their centers.
    2. Let (gravitational field strength due to the Sun at orbit of Earth) be GE

      Let (gravitational field strength due to the Sun at orbit of Jupiter) be GJ

      Gravitational field strength (GFS) = GM/r2, M = mass of Sun is contants, G is contants

      GFS ∝ 1/r2, so we can write



      Ratio = 27 : 1
    1. Gravitational force provides the centripetal force

      So GMm/R2 = mRω2, m = mass of earth, ω = 2π/T

      ∴ GM/R2 = R(2π/T)2

      ∴ GM/R2 = R(4π2/T2)

      ∴ M = 4π2R3/GT2
  1. It was generally understood that a gravitational field is a region of space where a mass experiences a force. A small minority of answers gave an inappropriate definition of gravitational field strength.
    1. With few exceptions, a basic statement of Newton's law of gravitation was given. Relatively few answers included the condition that the law applies to point masses.
    2. Although most answers included the correct expression for gravitational field strength, two common errors were evident in the ensuing calculation of the ratio. These were calculating the inverse of the required ratio and not squaring the radii of the orbits.
    1. The derivation of the expression for the mass of the Sun often consisted of pure algebraic working without any accompanying explanation.
