They then did not use the 30 dB signal-to-noise ratio at the receiver when calculating the length of the fibre. 
NO. 434题号：1562
    1. Describe what is meant by frequency modulation.
      ....................................................................................[2]
    2. A sinusoidal carrier wave has frequency 500 kHz and amplitude 6.0 V. It is to be frequency modulated by a sinusoidal wave of frequency 8 kHz and amplitude 1.5 V.
      The frequency deviation of the carrier wave is 20 kHz V-1.
      Describe, for the carrier wave, the variation (if any) of
      1. the amplitude,
        ...........................................................................[1]
      2. the frequency.
        ...........................................................................[3]
  2. State two reasons why the cost of FM broadcasting to a particular area is greater than that of AM broadcasting.
    1 ...........................................................................
    2 ........................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2008/Summer/Paper4/Q11
Question Answer Marks  
a.i frequency of carrier wave varies
in synchrony with displacement of information signal		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii 1. zero (accept constant) B1 [1]
2. upper limit 530 kHz
   lower limit 470 kHz
   changes upper limit → lower limit → upper limit at 8000 s–1		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
b e.g. more radio stations required / shorter range
    more complex electronics
    larger bandwidth required
(any two sensible suggestions, 1 each)		 B2 [2]
    1. The frequency of the carrier wave vary in synchrony with the displacement of the information signal.
      1. the amplitude: No change
      2. the frequency: The frequency of carrier wave vary with the frequency of information signal i.e; its upper limit changes to lower limit and than back to upper limit at 8 kHz.
        Also
        1 V deviate the frequency of carrier wave by = 20 kHg
        1.5 V deviate the frequency of carrier wave by = 1.5 × 20 = 30 kHz.
        So
        Upper limit frequency = (500 + 30) × 103 = 530 kHz
        Lower limit frequency = (500 - 30) × 103 = 470 kHz.
    1. FM transmitter has shorter range (30 km by line of sight) so greater transmitters are required to broadcast to a larger area.
    2. FM transmitter and receiver are electronically complex and occupy a much greater band witdh than those of AM.

Comment on answer

(a) (ii) The amplitude of the carrier wave does not vary.

    1. Many candidates had learned to quote this answer perfectly. 
    2. In 1, most gave the correct answer. However, in 2, very few attempted to give a quantitative description based on the given data. Of those who did attempt a quantitative analysis, many gave an incorrect frequency range.
  2. A common answer was that FM is more expensive, without giving a reason. Others referred to repeater amplifiers, rather than transmission stations. There were, however, many references to the range of FM broadcasts and also bandwidth.

(c)(1) Period of carrier wave

(2) Period of modulating waveform,

             fa = 5 kHz

  1. The section was answered well by many candidates but it was clear that some others had not studied this topic. 
  2. There were very few incorrect answers. Either candidates could give the correct answer or the answer space was left blank. 
  3. Sketches were, in general, poor. Many drew an unmodulated carrier wave whilst others drew only the envelope. 
NO. 436题号：1548

    ..........................................................................................................................................

  2. The attenuation of a parallel beam of X-ray radiation is given by the expression


    where µ is the linear attenuation (absorption) coefficient and x is the thickness of the material through which the beam passes.
    1. State
      1. what is meant by attenuation,

        ..................................................................................................................................

      2. why the expression applies only to a parallel beam.

        ..................................................................................................................................

        ........................................................................................................................... [2]

    2. The linear attenuation coefficients for X-rays in bone and in soft tissue are 2.9 cm–1 and 0.95 cm–1 respectively.
      Calculate, for a parallel X-ray beam, the ratio







      ratio = .................................................. [2]

[Total: 7]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper4_2/Q11
Question Answer Marks  
a changing voltage changes energy / speed of electrons
changing electron energy changes maximum X-ray photon energy		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i 1. loss of power / energy / intensity B1 [1]
2. intensity changes when beam not parallel
    decreases when beam is divergent		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii ratio = (exp {–2.9 × 2.5}) / (exp {–0.95 × 6.0})
        = 0.21 (min. 2 sig. fig.)
(values of both lengths incorrect by factor of 10–2 to give ratio of 0.985 scores 1 mark)		 C1
A1

 [2]
  1. Change in accelerating voltage changes the speed or kinetic energy of electrons, which therefore changes the maximum energy of X-ray photons.
      1. The decrease in intensity or power due to loss of energy in doing work against particles of a medium.
      2. Because intensity changes when a beam is not parallel i.e. intensity decreases when a beam is divergent.

Comment on answer

(a) Hardness is associated with the penetration of x-rays which depend upon their energy.

  1. Many answers dealt with anode voltage and hardness without any consideration of electron energy. There was widespread confusion between the beam of electrons and the X-ray beam. A significant number of answers linked anode voltage with the rate of production of electrons. 
    1. 1. The majority of answers were correct.
      2. There were very few answers based on the notion that the intensity of a non-parallel beam changes, even when there is no absorption. The most common answer was based on the fact that either the expression for attenuation does not involve an angle or that the coefficient is referred to as a linear coefficient.
    2. There were many correct answers. Some candidates lost all credit as a result of making what was probably an arithmetical error but none of their working was shown.

A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper4_2/Q10
Question Answer Marks  
a e.g. beam is divergent/obeys inverse square law
 absorption (in block)
 scattering (of beam in block)
 reflection (at boundaries)
(any two sensible suggestions, 1 each)		 B2 [2]
b.i    I = I0exp(–µx)
I0/I = exp(0.27 × 2.4)
    = 1.9		 C1

A1		 [2]
b.ii I0/I = exp(0.27 × 1.3) × exp(3.0 × 1.1)
     = 1.42 × 27.1
     = 38.5		 C1

A1		 [2]
c either  much greater absorption in bone than in soft tissue
or  I0/I much greater for bone than soft tissue		 B1 [1]
    1. The intensity of parallel X-ray beam decreases due to absorption in block.
    2. Parallel beam is also scattered in the block.
  3. Bone is a good absorber of x-rays than soft tissue. So photographic is blackened at soft tissue side and white at bone side.
Comment on answer

(a) • Some part of X-ray beam is reflected at boundaries of two media.
     • Beam also obeys inverse square law if it is divergent.

(b) (ii)

I = I1e-µbonexbone
I = (I0e-µtissuextissue)(e-µbonexbone)

(c) Good contrast is achieved if there is a clear difference in the blackening of the photographic film.

  1. In general, attenuation or absorption was mentioned. Those who stated that point B is at a greater distance than point A were not given credit unless it was also stated that the beam is either parallel or divergent.
    1. Many candidates calculated the inverse of the expected ratio.
    2. A common error was to calculate the ratios for the bone and the soft tissue and then to add these two quantities, rather than find the product.
  3. Most candidates did not consider the two ratios when answering this part. Rather, they commented on the two values of μ, without any consideration of the thickness or composition.
NO. 438题号：1529
    1. State what is meant by the acoustic impedance of a medium.

      ..................................................................................................................................

      Use data from Fig. 10.1 to calculate a value for the density of bone.

  2. A parallel beam of ultrasound has intensity I. It is incident at right-angles to a boundary between two media, as shown in Fig. 10.2.


    The media have acoustic impedances of Z1 and Z2 The transmitted intensity of the ultrasound beam is IT and the reflected intensity is IR.
    1. State the relation between I, IT and IR.

      ..............................................................................................................................[1]

    2. The reflection coefficient α is given by the expression
                         
      Use data from Fig. 10.1 to determine the reflection coefficient α for a boundary between
      1. gel and soft tissue,



          α = ...................................... [2]
      2. air and soft tissue.





          α = ...................................... [1]

  3. By reference to your answers in (b)(ii), explain the use of a gel on the surface of skin during ultrasound diagnosis.

    ..........................................................................................................................................
    ..........................................................................................................................................
    ..........................................................................................................................................
    .....................................................................................................................................[3]

[Total: 9]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper4_2/Q10
Question Answer Marks  
a.i density × speed of wave (in the medium) B1 [1]
a.ii ρ = (7.0 × 106) / 4100 
  = 1700kgm–3		 A1 [1]
b.i I = IT + IR B1 [1]
b.ii 1. α = (0.1 × 106)2 / (3.1 × 106)2
       = 0.001		 C1
A1		 [2]
2. α ≈ 1  A1 [1]
c either  very little transmission at an air-skin boundary
  (almost) complete transmission at a gel-skin boundary
  when wave travels in or out of the body		 M1
M1
A1		 [3]
or  no gel, majority reflection
  with gel, little reflection
  when wave travels in or out of the body		 (M1)
(M1)
(A1)
    1. Product of density of a medium and the speed of sound wave in it.
      Z = ρc
    2.             Z = ρc
      7.0 × 106 = ρ(4100)
                   ρ = 1.71 × 103 kgm-3
    1. I = IT + IR
  3. For air and soft tissue, α ≈ 1, practically very little sound is transmitted into the second medium and maximum is reflected back while with gel, maximum sound is transmitted and very little is reflected back when wave travel in or out of the body.
    1. Of those candidates who defined acoustic impedance as the product ρc, most could state what is meant by ρ but many referred to c as merely 'speed'. A minority thought that c is the speed of light.
    2. The calculation presented very few problems.
    1. Most answers were correct although a significant minority gave the answer I = IT/IR.
    2. Most answers were correct.
  3. Many candidates limited their answers to a statement that the gel would reduce reflection at the skin and thus were only awarded partial credit. The relative intensities for both transmission and reflection should have been considered. Furthermore, most answers considered only ultrasound entering the body and not returning to the transducer. 
NO. 439题号：1526
  1. A typical spectrum of the X-ray radiation produced by electron bombardment of a metal target is illustrated in Fig. 10.1.

    Explain why
    1. a continuous spectrum of wavelengths is produced,
      .................................................................. [3]
    2. the spectrum has a sharp cut-off at short wavelengths.
      .................................................................. [3]
  2. The variation with photon energy E of the linear absorption coefficient µ of X-rays in soft tissue is illustrated in Fig. 10.2.

    1. Explain what is meant by linear absorption coefficient
      ................................................................... [3]
    2. For one particular application of X-ray imaging, electrons in the X-ray tube are accelerated through a potential difference of 50 kV.
      Use Fig. 10.2 to explain why it is advantageous to filter out low-energy photons from the X-ray beam.
      ................................................................... [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper4_2/Q10
Question Answer Marks  
a.i e.m. radiation / photons is produced whenever a charged particle is accelerated
wavelength depens on magnitude of acceleration
electrons have a distribution of accelerations
so continuous spectrum		 M1
A1
A1
A0		 [3]
a.ii either  when electron loses all its energy in one collision
or  when energy of electron produces a single photon		 B1 [1]
b.i parallel beam (in matter)
I = I0 exp(-µx)
I, I0, (µ) and x explained		 B1
M1
A1		 [3]
b.ii either low-energy photons absorbed (much) more readily
or low-energy photons (far) less penetrating
low-energy photons do not contribute to X-ray image
low energy photons could cause tissue damage
B1
B1
B1		 [3]
    [Total: 10]
    1. X-ray are produced when fast moving electrons penetrate deep into an atom and come very close to a highly-charged nucleus which causes the electrons to swerve in their paths and to decelerate. The decrease in kinetic energy is radiated away as an X-ray photon. Millions of such electrons participating in this process give rise to a continuous spectrum. Different wavelengths are obtained which depends upon the magnitude of the deceleration.
    2. When electron loses all its energy in one collision in the metal target and comes to rest.
    1. Parallel beam of X-rays of intensity I0 are incident normally on matter having thickness x and the transmitted intensity is I. Then the relation between them is I = I0 e-µx where µ is the linear absorption coefficient.
    2. Low energy photons are less penetrating and are absorbed so that they could result in tissue damage. Also low energy photons do not make any contribution to the X-ray image.

Comment on answer

(a) (i) 
                
          where  is the energy of the photon of X-ray radiated away.
(ii) The shortest wavelength is produced when
          

    1. Only a small minority of candidates were able to explain that X-ray radiation is produced when the electrons are decelerated at the metal target. Since the electrons have a distribution of decelerations, there will be a continuous spectrum of wavelengths produced because the wavelength is dependent upon the magnitude of the deceleration. A common misconception was to believe that it is the electron's acceleration between the cathode and anode of the X-ray tube that is responsible for producing the X-ray radiation. Another common error was to describe the process that is responsible for producing the sharp intensity peaks. 
    2. With very few exceptions, it was not understood that the sharp cut-off at short wavelengths corresponds to an electron that is stopped in one collision in the metal target so that all of its kinetic energy is given up as one X-ray photon. 
    1. Although some candidates recalled the expression I = I0e–μx, very few went on to explain the symbols or to state that the expression applies to a parallel beam in a medium. 
    2. Some answers correctly explained that the low energy photons are less penetrating and are absorbed so that this could result in tissue damage. However, it was seldom pointed out that the low energy photons do not make any contribution to the X-ray image. One common mistake was to state that these photons affect either the sharpness or contrast of the image. Another was to state that the photons are unable to penetrate the surface of the skin. Candidates should avoid making vague and incomplete statements such as 'low energy photons are harmful' or 'low energy photons do not serve any useful purpose'. 
NO. 440题号：1524
  1. Explain the main principles behind the use of ultrasound to obtain diagnostic information about internal body structures.
    .................................................................................. [4]
  2. Data for the acoustic impedances and absorption (attenuation) coefficients of muscle and bone are given in table.
      acoustic im~edance / kg m-2 s-1 absorption coefficient / m-1
    muscle 1.7 × 106 23
    bone 6.3 × 106 130
    The intensity reflection coefficient is given by the expression
                           
    The attenuation of ultrasound in muscle follows a similar relation to the attenuation of X-rays in matter.
    A parallel beam of ultrasound of intensity 1 enters the surface of a layer of muscle of thickness 4.1 cm as shown in Fig.11.2.

    The ultrasound is reflected at a muscle-bone boundary and returns to the surface of the muscle.
    Calculate
    1. the intensity reflection coefficient at the muscle-bone boundary,

      coefficient = ............................................... [2]
    2. the fraction of the incident intensity that is transmitted from the surface of the muscle to the surface of the bone,

      fraction = ............................................... [2]
    3. the intensity, in terms of I, that is received back at the surface of the muscle.

      intensity = ............................................ I [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Summer/Paper4/Q11
Question Answer Marks  
a pulse of ultrasound (1)
reflected at boundaries / boundary (1)
received / detected (at surface) by transducer (1)
signal processed and displayed (1)
time between transmission and receipt of pulse gives
(information about) depth of boundary (1)
reflected intensity gives information as to nature of boundary (1)
(any four points, 1 each, max 4) 		 B4 [4]
b.i coefficient = (Z2 – Z1)2 / (Z2 + Z1)2
   = (6.3 – 1.7)2 / (6.3 + 1.7)2
   = 0.33 (unit quoted, then –1) 
C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii fraction = exp(–µx)
   = exp(–23 × 4.1 × 10–2)
   = 0.39		 C1

A1		 [2]
b.iii intensity = 0.33 × 0.392 × I
   = 0.050 I
(do not allow e.c.f. from (i) and (ii) if these answers are greater than 1)		 C1
A1

 [2]
  1. Pulse of ultrasound is transmitted into the body using a coupling medium which is reflected back from boundaries of different interfaces (mediums). The reflected pulse is received by the transducer probe and is processed to display on a screen. The amplitude/intensity of received signal provides information about the nature of boundary. The time between transmission and receipt of pulse gives information about depth of boundary.
    3. Received intensity = (0.33)(0.39)2 I = 0.050 I

Comment on answer
(a) Ultrasound is in pulse form because the piezoelectric crystal must come to rest after transmitting a signal and before receiving its echo due to critical damping by its backing material in the ultrasound probe.

  1. In general, this was answered well although, in a significant number of answers, it was not stated that either the ultrasound has to be pulsed or that the received pulses must be processed and displayed.
    1. Many answers were disappointing, with a significant number of candidates not realising that the equation for the coefficient was given to them. Many others substituted absorption coefficient, rather than acoustic impedance. 
    2. Many candidates did not attempt this part of the question.
    3. Again, there were many scripts where this question was not attempted. In general, candidates who had completed parts (i) and (ii) were able to complete the calculation successfully.
NO. 441题号：1520
  1. Distinguish between the images produced by CT scanning and X-ray imaging.
    ...............................................................................[3]
  2. By reference to the principles of CT scanning, suggest why CT scanning could not be developed before powerful computers were available.
    ...............................................................................[5]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2008/Winter/Paper4/Q11
Question Answer Marks  
a CT image: (thin) slice (through structure)
any further detail e.g. built up from many 'slices' / 3-D image
X-ray image: 'shadow' image (of whole structure) / 2-D image		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
b X-ray image of slice taken from many different angles (1)
these images are combined (and processed) (1)
repeated for many different slices (1)
to build up a 3-D image (1)
3-D image can be rotated (1)
computer required to store and process huge quantity of data (1)
(any five, 1 each to max 5) 		 B5 [5]
  1. The X-ray image is a "flat 2D image" of whole structure and does not give any impression of depth. CT scan takes many 2D images of a slice at different angles which then combine these images to give an image of slice. Images of successive slices can be combined to give a three dimensional image. This 3D image can be rotated and viewed from any angle.
  2. In CT scanning, a series of X-ray images are obtained from different angles through a slice. These images are combined and processed to give the image of the slice. This is repeated for other successive slices and images of successive slices are combined to give a three dimensional image. Computer program process this huge quantity of data and store the results. The image can be rotated and can be viewed at any angle again by a computer software.
  1. Most answers were restricted to a comment based on two-dimensional and three-dimensional images. In some scripts, there were references to the colours of the images. 
  2. Suggestions were very confused and inaccurate, indicating that the great majority of candidates did not appreciate how the image in a CT scan is built up. Many candidates thought that taking X-ray images from many angles built up a 3-dimensional image of the whole object, rather than one thin section through the object. The role of the computer to store and to process huge quantities of data was seldom clearly expressed. 
NO. 442题号：1518

Outline briefly the main principles of the use of magnetic resonance to obtain information about internal body structures.

.................................................................................................[8]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2008/Summer/Paper4/Q10
Question Answer Marks  
10 large / strong (constant) magnetic field  B1 [8]
nuclei rotate about direction of field / precess (1)
radio frequency / r.f. pulse		 B1
causes resonance in nuclei , nuclei absorb energy (1)
(pulse) is at the Larmor frequency (1)
on relaxation / nuclei de-excite emit (pulse of) r.f.		 B1
detected and processed B1
non-uniform field (superimposed) B1
allows for position of nuclei to be determined B1
and for location of detection to be changed (1)
(B6 plus any two extra details, 1 each, max 2)		 B2

Nuclei having odd number of either protons or neutrons behave like tiny magnets due to their spin. If a strong magnetic field is applied, these nuclei will align themselves with it. The direction of the magnetic axis of a nucleus rotates around the direction of the external field just as the axis of a spinning top rotates; this is called precession. The frequency of precession is called lamour frequency and lie in radio frequency region of electromagnetic spectrum.

If the precessing nuclei aligned in the external magnetic field are subject to short pulse of RF equal to lamour frequency, resonance occur and energy is transferred to the nuclei, which cause some of them to flip from the lower energy level to higher energy alignment. After an RF pulse ends, the nuclei return to their original state on relaxation by two electromagnetic processes. These RF radiations are received and processed to provide an image on the console.

Non-uniform magnetic field is charged to detect the atoms in different parts in the person.

There were some very good answers and many more where the basic facts had been learned. However, in these descriptions, it was common to find that MRI was thought to be associated with atoms, rather than nuclei, and the use of r.f. pulses was not understood. There were numerous attempts where it was clear that the candidate had no real understanding of the application. Frequently, there were elements of MRI, ultrasound diagnosis, X-ray and CAT scanning all included. 

NO. 443题号：1515
  1. State what is meant by acoustic impedance.
    ..............................................................................[1]
  2. Explain why acoustic impedance is important when considering reflection of ultrasound at the boundary between two media.
    ...............................................................................[2]
  3. Explain the principles behind the use of ultrasound to obtain diagnostic information about structures within the body.
    ...............................................................................[5]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2007/Winter/Paper4/Q9
Question Answer Marks  
a product of density (of medium) and speed of sound (in medium) B1 [1]
b difference in acoustic impedance
determines fraction of incident intensity
that is reflected/amount of reflection		 M1

A1		 [2]
c pulse of ultrasound (directed into body)
reflected at boundary (between tissues)
(reflected pulse is) detected and processed
time for return of echo gives (information on) depth
amount of reflection gives information on tissue structures		 B1
B1
B1
B1
B1		 [5]
  1. Product of density of a medium and the speed of sound in it is called acoustic impedance.
    Z = ρc
    Here c is the speed of sound in that medium, not thespeed of light.
  2. The difference in acoustic impedance Z between the two materials determine the reflected portion of incident intensity.

    Greater the difference in Z between two materials, the greater is the reflected part of the incident pulse.
  3. Ultrasound pulse from the transducer / transmitter is directed into the body and is reflected at boundaries between two media. The reflected pulse is detected by transducer / receiver and is processed. The time of return of echo gives information of depth and the amount of reflection gives information on tissue structure.

There was clear evidence that some candidates had not studied this topic.

  1. Of those candidates who defined acoustic impedance as the product ρc, most could state what is meant by ρ but many referred to c as 'the speed of light' or merely 'speed'. 
  2. Most candidates did not seem to appreciate that it is the change in acoustic impedance at a boundary that governs the fraction of the incident wave intensity that is reflected. Most candidates who attempted this part of the question were content to write about individual media.
  3. There were some very good accounts here but equally, it was clear that some candidates had little knowledge or understanding of the situation. Indeed, some candidates included aspects of MRI and CT scanning in their accounts.
    Even amongst better accounts, the role of the transducer as not only a transmitter but also a receiver was not made clear. 
NO. 444题号：1500

An electronic sensor may be represented by the block diagram of Fig. 9.1.

  1. State the function of the processing unit.
    ......................................................................[2]
  2. A student designs a sensing unit for temperature change. A 4V supply, a fixed resistor of resistance 2.5 kΩ and a thermistor are available. The thermistor has resistance 3.0kΩ at 6°C and resistance 1.8kΩ at 20 °C.
    Complete the circuit diagram of Fig.9.2 to show how the resistor and the thermistor are connected to provide an output that is greater than 2V at 6 °C and less than 2V at 20°C. Mark clearly the output VOUT. [3]
  3. Suggest two uses of a relay as part of an output device.
    1. ......................................................................
    2. ...................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Winter/Paper4_1/Q9
Question Answer Marks  
a operates on / takes signal from sensing device
(so that) it gives an voltage output		 B1
B1		 [2]
b thermistor and resistor in series between +4 V line and earth
VOUT shown clearly across either thermistor or resistor
VOUT shown clearly across thermistor		 M1
A1
A1		 [3]
c e.g. remote switching
 e.g. switching large current by means of a small current
 e.g. isolating circuit from high voltage
 e.g. switching high voltage by means of a small voltage/current
(any two sensible suggestions, 1 each to max. 2)		 B2 [2]
  1. It compares the signal from the sensing device with a pre-defined criteria to provide an output voltage to output device.
    1. To switch ON/OFF a high current circuit by means of low current.
    2. It isolates the main circuit from high voltage used to operate another circuit.

Comment on answer

(b) 

  1. Candidates should avoid paraphrasing the question. Some explanation, other than saying that data from the sensing device is processed, was expected.
  2. Many candidates found it difficult to draw a correct circuit. In many, the resistor and the thermistor were not drawn as being in series between the 4V line and earth. 
  3. Few candidates could give two reasons. A common answer was to state that the relay could be used to switch large currents, without making any reference to the small current that gives rise to this switching.
NO. 445题号：1497

The volume of fuel in the fuel tank of a car is monitored using a sensing device. The device gives a voltage output that is measured using a voltmeter. The variation of voltmeter reading with the volume of fuel in the tank is shown in Fig.9.1.

  1. Use Fig.9.1 to determine the range of volume over which the volume has a linear relationship to the voltmeter reading.

    from .................................. litres to .................................. litres [1]
  2. Suggest why, comparing values from Fig. 9.1,
    1. when the tank is nearly full, the voltmeter readings give the impression that fuel consumption is low,
      ........................................................................ [2]
    2. when the voltmeter first indicates that the tank is nearly empty, there is more fuel remaining than is expected.
      ........................................................................ [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper4_2/Q9
Question Answer Marks  
a 30 litres → 54 litres (allow ± 4 litres on both limits) A1 [1]
b.i only 0.1 V change in reading for 10 litre consumption (or similar numbers)
above about 60 litres gradient is small compared to the gradient at about 40 litres		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.ii voltmeter reading (nearly) zero when fuel is left
voltmeter reads only about 0.1 V when 10 litres of fuel left in tank
("voltmeter reads zero when about 4 litres of fuel left in tank" scores 2 marks)		 C1
A1

 [2]
  1. from 30 litres to 54 litres
    1. Change in gradient is small between 68 to 80 lit res as compared to 40 to 52 litres i.e. change in voltmeter reading is 0.2 v for last 12 litres of consumption.
    2. Voltmeter reads zero when about 4 litres of fuel is left in the tank.

In many answers to this question, there seemed to be a misunderstanding as to what was required. Some referred either to an insensitive voltmeter or based their answer on a warning so as not to run out of fuel. 

  1. The given range was frequently inappropriate with values quoted where the line is curved (e.g. 20 litres). 
    1. Many candidates did not answer the question. Frequently, reference was made to a decreasing gradient without quoting data from the graph, as was required in the question. Very few gave a comparison of apparent fuel consumption for (e.g.) 70 litres to 80 litres with that for 40 litres to 50 litres.
    2. Many candidates did comment that there would be fuel in the tank when the voltmeter reading is near to zero. Again, comments based on numerical evidence from the graph were rarely seen. 
NO. 446题号：1496

An operational amplifier (op-amp) may be used as part of the processing unit in an electronic sensor.

  1. State three properties of an ideal op-amp.
    1. .........................................................................
    2. .........................................................................
    3. ......................................................................... [3]
  2. A comparator circuit incorporating an ideal op-amp is shown in Fig. 9.1.

    1. In one application of the comparator, V2 is kept constant at +1.5 V.
      The variation with time t of the potential V1 is shown in Fig.9.2. The potential V2 is also shown.

      On Fig. 9.2, show the variation with time t of the output potential VOUT. [4]

    2. Two light-emitting diodes (LEDs) Rand G are connected to the output of the op-amp in Fig. 9.1 such that R emits light for a longer time than G.
      On Fig.1, draw the symbols for the two diodes connected to the output of the op-amp and label the diodes R and G. [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper4_1/Q9
Question Answer Marks  
a e.g. zero output impedance/resistance
infinite input impedance/resistance
infinite (open loop) gain
infinite bandwidth
infinite slew rate
1 each, max. 3		 B3 [3]
b.i graph: square wave
correct cross-over points where V2 = V1
amplitude 5V
correct polarity (positive at t = 0)		 M1
A1
A1
A1		 [4]
b.ii correct symbol for LED
diodes connected correctly between VOUT and earth
correct polarity consistent with graph in (i)
(R points 'down' if (i) correct) 		 M1
A1
A1

 [3]
  1. 1. Infinite input impedance
    2. Infinite open loop gain
    3. Infinite bandwidth.
    1. Vout = A0(V+ - V-)
      = 105(V2 - V1)
      At V1 = 0, Vout = 105 (1.5 - 0) = 150000 > supply voltage
      so saturation occur and Vout = + 5 V
      At V1 = +2.8 V, Vout = 105 (1.5 - 2.8) = -130000 > supply voltage
      so saturation occur and Vout = - 5 V
      At V1 = -2.8 V, Vout = 105[1.5 -(-2.8)] = 430000 > supply voltage
      so saturation occur and Vout = + 5 V
      At V1 =1.5V, Vout = 105(1.5-1.5)=0
      At V1 = -1.5 V, Vout = 105[1.5-(-1.5)] = 300000 > supplyvoltage = 5 V

comment on answer:
(a) Other properties are
1. Zero output impedance
2. Infinite slew rate

  1. In general, all three marks were scored. 
    1. The majority of answers were based, incorrectly, on some form of sinusoidal wave. This was despite being informed that the circuit is for a comparator. Of those who did draw a square wave, many indicated either incorrect cross-over points or incorrect polarity of the output. 
    2. A significant minority of candidates were unaware of the symbol for an LED. In most cases where symbols were drawn, these were shown as being connected between the output and earth.
NO. 447题号：1494

    1. ........................................................................
    2. ........................................................................
    3. ........................................................................
    4. ........................................................................ [4]

    The variation with time t of the input potential VIN is shown in Fig. 9.2.

    On the axes of Fig. 9.2, draw a graph to show the variation with time t of the output potential VOUT. [3]

  3. The output potential VOUT is to be displayed using two light-emitting diodes (LEDs). A diode emitting red light is to indicate when VOUT is positive and a diode emitting green light is to be used to indicate when VOUT is negative.
    Complete Fig. 9.3 to show the connections of the two LEOs to the output of the opamp. Label each LED with the colour of light that it emits. [3]

A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper4_2/Q9

 infinite (open loop) gain

 infinite slew rate
(any four, one mark each)		 B4 [4]
b graph: square wave
   180° phase change
   amplitude 5.0V		 M1
A1
A1		 [3]
c correct symbol for LED
diodes connected correctly between VOUT and earth
diodes identified correctly
(special case: if diode symbol, not LED symbol, allow 2nd and 3rd marks to be scored)		 M1
A1
A1

 [3]
  1. Other property is Infinite - slew rate.
    1. Infinite input impedance
    2. Infinite bandwidth
    3. Infinite open loop gain
    4. Zero output impedance

Comment on answer

(b) V0 =V0V+ - V-)
⇒ V- = 2V
V0 =105(0 - 2)= -2 × 105
Saturation occur and Vaut = -5V
⇒ At V- = -2V
V0 =105(0 - (-2)) = 2 × 105
Saturation occur and Vout =5V

  1. The great majority of candidates were able to state at least three properties.
  2. Despite being told that the question is based on a comparator, very few candidates produced a square-wave graph; most opted for a sinusoidal curve. 
  3. Many candidates were not familiar with the accepted symbol for an LED. Most drew some component between VOUT and the earth line.
NO. 448题号：1489
  1. Describe the structure of a metal wire strain gauge. You may draw a diagram if you wish.
    ............................................................................. [3]
  2. A strain gauge S is connected into the circuit of Fig. 9.1.

    The operational amplifier (op-amp) is ideal.
    The output potential VOUT of the circuit is given by the expression
                         
    1. State the name given to the ratio .
      ........................................................................ [1]
    2. The strain gauge S has resistance 125 Ω when not under strain.
      Calculate the magnitude of V1 such that, when the strain gauge S is not strained, the output VOUT is zero.

      V1 = ........................................... V [3]
    3. In a particular test, the resistance of S increases to 128 Ω. V1 is unchanged.
      The ratio  is 12.
      Calculate the magnitude of VOUT.

      VOUT = ........................................... V [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper4_2/Q9
Question Answer Marks  
a thin / fine metal wire 
lay-out shown as a grid
encased in plastic		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
b.i gain (of amplifier) B1 [1]
b.ii for VOUT = 0, then V+ = V– or V1 = V2
V1 = (1000/1125) × 4.5
V1 = 4.0V		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
b.iii V2 = (1000 / 1128) × 4.5
     = 3.99V		 C1 [2]
VOUT = 12 × (3.99 – 4.00)
          = (–) 0.12V		 A1

  1. A strain gauge consists of a length of very fine metal wire sealed into a small rectangular plastic case as shown above.
    1. Gain of the circuit.
      This can be the open loop gain of OP Amp.

    2. For VOUT = 0, the two inputs should be at same potential.
      So, V1 = V2 = 4.0 V
  1. In many scripts, credit was given for the shape of the wire in the gauge but features such as the use of thin wire and enclosing the wire in 'plastic' were omitted. Many thought that the wire would be in a box.
    1. In most answers, there was a reference to gain but equally, this could be the gain of the circuit, the open-loop gain or the gain of the op-amp. 
    2. There were many candidates who did not seem to realise that, for zero output, the two inputs must be at the same potential. Those who did understand this concept usually went on to complete the calculation.
    3. In most scripts where (ii) had been completed successfully, then the correct answer was obtained for VOUT.
NO. 449题号：1487

An amplifier circuit incorporating an operational amplifier (op-amp) is shown in Fig. 9.1.

  1. State
    1. the name of this type of amplifier circuit,
      ..................................................................[1]
    2. the gain G in terms of resistances R1 and R2.
      ..................................................................[1]
  2. The value of R1 is 820 Ω. The resistor of resistance R2 is replaced with a lightdependent resistor (LDR).
    The input potential difference VIN is 15 mV.
    Calculate the output potential difference VOUT for the LDR having a resistance of
    1. 100 Ω (the LDR is in sunlight),

      VOUT = ............................................. V [2]
    2. 1.0 MΩ (the LDR is in darkness).

      VOUT = ........................................... V [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper4_1/Q9
Question Answer Marks  
a.i non-inverting (amplifier) B1 [1]
a.ii (G =) 1 + R2 / R1 B1 [1]
b.i gain = 1 + 100 / 820
output = 17 mV		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii 9V
(R2 / R1 scores 0 in (a)(ii) but possible 1 mark in each of (b)(i) and (b)(ii)
(1 + R1 / R2) scores 0 in (a)(ii), no mark in (b)(i), possible 1 mark in (b)(ii)
(1 – R2 / R1) or R1 / R2 scores 0 in (a)(ii), (b)(i) and (b)(ii))		 A1 [1]
    1. Non-inverting amplifier.
    1. There was much confusion as to whether the amplifier is of the non-inverting or the inverting type. 
    2. The confusion in (i) spread to answers for the gain. Candidates should be encouraged to improve their knowledge of this topic. 
    1. In general, the formula stated in (a) was used correctly in order to determine VOUT.
    2. It was quite normal to see answers where the output was greater than 9 V. Candidates need to appreciate what is meant by saturation in the context of an amplifier. 
NO. 450题号：1484
  1. Negative feedback may be used in amplifier circuits. State
    1. what is meant by negative feedback,
      .......................................................................... [2]
    2. two effects of negative feedback on an amplifier incorporating an operational amplifier (op-amp).
      1. .....................................................................
      2. ..................................................................... [2]
  2. Figure is a circuit for an amplifier that is used with a microphone.

    The output potential difference VOUT is 4.4 V when the potential at point P is 62 mV.
    Determine
    1. the gain of the amplifier, ..........................................................................[1]
    2. the resistance of the resistor R........................................................................... [2]
  3. The maximum potential produced by the microphone at point P on Figure is 95 mV. The power supply for the operational amplifier may be either +/- 5 V or +/- 9V.
    State which power supply should be used. Justify your answer quantitatively...........................................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper4_2/Q9
Question Answer Marks  
a.i fraction of the output (signal) is added to the input (signal)
out of phase by 180° / π rad / to inverting input		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii e.g. reduces gain
 increases bandwidth
 greater stability
 reduces distortion
 (any two, 1 mark each)		 B2 [2]
b.i gain = 4.4 / 0.062
        = 71		 A1 [1]
b.ii 71 = 1 + 120/R
R = 1.7 × 103 Ω		 C1
A1		 [2]
c for the amplifier not to saturate
maximum output is (71 × 95 × 10–3 =) approximately 6.7 V
supply should be +/– 9 V		 B1
M1
A1		 [3]
    1. The process of taking same, or all, of the output of the amplifier and adding it to the inverting input so that input and output are 180° out of phase with each other.
    2. 1. Greater operating stability.
      2. Distortion of the output is reduced.
  3. For the amplifier not to saturate.

    So power supply voltage = +/- 9 V.

Comment on answer

(a) (ii) Other valid effects are
1. Gain of the amplifier is reduced.
2. Increased band width.
3. The gain is accurately predictable.

(c) Since Vout > 5V so saturation occur with Vs = ±5V.

There were a significant number of good answers to this question

    1. Candidates lost marks here by using the term 'feedback' and not explaining its meaning. Only a small number stated that it was only part of the output that was added to the input. Very few mentioned that this was added 'out of phase by π' although some retrieved the mark by stating it was added to the inverting input.
    2. The majority of candidates were able to give at least one effect of negative feedback.
    1. The gain was correctly calculated by the majority of candidates. The mark was lost by incorrect rounding of the value. 
    2. The wrong expression for the gain was used by a significant number of candidates and a number made a power of ten error in the calculation of the resistance.
  3. This part differentiated well with the full range of marks being awarded. The good candidates often scored all three marks. There were some candidates who suggested that saturation was a desirable feature. 
NO. 451题号：1482

An amplifier incorporating an operational amplifier (op-amp) has three inputs A, B and C, as shown in Fig. 9.1.

Negative feedback is provided by the resistor RF of resistance 8.0 kΩ.

For each of the inputs A, Band C, the amplifier may be considered as a single input amplifier. That is, each input is independent of the other two.

When the amplifier is not saturated, the output potential VOUT is given by the expression

VOUT = –(4VA + GVB + VC),

where VA, VB and VC are the input potentials of the inputs A, Band C respectively and G is a constant.

  1. State two effects of negative feedback on an amplifier.
    1. ..........................................................................
    2. .......................................................................... [2]
  2. In the expression for the output potential VOUT, the constant G is the gain associated with input B. Show that the numerical value of G is 2. [1]

  3. The input potentials VA, VB and VC are either zero or 1.0 V.
    The magnitudes of some output potentials for different combinations of VA, VB and VC are shown in Fig. 9.2.

    1. Complete Fig. 9.2 for the three remaining values of VOUT. [1]
    2. Suggest a use for this circuit.
      ................................................................... [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper4_2/Q9
Question Answer Marks  
a e.g. reduces gain
 increases bandwidth
 less distortion
 greater stability ………(1 each, max 2)		 B2 [2]
b gain = – RF / RI
     = – 8.0 / 4.0
numerical value is 2		 M1
A0

 [1]
c.i 2, 6 and 7 A1 [1]
c.ii e.g. digital-to-analogue converter  (allow DAC)
  adding / mixing signals with 'weighting'		 B1 [1]
  1. 1. Reduces gain
    2. Increases bandwidth

    1. VA / V VB / V VC / V VOUT / V
      0 0 1 1
      0 1 0 2
      1 0 0 4
      1 0 1 5
      1 1 0 6
      1 1 1 7 
    2. Since the inputs are binary numbers and output is a decimal number, so it can be used as digital-to-analogue converter.

Comment on answer

(a) Other benefits of -ve feedback are
• Greater stability
• Lesser distortion.

(c) (i) 

  1. Less-able candidates were often unable to recall two of the effects of negative feedback on an amplifier. 
  2. The value of G could be calculated simply from the ratio of the feedback resistance to the input resistance at B. However, some answers showed an incorrect circular calculation which involved initially assigning values of voltage to VOUT and VB (based on an unexplained assumption that G is 2) and then using these voltages to show that G is 2.
  3. The vast majority of candidates were able to complete the table correctly. There were few correct uses suggested for the circuit, although a few candidates did realise that it could be used as a digital-to-analogue converter. 
NO. 452题号：1479
  1. By reference to an amplifier, explain what is meant by negative feedback.
    .................................................................................... [2]
  2. An amplifier circuit incorporating an ideal operational amplifier (op-amp) is shown in Fig. 10.1.

    The supply for the op-amp is ± 9.0 V.
    The amplifier circuit is to have a gain of 25.
    Calculate the resistance of resistor R.

    resistance = ........................................... Ω [2]
  3. State the value of the output voltage VOUT of the amplifier in (b) for input voltages VIN of
    1. – 0.08 V,

      VOUT = ............................................ V [1]
    2. + 0.4 V.

      VOUT = ............................................ V [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Summer/Paper4/Q10
Question Answer Marks  
a (part of) the output is added to /returned to / mixed with the input
and is out of phase with the input / fed to inverting input		 B1
B1		 [2]
b 25 = 1 + (120 / R)
R = 5 kΩ		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.i –2 V A1 [1]
c.ii 9 V A1 [1]
  1. Part or whole of the output is added or returned to the inverting input so that output is out of phase with the input is called negative feedback.

    1. Since Vout < Vs. So no saturation occurs.

comment on answer:
(c)(i) Since Vout < Vs. So no saturation occurs.

  1. Many candidates paraphrased the question, using the term 'fed back'. It was common to find that there was no direct reference to the inverting input. Terms such as 'negative pin' were quite usual.
  2. There were many correct answers although a significant minority used the equation for the gain of an inverting amplifier. 
  3. A surprisingly large proportion of candidates did not score marks in this section. In particular, they did not appreciate that, in (ii), the amplifier would saturate. 
NO. 453题号：1477
  1. The circuit for an amplifier incorporating an ideal operational amplifier (op-amp) is shown in Fig.10.1.

    1. State
      1. the name of this type of amplifier circuit,
        ....................................................................[1]
      2. why the point P is referred to as a virtual earth.
        ....................................................................[3]
    2. Show that the gain G of this amplifier circuit is given by the expression
         
      Explain your working. [4]

  2. The circuit of Fig.10.1 is modified by connecting a light-dependent resistor (LDR) as shown in Fig.10.2.

    The resistances R1 and R2 are 5.0 kΩ and 50 kΩ  respectively. 
    The input voltage VIN is +1.2 V. A high-resistance voltmeter measures the output VOUT.
    The circuit is used to monitor low light intensities.
    1. Determine the voltmeter reading for light intensities such that the LDR has a resistance of
      1. 100 kΩ,

        reading = .............................................. V [3]
      2. 10 kΩ

        reading = .............................................. V [2]
    2. The light incident on the LDR is provided by a single lamp. Use your answers in (i) to describe and explain qualitatively the variation of the voltmeter reading as the lamp is moved away from the LDR.
      ............................................................................[3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2008/Winter/Paper4/Q10
Question Answer Marks  
a.i 1. inverting (amplifier) B1 [1]
2. gain of op-amp is very large / infinite
  non-inverting input is at earth / 0V
  for amplifier not to saturate, P must be at about earth / 0V		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
a.ii input resistance is very large
(so) current in R1 = current in R2
I = VIN / R1
I = – VOUT / R2  (minus sign can be in either of the equations)
hence gain = VOUT / VIN = –R2 / R1		 B1
B1
B1
B1
A0		 [4]
b.i 1. feedback resistance = 33.3 kΩ
   gain (= 33.3 / 5) = 6.66
   VOUT (= 6.66 × 1.2) = 8.0 V  (+ or – acceptable, allow 1 s.f.)		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
2. feedback resistance = 8.33 kΩ
   VOUT (= {6.66 × 1.2} / 5) = 2.0 V (+ or – acceptable, allow 1 s.f.)		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii (Increase in lamp-LDR distance gives) decrease in intensity
Feedback / LDR resistance increases
voltmeter reading increases / becomes more negative		 M1
M1
A1		 [3]
      1. Inverting amplifier.
      2. Since potential at non-inverting input is 0 V as it is directly connected to Earth. Therefore potential at point 'P' is also 0 V so as to get a very large gain and the op-amp is not saturated.
    2. Since input impedance of op-amp is infinite so no current flows through any of the inputs.
    2. The resistance of LDR increases with the decrease in illumination as lamp is moved away. It therefore increases the effective resistance of LOR and 5.0kΩ resistor. So this increase in feedback resistance give rise to voltmeter reading.

Comment on answer

    1. 1. Negative feedback is provided by resistor R2 in this op.amp.
      2. In order that the amplifier is not saturated, the two inputs must be almost the same.
    2. Current always flow from high to low potential.
    1. 1. LDR and R2 are connected in parallel to each other.
    2. Reading of voltmeter increases towards negative side.
    1. Most candidates did recognise the circuit as being that of an inverting amplifier although many quoted 'inverting op-amp'. When explaining the concept of the 'virtual earth' very few mentioned that the open-loop gain of the op-amp is very large. 
    2. There were some clear, well presented derivations. However, the majority merely quoted the current in terms of the input and the output signals. Credit was lost because it was not stated that the input impedance is very large, leading to the conclusion that the currents in R1 and R2 are the same. 
    1. Many gave answers where the reading was greater than the supply potential difference. Although there were some very clear answers, many candidates did not appear to realise that R2 in parallel with the thermistor provides the total feedback resistance.
    2. Most candidates realised that the thermistor resistance would increase but a significant number did not mention decreasing light intensity. The outcome for the voltmeter reading was frequently confused, contradicting the answers obtained in (b).
NO. 454题号：1463

A block diagram for an electronic sensor is shown in Fig. 9.1.

  1. Complete Figure by labelling the remaining boxes. [2]

  2. A device is to be built that will emit a red light when its input is at +2 V. When the input is at -2 V, the light emitted is to be green.
    1. On Figure, draw a circuit diagram of the device.
    2. Explain briefly the action of this device.
      ................................................................................[1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2008/Summer/Paper4/Q9
Question Answer Marks  
a blocks labelled  sensing device / sensor / transducer 
   processor / processing unit / signal conditioning		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.i two LEDs with opposite polarities (ignore any series resistors)
correctly identified as red and green		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.ii correct polarity for diode to conduct identified
hence red LED conducts when input (+)ve or vice versa		 M1
A0		 [1]
    2. A diode conducts when it is forward biased so at +2V input, Red LED is forward biased while at -2V, green LED emit light due to forward biasing.

Comment on answer

(a) Other valid labelling for extreme left block is sensor or transducer. Similarlymiddle box be a processor or signal conditioning
(b) (ii)
• When P-type is connected to positive and N-type to the negative terminals of direct current source then diode is forward biased.
• A diode is reversed biased when P-type is connected to negative and Ntype to positive terminal of direct current source and does not conduct.

  1. There were many correct answers. However, it was not uncommon for the first block to be named 'input', rather than identifying the input as being a sensor or transducer.
    1. Many candidates attempted to include an op-amp in the circuit. This was completed successfully by many but was not necessary. It was surprising to note the large proportion of candidates who were unaware of the electrical symbol for an LED. 
    2. Some attempted to give a use for the circuit (e.g. traffic lights) rather than explain its action. Explanations were frequently inadequate in that they merely identified which diode would be forward-biased, rather than go on to state that the diode would then conduct and emit light. 
NO. 455题号：1457
  1. Fig.8.1 shows a circuit incorporating an ideal operational amplifier (op-amp).

    The voltages applied to the inverting and the non-inverting inputs are V1 and V2 respectively.
    State the value of the output voltage VOUT when
    1. V1 > V2,

      VOUT = .................................................... V 
    2. V1 < V2.

      VOUT = .................................................... V
      [1]
  2. The circuit of Fig.8.2 is used to monitor the input voltage VIN.

    At point A, a potential of 5.0 V is maintained. At point B, a potential of 3.0 V is maintained.
    Complete Fig.8.3 by indicating with a tick (✔) the light-emitting diodes (LEOs) that are conducting for the input voltages VIN shown. Also, mark with a cross (✘) those LEOs that are not conducting. [3]
     
  3. The input voltage VIN in (b) is provided by a sensor circuit.
    1. Complete Fig.8.4 to show a sensor circuit that will provide a voltage output that increases as the temperature of the sensor decreases. Show clearly the output connections from the circuit. [2]
    2. Explain the operation of the sensor circuit.
      ....................................................................[3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2007/Winter/Paper4/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a.i –9 V B1 [1]
a.ii + 9 V  (both (i) and (ii) correct for the mark)
b ✘  ✘ B1 [3]
✔  ✘ B1
✔  ✔ B1
(no e.c.f. from (a))  
c.i cct: thermistor and resistor in series
output connections across thermistor		 M1
A1		 [2]
c.ii as temperature decreases, thermistor resistance increases
p.d. across thermistor = RT / (R + RT) × V
as RT increases, output increases		 B1
M1
A1		 [3]
    1. VOUT = - 9 V
    2. VOUT = + 9 V

  2. VIN / V red LED green LED
    +2.0 × ×
    +4.0 √ ×
    +6.0 √ √
    2. The resistance of thermistor increases as temperature decreases. So by potentiometer circuit, the p.d. across thermistor is . Therefore as RT increases, the output VIN also increases.

Comment on answer

  1. Amplification in open loop is:
    V0 = A0(V+ - V-)
    Typically, A0 = 105, So saturation occurs and output voltage is equal to the supply voltage.
  2. The open loop gain of an opamp is V0 = A0(V+ - V-) .
    At VIN = + 2.0, both amplifiers provide output in negative. so both diodes are reverse biased and do not conduct.
    At VIN = + 4.0V, upper opamp provides negative output while lower one's output is positive to conduct red LED and green LED remain reversed biased.
    At VIN = 6.0, both opamps provide positive outputs and both LEOs are forward biased.
  3. (i) Temperature sensor is thermistor which is negative temperature coefficient.
  1. Most candidates who had any understanding of the situation gave the correct answer. From the responses of some candidates, it was clear that they had not studied this topic. 
  2. Most candidates scored either full marks or no marks. 
    1. A thermistor connected in series with a resistor was shown in approximately 50% of scripts. In those scripts with a series circuit, it was common to find only one output terminal.
    2. Most candidates who drew a thermistor in (i) did state that the resistance of the thermistor would decrease with increasing temperature (or vice versa). However, very few could discuss how this potential divider circuit would give rise to a change in the output potential difference.
NO. 456题号：1452
  1. State three characteristics of an ideal operational amplifier (op-amp).
    1. .......................................................................
    2. .......................................................................
    3. ....................................................................... [3]
  2. An amplifier circuit for a microphone is shown in Fig.8.1.

    1. Name the type of feedback used with this op-amp.
      ................................................................................ [1]
    2. The output potential difference VOUT is 5.8 V for a potential difference across the resistor R of 69 mV. Calculate
      1. the gain of the amplifier circuit,

        gain = ……………………… [1]
      2. the resistance of resistor X.

        resistance = ……………………… Ω [2]
    3. State one effect on the amplifier output of reducing the resistance of resistor X.
      ................................................................................ [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2007/Summer/Paper4/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a e.g. infinite (voltage) gain
 infinite input impedance
 zero output impedance
 infinite bandwidth
 infinite slew rate
 (any three, 1 each) 		 B3 [3]
b.i negative (feedback) B1 [1]
b.ii 1. gain (= 5.8/0.069) = 84  B1 [1]
2. gain = 1 + 120/X
 84 = 1 + 120/X
 X = 1.45 kΩ 		 C1

A1		 [2]
b.iii gain increases OR bandwidth reduced OR output increases B1 [1]
  1. 1. Infinite (voltage) gain.
    2. Infinite input gain.
    3. Zero output impedance.
    1. Negative feedback
      2. Voltage gain of Non-inverting amplifier with -ve feed back is
    3. Gain increases or output increases.

Comment on answer

  1. Other characteristics:
    • infinite bandwidth
    • infinite slew rate
  2. (i) If part of the amplified output is fed back to inverting input then it is negative feedback.
    (ii) Here    Rt = Feedback resistor     Rx = Resistor identified byX.
    (iii) Other valid answers can be:
          • bandwidth decreases.
          • Distortion of the output increases.
  1. Generally, candidates either scored three marks or none in this section.
    1. Although candidates were asked to identify the type of feedback, many gave the answer as some form of amplifier circuit.
    2. The calculation of the gain was completed successfully in the majority of scripts. However, there was a significant minority where this calculation was not attempted.
      There was some confusion as to which formula to use for the calculation of the resistance. Of those who did give a recognisable equation, opinion was equally divided between the gain formula for an inverting and a non-inverting amplifier.
    3. The majority of candidates made a reference to 'output increases'. Only a minority considered either the gain or the bandwidth of the amplifier.
NO. 457题号：1445
  1. State what is meant by nuclear binding energy.
    ...................................................................[2]
  2. The variation with nucleon number A of the binding energy per nucleon BE is shown in Fig. 8.1.

    When uranium-235  absorbs a slow-moving neutron, one possible nuclear reaction is
     
    1. State the name of this type of nuclear reaction.
      .................................................................[1]
    2. On Fig. 8.1, mark the position of
      1. the uranium-235 nucleus (label this position U), [1]
      2. the molybdenum-95  nucleus (label this position Mo), [1]
      3. the lanthanum-139  nucleus (label this position La). [1]

    3. The masses of some particles and nuclei are given in Fig. 8.2.

      Calculate, for this reaction,
      1. the change, in u, of the rest mass,

        change in mass = .............................. u [2]
      2. the energy released, in MeV, to three significant figures.

        energy = ................................ MeV [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Winter/Paper4_1/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a energy to separate nucleons (in a nucleus)
separate to infinity		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i fission B1 [1]
b.ii 1. U: near right-hand end of line B1 [1]
2. Mo: to right of peak, less than 1/3 distance from peak to U B1 [1]
3. La: 0.4 → 0.6 of distance from peak to U B1 [1]
b.iii 1. right-hand side, mass = 235.922 u
   mass change = 0.210 u		 C1
A1		 [2]
2. energy = mc2
   = 0.210 × 1.66 × 10–27 × (3.0 × 108)2
   = 3.1374 × 10–11 J
   = 196 MeV (need 3 s.f.)
(use of 1 u = 934 MeV, allow 3/3; use of 1 u = 930 MeV or 932 MeV, allow 2/3)
(use of 1.67 × 10–27 not 1.66 ×10–27 scores max. 2/3) 		 C1

C1
A1


 [3]
  1. The external energy required to completely separate nucleons in a nucleus to an infinite distance.
    1. Fission reaction
      1. Δm = (mu + mn) - (mMo + mLa + 2mn + 7mβ)
              = (235.123 + 1.009) - {94.945 + 138.955 + 2(1.009) + 7(5.5 × 10-4 )}
              = 236.132 - 235.922
              = 0.210 u
      2. ΔE = (Δm)c2
              = {(0.21 0)(1.66 × 10-27)}{3.0 × 108}2
              = 3.1374 × 10-11 J
        1 MeV = (106 )(1.60 × 10-19 ) = 1.60 × 10-13 J
        As 1 MeV =1.60 × 10-13
  1. This was generally satisfactory although there was confusion between the terms nucleus, nucleon, neutron and nuclide. 
    1. With few exceptions, the reaction was named correctly.
    2. Reference to the nucleon numbers shown in the reaction should have provided a very clear indication as to the positions. It was not uncommon to have the nuclei in an incorrect order. Others showed all three nuclei to the left of the peak. 
    3. 1. A significant number of answers were incorrect through errors other than arithmetical. Some candidates did not include all of the particles in their calculations. 
      2. It was expected that candidates would use the expression E=c2Δm and then convert energy in joules to MeV. Some candidates gave a figure, correctly or incorrectly, for the number of MeV equivalent to 1.0 u. The correct number for the calculation, based on three significant figures, was accepted. 
NO. 458题号：1443
  1. Explain why the mass of an α-particle is less than the total mass of two individual protons and two individual neutrons.
    ............................................................................ [2]
  2. An equation for one possible nuclear reaction is
         
    Data for the masses of the nuclei are given in Fig. 8.1.

    1. Calculate the mass change, in u, associated with this reaction.

      mass change = .............................................. u [2] 
    2. Calculate the energy, in J, associated with the mass change in (i).

      energy = ............................................... J [2]
    3. Suggest and explain why, for this reaction to occur, the helium-4 nucleus must have a minimum speed.
      ............................................................................. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper4_2/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a energy is given out / released on formation of the α-particle (or reverse argument)
either E = mc2 so mass is less
or  reference to mass-energy equivalence		 M1

A1		 [2]
b.i mass change = 18.00567u – 18.00641 u
  = 7.4 × 10–4 u (sign not required)		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii energy = c2∆m
  = (3.0 × 108)2 × 7.4 × 10–4 × 1.66 × 10–27
  = 1.1 × 10–13 J
(allow use of  u = 1.67 × 10–27 kg)
(allow method based on 1u equivalent to 930 MeV to 933 MeV)		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.iii either mass of products greater than mass of reactants
   this mass/energy provided as kinetic energy of the helium-4 nucleus
or both nuclei positively charged
   energy required to overcome electrostatic repulsion		 M1
A1
(M1)
(A1)		 [2]
  1. Because energy is released when an α-particle is formed from its constituent particles by E = Δmc2 , so mass is less.
    1. Total mass of 42He and 147N  = 4.00260 + 14.00307 = 18.00567u
      Total mass of 178O and 11P  = 16.99913 + 1.00728 = 18.00641 u
      Δm = 18.00641-18.00567 = 7.4 × 10-4
      ∴ mass change = 7.4 × 10-4 u
    2. Energy,
      E = Δmc2
         = [(7.4 × 10-4 )(1.66 × 10-27 )][3.0 × 108]2
         = 1.1 × 10-13 J
    3. Since both nuclei (42He and 147N) are positively charged, so energy is needed to overcome the electrostic repulsion.

Comment on answer:
(b) (ii) 1U = 1.66 × 10-27 kg

  1. In many responses, either binding energy or mass defect were mentioned, without placing either in the context of an α-particle. Mass-energy was rarely discussed.
    1. There were many correct answers. The most common error was to multiply each mass by the relevant mass number. Some candidates could not be given any credit because they quoted an incorrect answer without giving any form of derivation. Working should always be shown. 
    2. Most candidates did quote the correct expression. A significant number did not convert the mass in u to kg. 
    3. There were very few correct answers, possibly because most candidates did not appreciate the sign of the mass change in (i). An alternative approach was to realise that the nucleus and the αparticle are both positively charged and would repel each other. Many did suggest that a minimum velocity is required for fusion to occur. 
NO. 459题号：1441

A polonium nucleus is radioactive and decays with the emission of an α-particle. The nuclear reaction for this decay is given by

    1. State the values of 
      W ...............
       X ...............
       Y ...............
       Z ............... [2]
    2. Explain why mass seems not to be conserved in the reaction.
      ..........................................................................[2]
  2. The reaction is spontaneous. Explain the meaning of spontaneous.
    .............................................................................[1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i W = 206 and X = 82
Y = 4 and Z = 2		 A1
A1		 [2]
a.ii mass-energy is conserved
mass-energy is conserved		 B1
B1		 [2]
b not affected by external conditions/factors/environment
or two examples temperature and pressure		 B1 [1]
    1. W: 206, X: 82, Y: 4 and Z: 2.
      In any nuclear reaction, mass number and charge number are conserved.
    2. Mass of 21084PO is greater than (20682Q + 42He) because this difference of mass is converted into energy by mass-energy equation E = Δmc2.
  2.  Decay is independent of external factors such as temperature, pressure, humidity factor, electric or magnetic field.

Comment on answer:
(a) (i) In any nuclear reaction, mass number and charge number are conserved.
(ii) Mass and energy are also conserved in a nuclear decay.

    1. This was generally well answered. 
    2. The majority of candidates were not awarded credit because their answers lacked detail or the process of a nuclear reaction was not completely understood. The question stated that there was a difference in mass. The candidate was expected to realise that there was less mass on the right hand side and that this mass was released as energy.
  2. This was generally well answered. A small minority confused spontaneous with random. 
NO. 460题号：1439

The element strontium has at least 16 isotopes. One of these isotopes is strontium-89. This isotope has a half-life of 52 days.

  1. State what is meant by isotopes.
    ...........................................................................[2]
  2. Calculate the probability per second of decay of a nucleus of strontium-89.

    probability = ............................................ s–1 [3]
  3. A laboratory prepares a strontium-89 source.
    The activity of this source is measured 21 days after preparation of the source and is found to be 7.4 × 106 Bq.
    Determine, for the strontium-89 source at the time that it was prepared,
    1. the activity,

      activity = ............................................ Bq [2]
    2. the mass of strontium-89.

      mass = ...............................................g [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper4_2/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a nuclei having same number of protons/proton (atomic) number 
different numbers of neutrons/neutron number
(allow second mark for nucleons/nucleon number/mass number/atomic
mass if made clear that same number of protons/proton number)		 B1
B1


 [2]
b probability of decay per unit time is the decay constant
λ = ln 2 / t½
   = 0.693 / (52 × 24 × 3600)
   = 1.54 × 10–7 s–1		 C1

C1
A1		 [3]
c.i A = A0exp(–λt)
7.4 × 106 = A0exp(–1.54 × 10–7 × 21 × 24 × 3600)
A0 = 9.8 × 106Bq
(alternative method uses 21 days as 0.404 half-lives)		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.ii A = λN and mass = N × 89 / NA
mass = (9.8 × 106 × 89) / (1.54 × 10–7 × 6.02 × 1023)
   = 9.4 × 10–9g		 C1

A1		 [2]
  1. Nuclei having same number of protons and different number of neutrons.
  2. Probability of decay of a nucleus per Uilit time is called decay constant (λ)

    2. 6.02 × 1023 atoms of strontium has mass = 89 g
      1 atom of strontium has mass 
      6.32 × 1013 atoms of strontium has mass 

Comment on answer
(b) 
  1. Most candidates were able to state that something would contain the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons. Frequently, reference was made to elements, nuclides or atoms, rather than nuclei. 
  2. With few exceptions, the decay constant λ was calculated correctly but without any statement that this constant is the probability of decay per unit time.
    1. This part was answered correctly by most candidates. A minority assumed A0 to be 7.4MBq and thus calculated the initial activity to be less than that after 21 days.
    2. Although many candidates could correctly calculate the number of nuclei, they were unable to convert this number to a mass in grams.
NO. 461题号：1435

The isotope phosphorus-33  undergoes β-decay to form sulfur-33 , which is stable.

The half-life of phosphorus-33 is 24.8 days.

    1. Define radioactive half-life.
      ...................................................................[2]
    2. Show that the decay constant of phosphorus-33 is 3.23 × 10-7s-1. [1]

  2. A pure sample of phosphorus-33 has an initial activity of 3.7 × 106 Bq.
    Calculate
    1. the initial number of phosphorus-33 nuclei in the sample,

      number = ...........................................[2]
    2. the number of phosphorus-33 nuclei remaining in the sample after 30 days.

      number = ...........................................[2]
  3. After 30 days, the sample in (b) will contain phosphorus-33 and sulfur-33 nuclei.
    Use your answers in (b) to calculate the ratio
         

    ratio = ..................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper4_1/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a.i time for initial number of nuclei/activity
to reduce to one half of its initial value		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii λ = ln 2/(24.8 × 24 × 3600)
   = 3.23 × 10–7 s–1		 M1
A0		 [1]
b.i A = λN
3.76 × 106 = 3.23 × 10–7 × N
N = 1.15 × 1013		 C1

A1		 [2]
b.ii N = N0 e–λt
   = 1.15 × 1013 × exp(–{ln 2 × 30}/24.8)
   = 4.97 × 1012
C1
A1		 [2]
c ratio = (4.97 × 1012)/(1.15 × 1013 – 4.97 × 1012)
        = 0.76		 C1
A1		 [2]
    1. The time in which half of the original number of un decayed nuclei decays is called half-life.

Comment on answer
(a) (i) The time in which an activity is reduced to one half of its initial value.
(b) (i) Negative sign is neglected in numerical problems.
    1. Candidates do need to learn definitions with care. For half-life, it is the number of nuclei or the activity that is halved. Candidates frequently referred to either the halving of the mass of the sample or to nuclides/atoms/molecules. 
    2. The calculation presented very few problems but candidates should be advised to give full explanation where they are deriving a given answer. 
  2. The majority of answers were correct. Some candidates do need further practice with calculations where large numbers are involved, particularly the manipulation of powers-of-ten.
  3. Whether caused by a failure to read carefully the question or whether there was doubt as to what was required by the question, the major difficulty occurred when attempting to determine the number of sulfur-33 nuclei. 
NO. 462题号：1433
  1. State the experimental observations that show radioactive decay is
    1. spontaneous,
      .....................................................................[1]
    2. random.
      .....................................................................[1]
  2. On Fig. 7.1, complete the charge and mass of α-particles, β-particles and γ-radiation.
    Give example speeds of α-particles and γ-radiation emitted by a laboratory source. [3]
  3. Explain the process by which α-particles lose energy when they pass through air.
    ........................................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper2_2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i the half life / count rate / rate of decay / activity is the same no matter what external factors / environmental factors or two named factors such as temperature and pressure changes are applied B1 [1]
a.ii the observations of the count rate / count rate / rate of decay / activity / radioactivity during decay shows variations / fluctuations B1 [1]
b
property α-particle β-particle γ-radiation
charge (+)2e –e 0
mass 4u 9.11 × 10–31kg 0
speed 0.01 to 0.1c up to 0.99 c c
one mark for each correct line 		 B3 [3]
c collision with molecules
causes ionisation (of the molecule) / electron is removed		 B1
B1		 [2]
    1. spontaneous: Rate of decay or half-life does not vary due to change in external factors i.e. temperature, pressure, humidity factor, electric or magnetic field.
    2. random: Fluctuations in the decay curve indicates random nature.
      The variation in count rate show random process.
  2.   α-particle β-particle γ-radiation
    charge +2e -e 0
    mass 4u 9.11 × 10-31 kg 0
    speed 1/10 c up to 0.99c c
  3. α-particles transfer their energy on collision to knock out electrons from atoms of air resulting a decrease in their energy.
  1. The majority of candidates did not answer the question, suggesting they had not read the question sufficiently carefully. The question asked for experimental observations, but most candidates instead gave explanations of the terms.
  2. The majority of candidates did not know the values required or did not give them in sufficient detail. Common errors included giving the charges as + and – instead of +2e and –e, or giving speeds greater than c for the α-particle and γ-radiation.
  3. A number of candidates were able to gain at least partial credit. A significant number of candidates considered the loss of energy to be due to either the α-particle becoming ionised or it decaying.
NO. 463题号：1432
  1. State what is meant by the binding energy of a nucleus.
    .................................................................................. [2]
  2. Show that the energy equivalence of 1.0 u is 930 MeV.
    .................................................................................. [3]
  3. Data for the masses of some particles and nuclei are given in Fig. 8.1.
           
    Use data from Fig. 8.1 and information from (b) to determine, in MeV,
    1. the binding energy of deuterium, 

      binding energy = ....................................... MeV  [2]
    2. the binding energy per nucleon of zirconium.

      binding energy per nucleon = ....................................... MeV  [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Summer/Paper4_3/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a energy required to separate nucleons in a nucleus
to infinity		 M1
A1		 [2]
b 1u = 1.66 × 10–27 kg
E = mc2
   = 1.66 × 10–27 × (3.0 × 108)2 
   = 1.49 × 10–10 J
   = (1.49 × 10–10) / (1.6 × 10–13)
   = 930 MeV
C1
M1

M1
A0		 [3]
c.i ∆m = 2.0141u – (1.0073 + 1.0087)u
      = –1.9 × 10–3u
binding energy = 1.9 × 10–3 × 930
                         =1.8MeV
C1

A1		 [2]
c.ii ∆m = (57 × 1.0087u) + (40 × 1.0073u) – 97.0980u
      = (–)0.69u
binding energy per nucleon = (0.69 × 930) / 97
                         = 6.61MeV		 C1

C1
A1		 [3]
  1. Energy required to completely separate the nucleons in a nucleus to an infinite distance.
  2. 1.0 u = 1.66 × 10-27 kg
    E = mc2
       = [(1.0)(1.66 × 10-27)][3.0 × 108]2 = 1.49 × 10-10 J
    1 ev = 1.60 × 10-19 J
    ⇒ 1 Mev = (106)(1.60 × 10-19) = 1.60 × 10-13 J
    1. Mass deficit = Δm
                  = mdeuterium - (mproton + mneutron)
                  = 2.0141 - (1.0073 + 1.0087)
                  = -1.9 × 10-3 u
      ΔE = (1.9 × 10-3)(930) = 1.77 MeV
    2. Δm = 97.0980 - [40(1.0073) + 57(1.0087)] = -0.69 u
      ΔE = (0.69)(930) = 642 MeV

      binding energy per nucleon = 6.61 MeV

Comment on answer
(e) (ii) Number of protons = 40
Number of neutrons = 97 - 40 = 57
