  1. There was some confusion between the terms nucleus, nucleon and nuclide. Nuclear binding energy involves separating the nucleons of a nucleus to infinity.
  2. The most common error was to misquote the atomic mass unit as being 1.67 × 10–27 kg. This lead to an answer of 939 MeV which was, invariably, then assumed to be 930 MeV. Others did not show clearly how energy in joule is converted to energy in MeV.
  3. It was expected that candidates would determine the mass defect and then, in (i) they would multiply this defect by 930. In (ii), they would multiply the defect by 930/97. Unfortunately, many did not calculate a mass defect, but instead used the total mass of one of the particles.
NO. 464题号：1424

In some power stations, nuclear fission is used as a source of energy.

  1. State what is meant by nuclear fission.
    ......................................................................[2]
  2. The nuclear fission reaction produces neutrons. In the power station, the neutrons may be absorbed by rods made of boron-10.
    Complete the nuclear equation for the absorption of a single neutron by a boron-10 nucleus with the emission of an α-particle.
      [3]
  3. Suggest why, when neutrons are absorbed in the boron rods, the rods become hot as a result of this nuclear reaction.
    ..................................................................[3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper4_2/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a splitting of a heavy nucleus  (not atom/nuclide)
into two (lighter) nuclei of approximately same mass		 M1
A1		 [2]
b M2
A1		 [3]
c emitted particles have kinetic energy
range of particles in the control rods is short / particles stopped in rods / lose kinetic energy in rods
kinetic energy of particles converted to thermal energy		 B1
B1
B1		 [3]
  1. Splitting up of a heavy nucleus into two intermediate nuclei along with the release of energy.
  3. The neutrons have kinetic energy. The Boron rod stop these moving neutrons and their change of kinetic energy becomes the thermal energy which results in an increase of temperature.

Comment on answer
(b) Nucleon number, proton number and mass-energy are all conserved in nuclear processes.
  1. Candidates need to appreciate the difference between the terms atom, nucleus, nucleon and nuclide. In nuclear fission, it is a 'heavy' nucleus that forms two 'lighter' nuclei of approximately the same mass.
  2. Candidates should be advised not to use an upper case N as the symbol for the neutron. 
  3. There were very few explanations where the candidate demonstrated any real understanding of the situation. Most explanations were based on the notion that the neutrons would give off ‘heat and light’ when they are absorbed in the boron rods. Seldom was any reference made to the nuclear equation in (b). Candidates did not appreciate that the lithium nucleus and the α-particle would have kinetic energy and that this would be transferred in the rods.
NO. 465题号：1421

The results of the α-particle scattering experiment provided evidence for the existence and small size of the nucleus.

  1. State the result that provided evidence for
    1. the small size of the nucleus, compared with the atom,
      ..................................................................[2]
    2. the nucleus being charged and containing the majority of the mass of the atom.
      ..................................................................[2]
  2. The a-particles in this experiment originated from the decay of a radioactive nuclide. Suggest two reasons why β-particles from a radioactive source would be inappropriate for this type of scattering experiment.
    1. .....................................................................
    2. ..................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper2_2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i most α-particles were deviated through small angles
(allow 1 mark for 'straight through' / undeviated)		 B2 [2]
a.ii small fraction of α-particles deviated through large angles
greater than 90° (allow rebound back)		 M1
A1		 [2]
b e.g. β-particles have a range of energies
 β-particles deviated by (orbital) electrons
 β-particle has (very) small mass
 (any two sensible suggestions, 1 each, max 2)		 B2 [2]
Do not allow β-particles have negative charge or β-particles have high speed    
    1. A large number of a-particles were deflected through small angles.
    2. The electrostatic repulsion of a-particles from gold nucleus deflect a smaller fraction of α-particle at an angle greater then 90°.
    1. β-particles are smaller in mass and are deflected by the orbiting electrons of an atom.
    2. β-particles have a range of energies.
  1. The majority of the candidates did not state the result that was the relevant evidence for the two conclusions given in the question. The answers given suggested that the candidates had not read the questions carefully. Often all the evidence was given in (a)(i) or the structure of the atom was described in detail. Many of the answers that did attempt to give the required evidence did not gain any credit because the statements given were not comparative. The use of 'some', 'a small number', 'many' or 'large number' was not accepted. The answers that were required included such statements as 'a small proportion', 'most' or 'the majority'. 
  2. There were very few answers that achieved full credit. Many candidates stated different properties of β-particles without considering whether they were relevant to the context of the question. 
NO. 466题号：1420

Americium-241 is an artificially produced radioactive element that emits α-particles.
A sample of americium-241 of mass 5.1 µg is found to have an activity of 5.9 × 105 Bq.

  1. Determine, for this sample of americium-241,
    1. the number of nuclei,

      number = ............................................... [2]
    2. the decay constant,

      decay constant = ........................................ s–1 [2]
    3. the half-life, in years.

      half-life = .................................... years [2]
  2. Another radioactive element has a half-life of approximately 4 hours.
    Suggest why measurement of the mass and activity of a sample of this element is not appropriate for the determination of its half-life.
    ................................................................................... [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper4_2/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a.i number = (5.1 × 10–6 × 6.02 × 1023) / 241
             = 1.27 × 1016		 C1
A1		 [2]
a.ii A = λN
5.9 × 105 = λ × 1.27 × 1016
λ = 4.65 × 10–11 s–1		 C1

A1		 [2]
a.iii 4.65 × 10–11 × t½ = ln2
t½ = 1.49 × 1010 s
     = 470 years		 C1

A1		 [2]
b sample / activity would decay appreciably whilst measurements are being made B1 [1]
  2. Since half life is very small so the activity would change appreciably whilst measurements are being made.

The majority of candidates scored high marks on this question.

    1. The majority of candidates gave the correct answer. There was a tendency to round off calculations a little too early in the process. The weaker candidates had problems with the units and the powers of ten. 
    2. The majority of candidates gave the correct answer. 
    3. The majority of candidates gave the correct answer. The most common error was to fail to convert seconds into years correctly or at all. 
  2. The majority of answers stated that the half life was too short to measure and hence did not score the mark. There were very few answers that referred to the difficulty produced by the decay while measurements were being taken. 
NO. 467题号：1415
  1. The radioactive decay of some nuclei gives rise to the emission of α-particles. State
    1. what is meant by an α-particle,
      .......................................................................[1]
    2. two properties of α-particles.
      1. ..........................................................................
      2. .......................................................................... [2]
  2. One possible nuclear reaction involves the bombardment of a stationary nitrogen-14 nucleus by an a-particle to form oxygen-17 and another particle.
    1. Complete the nuclear equation for this reaction. [2]
         
    2. The total mass-energy of the nitrogen-14 nucleus and the α-particle is less than that of the particles resulting from the reaction. This mass-energy difference is 1.1 MeV.
      1. Suggest how it is possible for mass-energy to be conserved in this reaction.
        .................................................................[1]
      2. Calculate the speed of an α-particle having kinetic energy of 1.1 MeV.

        speed = ....................................... m s–1 [4]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper2_2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a.i either  helium nucleus
or  contains 2 protons and 2 neutrons		 B1 [1]
a.ii e.g. range is a few cm in air/sheet of thin paper
speed up to 0.1 c
causes dense ionisation in air
positively charged or deflected in magnetic or electric fields
(any two, 1 each to max 2)		 B2 [2]
b.i 42α B1 [2]
either  11p or 11H B1
b.ii 1. initially, α-particle must have some kinetic energy B1 [1]
2. 1.1 MeV = 1.1 × 1.6 × 10–13 = 1.76 × 10–13 J
EK = ½mv2
1.76 × 10–13 = ½ × 4 × 1.66 × 10–27 × v2
v = 7.3 × 106 m s–1
use of 1.67 × 10–27 kg for mass is a maximum of 3/4		 C1
C1
C1
A1

 [4]
    1. Helium nucleus.
      1. Positively charged particle and is deflected in an electric or magnetic field.
      2. α-particles cause greatest ionisation in air.
      1. Initially, all α-particles must have same kinetic energy.

Comment on answer
  1. Other properties are
    • Range in air is 5.0cm and can be stopped by a thin sheet of paper.
    • Speed in air or vacuum is 1/10 of speed of e.m. waves.
    1. Mass number, charge number, mass and energy are conserved in a nuclear reaction.
    2. • 1ev =1.60 ×10-19J
      • Mass of an α-particle = 4u and 1u = 1.66 × 10-27 kg.

The majority of candidates were able to score almost full marks for (a) and (b)(i). Very few candidates scored full marks for the remaining parts of the question.

    1. The majority of candidates gave the correct response. Only a small minority referred to a helium atom or particle and lost the mark.
    2. The majority of candidates gave two properties. Vague answers that did not score the marks were the 'least penetrating' or the 'most ionising'.
    1. The equation was generally completed correctly. The lack of knowledge of a symbol for the proton caused the weaker candidates to lose the second mark. 
    2. 1. The majority of candidates were unable to give a satisfactory answer. 
      2. The conversion of MeV into J was ignored by all but the very good candidates. The use of eV in examination papers is referred to in the 'Additional Information' section 3.4 of the syllabus. The mass of the α-particle was also incorrectly given by most candidates. Very few candidates obtained a correct value for the speed of the α-particle.
NO. 468题号：1406
  1. State what is meant by the decay constant of a radioactive isotope.
    .......................................................................... [2]
  2. Show that the decay constant λ is related to the half-life t½ by the expression
              λt½ =0.693.   [3]

  3. Cobalt-60 is a radioactive isotope with a half-life of 5.26 years (1.66×108 s).
    A cobalt-60 source for use in a school laboratory has an activity of 1.8×105 Bq.
    Calculate the mass of cobalt-60 in the source.

    mass = ............................................. g [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper4_2/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a (constant) probability of decay
per unit time
(reference to decay of isotope / mass / sample / nuclide, allow max 1 mark)		 M1
A1

 [2]
b either   when time = t½, N = ½N0
or   ½N0 = N exp(-λt½) t½
either  2 = exp(λt½)
or  ½ = exp(-λt½)
(taking logs), ln2 = 0.693 = λt½
M1

M1
A1		 [3]
c A = λN 
1.8 × 105 = N × (0.693 / {1.66 × 108})
N = 4.3 × 1013
mass = 60 × (N / NA)  or 60 × N × u
  = (60 × 4.3 × 1011) / (6.02 × 1023)
  = 4.3 × 10-9 g
C1

C1

A1		 [3]
  1. It is the probability of decay of a nucleus per unit time.
  2. The general eq. of decay life is: N = N0e-λt
    after first half life, t = t1/2 and N = N0/2

    taking natural log to both sides,
    In1 - ln2 =-), -λt1/2 In e
    0 - ln2 = -λt1/2 ⇒  λt1/2 = 0.693
  1. The concept that decay constant is the probability per unit time of the decay of a nucleus is still appreciated by only a minority of candidates. 
  2. There was more than one way of deriving the final expression. Good answers showed the derivation broken down into a series of small clear steps with each step carefully explained. 
  3. Many candidates were able to calculate the number of atoms in the cobalt-60 source. However, when calculating its mass, a common error was to omit either the molar mass or the Avogadro constant. Some mistakes led to a very large value which should have led candidates to check their working. 
NO. 469题号：1396
  1. A sample of a radioactive isotope contains N nuclei at time t. At time (t + Δt), it contains (N - ΔN) nuclei of the isotope.
    For the period Δt, state, in terms of N, ΔN and Δt,
    1. the mean activity of the sample,

      activity = ............................................... [1]
    2. the probability of decay of a nucleus.

      probability = ............................................... [1]
  2. A cobalt-60 source having a half-life of 5.27 years is calibrated and found to have an activity of 3.50 × 105 Bq. The uncertainty in the calibration is ±2%.
    Calculate the length of time, in days, after the calibration has been made, for the stated activity of 3.50 × 105 Bq to have a maximum possible error of 10%.

    time = ...................................... days [4]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Summer/Paper4/Q9
Question Answer Marks  
a.i ∆N / ∆t (ignore any sign) B1 [1]
a.ii ∆N / N (ignore any sign) B1 [1]
b source must decay by 8%
A = A0 exp(–ln2 t / T½) or A/ A0 = 1 / (2t/T)
0.92 = exp(–ln2 × t / 5.27) or 0.92 = 1 / (2t/5.27)
t = 0.634 years
  = 230 days
(allow 2 marks for A/ A0 = 0.08, answer 7010 days
allow 1 mark for A/ A0 = 0.12, answer 5880 days)		 C1
C1
C1

A1


 [4]
    1. activity = ΔN / Δt
      Rate of decay of a nucleus is called activity.
    2. probability = ΔN / N
  2. Absolute decay of source = (10 - 2)% = 8%
    So remaining activity = (100 - 8) = 92%

    taking natural log (In) to both sides,
  1. There were very few correct answers, even in (i).
  2. In many scripts, it was not appreciated that the radioactive decay equation should be used. Of those who did use the equation, very few realised that the source would have to decay by 8%.
NO. 470题号：1392

Thoron is a radioactive gas. The variation with time t of the detected count rate C from a sample of the gas is shown in Fig. 8.1.

Radioactive decay is said to be a random and spontaneous process.

  1. Explain, by reference to radioactive decay, what is meant by a random process.
    .............................................................................. [2]
  2. State the feature of Fig. 8.1 which indicates that the process is
    1. a decay process,
      .................................................................... [1]
    2. random.
      .................................................................... [1]
  3. A second similar sample of thoron is prepared but it is at a much higher temperature.
    The variation with time of the count rate for this second sample is determined.
    State the feature of the decay curves for the two samples that suggests that radioactive decay is a spontaneous process.
    .............................................................................. [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2008/Winter/Paper2/Q8
Question Answer Marks  
a nucleus has constant probability of decay
per unit time / in a given time
(allow 1 mark for 'cannot predict which nucleus will decay next') 		 M1
A1

 [2]
b.i count rate / activity decreases B1 [1]
b.ii count rate fluctuates / is not smooth B1 [1]
c either  the (decay) curves are similar / same
or  curves indicate same half-life		 B1 [1]
  1. There is a constant probability of decay of a nucleus per unit time.
    1. Count rate decreases with time.
    2. Fluctuations in graph shows random process.
  3. Decay curves have same shape or same half life at different temperatures.
    Spontaneous means independent of any physical condition i.e. temperature, pressure, humidity factor, electric or magnetic field.
  1. Many answers involved a statement that it is not possible to predict when a nucleus will decay. Such a statement is inadequate at AS Level. Others made reference to constant probability of decay without stating that this constant probability is per unit time. 
  2. With few exceptions, both parts were answered satisfactorily. 
  3. Most answers included a statement that the curves would be 'the same'. Usually, some explanation was given although this was not necessary. A minority of candidates thought that the curve would be steeper. 
NO. 471题号：1389

Uranium-236 (23692U) and Uranium-237 (23792U) are both radioactive.

Uranium-236 is an α-emitter and Uranium-237 is a β-emitter

  1. Distinguish between an α-particle and a β-particle.
    .................................................................................................[4]
  2. The grid of Fig.7.1 shows some proton numbers Z on the x-axis and the number N of neutrons in the nucleus on the y-axis.

    The α-decay of uranium-236(23692U) is represented on the grid. This decay produces a nucleus of thorium (Th).
    1. Write down the nuclear equation for this α-decay.
      ......................................................................................[2]
    2. On Fig, mark the position for a nucleus of
      1. Uranium-237 (mark this position with the letter U),
      2. Neptunium, the nucleus produced by the β-decay of Uranium-237 (mark this position with the letters Np).
        [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2008/Summer/Paper2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a α-particle: either  helium nucleus or  contains 2 protons + 2 neutrons or  42He B1 [4]
β-particle: either  electron or  0−1e B1
α speed < β speed (1)
α discrete values of speed/energy, β continuous spectrum (1)
either  α ionising power >> β ionising power
or  α range << β range (1)
α positive, β negative (only if first two B marks not scored) (1)
α mass > β mass (only if first two B marks not scored) (1)
(any two sensible pairs of statements relevant to differences, – do not allow statements relevant to only α or β, 1 each, max 2)		 B2
b.i M1
A1		 [2]
b.ii 1. correct position for U at Z = 92, N = 145
2. correct position for Np relative to U i.e. Z + 1 and N – 1		 B1
B1		 [2]
  1. Compare the properties in terms of nature, speed, ionising ability and range.
    1. α-particle is a helium nucleus while β is an electron.
    2. Speed of α-particle is lesser than β-particle
    3. Ionising power of α-particle is much greater than β.
    4. Range of α-particle is lesser than β.

    1. Proton no. = 90
      Neutron no. = 142
      Mass no. of thorium = 90 + 142 = 232
  1. Most candidates attempted to relate α- and β-particles to helium nuclei and electrons respectively. However, many stated that an α-particle is a helium atom. Others thought that α- / β-particles are emitted by helium nuclei / electrons. Many candidates compared properties such as speed, range and ionising power. However, such comparisons frequently either lacked sufficient detail or were inaccurate so that credit could not be given.
    1. Most candidates correctly gave the required equation. The most common error was the representation of the α-particle with some symbol other than that of a helium nucleus.
    2. Most candidates did show the correct position on the grid for uranium-237. Comparatively few positioned the neptunium nucleus to show that β-decay resulted in an increase by one in the proton number and a corresponding decrease in the neutron number. 
NO. 472题号：1386
  1. Explain what is meant by the binding energy of a nucleus.
    ...........................................................................[1]
  2. Fig.7.1 shows the variation with nucleon number (mass number) A of the binding energy per nucleon EB of nuclei.

    One particular fission reaction may be represented by the nuclear equation
             
    1. On Fig, label the approximate positions of
      1. the uranium  nucleus with the symbol U,
      2. the barium  nucleus with the symbol Ba,
      3. the krypton  nucleus with the symbol Kr.
        [2]
    2. The neutron that is absorbed by the uranium nucleus has very little kinetic energy. Explain why this fission reaction is energetically possible.
      .........................................................................[2]
  3. Barium-141 has a half-life of 18 minutes. The half-life of Krypton-92 is 3.0 s.
    In the fission reaction of a mass of Uranium-235, equal numbers of barium and krypton nuclei are produced.
    Estimate the time taken after the fission of the sample of uranium for the ratio
              
    to be approximately equal to 8.

    time = ............................................... s [3]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2007/Winter/Paper4/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a energy required to (completely) separate the nucleons (in a nucleus) B1 [1]
b.i U labelled near right-hand end of line
Ba and Kr in approximately correct positions		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.ii binding energy is A × EB
either binding energy of U < binding energy of (Ba + Kr)
or  EB of U < EB of (Ba + Kr)		 B1

B1		 [2]
c Krypton-92 reduced to 1/8 in 9 s
in 9 s, very little decay of Barium-141
so, approximately 9 s		 M1
M1
A1		 [3]
OR
λKr = 0.231 or λBa = 6.42 × 10-4  (M1)
8 = e-λB × t/e-λK × t  (C1)
t = 9.0 s  (A1)		  
  1. It is the amount of energy required tocompletely separate the nucleons in a nucleus.
    2. Since binding energy of a nucleus EB × A . Graph shows that binding energy of uranium is lesser than sum of binding energy of Sa and Kr. So uranium is more unstable.

  3. Taking natural log (In) to both sides

Comment on answer

(b) (ii) State initially what is meant by binding energy and then compare the binding energy of the uranium nucleus to that of the products.

(c) Change 18 minutes into seconds to get decay constants of both nuclei in same units.
N0 represents the number of undecayed atoms at time, t = 0.

  1. It is expected that the majority of candidates would be awarded full credit for knowledge such as this. However, many candidates referred to removing either protons or neutrons from the nucleus, rather than separating nucleons to infinity. 
    1. Less able candidates labelled the peaks. Many showed the krypton at the maximum of the graph. 
    2. Very few candidates had any real understanding of the situation. Some did refer to stability but at no time did they discuss the meaning of this term. Many did not make a comparison between the parent nucleus and the products. Instead, they merely referred to the stability of the uranium nucleus. 
      For a comprehensive answer, candidates should state what is meant by binding energy and then compare the binding energy of the uranium nucleus to that of the products. 
  3. A small number of candidates stated that, in 9 s, the amount of krypton would be reduced to 1/8. However, they did not go on to say that in this same period of 9 s, there would be negligible decay of the barium.
    There were some excellent answers based on a full mathematical treatment. This was not necessary. On the other hand, many candidates could do no more than calculate the decay constant for each nuclide. 
NO. 473题号：1380
  1. Define the decay constant of a radioactive isotope.
    ................................................................................. [2]
  2. Strontium-90 is a radioactive isotope having a half-life of 28.0 years. Strontium-90 has a density of 2.54g cm-3.
    A sample of Strontium-90 has an activity of 6.4 × 109 Bq. Calculate
    1. the decay constant λ. , in s-1, of Strontium-90,

      λ = …………………………. s–1 [2]
    2. the mass of Strontium-90 in the sample,

      mass = …………………………. g [4]
    3. the volume of the sample.

      volume = …………………………. cm3 [1]
  3. By reference to your answer in (b)(iii), suggest why dust that has been contaminated with Strontium-90 presents a serious health hazard.
    ............................................................................................. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2007/Summer/Paper4/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a probability of decay
of a nucleus per unit time
(allow 1 mark for A = λN, with symbols explained)		 M1
A1

 [2]
b.i λ = ln2/(28 × 365 × 24 × 3600)
= 7.85 × 10–10 s–1		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.ii A = (–)λN
N = (6.4 × 109)/(7.85 × 10–10)
= 8.15 × 1018
mass = (8.15 × 1018 × 90)/(6.02 × 1023) (e.c.f. for value of N)
= 1.22 × 10–3 g
C1
C1
C1
A1		 [4]
b.iii volume = (1.22 × 10–3/2.54 =) 4.8 × 10–4 cm3 A1 [1]
c either very small volume of Strontium-90 has high activity
or dust can be highly radioactive
breathing in dust presents health hazard
B1
B1		 [2]
  1. It is the probability of decay of a nucleus per unit time.

    2. 6.02 x 1023 atoms have mass = 90g
      1 atom has mass = 
      8.15 x 1018 atoms have mass =  x (8.15 x 1018) = 1.22 x 10-3 g
  3. Since volume of dust is small and Strontium-90 make the dust highly radioactive that can cause health hazard during breathing (inhaling).

Comment on answer

(a) 

(b) (i) Change half-life from years to get answer in seconds.
(b) (ii) Neglect negative sign as number is always positive.

  1. The basic concept that decay constant is the probability of decay of a nucleus per unit time is still appreciated by only a small minority of candidates.
  2. There were many scripts where it was clear that this type of calculation had been rehearsed in that even weaker students were able to score full credit on (i) and (ii). There were, regrettably, a small number of candidates who did not understand how to approach the problem
    1. A small number of candidates failed either to calculate correctly the number of seconds in one year or they determined λ in yr-1. Significantly, there were some candidates who gave the number of days in one year as (30 × 12). 
    2. With few exceptions, the number of nuclei in the sample was calculated correctly. However, when determining the mass, it was common to find that either the Avogadro constant or the molar mass was omitted. Some very large, or very small, values were found that did not raise any comment. 
    3. Generally, the expression for density was known. However, the astronomic volumes that were sometimes generated did not raise comment.
  3. Most candidates made a reference to inhaling the radioactive material even when the calculated volume was very large. Very few realised that the small volume of radioactive material would have a large activity or that, because the volume is small, the dust could come become contaminated easily. 
NO. 474题号：1375

The radioactive decay of a strontium (Sr) nucleus is represented in Fig.7.1.

  1. State whether Fig.7.1 represents α-decay, β-decay, or γ-decay.
    ........................................................................................ [1]
  2. One type of radioactive decay cannot be represented on Fig.7.1
    Identify this decay and explain why it cannot be represented.
    ...................................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2007/Summer/Paper2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a β(-decay) B1 [1] 
b γ(-decay)
either  any two of Z, N and A do not change
or  it is loss of energy only
or  it is an electromagnetic wave		 B1


B1		 [2]
Allow 'α(-decay) as change of 4 in the nucleon number cannot be shown on the diagram'
Do not give credit for a 'bald' α(-decay)		 (B2)
  1. β-decay
  2. γ-decay because it is an electromagnetic wave and there is no change in proton and nucleon number.
    Other valid answer can be α-decay becausea change of 4 in the nucleon number cannot be shown on the diagram.
  1. With few exceptions the correct answer was quoted.
  2. It was pleasing to note that most answers were given with an explanation. The answer that was expected was γ-radiation because this would not affect either the nucleon number or the proton number. However, some candidates had spotted that, for α-decay, the nucleon number would be reduced by four and that this could not be represented on Fig. 7.1. This latter approach, if explained, was given credit.
NO. 475题号：1328

Strontium-90 decays with the emission of a β-particle to form Yttrium-90. The reaction is represented by the equation

The decay constant is 0.025 year-1.

  1. Suggest, with a reason, which nucleus,   or , has the greater binding energy.
    ........................................................................................ [2]
  2. Explain what is meant by the decay constant.
    ........................................................................................ [2]
  3. At the time of purchase of a Strontium-90 source, the activity is 3.7 × 106 Bq.
    1. Calculate, for this sample of Strontium,
      1. the initial number of atoms,

        number = ……………………………………. [3]
      2. the initial mass.

        mass = ………………………………. kg [2]
    2. Determine the activity A of the sample 5.0 years after purchase, expressing the answer as a fraction of the initial activity A0, That is, calculate the ratio A/A0.

      ratio = ………………………………….. [2] 
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2003/Summer/Paper4/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a greater binding energy gives rise to release of energy
so must be yttrium		 M1 
A1		 [2]
b probability of decay
of a nucleus per unit time		 M1
A1		 [2]
c.i.1 A = N
3.7 × 106 × 365 × 24 × 3600 = 0.025N
N = 4.67 × 1015		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
c.i.2 mass = 0.09 × (4.67 × 1015)/(6.02 × 1023)
         = 6.98 × 10-10 kg		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.ii A = A0 e-λt
A/A0 = e-0.025t
         = 0.88
C1 
A1		 [2]
  1. has the greater binding energy.
    This is because energy is released wh.en   decays into .
  2. The decay constant A is the constant of proportionality that relates the activity, A of a radioactive substance to the number, N of radioactive nuclei present
    A = λN
      2. Initial mass = N x mass of one Sr nucleus (assume mp ≈ mn )
        = 4.67 x 1015 x (90 x 1.67 x 10-27)
        = 7.02 x 10-10 kg

    2. 5 years after purchase, 

Comment on answer
(e) (i)

  1. Answers were disappointing. Very few candidates stated that yttrium would have greater binding energy because the strontium gives off energy when it decays. Most thought that the strontium would have the greater binding energy 'because it gives off energy when it decays'.
  2. Most realised that decay constant is concerned with a probability of decay. Just what would decay, and in what period of time, was frequently highly confused. Candidates must learn to distinguish between atoms, nuclei, nuclides and isotopes.
  3. In general, the calculations involving radioactive decay were done well. As is usually the case, there was confusion amongst less able candidates as to how to convert a number of nuclei to a mass. That is, a calculation involving the Avogadro constant.
NO. 476题号：1325
  1. Describe apparatus that demonstrates Brownian motion. Include a diagram.
    ....................................................................................[2]
  2. Describe the observations made using the apparatus in (a).
    ....................................................................................[2]
  3. State and explain two conclusions about the properties of molecules of a gas that follow from the observations in (b).
    1. ..............................................................................
    2. .............................................................................. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper2_2/Q4
Question Answer Marks  
a apparatus: cell with particles e.g. smoke (container must be closed)
diagram showing suitable arrangement with light illumination and microscope		 B1
B1		 [2]
b specks / flashes of light
in random motion		 M1
A1		 [2]
c cannot see what is causing smoke to move hence molecules smaller than smoke particles (B1) max. 2 [2]
continuous motion of smoke particles implies continuous motion of molecules (B1)
random motion of particles implies random motion of molecules (B1)

  1. The smoke along with air particles are enclosed in a small transparent cell. The smoke particles are strongly illuminated from a side and their motion is viewed by using a microscope as shown above.
  2. Small specks of light that move haphazardly/ randomly through out the smoke cell.
    1. Random motion of smoke particles shows the random motion of gas / air particles.
    2. Continuous motion of smoke particles provide an evidence for the perpetual motion of gas/air particles.

Candidates found this question difficult.

  1. The majority of diagrams did not include a source of light or smoke or a closed cell. Only a small minority drew carefully labelled diagrams. A significant number described an experiment on diffusion of gases. 
  2. Very few candidates described the observations of random movement of specks of light. The majority referred to the smoke particles and gave conclusions rather than observations. 
  3. The majority of candidates did not give the detail asked for in the question. An explanation was rarely associated with a given statement. Many gave properties of an ideal gas or statements from the kinetic theory. 
NO. 477题号：1323
    1. State one similarity between the processes of evaporation and boiling.
      .................................................................. [1]
    2. State two differences between the processes of evaporation and boiling.
      1. .................................................................
      2. ................................................................. [4]
  2. Titanium metal has a density of 4.5 g cm-3.
    A cube of titanium of mass 48 g contains 6.0×1023 atoms.
    1. Calculate the volume of the cube.

      volume = ......................................... cm3 [1]
    2. Estimate
      1. the volume occupied by each atom in the cube,

        volume = ......................................... cm3 [1]
      2. the separation of the atoms in the cube.

        separation = .......................................... cm [1]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper2_2/Q2
Question Answer Marks  
a.i e.g. (phase) change from liquid to gas / vapour
 thermal energy required to maintain constant temperature
 (do not allow 'convert water to steam') 		 B1 [1]
a.ii e.g. evaporation takes place at surface
  boiling takes place in body of the liquid
e.g. evaporation occurs at all temperatures
  boiling occurs at one temperature		 B1
B1
B1
B1		 [4]
b.i volume = 10.7 cm3  A1 [1]
b.ii 1. volume = 10.7 / (6.0 × 1023)
   = 1.8 × 10-23 cm3		 A1 [1]
2. separation = 3√(1.8 × 10-23)
   = 2.6 × 10-8 cm		 A1 [1]
    [Total: 8]
    1. In both these processes, a liquid changes to vapour state.
      1. Evaporation occurs at the surface of liquid. Boiling occurs throughout the liquid.
      2. Evaporation occurs at any temperature. Boiling occurs at one temperature.
      1.  
      2.   

Comment on answer:
  1. (i) Thermal energy need to be supplied to maintain constant temperature during both processes.
    (ii) Other differences are:
    • The temperature of liquid during evaporation decreases. The temperature of liquid during boiling remain constant.
    • No bubbles are formed during evaporation. Bubbles are formed during boiling.
  2. (ii) The mean separation between two atoms is equal to its size. If 'd' is the separation, then the volume of an atom, V ∝ d3
    1. Most answers included a reference to change of state from liquid to gas/vapour. The need to supply thermal energy to maintain constant temperature during both processes was also accepted.
    2. Answers were, in general, quite comprehensive although a minority found difficulty when expressing the fact that evaporation occurs at any temperature of the liquid. 
    1. This was answered correctly by most candidates.  
    2. The calculation in 1 of the volume occupied by each atom presented very few problems. However, in 2, only a minority realised that, in order to find the separation of the atoms, then it is necessary to take the cube root of the answer in 1. Candidates should be encouraged to consider the answers they obtain so that ridiculous answers, produced as a result of power-of-ten errors, can be avoided. 
NO. 478题号：1322
  1. Define density.
    ............................................................................... [1]
  2. Liquid of density ρ fills a container to a depth h, as illustrated in Fig.3.1.

    The container has vertical sides and a base of area A.
    1. State, in terms of A, h and ρ, the mass of liquid in the container.
      ...................................................................................[1] 
    2. Hence derive an expression for the pressure ρ exerted by the liquid on the base of the container. Explain your working. [2]

  3. The density of liquid water is 1.0g cm-3. The density of water vapour at atmospheric pressure is approximately g cm-3.
    Determine the ratio


    1. ratio = ..................................................[1]


    2. ratio = ...................................................[2]
  4. State the evidence for
    1. the molecules in solids and liquids having approximately the same separation,
      ...................................................................................[1]
    2. strong rigid forces between molecules in solids.
      strong: ......................................................................
      rigid: ......................................................................... [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2007/Summer/Paper2/Q3
Question Answer Marks  
a mass / volume (ratio idea essential) B1 [1]
b.i mass = Ahρ B1 [1]
b.ii pressure = force/area
weight (of liquid)/force (on base) = Ahρg
pressure = hρg		 B1
B1
A0		 [2]
c.i ratio = 1600 or 1600:1 A1 [1]
c.ii ratio = 3√1600
        = 11.7  (allow 12)		 C1
A1		 [2]
d.i density of solids and liquids are (about) equal B1 [1]
d.ii strong forces: fixed volume
rigid forces: retains shape / does not flow / little deformation
(allow 1 mark for fixed volume, fixed shape)		 B1
B1

 [2]
    1. Mass per unit volume is called density.
      1. m = ρhA
      1. Density of solids and liquids are equal.
      2. strong: volume is fixed
        rigid: does not flow and retain shape
Comment on answer:
(b)(i) Note that:
m = ρ v
m = ρ Ah, as volume = area x height
(c) 
(i) Liquid water expands when it evaporates and so answer must be greater than 1.
(ii) The mean separation between two molecules is equal to its size. If 'd' is the separation, then the volume of the molecule (assuming spherical) is given by
the density of moleculeis then inversely proportional to the mean separation 'd' raised to the power of three.
  1. There were many correct responses. However, a minority did not indicate that a ratio is involved or gave units in the definition. 'Mass of 1 m3' is not credit-worthy.
    1. With few exceptions, the correct relation was given.
    2. Candidates were instructed to explain their working. There were some very good, clearly expressed answers. However, approximately one half of all candidates gave their answers in symbols and with no explanation. 
      Where candidates are told to explain their working, then it is expected that, for full credit, symbols will be explained. 
    1. The vast majority of candidates gave the answer as either 1600 or 1/1600. For those who gave the answer as 1/1600, it would have been worthwhile for them to reflect on the answer they had written down. Liquid water expands when it evaporates and so the answer must be greater than 1! 
    2. There were very few correct answers involving the cube root. Many candidates just wrote down the same answer they had given in (i). 
    1. Frequently, the question was paraphrased, rather than given in terms of macroscopic evidence for the molecular behaviour. It was common for an answer to be based on 'the separations are about equal' rather than to consider density or change in volume on melting.
    2. The strong forces may be indicated by the fact that the volume is fixed whereas rigid forces are indicated by fixed shape. Frequently, candidates were unable to distinguish between the two, giving an answer such as 'hard to compress' for rigid forces. This answer is not only inappropriate but also applies to liquids as well as solids. 
NO. 479题号：1317

Positively charged particles are travelling in a vacuum through three narrow slits S1, S2 and S3,  as shown in Fig. 5.1.

Each particle has speed v and charge q.
There is a uniform magnetic field of flux density B and a uniform electric field of field strength E in the region between the slits S2 and S3.

  1. State the expression for the force F acting on a charged particle due to
    1. the magnetic field,
      ..............................................................[1]
    2. the electric field.
      ..............................................................[1]
  2. The electric field acts downwards in the plane of the paper, as shown in Fig. 5.1.
    State and explain the direction of the magnetic field so that the positively charged particles may pass undeviated through the region between slits S2 and S3.
    ..............................................................[2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2011/Winter/Paper4_1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i Bqv(sinθ)  or  Bqv(cosθ) B1 [1]
a.ii qE B1 [1]
b FB must be opposite in direction to FE
so magnetic field into plane of paper		 B1
B1		 [2]
    1. F = Bqv sin θ
    2. F = Eq
  2. Magnetic field is directed into the plane of page because downward Electric force is balanced by upward magnetic force.
  1. In general, correct expressions were given in both parts. Candidates should be encouraged to use the symbols that are specified in the question.
  2. It should have been noted that the direction of the force due to the electric field must be in the opposite direction to that provided by the magnetic field. Even where this was stated clearly by the candidate, the direction of the magnetic field was often incorrect.  
NO. 480题号：1305

A charged particle of mass m and charge –q is travelling through a vacuum at constant speed v.
It enters a uniform magnetic field of flux density B. The initial angle between the direction of motion of the particle and the direction of the magnetic field is 90°.

  1. Explain why the path of the particle in the magnetic field is the arc of a circle.
    .......................................................................[3]
  2. The radius of the arc in (a) is r.
    Show that the ratio  for the particle is given by the expression
            [1]
  3. The initial speed v of the particle is 2.0 × 107 m s–1. The magnetic flux density B is 2.5 × 10–3 T.
    The radius r of the arc in the magnetic field is 4.5 cm.
    1. Use these data to calculate the ratio .

      ratio = ...................................... C kg–1 [2]
    2. The path of the negatively-charged particle before it enters the magnetic field is shown in Fig. 6.1.

      The direction of the magnetic field is into the plane of the paper.
      On Fig. 6.1, sketch the path of the particle in the magnetic field and as it emerges from the field. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Winter/Paper4_1/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a force due to magnetic field is constant
force is (always) normal to direction of motion
this force provides the centripetal force		 B1

A1		 [3]
b mv2 / r = Bqv
hence q / m = v / Br		 M1
A0		 [1]
c.i q / m = (2.0 × 107) / (2.5 × 10–3 × 4.5 × 10–2)
   = 1.8 × 1011 C kg–1		 C1
A1		 [2]
c.ii sketch: curved path, constant radius, in direction towards bottom of page
tangent to curved path on entering and on leaving the field		 M1
A1		 [2]
  1. Magnitude of force on moving charged particle is constant due to constant charge, speed and perpendicular uniform magnetic flux density by F = Bqv sin 90°. Also the direction of force is normal to both field lines and initial direction of motion of charged particle. Therefore this force provides centripetal force to trace a curved path.
  2. Magnetic force provides centripetal force

    2. Fleming's left-hand rule is used to determine the direction of magnetic force.
  1. Candidates found this explanation challenging. Most were based, simply, on the force in the magnetic field providing the centripetal force. Many stated that the force would be normal to the magnetic field, rather than the direction of motion. Very few stated that the force would have a constant magnitude. 
  2. With few exceptions, the derivation was acceptable.
    1. Apart from occasional arithmetical errors, the calculation caused very few problems.
    2. Candidates should realise that any line should show the main features. Many rough sketches were drawn with a varying radius within the region of the field. The path on entering and leaving the region of the field should be a tangent to the curved path. Often the path was drawn with a pronounced kink. 
NO. 481题号：1304
  1. Define the tesla.
    .............................................................................. [2]
  2. Two long straight vertical wires X and Y are separated by a distance of 4.5 cm, as illustrated in Fig. 5.1.

    The wires pass through a horizontal card PQRS.
    The current in wire X is 6.3 A in the upward direction. Initially, there is no current in wire Y.
    1. On Fig.5.1, sketch, in the plane PQRS, the magnetic flux pattern due to the current in wire X. Show at least four flux lines. [3]

    2. The magnetic flux density B at a distance x from a long straight currentcarrying wire is given by the expression
       
      where I is the current in the wire and µ0 is the permeability of free space.  µ0 = 4π × 10–7H m–1 
      Calculate the magnetic flux density at wire Y due to the current in wire X.

      flux density = .............................................. T [2]
    3. A current of 9.3 A is now switched on in wire Y. Use your answer in (ii) to calculate the force per unit length on wire Y.

      force per unit length = ....................................... N m–1 [2]
  3. The currents in the two wires in (b)(iii) are not equal.
    Explain whether the force per unit length on the two wires will be the same, or different.

A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper4_2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a (uniform magnetic) flux normal to long (straight) wire carrying a current of 1 A
(creates) force per unit length of 1 N m–1		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i sketch: concentric circles
   increasing separation (must show more than 3 circles)
   correct direction (anticlockwise, looking down)		 M1
A1
B1		 [3]
b.ii B = (4π × 10–7 × 6.3) / (2π × 4.5 × 10–2)
   = 2.8 × 10–5 T		 C1
A1		 [2]
b.iii F = BIL (sinθ)
  = 2.8 × 10–5 × 9.3 × 1
  F/L = 2.6 × 10–4 N m–1		 C1

A1		 [2]
c force per unit length depends on product IXIY / by Newton's third law / action and reaction are equal and opposite
so same for both
M1
A1		 [2]
  1. Magnetic flux density is 1 tesla if a force of 1 N is experienced by 1 m length of a conductor carrying a current of 1 A when placed perpendicular to magnetic-field lines.

    1. Concentric circular pattern.
      Field is non-uniform, so separation between field lines increases.
      Direction of magnetic field is obtained by right hand grip rule.
  3. Force between two parallel conductors depends directly on product of their currents.
    So force per unit length on both wires is equal in magnitude but opposite in directions by Newton's third law.
  1. In general, definitions were not well expressed. Comparatively few even suggested that the tesla measures magnetic flux density. The statement frequently began with wording such as "A force of 1 N acting on a wire…" or "A conductor carrying a current of 1 A has a force…". 
    1. With few exceptions, diagrams illustrated concentric circles with the correct direction. However, very few were drawn with sufficient care to show the relative separation of the lines. 
    2. Apart from power-of-ten errors, this calculation was completed successfully in most scripts.
    3. Again, this was generally answered correctly. Some less able candidates did not realise that the force per unit length was required and, consequently, included the distance 4.5 cm in the calculation, despite this distance not being a length of any conductor. 
  3. Answers to this question tended to be Centre-dependent. Some candidates based their argument on Newton's third law. Others realised that the force per unit length depends on the product of the two currents. Both approaches were quite acceptable. Some candidates stated that the force would be different because the currents are different.  
NO. 482题号：1302
    1. State the condition for a charged particle to experience a force in a magnetic field.
      ...................................................................[2]
    2. State an expression for the magnetic force F acting on a charged particle in a magnetic field of flux density B. Explain any other symbols you use.
      ...................................................................[2]
  2. A sample of a conductor with rectangular faces is situated in a magnetic field, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

    The magnetic field is normal to face ABCD in the downward direction.
    Electrons enter face CDHG at right-angles to the face. As the electrons pass through the conductor, they experience a force due to the magnetic field.
    1. On Fig. 6.1, shade the face to which the electrons tend to move as a result of this force. [1]

    2. The movement of the electrons in the magnetic field causes a potential difference between two faces of the conductor.
      Using the lettering from Fig, state the faces between which this potential difference will occur.

      face ................... and face .................[1]
  3. Explain why the potential difference in (b) causes an additional force on the moving electrons in the conductor.
    ...........................................................................[2]

A level PHYSICS 2012/Winter/Paper4_1/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i particle must be moving
with component of velocity normal to magnetic field		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii F = Bqv sin θ
q, v and θ explained		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i face BCGF shaded A1 [1]
b.ii between face BCGF and face ADHE A1 [1]
c potential difference gives rise to an electric field
either FE = qE  (no need to explain symbols) 
or electric field gives rise to force (on an electron)		 M1

A1		 [2]
    1. Since F = Bqv sin θ ⇒ F = Bqv sin 90°
      Charge must move (v ≠ 0) and the velocity or its component must be perpendicular to magnetic field lines.
    2. F = Bqv sin θ, where,
      q-charge on particle, v-velocity of particle and θ-angle between magnetic flux density and motion (velocity) of the particle.

    1. Fleming's left hand rule is used to determine direction .
    2. face ADHE and face BCGF.
  3. Potential difference provides an electric field which therefore gives rise to force on electrons by F = vq /d
    1. Many candidates thought that the particle must be moving at right-angles to the direction of the field. A common answer was to state that the particle must be normal to the field, without any reference to motion.
    2. The most usual answer was F = Bqv, with no reference to an angle. 
    1. There appeared to be a large element of guesswork when attempting to identify the correct face. 
    2. Surprisingly, many candidates who did identify the correct face in (i), did not then specify this in (ii). Frequently, the faces specified where not on opposite faces of the block.
  3. Some candidates did recognise that an electric field would be established and that this field would give rise to a force on the electrons.
NO. 483题号：1290
  1. Define the tesla.
    .............................................................................[3]
  2. A horseshoe magnet is placed on a balance. A stiff metal wire is clamped horizontally between the poles, as illustrated in Fig. 5.1.

    The magnetic flux density in the space between the poles of the magnet is uniform and is zero outside this region.
    The length of the metal wire normal to the magnetic field is 6.4 cm.
    When a current in the wire is switched on, the reading on the balance increases by 2.4 g. The current in the wire is 5.6 A.
    1. State and explain the direction of the force on the wire due to the current.
      ......................................................................[3]
    2. Calculate the magnitude of the magnetic flux density between the poles of the magnet.

      flux density = ...............................................T [2]
  3. A low frequency alternating current is now passed through the wire in (b).
    The root-mean-square (r.m.s.) value of the current is 5.6 A.
    Describe quantitatively the variation of the reading seen on the balance.
    .........................................................................[2]

A level PHYSICS 2012/Summer/Paper4_2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a (long) straight conductor carrying current of 1A
current/wire normal to magnetic field
(for flux density 1T,) force per unit length is 1Nm–1		 M1
M1
A1		 [3]
b.i (originally) downward force on magnet (due to current)
by Newton's third law (allow "N3")
upward force on wire		 B1
M1
A1		 [3]
b.ii F = BIL
2.4 × 10–3 × 9.8 = B × 5.6 × 6.4 × 10–2
B = 0.066T (need 2SF)
(g missing scores 0/2, but g = 10 leading to 0.067T scores 1/2)		 C1
A1		 [2]
c new reading is 2.4√2g
either  changes between +3.4g and –3.4g
or  total change is 6.8g		 C1

A1		 [2]
  1. Magnetic flux density is 1T if a force of 1 N is experienced by 1 m length of a conductor carrying 1 A current when placed perpendicular to magnetic field lines.
    1. An increase in balance reading indicates an increase of downward force on magnet due to current in wire. So wire experienced an upward force as per Newton's third law.

  3. 5.6 A current causes a change in reading = 2.4 g
    1 A current causes a c hange in readingng = (2.4 / 5.6)
    7.92 A current causes a change in reading = (2.4 / 5.6) × 7.92 = 3.4g
    For both half cycles of AC
    Total change in reading = 2(3.4) = 6.8g
  1. Very few candidates gave a complete definition. Frequently, the fact that the conductor must be straight was omitted. Candidates should refer to force per unit length being one newton per metre, rather than a force of one newton on a one metre length of wire.
    1. There were some good comprehensive answers. Some candidates identified the increased reading with a downward force on the wire, or attempted an explanation by referring to the lefthand rule. 
    2. Most candidates were familiar with this type of calculation but there were numerous errors with powers-of-ten. Candidates should be advised to use the data given on the question paper. The use of g = 10ms–2 in calculations where data is given to two significant figures is unacceptable, especially when the final answer is then quoted to three or more significant figures. 
  3. Although there were some good answers here, many were incomplete. It was common to find that the new maximum current was calculated but this was not related to force. Many others calculated the new maximum force without commenting on the variation.  
NO. 484题号：1282

Positive ions are travelling through a vacuum in a narrow beam. The ions enter a region of uniform magnetic field of flux density B and are deflected in a semi-circular arc, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

The ions, travelling with speed 1.40×105 m s-1, are detected at a fixed detector when the diameter of the arc in the magnetic field is 12.8 cm.

  1. By reference to Fig. 5.1, state the direction of the magnetic field.
    .....................................................................[1]
  2. The ions have mass 20 u and charge +1.6×10-19 C. Show that the magnetic flux density is 0.454 T. Explain your working. [3]

  3. Ions of mass 22 u with the same charge and speed as those in (b) are also present in the beam.
    1. On Fig, sketch the path of these ions in the magnetic field of magnetic flux density 0.454 T. [1]
    2. In order to detect these ions at the fixed detector, the magnetic flux density is changed.
      Calculate this new magnetic flux density.

      magnetic flux density = .................................. T [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Winter/Paper4_1/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a field into (the plane of) the paper B1 [1]
b force due to magnetic field provides the centripetal force
mv2 / r = Bqv
B = (20 × 1.66 × 10–27 × 1.40 × 105) / (1.6 × 10–19 × 6.4 × 10–2)
  = 0.454 T		 B1
C1
B1
A0		 [3]
c.i semicircle with diameter greater than 12.8cm B1 [1]
c.ii new flux density = × 0.454
    B = 0.499T		 C1
A1		 [2]
  1. Into the plane of paper.
    Fleming's Left-hand rule is used to get direction of magnetic field.
  2. Electromagnetic force provide centripetal force


    1. Therefore semicircular path with diameter greater than 12.8 em is traced.
  1. Where a direction is to be described, then candidates should appreciate that an unambiguous term should be used. Many answers included the term downwards, without any further amplification.
  2. The calculation was completed successfully by many candidates. However, explanation was often lacking. Candidates should appreciate that this situation is not an equilibrium situation. There is a resultant magnetic force that provides the centripetal force.
    1. As in previous questions, the quality of sketches was frequently below the standard required. The path should be a semicircle with a diameter greater than 12.8 cm. In many sketches, the beam quite rightly entered the magnetic field at the same position but left the field at the centre of the detector. 
    2. There were many correct answers but, in general, a full substitution was made into the basic formula. Candidates should be encouraged to use proportions, where appropriate. This not only saves time but is less prone to calculator error.
NO. 485题号：1271
  1. A uniform magnetic field has constant flux density B. A straight wire of fixed length carries a current I at an angle θ to the magnetic field, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

    1. The current I in the wire is changed, keeping the angle θ constant.
      On Fig. 6.2, sketch a graph to show the variation with current I of the force F on the wire.
      [2]
    2. The angle θ between the wire and the magnetic field is now varied. The current I is kept constant.
      On Fig. 6.3, sketch a graph to show the variation with angle θ of the force F on the wire.
      [3]
  2. A uniform magnetic field is directed at right-angles to the rectangular surface PQRS of a slice of a conducting material, as shown in Fig. 6.4.

    Electrons, moving towards the side SR, enter the slice of conducting material. The electrons enter the slice at right-angles to side SR.
    1. Explain why, initially, the electrons do not travel in straight lines across the slice from side SR to side PQ.
      .............................................................................. [2]
    2. Explain to which side, PS or QR, the electrons tend to move.
      .............................................................................. [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2010/Summer/Paper4_2/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i straight line with positive gradient 
through origin		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii maximum force shown at θ = 90°
zero force shown at θ = 0°
reasonable curve with F about ½ max at 30°		 M1
M1
A1		 [3]
b.i force on electron due to magnetic field
force on electron normal to magnetic field and direction of electron		 B1
B1		 [2]
b.ii quote / mention of (Fleming's) left hand rule
electron moves towards QR		 M1
A1		 [2]


    1. F = (B sinθ)IL
      F = (constant)I
      F ∝ I

    2. F = (BIL)sinθ
      F = (constant)sinθ
      F ∝ sinθ
    1. Electrons experience a deflecting force due to magnetic field which is perpendicular to both magnetic field and motion of electrons.
    2. OR by Fleming's left hand rule.
      Use Fleming's left hand rule when current produces motion.
      Use Fleming's right hand rule when motion produces current.

This question was found to be accessible by the majority of candidates.

    1. The majority of candidates scored both marks. However, some lines were poorly drawn without a ruler.
    2. The majority of candidates knew the correct shape and scored at least two marks. The marks were generally lost owing to carelessness. A mark was lost if the curve did not reach a clear maximum at 90° or if the curve was of a poor shape and was clearly not about half the maximum at 30°. 
    1. The average and above-average candidates explained the deflection of the electron as due to the magnetic force but very few went on to say that the deflection was at right angles to this force. The weaker candidates did not mention a force and referred to a magnetic or electric field. 
    2. The majority of candidates gave the correct side and explanation. Weaker candidates failed to give an explanation and it was therefore difficult to judge whether this was just a guess; hence no marks were awarded. A significant minority stated the right hand rule and then gave the wrong side.
NO. 486题号：1262

Two long straight vertical wires X and Y pass through a horizontal card, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

The current in each wire is in the upward direction.

The top view of the card, seen by looking vertically downwards at the card, is shown in Fig. 5.2.

  1. On Fig. 5.2,
    1. draw four field lines to represent the pattern of the magnetic field around wire X due solely to the current in wire X, [2]



    2. draw an arrow to show the direction of the force on wire Y due to the magnetic field of wire X. [1]



  2. The magnetic flux density B at a distance x from a long straight wire due to a current I in the wire is given by the expression

    where µ0 is the permeability of free space, which is 4π x 10-7 Hm-1.

        The current in wire X is 5.0 A and that in wire Y is 7.0 A. The separation of the wires is 2.5 cm.

    1. Calculate the force per unit length on wire Y due to the current in wire X.








      force per unit length = ...................................... N m–1 [4]

    2. The currents in the wires are not equal.

      State and explain whether the forces on the two wires are equal in magnitude.

      ..................................................................................................................................
      ..................................................................................................................................
      ........................................................................................................................... [2]

[Total: 9]

[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Winter/Paper4_2/Q5
Question Answer Marks  
a.i concentric circles, anticlockwise ……(minimum 3 circles)
separation of lines increases with distance from wire		 M1
A1		 [2]
a.ii direction from Y towards X A1 [1]
b.i flux density at wire Y = (4π × 10-7 × 5.0) / (2π × 2.5 × 10-2)
   = 4.0 × 10-5 T
force per unit length = BI
   = 4.0 × 10-5 × 7.0
   = 2.8 × 10-4 N		 C1
C1

C1
A1		 [4]
b.ii either force depends on product of the currents in the two wires
          so equal 
or  (isolated system so) Newton's 3rd law applies
    so equal		 M1
A1
(M1)
(A1)		 [2]
  1. (i), (ii)

    (i) Separation between field lines must be increased with the increase of distance from the wire, i.e. magnetic field strength decreases with the increase of distance. Direction of field lines is obtained by Right Hand grip rule in which thumb paints towards current and curl of fingers provide the direction of magnetic field lines.
    1. Magnetic flux density of wire X on wire Y,

      F = BlLsin90° ⇒ F / L = BI
      ∴ force per unit length = (4.0 × 1 0-5 )(7.0) = 2.8 × 10-4 N m-1
    2. Forces on the wires are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction by Newton's third law.
      The force F acting on length L of wire Y carrying current Iy due to magnetic field strength of X is:

      So force depends upon the product of the currents in the two wires. So forces are equal in magnitude.
    1. The vast majority of responses correctly showed the magnetic field lines as anticlockwise concentric circles. However, the quality of some sketches was poor and in almost all cases the separation of the field lines did not increase with distance from the wire. Candidates should be aware of the significance of the spacing of field lines. 
    2. Candidates who attempted this part of the question usually managed to show the arrow pointing in the correct direction. 
    1. Although many candidates tried to use the given expression and F = BIL to calculate the force per unit length, mistakes were frequent. A common error was to substitute a current of 5.0A where 7.0A was needed or vice versa. The permittivity of free space was sometimes substituted into the equation instead of the permeability of free space, whilst some candidates mistakenly calculated the force on a 2.5cm length of wire. 
    2. Very few candidates realised that the forces on the two wires are equal in magnitude and rarely was an explanation given in terms of either the force being dependent on the product of the two currents or Newton's third law of motion.  
NO. 487题号：1254
  1. Define the tesla.
    ............................................................................... [3]
  2. A large horseshoe magnet produces a uniform magnetic field of flux density B between its poles. Outside the region of the poles, the flux density is zero.
    The magnet is placed on a top-pan balance and a stiff wire XY is situated between its poles, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

    The wire XY is horizontal and normal to the magnetic field. The length of wire between the poles is 4.4 cm.
    A direct current of magnitude 2.6 A is passed through the wire in the direction from X to Y.
    The reading on the top-pan balance increases by 2.3 g.
    1. State and explain the polarity of the pole P of the magnet.
      ......................................................................... [3]
    2. Calculate the flux density between the poles.

      flux density = ............................................ T [3]
  3. The direct current in (b) is now replaced by a very low frequency sinusoidal current of r.m.s. value 2.6 A.
    Calculate the variation in the reading of the top-pan balance.

    variation in reading = ............................................ g [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2009/Summer/Paper4/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a unit of magnetic flux density / magnetic field strength
(uniform) field normal to wire carrying current of 1 A
giving force (per unit length) of 1 N m–1		 B1
M1
A1		 [3]
b.i force on magnet / balance is downwards (so by Newton’s third law)
force on wire is upwards
pole P is a north pole		 B1
M1
A1		 [3]
b.ii F = BIL and F = mg (g missing, then 0/3 in (ii))
2.3 × 10–3 × 9.8 = B × 2.6 × 4.4 × 10–2 (g = 10, loses this mark)
B = 0.20 T		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
c reading for maximum current = 2.3 × √2
total variation = 2 × 2.3 × √2
                 = 6.5 g		 C1

A1		 [2]
  1. Magnetic flux density is equal to 1 tesla if a force of 1 N is experienced by 1 m length of a conductor carrying 1 A current when placed perpendicular to field lines.
    1. The increase of force in downward direction measured by top pan balance on the magnet is equal to the force on the wire but in upward direction by Newton's third law. Hence by Fleming's Left Hand Rule, pole P is the North pole.
    2. F = BlLsin90°
      mg = BlL
      (2.3 × 10-3 )(9.81) = B(2.6)(4.4 × 1 0-2 )
      B = 0.197 ≈ 0.20 T

  3. 2.6 A d.c. current causes variation = 2.3 g
    3.68 A d.c. current causes variation = (2.3 /2.6) × 3.68 = 3.26 g
    For both half cycles of A.C., the variation is = 2(3.26) = 6.52 g
  1. Candidates should be encouraged to distinguish clearly between the definition of a quantity and that of a unit. The tesla is the unit of magnetic flux density and should be defined in terms of the units metre, newton and amp. Furthermore, many started their answers by stating that 'the tesla is the force acting.....'. Clearly, this is incorrect. 
    1. Fully correct answers were in a minority. Many failed to appreciate that the force is downwards on the magnet, not on the wire, and thus there is an upward force on the wire.
    2. In general, the calculation was completed successfully although power-of-ten errors were seen quite frequently.
  3. Many answers were long and involved, in that the peak current was calculated and then the force was determined using the equation F = BIL. Very few answers were seen where allowance was made for ± I0. Instead, candidates did, quite wrongly, deduct 2.3 from their answers.
NO. 488题号：1250
  1. A straight conductor carrying a current I is at an angle θ to a uniform magnetic field of flux density B, as shown in Fig.6.1.
     
    The conductor and the magnetic field are both in the plane of the paper. State
    1. an expression for the force per unit length acting on the conductor due to the magnetic field,

      force per unit length =......................................[1]
    2. the direction of the force on the conductor.
      .....................................................................[1]
  2. A coil of wire consisting of two loops is suspended from a fixed point as shown in Fig.6.2.
     
    Each loop of wire has diameter 9.4 cm and the separation of the loops is 0.75 cm.
    The coil is connected into a circuit such that the lower end of the coil is free to move.
    1. Explain why, when a current is switched on in the coil, the separation of the loops of the coil decreases.
      ........................................................................ [4]
    2. Each loop of the coil may be considered as being a long straight wire.
      In SI units, the magnetic flux density B at a distance x from a long straight wire carrying a current I is given by the expression
                       
      When the current in the coil is switched on, a mass of 0.26 g is hung from the free end of the coil in order to return the loops of the coil to their original separation.
      Calculate the current in the coil.

      current = ...............................................A [4]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2007/Winter/Paper4/Q6
Question Answer Marks  
a.i BI sinθ B1 [1]
b.ii (downwards) into (the plane of) the paper B1 [1]
b.i magnetic field (due to current) in one loop OR each loop acts as a coil
cuts/is normal to current in second loop OR produces magnetic field
causing force on second loop   OR fields in same direction
either Newton's 3rd discussed
or vice versa clear gives rise to attraction OR so attracts		 B1
B1
M1

A1		 [4]
b.ii B = 2 × 10-7 I/0.75 × 10-2 (= 2.67 × 10-5 I)
force = 0.26 × 10-3 × 9.81 (= 2.55 × 10-3 N)
F = BIL
2.55 × 10-3 = 2.67 × 10-5 × I2 × 2π × 4.7 × 10-2
I = 18 A		 C1
C1

C1
A1		 [4]
    1. BI sin θ

      Force on a current carrying conductor in a magnetic field,
      F = BILsin θ
      F / L = BI sin θ
    2. into the plane of page / paper.
      Make use of Flemming left hand rule to get the direction.
    1. The current in one loop of wire produces magnetic field which is perpendicular to the current in the second loop. Therefore both exert equal and opposite force on each other by Newton's third law. Hence separation of the loops of coil decreases.

    2. Force on 2nd loop as a result of magnetic field of first loop


      To return to the original separation, upward mag netic force is equal to the downward weight.
    1. Most answers involved the correct sine function. However, many gave an expression for force, rather than force per unit length. 
    2. Surprisingly for this level of examination, only approximately half of the answers were correct. 
    1. Some candidates thought that this question related to the induction of an e.m.f. More able candidates frequently realised that the current in the two loops is in the same direction. However, rather than explain how this leads to a decrease in separation, most merely stated that 'the currents will attract'. Such a statement does not constitute an explanation, as required in the question.
    2. There were some clearly laid-out correct answers. Other candidates appeared to know how to approach the problem but made careless mistakes through untidy work. Common errors were either to assume that the separation of the loops is equal to the length of wire in a loop or to substitute mass, rather than weight, for the force. 
NO. 489题号：1241

Electrons, travelling at speed v in a vacuum, are incident on a very thin carbon film, as illustrated in Fig. 7.1.

The emergent electrons are incident on a fluorescent screen.
A series of concentric rings is observed on the screen.

  1. Suggest why the observed rings provide evidence for the wave nature of particles.
    .....................................................................[2]
  2. The initial speed of the electrons is increased. State and explain the effect, if any, on the radii of the rings observed on the screen.
    .....................................................................[3]
  3. A proton and an electron are each accelerated from rest through the same potential difference.
    Determine the ratio 
       

    ratio = ..................................................[4]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Winter/Paper4_1/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a either if light passes through suitable film / cork dust etc.
   diffraction occurs and similar pattern observed
or concentric circles are evidence of diffraction
 diffraction is a wave property		 M1
A1
(M1)
(A1)		 [2]
b (speed increases so) momentum increases
λ = h/p so λ decreases
hence radii decrease
(special case: wavelength decreases so radii decreases – scores 1/3)
 or
(speed increases so) energy increases
λ = h / √(2Em) so λ decreases
hence radii decrease		 M1
M1
A1


(B1)
(M1)
(A1)		 [3]
c electron and proton have same (kinetic) energy
either E = p2 / 2m or p = √(2Em)
ratio = pe / pp = √(me / mp)
  = √{(9.1 × 10–31) / (1.67 × 10–27)}
  = 2.3 × 10–2		 C1
C1
C1

A1		 [4]
  1. Concentric rings are produced due to diffraction of electrons by carbon atoms and the spacing between layers of carbon atoms in the film. Diffraction is the property of wave.
  2. Momentum of electrons increases as speed increases by p = mv. Therefore wavelength associated with electrons decreases as λ = h / p and inter atomic spacing in carbon film is constant. So lesser is diffraction and radius of rings decreases.
    The rings are similar to those produced by light waves passing through a small circular hole due to diffraction and diffraction is the property of wave nature.

Comment on answer:
(b) The rings are similar to those produced by light waves passing through a small circular hole due to diffraction and diffraction is the property of wave nature.

  1. Most explanations were based on the fact that the observed pattern provides evidence of diffraction. This was then related to diffraction of waves. 
  2. Many answers were restricted to a statement that the wavelength and hence the radii would decrease. There were comparatively few explanations based on increased momentum and giving the de Broglie relation. 
  3. The majority of derivations were based on an incorrect assumption. Rather than determine momentum based on the premise that the energies of the particles are equal, candidates assumed that the speeds of the particles would be identical.
NO. 490题号：1234
  1. The emission spectrum of atomic hydrogen consists of a number of discrete wavelengths. Explain how this observation leads to an understanding that there are discrete electron energy levels in atoms.
    ................................................................................... [2]
  2. Some electron energy levels in atomic hydrogen are illustrated in Fig.7.1.

    The longest wavelength produced as a result of electron transitions between two of the energy levels shown in Fig. is 4.0 × 10-6 m.
    1. On Fig.7.1,
      1. draw, and mark with the letter L, the transition giving rise to the wavelength of 4.0 × 10-6 m, [1]
      2. draw, and mark with the letter S, the transition giving rise to the shortest wavelength. [1]

    2. Calculate the wavelength for the transition you have shown in (i) part 2.

      wavelength = ............................................. m [3]
  3. Photon energies in the visible spectrum vary between approximately 3.66 eV and 1.83 eV.
    Determine the energies, in eV, of photons in the visible spectrum that are produced by transitions between the energy levels shown in Fig.7.1.

    photon energies ....................................................... eV [2]
[-收起]
A level PHYSICS 2013/Summer/Paper4_2/Q7
Question Answer Marks  
a each wavelength is associated with a discrete change in energy
discrete energy change / difference implies discrete levels		 M1
A1		 [2]
b.i 1. arrow from –0.54 eV to –0.85 eV, labelled L B1 [1]
2. arrow from –0.54 eV to –3.4 eV , labelled S
   (two correct arrows, but only one label – allow 2 marks)
   (two correct arrows, but no labels – allow 1 mark) 		 B1 [1]
b.ii E = hc / λ
(3.4 – 0.54) × 1.6 × 10–19 = (6.63 × 10–34 × 3.0 × 108) / λ
λ = 4.35 × 10–7 m		 C1
C1
A1		 [3]
c –1.50 → –3.4 = 1.9 eV
–0.85 → –3.4 = 2.55 eV (allow 2.6 eV) 
–0.54 → –3.4 = 2.86 eV (allow 2.9 eV)
3 correct, 2 marks with –1 mark for each additional energy
2 correct, 1 mark but no marks if any additional energy differences		 B2 [2]
  1. Each emitted wavelength corresponds to a specific photon energy. Since the photon is emitted when an electron changes its energy level i.e. from high to low. So it can be deduced that energy changes are discrete and therefore, energy levels must also be discrete.
  2. Energy of photon when transition is from
    –0.54 eV to –3.4 eV = –0.54 – (–3.4) = 2.86 eV
    –0.85 eV to –3.4 eV = -0.85 – (–3.4) = 2.55 eV
    –1.5 eV to –3.4 eV = -1.5 – (–3.4) =1.9 eV
    photon energies = 1.90, 2.55 and 2.86 eV

Comment on answer:

(b) (i)&(ii)

if ΔE is small, then λ is large or vice versa.
(b) (ii) Do not forget to change eV to J.

  1. There were very few convincing explanations. In many scripts, it was not made clear that each wavelength results from an electron changing energy levels. It was common to find that each wavelength was thought, quite wrongly, to be associated with a particular energy level. 
    1. There were many correct answers here but a significant number were spoiled by having arrows in the wrong direction or having double-headed arrows.
    2. The correct expression was quoted in most scripts. A common error was a failure to convert the energy from units of eV to J.
  3. The three correct responses were in a minority. Many suggested two energies.

    Determine whether electrons will be emitted, by the photoelectric effect, from the surface. [3]
